PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Bolkus and Senator Margetts, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges:

Whether statements by Senator Colston and Mrs C Smith, relating to payments of travelling allowances to Senator Colston, tabled in the Senate on 24 March and 6 May 1997, were false or misleading in any particular, and, if so, whether a contempt of the Senate was committed by the making of those statements.

The issue before the chamber is whether the Senate Privileges Committee should undertake an inquiry into whether the tabled statements by Senator Colston and Mrs Christine Smith were false and misleading in any particular and, if so, whether a contempt of the Senate was committed. The opposition strongly believes that it is not only appropriate but absolutely imperative that the Privileges Committee investigate these matters. As the Clerk of the Senate said in his advice to me on 18 April:

It is difficult to imagine an issue more important to the integrity and the proper operation of the legislature than ensuring that statements deliberately made to it are truthful and that untruthful statements are detected and a remedy applied to the making of such statements.

So let me outline the basis on which the opposition believes there is good reason to suppose that the tabled statements of Senator Colston and Mrs Smith were untruthful in some particular. I think our case in respect of this is strong. In fact, I think it is so self-evident that even Senator Hill and Senator Alston might not challenge it.

You, Madam President, tabled in the Senate on 24 March a document that was entitled `Senator Colston: Travelling allowance documents tabled by Madam President.' Those documents included two letters from Senator Colston attempting to explain his bogus travel claims. They also included a statement from Mrs Smith, who was Senator Colston's office manager from August 1992 to December 1996. In his letter to you on 24 March, Senator Colston claimed by way of explaining the cause of 19 overpayments that:

My investigations have discovered that the inadequate bookkeeping systems in my office led to administrative errors on the part of my office staff which caused the overpayments. I would regularly ask my office manager at the time for the dates of my travelling to place on my claims and I would transcribe those dates onto the claim form. In doing so, I assumed that the dates which were given to me by my office manager were correct. In the course of my investigation I have discovered that in numerous cases these dates were not correct.

Senator Colston also wrote to the Clerk of the Senate on 24 March offering the same explanation for a further six overpayments. In support of Senator Colston's explanation, and included in his letter to you, Madam President, there was a statement that he knew full well would be tabled in the Senate, a statement signed by Mrs Christine Smith and dated 24 March 1997. In this statement Mrs Smith confirmed that she had acted as office manager for Senator Colston during the relevant period. She also said:
One of my duties during that time was to record the dates for which the senator was eligible for travelling allowance.
She explained that the senator often notified her of changes, but stated:

I did not notify the transport officers required nor did I sometimes make adequate note of the changed travel arrangements. The only excuse that I have is that the pressures of work in the office made me put these matters to one side. The result was that on a number of occasions I gave the senator an incorrect list of dates for his travelling allowance claims. The senator accepted the dates I provided to him as being correct.
Mrs Smith's statement concluded:
I accept full responsibility for providing the wrong dates to Senator Colston for transcription to his travel allowance claims.

Then on 8 April Mrs Smith supplied additional information to you and to the Clerk of the Senate. In that communication, which you tabled yesterday, Mrs Smith stated that she wished to withdraw her earlier statement, and replaced it with a statement that declared, amongst other things:

Both the senator and I were aware at this time that in fact the mistakes were not mine as it was not part of my duties to provide the senator with information for his TA claims nor did I ever provide claims on his behalf.
She went on to say:

I asked the senator whether the statement had in fact already been typed because I had not done it and he said words to the effect of: `Yes, Douglas has been working all weekend.' I now wish to advise that my statement was incorrect. I was not responsible for preparing the senator's travelling allowance claims nor required to keep a record of dates of travel for TA purposes. The senator always prepared his own claims.

Madam President, if any of these versions of events happens to be true or is to be believed, the inescapable conclusion is that misleading evidence has been provided to the Senate. On the basis of the second statement, both Senator Colston and Mrs Smith knowingly provided misleading statements to the Senate on 24 March. Further, Mrs Smith's statement asserts that a member of Senator Colston's staff, Mr Douglas Colston, was responsible for drafting her first statement.

Surely these must be the most serious matters of privilege that could be raised. The record shows that the Senate has always taken extremely seriously any suggestion that misleading evidence had been given to it or to any of its committees. What we are dealing with here is, on the face of it, a very deliberate attempt to mislead the Senate by supplying a false statement. As the Clerk of the Senate has pointed out, it is difficult to imagine that the Senate should regard these circumstances as worthy of less attention than earlier less serious cases.

I want to address the issue of the parallel police inquiry which the government alleges would be prejudiced by an inquiry by the Senate privileges committee. It is common ground that the conflicting statements by Senator Colston and Mrs Smith are covered by parliamentary privilege and therefore cannot be used in any way in legal proceedings. In other words, it is only the parliament which is competent to investigate the issue of deliberate misleading.

The issue is whether the Senate privileges committee inquiry would necessarily prejudice the police inquiry. But I put to you and to the Senate that the answer to that question is no. Firstly, the matters which are subject to the police inquiry on the one hand, that is, the fraudulent claims on the Commonwealth, and on the other hand the matters which would be subject to a Senate privileges inquiry, that is, whether the Senate has been deliberately misled, are two separate matters. They are quite distinct matters. Of course, there might be some overlap between the two, but the terms of reference to the Senate privileges committee, which we are debating, have been deliberately strictly limited to matters of misleading and possible contempt. They do not go to the issue of fraudulent claims. Secondly, while the statements are covered by parliamentary privilege and are therefore not available to the police inquiry, the primary evidence on which they are based is accessible to the Australian Federal Police.

Furthermore, in the interests of ensuring that there is no risk at all of prejudice to the police inquiry, I have proposed, on behalf of the opposition, that there be a meeting between all parliamentary leaders in the Senate to ensure that the terms of reference to the privileges committee are framed in such a way as to avoid any possible trespass into the Australian Federal Police inquiry. Needless to say, I have not had the courtesy or the benefit of any reply from the government to my proposal. Nor have I had any response from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to my written request for a confidential briefing on the terms of reference of the police inquiry—a briefing which would have assisted us greatly in ensuring that any potential overlap between the two inquiries was avoided.

I also want to say, Madam President, that I have even suggested that, to allay any concerns of possible prejudice to the police inquiry, the Attorney‐General's Department make available to the Senate privileges committee an adviser who would ensure that the committee did not trespass on the AFP inqui ries. Again, I have had no response from the government on those proposals.
I want to remind the Senate of the words of its Clerk. Let me quote:

It is difficult to imagine how the Senate can be asked to refrain from inquiry into a matter of such seriousness and of such significance to its operations on the basis that its inquiry might cause some inconvenience in a prosecution of different acts as a criminal offence, a prosecution which at present is only potential.

Madam President, the case is clear. The issue that we are debating now is the concern about timing. I genuinely believe that the Senate privileges committee does have sufficient experience and expertise to be able to deal with this matter in a manner which would mean that the issues before it did not trespass or interfere in any way with the matters being inquired into by the Australian Federal Police. But, of course, if the Senate comes to the view that they have concerns about this, if the Senate becomes convinced that that remains a concern, perhaps the amendment that has been foreshadowed by the Australian Democrats might be one that it might consider embracing.

What we have now is a situation where, regrettably, as the debate before us proceeds, you see the government digging in deeper and deeper to protect what remains of their very substantial investment in Senator Colston. Their arguments may also, of course, be motivated by a concern that a Senate inquiry might stray into operational areas of a police inquiry, but I think probably more likely their concern is that such a privileges inquiry might stray into those areas which might shed some light on the arrangements that the government entered into to secure Senator Colston's votes.

We have done our best to try to allay those concerns. We have been very straightforward about what we want to see the Senate Privileges Committee deal with. It is important to place on record that you do have, as I have said, an enormous investment from the government in Senator Colston. After all, we know that the government did everything they could to resist any call for an Australian Federal Police investigation until the clamour became too great, until the public and media pressure was so hot, even Mr Howard had to cave in. We know how, until the eleventh hour, they resisted all the calls for Senator Colston to resign as Deputy President of the Senate. It was only right at the end—the absolute last gasp—late one night that that weak leader Mr Howard finally agreed to refer this matter to the Australian Federal Police for an investigation and report as the opposition had been calling for for months.

We still see Mr Howard and the government refuse to endorse the call from the opposition and the Labor Party for Senator Colston to resign from the Senate. I say today that it is now an occasion for Mr Howard and his government to do something positive about the Colston issue, to show for the first time some genuine leadership and to do something that might restore the confidence of the Australian people in the standing of the parliament as an institution and in the standing of the Senate.

It was Mr Howard who rode into government on a white charger saying that as one of his highest priorities he would do something about parliamentary standards and the standing of our parliamentary institution in the eyes of the Australian public. What has he done? He has presided over a situation where the parliament's standing is at its lowest ebb in our history since Federation. That is the truth of the matter. That is Mr Howard's achievement. That is what he has been able to do. He has debauched the institution of the parliament through his behaviour in relation to the Colston affair. I believe the Australian population have caught on to this in spades. Mr Howard and Mr Howard's government have an opportunity today to do something about this.

I have something to say to Senator Harradine, who is very important in this debate, particularly if the government applies its latest scam to try to wring some value from the Colston votes—still trying to squeeze the last bit of benefit from the deal they did with Senator Colston by his latest artificial scam as to how he votes in the chamber. In the light of that device, that artificial mechanism, Senator Harradine's vote on this matter becomes very important. Madam President, I urge Senator Harradine, and particularly I urge you, as the President of the Senate with the responsibility to uphold the standing of this institution, to give very serious consideration to this matter before the chair.

As I said yesterday when Senator Sue West was elected as Deputy President of the Senate, she has a great responsibility in the light of what has occurred over the past few months courtesy of the Howard government's approach to the parliament and courtesy of what has occurred over the past year or so during the life of the Howard government in relation to the standing of the parliament in the eyes of the community. This is an opportunity to start to rebuild confidence in the Senate, to start to rebuild confidence in the institution of the parliament and to start to rebuild some confidence in members of parliament and senators, which is also at an all-time low in the public mind.

So I urge you, Madam President, and I urge Senator Harradine, to weigh very carefully the arguments that I presented in support of this motion. I ask you also to weigh very carefully the arguments and the advice put forward by the Clerk of the Senate on this matter. I urge you and I urge all senators in this chamber to support this motion in the interests of clearing up the most serious matter of grievously misleading the Senate and in the interests of restoring public trust and confidence in both parliament and its members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise as the co‐sponsor of the motion that we are debating today concerning Senator Colston. On 9 April 1997 I wrote to you expressing my concerns about the issues raised in the statement by Mrs Christine Smith, her role and that of Senator Colston and the response by Senator Colston to the report by the Department of the Senate officers concerning the claim that he had fraudulently claimed travelling allowance.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no personal grudge in any way against Senator Colston. I have no personal feelings of anger or revenge. I have nothing of that in putting this letter. My feelings are and always have been that it is necessary for the Senate as an elected chamber—to my belief the only chamber—of the federal parlia ment, where there is some sort of ability for the community to access the actual debate, put their views forward and maybe change the way decisions are made in this chamber.

Considering how important the Senate is, I believe it is extremely important that, no matter what people think of individual senators and members, no matter what they think of the parliament, no matter what they think of the lifestyles of individual senators, they have this belief that when a direct question is asked in this place there is a reasonable expectation that to the best knowledge of the person who has asked that reasonable question, the answer is the truth. There is in many ways a lack of faith in many of the institutions in modern society: in the police, in the church, in schools and teachers. A lot of this is partly a beat‐up by the media. On various occasions they will focus on individuals, then there will be a spate of cases and then suddenly the whole institution is considered threatened.

It is not necessarily that there are more cases now than there were before. We now have multimedia that enable everybody to find out all at once what the issues are. In the past, I guess, many of these things would never surface. In the past, many things with politicians and royalty would never make the news pages. However, it is a different society we are living in today. We are finding out that the general level of belief, if there ever was a huge level of belief, and the general level of trust in politicians in particular—not so much the political system—is about as low as it has been for a long time.

No matter what that belief is about politicians, I have to say that those people who are friends and family of politicians and know what type of lifestyle it is—how long you spend away from the people you love, how your hours are taken up on your weekends, how no time is actually your own and how difficult it is to get away and actually have a break of any sort—and those people who work their insides out within the office structures and within the support base of politicians to try to make a better world, deserve, as well as the wider community, to know that there are some elements within the parlia mentary process which are considered important. I believe that the ability to believe that a direct question in this place is expected to be answered by the truth is one of those things.

That is the basis by which I have put forward my request. That is the basis upon which I have co-sponsored this notice of motion and that is the basis upon which I urge the Senate to support it and to support it as a matter of urgency. I do think that there are issues in the end where, if we fail to act, we will be laying a legacy for the future, which I think we will all regret in terms of the public confidence in, I guess, one of the few institutions where they feel there is a lot of control, if you like, in their lives in relation to the way this body works. You only have to look at last night's superannuation bill, for example, to see that the Senate can make a lot of changes to people's lives overnight.

However, in the end, people need to believe that the parliament is accountable, they need to know that, for instance, ministers are accountable and that if they ask questions, if they ask individual senators or members specific questions or for information in writing in particular, they are able to have a reasonable assumption that that information will be correct to the best of the knowledge of the person giving that information. Therefore, I urge the Senate's support for this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The continual questions of the media on this issue reflect the huge concern of the public. We know that parliament has been damaged by this affair and we all know that the damage is long term. We hope that it will not be fatal. There is a requirement that all matters relevant to senators and members be exposed in this issue of entitlements and allowances. The Senate, to its credit, has moved to greater and greater exposure. The House of Representatives has not. The Prime Minister must be strongly condemned by us and the nation for failing to take the lead by having the same degree of exposure that we are seeking and have sought in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Moving to the matter at hand, whilst due process and even-handedness are essential and necessary, I would say to the Senate that, in this matter, time is of the essence. We cannot allow the damage to continue. I believe that no comfort, no quarter and no leeway must be offered in this matter over and above the essential requirements of natural justice. We have received advice from the Attorney-General and the Clerk of the Senate. That advice is partial. Both those counsels are esteemed and respected sources. Unfortunately, they differ and the Senate has insufficient advice to be sure that the route we propose to follow would not result in a lesser outcome than we would desire in this matter.

The Democrats wish to avoid a situation where the fullest power of the Senate and of the police and of the courts can be exercised. The strength and vigour of this institution must be protected and the strength of this institution must be enforced.

I have been afraid that the Labor motion before us would give at least one particular senator the opportunity to vote against it with the excuse of the conflicting advice of the Attorney‐General's counsel and the clerk. As a consequence of a situation where we have limited advice to deal with and of my fear that the motion, as it stands, might provide an excuse for a particular senator to vote against the motion, I have put before the Senate motion 503. I think everyone in the Senate has it. I would like to alter item 3 of my amendment which has been circulated and change the date from 15 May to 29 May. I have made that change at the request of Senator Ray who quite properly pointed out that the existing date is very difficult to deal with given that the coming week is the budget week and all the efforts associated with that.

We will listen with particular care to the speeches of Senator Ray, a member of the Privileges Committee, and Senator Hill, the leader of the coalition in the Senate. I would like to hear the reaction of both to my amendment. You will see that the purpose of my amendment is to provide our Privileges Committee, a very considerable and experienced body, with the opportunity of assessing more fully the true risk that such an inquiry may present to any legal proceedings arising out of matters in relation to Senator Colston currently being investigated by the Australian Federal Police.

We as the Australian Democrats do not want, under any circumstances, the full recourse of both the law and the Senate to be restrained in any sense. They should recommend whether an inquiry should proceed and the Senate should then make a determination, in our view, once we have a much deeper analysis of this particular issue than we have had presented to us to this time. I do not intend to speak on this much more. We have given, both privately and publicly, full support to the opposition in their intention to have this matter fully, publicly and quickly exposed and dealt with. I move:
At the end of the motion, add:
(2) That the Committee of Privileges not commence its inquiry into this matter until:

PARA.TAB: (a) the Committee has presented a report to the Senate:

TAB.TAB: (i) assessing the potential risk that such an inquiry may present to any legal proceedings arising out of matters in relation to Senator Colston, currently being investigated by the Australian Federal Police, and
(ii) recommending whether the inquiry should proceed; and

PARA.TAB: (b) the Senate has made a determination in relation to the recommendation .

SPEECH.PARA: (3) That the report referred in paragraph (2)(a) be presented to the Senate by 12 noon on Thursday, 29 May 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing I did agree with in Senator Murray's contribution was that we should not forget the rules of natural justice in this matter. It certainly has not in any way inhibited the Labor Party in its contribution in relation to Senator Colston from day one of this exercise. The Labor Party found Senator Colston guilty without a trial, convicted him and sought to bring him down, successfully as it has turned out, and to remove him from the deputy presidency. Of course, they will not rest until he has been driven out of the Senate. The objective is to replace him with a Labor vote.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to give Senator Ray in particular some credit because he has been quite honest about all of this. It was Senator Colston who had to be punished for his treachery to the Labor Party. He had to be punished for his decision to leave the party for reasons he saw fit by being driven from office. Senator Ray was up-front and honest about that from day one. For that, as I said, I give him some credit.

I also give some credit to Mr Crean, one of the senior frontbenchers of the Labor Party, who advised the press that the purpose—you might listen to this, Senator Murray—of referring this inquiry to the Senate Privileges Committee was to get the government. It had nothing at all to do with issues such as the sanctity of the Senate, whether the public should have confidence in the Senate or whether they should be able to rely on truthful statements being made to the Senate. It has nothing at all to do with those matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —We agree.

—Senator Ray agrees with this as well. The purpose of the inquiry before the Senate Privileges Committee is to examine the government's role in matters relating to Senator Colston. That is what it is all about. That is what Mr Crean said. That is what he told the press. That is what the Labor Party briefed the press before the weekend. This ought to be on the table.
—Not true, it's wrong.

—It is correct. That is exactly what Mr Crean said. So you are now embarrassed by that and you have good reason, Senator Carr, to be embarrassed by that because it demonstrates what a fraud this whole business is. That is what the Labor Party is all about. The Labor Party has never even believed in this chamber, Senator Carr. The Labor Party has wished to abolish this chamber. Now you come in here and talk about the sanctity of the Senate. The Labor Party has never cared about the sanctity of the Senate. All the Labor Party is interested in is playing politics.

SPEECH.PARA: As a practising politician I understand that. Your game is to seek to defeat the government and that is all you are interested in one step on. The first step is to punish Colston for his treachery. The second step is to seek to use this exercise to advantage your position vis-a-vis the government. We understand what the real story is. It is consistent with the Labor Party's approach to the whole Colston affair from day one.

Day one goes back a long way. After these matters started to come onto the table rather than under the table we learnt a great deal. We learnt that in 1983 there was a matter raised concerning Senator Colston—a matter that was sufficiently serious that the senior law officers of the land advised Mr Beazley, who then had the administrative responsibility as minister, and the Attorney-General, then Senator Gareth Evans who is now the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, that the matter should be referred to the Federal Police.

But was it referred to the Federal Police? No, it was settled. They took the money and put the file in the bottom drawer. That sounds familiar, Senator Ray. That is what the Labor Party did in this instance. They did not refer the matter to the police as advised. Why, Senator Carr, wasn't it sent to the police? Why?

TALK.START.PARA: —What about 82?

—No. Why didn't the Labor Party send it to the police as advised in 1983? One can only suspect, Senator Carr, it was because it was regarded at that time as not politically smart to do so. With the knowledge of that background, what happened in 1990? In 1990 the Labor Party came in here and promoted Senator Colston to the position of Deputy President of the Senate. What hypocrisy!
—Oh, you didn't know! You didn't know!
—We did not know. You knew, Senator Schacht. The Labor Party knew.
—Knew what?
—You knew what had happened in all the years in between. You were in government. You controlled the books.
—Did you know all about Noel Crichton-Browne?

—The books that were in the drawer, Senator Schacht. When asked about this, Senator Faulkner said, `But after 1992 we promoted him to nothing else.' That was the then explanation. It became awkward, so after 1992 they did not promote him. But they did. They put him on the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. The regs and ordinances committee is what you are now complaining about. They argue that, when he was on the regs and ordinances committee, he rorted the books. But they put him on.

SPEECH.PARA: Then Labor put him on the committee that scrutinises members' interests. So, despite what they knew, despite what they had in the bottom drawer, they continued to promote Senator Colston. So what has changed? What changed was that he moved from one side of the chamber to the Independent benches. That is the only difference that occurred. Once that occurred, Senator Ray went to the bottom drawer and searched and searched the files to get ammunition on Senator Colston. One has to admit that he has done it very well.

Then comes the responsibility of the new incoming government. What a contrast. Firstly, we decided that the principles of natural justice should not just be abandoned. We actually believe in the presumption—

TALK.START.PARA: —What!
—No, we actually believe, Senator, in the presumption of innocence.
—Is that right? Is that why you are doing this?

—We believe in the presumption of innocence and we have been prepared to take a bit of political water because we believe in that, and we will continue to stand by the fact that any person is entitled to be treated as innocent until it is proven otherwise.
—The opinion polls are the real issue, aren't they?

—No. You see, Senator Carr, you get driven by the opinion polls; we get driven by principle. And that is something worth standing here to say. We said that he should be given an opportunity to answer. We said that, when matters were not then satisfactory, it should be sent to the Federal Police. It was sent to the Federal Police. That is in very stark contrast, I would suggest, Senator Carr. Labor put it in the bottom drawer; the coalition government sent it to the Federal Police.

SPEECH.PARA: The police are looking at it. The police are deciding whether further action should be taken. The issue now is whether there is in fact action that the Senate should take notwithstanding the police investigation because there is now a letter on the table—a letter that has been presented to the Senate—which, on the face of it, is misleading.

I do not dispute the right of the Privileges Committee to examine that, because I do believe that the Senate and the people of Australia have the right to expect truthful statements to be made in this place. We do not know whether that is now the case because the person whose letter it is has now changed her explanation. It does therefore seem to be a legitimate issue for the Privileges Committee to look at.

I accept the judgment of Madam President that this debate should take precedence. There is an issue that the Privileges Committee can examine to see whether or not the Senate has been misled. But should the Privileges Committee be seeking to do that now when matters have been so overtaken by the police investigation? I would argue that it would be better for this debate to be taking place after the police matters have been resolved. If the police decide that there is nothing to pursue in terms of criminal breach against Senator Colston, the issue as to whether or not he has misled the Senate is still on the table and the Senate has every right to seek to have that resolved.

But that is not a convenient process for those who want to turn this into a political witch‐hunt. They want the committee to meet now for, as Mr Crean said, the purpose of seeking political advantage against the government. That is Labor's motivation in this. The opportunity to take what I think is the most correct course in this matter—which is to defer it until after police investigations are complete—is probably not available.

At the very least, what the Senate ought to be considering, particularly the Labor Party as it goes down this track of seeking political advantage from it, is the issue as to whether a Senate privileges inquiry may in some way prejudice that police investigation. The best advice from senior law officers of the land, with great respect to the Clerk of the Senate, is that it could prejudice that investigation.

I would have thought that a prudent Senate would not take a chance on that. A prudent Senate would say that it would be improper for it to take a course of action which may in some way prejudice the police inquiry and anything that would flow from that inquiry. I cannot see any argument against that position except an argument that is of political advantage.

What I say to the Australian Democrats and what I say to the Greens and what I say to Senator Harradine is, yes, if the Senate Privileges Committee wants to examine whether the Senate has been misled, that is fine, but it should do so after matters relating to the police investigation and anything that flows from it have been completed.

That is the advice we have got from Mr Burmeister. It is sensible advice for the Senate to follow. I foreshadow that I will move an amendment. I think I need to foreshadow it because it is inconsistent with the amendment put down by Senator Murray. My amendment will be in the following terms:
(2) That the Committee of Privileges not commence its inquiry into this matter until a statement is provided in accordance with paragraph (3)
paragraph (1) restates Senator Faulkner's motion—
indicating that Australian Federal Police investigations of payments made to Senator Colston and any legal proceedings consequent on those investigations have been concluded.

(3) That, for the purpose of paragraph (2), the Attorney‐General provide to the President, as soon as possible after the conclusion of such investigations and any such legal proceedings, a statement indicating that such investigations and any such legal proceedings have concluded, and the President immediately provide that statement to the Committee of Privileges.

So yes, pass the motion handing this matter to the Privileges Committee, but the Senate should resolve that the privileges inquiry should not commence until all matters relating to these police investigations have been brought to finality. By adopting that process, the Senate would be able to preserve its integrity and work out whether these statements were untrue or otherwise, but we would not be acting in a way that would risk that police investigation and matters that would flow from it. I therefore put that proposition to the Senate as the proper way to resolve this matter in the interests of the public at large and for the future standing of this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset of my contribution, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter I sent to all senators on this matter. I think Senator Hill has okayed that.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—
SENATOR ROBERT RAY
28 April 1997
NAME
ADDRESS
SUBTOWN STATE P/CODE
Dear Senator

As a consequence of the Resolution of the Senate agreed to on the 25 February 1988, the President is required to have regard to only two criteria when determining if a matter of privilege should have precedence.
The first criterion requires that the issue for judgement should be of sufficient gravity that a substantial obstruction of the Senate or its committees could be held to have occurred.
The second criterion requires that no other remedy for addressing the contempt exists.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Prime Facie Case:

SPEECH.PARA: What are the circumstances that require investigation by the Privileges Committee?

On 24 March 1997 the President tabled in the Senate a document entitled `Senator Colston—Travelling Allowance Documents Tabled by Madam President'. These documents consisted of various reports from Senate officials detailing irregular travel claims made by Senator Colston. They included an exchange of correspondence between the President and Senator Colston in relation to the timing of his response to the reports and they included two letters from Senator Colston explaining how the bogus claims occurred. They also included a statement by Mrs Christine Smith, a former office manager for Senator Colston.
In his letter to the President of 24 March 1997 Senator Colston claimed that:

"My investigations have discovered that the inadequate bookkeeping systems in my office led to administrative errors on the part of my office staff which caused the overpayments. I would regularly ask my office manager at the time for the dates of my travelling to place on my claims and I would transcribe those dates onto the claim form. In doing so I assumed that the dates which were given to me by my office manager were correct. In the course of my investigation, I have discovered that in numerous cases these dates were not correct."
Senator Colston offered this explanation as the cause of overpayments on 19 occasions in that correspondence.
Senator Colston wrote to the Clerk of the Senate on 24 March 1997 and offered the same explanation for the cause of travel allowance overpayments on a further six occasions.
In support of this explanation Senator Colston caused to be tabled a statement signed by Mrs Christine Smith and dated 24 March 1997.
In this statement Mrs Smith confirmed that she acted as office manager for Senator Colston during the relevant period. She also stated:
"One of my duties during that time was to record the dates for which the Senator was eligible for travelling allowance".
She explained that the Senator often notified her of changes but stated that:

"I did not notify the transport office as required nor did I sometimes make adequate note of the changed travel arrangements. The only excuse that I have is that the pressures of work in the office made me put these matters to one side.
The result was that on a number of occasions I gave the Senator an incorrect list of dates for his travelling allowance claims. The Senator accepted the dates I provided to him as being correct."
Mrs Smith's statement concluded:
"I accept full responsibility for providing the wrong dates to Senator Colston for transcription to his travel allowance claims."

The Clerk of the Senate has advised that these documents, having been presented to the Senate, were published in accordance with Standing Order 167. They are therefore proceedings in parliament within the meaning of section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 which applies article nine of the Bill of Rights 1688 to the Parliament of the Commonwealth.
It is therefore common ground that these statements are unimpeachable in any court or tribunal or any other place outside of the Parliament.
On 8 April 1997 Mrs Smith supplied to the President and the Clerk of the Senate additional infor mation relating to her earlier statement of the 24 March 1997.
She stated that she wished to withdraw her earlier statement and replace it with a statement that declared, amongst other things,:

"Both the Senator and I were aware at this time that in fact the mistakes were not mine as it was not part of my duties to provide the Senator with information for his TA claims, nor did I ever provide claims on his behalf."
She stated that:
"I asked the Senator whether the statement had in fact already been typed, because I had not done it, and he said words to the effect of `yes, Douglas has been working all weekend'."
She continued:

"I now wish to advise that my statement was incorrect. I was not responsible for preparing the Senator's Travelling Allowance claims nor required to keep a record of dates of travel for TA purposes. The Senator always prepared his own claims."
Senator Colston has rejected the assertions contained within Mrs Smith's second statement.
Whichever statement or statements is to be believed, misleading evidence has been provided to the Senate.

On the basis of the second statement provided by Mrs Christine Smith, both Senator Colston and Mrs Smith knowingly provided misleading statements to the Senate on 24 March 1997. Further, Mrs Christine Smith's second statement asserts that a member of Senator Colston's staff, Douglas Colston, was responsible for drafting her first statement.
The Senate has always regarded the provision of misleading information to itself or one of its committees as one of the most serious matters of privilege that can be raised.
It is surely no less serious when a Senator himself knowingly causes misleading information to be presented.
There is no doubt therefore that the requirements of the first criterion have been satisfied.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Other remedies:

SPEECH.PARA: Whatever the arguments about the scope of the AFP investigation and its impact on a Senate inquiry one fact is clear. The AFP, or any court, will never be able to produce or test those statements attracting absolute parliamentary privilege. This was the point made by the Clerk of the Senate in his letter to the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate on 22 April 1997. He stated that:

"The significant feature of the statements by Senator Colston and Mrs Smith is not that they were published by the Senate but that they were created for the purpose of submission to the Senate (the President having stated that she would present them to the Senate on their receipt by her) and they therefore have no prior or independent existence apart from the Senate's inquiry."

On at least six occasions in recent years the President has granted precedence and the Senate has referred matters to the Privileges Committee based on allegations of misleading evidence provided by witnesses to Senate committees.

On none of those occasions was the evidence so substantial or the gravity so clear as this. On no occasions was the information provided directly to the Senate and on no occasion was a Senator directly accused of responsibility for actually preparing the misleading information.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The AFP investigation:

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, it is not surprising that the Government, the Opposition, the Democrats and the Greens all agree that a case has been established to refer this matter to the Privileges Committee.
The question is rather one of timing.

The Attorney General asked the Chief General Counsel of his Department, Mr Henry Burmester, to provide advice on the difficulties that an inquiry by the Senate Privileges Committee might create for the investigation in progress by the Australian Federal Police.

In his advice the Chief General Counsel acknowledged the broad definition given to proceedings in parliament by section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987. His advice acknowledged the severe limitations that are attached to the use of documents that constitute parliamentary proceedings. He stated that the Act:

". . . significantly limits the ability to question a person about the veracity of anything forming part of parliamentary proceedings, and from questioning the credibility, motive, intentions, or good faith of a person, or drawing inferences or conclusions wholly or partly from anything forming part of those proceedings in parliament."

Mr Burmester then conceded the vital point—nothing prevents either Senator Colston or Mrs Christine Smith from giving their accounts of the circumstances surrounding the bogus travel Claims to any inquiry or court.

But only the Senate can conduct an investigation into whether a contempt has occurred as a consequence of the tabling and publication of the documents presented by the President on 24 March 1997. These are two distinct and exclusive issues. As the Clerk stated in his advice:

"The Senate would inquire into the truthfulness of the statements made to it by Senator Colston and Mrs Smith and whether a contempt was committed by the making of false statements. This question cannot be the subject of any legal proceedings. . . "
Mr Burmester's advice conceded that the vital issue was the scope of any proposed Senate inquiry—he conceded that:

"It is a matter for judgement whether a Senate inquiry into these matters could in fact be confined in a way that did not trespass more broadly into matters the current subject of criminal investigation"

The basic point remains—an inquiry into the truthfulness or otherwise of the statements presented to the Senate is based on evidence that only the Senate can access and therefore issues that only the Senate can assess.

Nevertheless, the Opposition's position is not an unreasonable one. We believe that the terms of a proposed inquiry can best be developed through a conference of Senate Party Leaders to ensure that the inquiry is focussed only on the issues that can potentially represent a clear breach of Senate privilege.

We invite the Attorney General to nominate an officer from his department to monitor the Committee's deliberations and provide advice in the event that the AFP investigation is to be affected in any way by the Committee's inquiry. If a matter that is the subject of the AFP investigation is to be materially canvassed then the inquiry should cease.

The purpose of a Privileges Committee inquiry is not to duplicate or `shadow' any AFP investigation. Rather, it is to inquire into and, if necessary, provide a sanction for, matters which have no other potential remedy.

The Privileges Committee has a history of dealing appropriately with these types of issues. Matters relating to breaches of Senate privilege are, by their nature, sensitive. In my experience the Committee has always behaved cooperatively and sensibly—I see no reason why that would not continue to occur in this instance.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Chair of the Privileges Committee:

SPEECH.PARA: Senators would be aware of my role both as Chair of the Privileges Committee and as a Senator who has been outspoken on many of the issues relating to Senator Colston. I therefore consider it appropriate to stand aside from the Chairmanship of the Privileges Committee should it conduct an inquiry into matters relating to Senator Colston. I also intend to stand aside from the inquiry itself.

I have received advice from the Clerk that I can be replaced by another senator for the purposes of any inquiry into Senator Colston while continuing to be a member of the Committee for other work—including other inquiries. According to standing orders the Committee would elect an opposition Senator as chair.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Conscience Votes:

SPEECH.PARA: On 20 April 1997, Senator Vanstone stated that she would not like to see a conscience vote on this issue. She twice rejected the notion and asked rhetorically "Why should there be?"
Yet, when the Senate debated a matter of privilege in August 1990 relating to information supplied by the Department of Defence on the use of asbestos by the Royal Australian Navy, I commented:
"It is not a party matter, so today I am not just addressing the Opposition and the Australian Democrats; I am also addressing people on my own side of the chamber."
In response to an interjection, I said:
"Senator Michael Baume has already made up his mind, on a conscience vote, without listening to both sides."
Yet Senator Vanstone told us, on the Sunday Program, that matters of privilege should be party votes, like most other matters before this chamber.

I have no problem with a party vote on matters of privilege. But let's have some consistency. If it is to be the case that in future matters of privilege are to be party votes on all occasions, let's set the ground rules now. Otherwise the Labor Party will again be the bunnies—as in the case of pairs and on the recommittal of motions lost through misadventure—taking the honourable course when it suits the Coalition and then being ratted on by a Government which refuses to observe the same courtesies when they see partisan advantage for themselves.

On the question of partisanship insofar as it applies to the Privileges Committee itself. Having served on this Committee for some time, it has always been my experience that the Committee discharges its work without regard to a party line.

Given its important role within the Senate and its quasi‐judicial character this is entirely appropriate. If we are no longer going to observe conscience votes on matters of privilege in the chamber, I would hope that this would not extend to the operation of the Committee itself This would be a backward step.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Conclusion:

SPEECH.PARA: In recent years we have seen a proliferation of seminars and publications advising public servants on their legal obligations when giving evidence before Senate committees. Indeed, on some occasions references and findings of the Privileges Committee have been based on the need to educate by example public servants who, even inadvertently, have committed a breach of Senate privilege.

If we refuse to refer this matter to the Privileges Committee we should be clear on one point. The Senate will have no credibility with public servants or other classes of witnesses if we refuse to investi gate one of our own for causing misleading evidence to be presented to the Senate.

There has been much talk recently about the effect that this matter has had on the standing of the Parliament and of all Senators and Members. Whatever shabby—excuse the Senate finds not to cause this matter to be investigated the real effect will be to reveal to the Australian public that a double standard applies—that the Senate is unwilling to apply the rules that it insists upon for public servants and the rest of the community to senators themselves. That is what will diminish the Senate further. In effect the Senate would be turning the Resolution of the 25th February 1988 on its head. Through not investigating the matter we would be ensuring that no one else could either—there would in effect be no remedy for any untruthful statements tabled in relation to this issue. No greater damage could be done to the integrity and proper operation of the Senate.
Yours sincerely
ROBERT RAY

TALK.START.PARA: —Cutting away the verbiage of Senator Hill's speech and getting to the content of it in the last five minutes—it was a reasonable contribution at that stage by Senator Hill—I think there is general agreement around the Senate that there is a prima facie case for the Privileges Committee to look at. Without prejudging who is telling the truth in the matter, whether it is Senator Colston or Mrs Smith, there is an obvious conflict of statement there and it is a matter in regard to which there is a very strong prima facie case to go to the Privileges Committee. Therefore, the only debate about that is a question of timing. When should it go? I still have an open mind on that matter, but I want to address—
—Oh!
—I do not need your cynical, pathetic interventions, Senator Abetz—the sneering senator from Tasmania, the magistrates court's bully boy. We do not need your contribution today.

SPEECH.PARA: The real question is: is it possible for a co‐joint Privileges Committee inquiry and police inquiry and would their inquiries overlap and conflict? The answer to that is both yes and no. With a properly run privileges inquiry, with proper caveats, it would be possible to have an inquiry into the contempt matter at the same time as a police inquiry. But it also should be acknowledged that a badly run inquiry, a poorly advised inquiry, does have the potential to interfere with the police inquiries. The Labor Party takes the view that under no circumstances should the police inquiries be interfered with. But we reject the coalition's assertion that such overlapping and interference is inevitable.

There are two amendments before the chair. One is by Senator Murray, which asks for the Privileges Committee itself to weigh up these legal opinions and report back to the Senate. In fact, a resolution from the Senate will then be required, as to whether the inquiry proceeds. It is a fairly reasonable proposition, made more reasonable by my colleague when he put the reporting date out by an extra couple of weeks, which would at least allow members of the Privileges Committee to give some considered view to put to this chamber.

Senator Hill's proposed amendment states that there should be absolutely, categorically no inquiries until all police and potential court matters are resolved. I would have thought that was a better motion to move in two or three weeks time, when the Privileges Committee has looked at all these matters and reported back to the Senate. Then Senator Hill could put that particular motion, if it was still his view. It would have been a much more reasonable approach in these matters.

As I said, the prima facie case has been established; the only debate is about timing. I want to make this point, as I did in my letter: the Privileges Committee has had something like 29 references in the last seven or eight years, nearly all associated with misleading evidence—not by senators, but by public servants and the public. How can we look them straight in the face and say, `Hold on, we're going to investigate all of you, but when one of our own may potentially have committed a sin, we're going to expiate that immediately'?

There are certain matters that have to be dealt with here from Senator Hill's contribution. Firstly, he says this is a political exercise. There have been aspects to the Colston affair that have been political; there is no question about that. But there is no way, under this reference, as Senator Faulkner has termed, that the Senate Privileges Committee could look at any deal between the government and Senator Colston. It is not in the terms of reference and no chairman or no member of the Privileges Committee would allow the inquiry to stray into those areas. But Senator Hill said, `Mr Crean said so and so.' Yes, a member of the House of Representatives, not understanding the Senate procedures, said that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course you didn't take any notice of him!

—Equally, we could ask, Senator Ferguson, why it was left to Mr Reith, a member of the House of Representatives—penthouse Pete—to release the initial preliminary advice from A‐G's and from the DPP on this matter.
—How did he get it?

—Yes, how did he get the advice? The reason is that they had to pull Senator Hill out of the batting order; they did not want him exposed to any questions on this. Senator Alston was left out of it; they did not want him to be asked any questions on it. Also, they just completely ignored the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams). So you have some mundane suburban solicitor running the government's case from the House of Representatives, arguing that we did not have the right in the Senate to determine whether this matter goes to the Privileges Committee and is heard. That is the level to which the coalition had to stoop.

SPEECH.PARA: I would say to all those in the House of Representatives—Mr Crean, Mr Reith and all the rest of them—butt out. This is Senate business. It is a potential contempt of the Senate that we are looking at and it is, frankly, none of their business. I hope, equally, that none of us ever proceed to try to interfere with privileges matters that occur in the other place.

We have the situation of Senator Hill coming in here and talking about the rules of natural justice. I did point out yesterday, in a question to Senator Hill, that this is a remarkable conversion. It was only in 1994‐95 that he let all his senators off the leash to ask operational police matters in this chamber, in the estimates committee and in the select committee on radioactive waste. They were like pigs in mud there. They had great fun there asking all sorts of questions. But suddenly, when they make the 10‐metre journey to the other side, natural justice comes forward as an argument.

If they really believed in natural justice and in the presumption of innocence, why have they stripped the former Deputy President of his position? Haven't they judged him? In the panic press conference, when Mr Howard demanded that he give up the post, was that not bringing a judgment down on Senator Colston? And when the opinion polls came out and the slide continued and the cabinet discussion occurred and the Grahame Morris solution came forth that they would never accept Senator Colston's vote again, wasn't that a slight infringement on the presumption of innocence? Of course it was. They are very happy to presume.

So we have to ask the question: why has the coalition been so paranoid about this matter going to the Privileges Committee? The first reason was given by Senator Hill today. He might have had every reason, with justice, to be paranoid about it. He says he thought that this committee would look at the deal. I am telling him now it will not and it was never going to. So that removes that.

I think, from the questions asked yesterday in the chamber, we now know why the coalition do not want this to go to the Privileges Committee. They probably do not want immediate evidence from Mrs Smith as to what her discussions with Senator Alston were. They do not want any input by this government into Mrs Smith's or Senator Colston's statements, which were put down in this chamber on 24 March, cross‐examined and put in the evidence. I think it is there you will find the sudden creation of the natural justice argument as a smokescreen to hide their own political hides.

Of course, Senator Hill has run out the old chestnuts today. He says, `Look at 1983.' He was here in 1981 and 1982, but political amnesia has hit him: he cannot recall the fact that the first offences by Senator Colston were under the Fraser government. He cannot recall the fact that the first discovery was under the Fraser government. He cannot recall the fact that it was a Liberal minister, Mr Newman, that allowed Senator Colston to repay the money. All we have from Mr Newman is, `I would have liked it to have gone to the Federal Police.' There is no evidence of that. None of those documents have been released to the opposition to sustain or support that particular point of view. But they forget that. They conveniently forget that the first offences occurred under the Fraser government and were discovered under the Fraser government, and that administrative means were used to repay that.

We have the cheek of someone like Senator Knowles, who came in here yesterday and said that we were cabinet ministers and we should have known. Let me say to you, Senator Knowles, that in 1982 the current Prime Minister (Mr Howard) was a member of cabinet. Why didn't he know about Senator Colston's matters?

TALK.START.PARA: —But you're saying that Senator Hill and Senator Alston should know what happened when you were in government.
—No. Senator Knowles, you said yesterday that because we were cabinet ministers we should have known of his offences.

SPEECH.PARA: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —John Howard was a cabinet minister and offences occurred under a Liberal government. Was he expected to have knowledge of them? Of course not. Those sorts of matters would never go to a cabinet minister or a Treasurer or anyone else, and you know it.
—But Gareth was deputy; Gareth nominated him.

—You can interject as much as you like. You will not acknowledge that the first offences occurred under a Liberal government and that the money was repaid under a Liberal government in an administrative way. That occurred under your administration but you, collectively, always have amnesia about the Fraser government. Senator Hill comes in and says, `Look, you supported Senator Colston in 1990 and you knew.' First of all, we did not know. I have asserted that and you cannot contradict that I knew.
—You recommended it go to the AFP.

—No‐one has actually put on the public record what happened in 1990. Let me put it there and dob in Senator Kernot and co. We had a federal election in 1990. Remember that we had a caucus meeting after that. Remember, at the time, the presidency and deputy presidency were contested positions—always. Even though the presidency went to government and the deputy presidency went to opposition, there were always ballots for these positions. Senator Colston put his hand up and said, `I'll be the sacrificial lamb and run for the deputy presidency.' He was endorsed in about late March or April to run for that position. Remember, the position does not come up until August. What happened in the meantime was that you had not selected a candidate on the other side there. You then selected Senator Crichton‐Browne. So it was going to be a run off between Senator Crichton‐Browne and Senator Colston. We obviously assumed we were going to lose. It was only at the last minute that the Democrats announced they would not support Crichton‐Browne.
—And would only support another Liberal.
—And that they would support another Liberal. They were the votes that put Senator Colston up.

SPEECH.PARA: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Then what happens?
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—History seems to have a way of saying that was a very doomed position in 1990. Look at what has happened to the two colleagues since then. But we will not go into the intense detail of that. Aren't we just lucky that no‐one else ran in that ballot? In terms of what Senator Hill has to say about 1990, he does it totally without knowledge of the history of it.

BREAK.PARA: Look at the transparency on these matters. We had Senator Hill get up on the Sunday program and say that this should not go to the Privileges Committee but, `I have to face question time,' he says, with a furrow on his brow. `I have to face intense questioning at estimates committee.' But when we ask him about the details of meetings he says, `I'm not going to reveal that.' When we ask him whether there was a deal he says, `I answered those questions last year.' But when you look up the answers from last year they are non‐answers. There is no transparency in this.

There is a need, I think, for this government to come clean. It should reveal what discussions they had with Senator Colston leading up to his defection in August last year. They should say what discussions they had with Mrs Smith with regard to the statement that she made. They should put those things on the record. If they do, then some of the conspiracy theories may get deflated and some may in fact get sustained over time. But there has been throughout this a lack of transparency.

They finally talk about, `Aren't we goody‐two‐shoes? We sent this off to the Federal Police.' Have a look at the circumstances in which they sent it off. They said time and time again before 8 April, `We'll let matters take their course.' They put extended reporting dates by Senator Colston back to protect him. They did everything possible to protect him. Then suddenly, on 8 April, the following sequence of events occurs: Mr Douglas B. Colston finds out that Mrs Smith is going to retract her statement. He informs his father, Senator Colston, who then rings Senator Alston, who then rings the office of the Prime Minister, and a panic starts. They desperately try to get hold of a copy of the recantation. Quite properly, Madam President, it was not handed over by the parliamentary side to the executive, and you came up—it must have been pretty good—at 4 o'clock in the morning with a very clever move: `Send it out to all the party leaders, and that's a way of getting it out.' I congratulate you for it.

So the panic is on. They were desperately trying to get hold of a copy of this recantation. Eventually, they get hold of a copy and at about 8.20 they give notice of a press conference for 9 o'clock that night. These are the circumstances in which it went to the Federal Police. It was not a considered decision, not a rational decision, not a moral or principled position but absolute political panic before it got sent across. They worry that even the press conference may not go ahead, because it was slotted for 9 o'clock and they are having trouble analysing it.

They even have to pull the Prime Minister's doormat out of Falstaff or whatever the show was to get his legal opinion. I can tell you the reason they did that. Senator Alston was in fact the agent who ran Senator Colston, and he was a vital part of it. That is why he refuses to comment on how many phone calls he has made to Senator Colston and why he has had Senator Colston in his office so often. But he cannot even remember this person. He cannot even remember why he went to Senator Colston's office in mid‐March. Here you have the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate making the long walk around to the office of the Deputy President to discuss something with him and he cannot even recall the subject matter. He does not know why he is in that office. We have the deputy leader of the coalition in this place wandering around the building not knowing where he is or what he is doing. There is some other evidence for that. He has wandered around, missed divisions and booked overseas trips not even knowing where he is going or what he is doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —But he stayed in the best hotels.

—I will not go into that. I think we have all stayed at the best hotels over the years. He goes over to Senator Colston's office but doesn't now remember why he went. He has some vague recollection of meeting Mrs Smith and off he wanders, apparently back to his own office. He has shown no transparency in his activities.

BREAK.PARA: As Senator Faulkner reminded us, the most degrading moment in my time in the Senate was to watch Senator Alston make the walk right over here during a division, tap Senator Colston on his shoulder and tell him to come to the other side. Then, panting like Fido, he followed Senator Alston across to the other side of the chamber. That was absolutely humiliating.

As I said at the outset of this debate, the only question before this parliament and this chamber at the moment appears to be that of timing, in which I think there are valid arguments going both ways. We restate our position that we do not believe there would necessarily be a clash between the Privileges Committee and the police inquiry. We say that, if there is a clash, the Privileges Committee could not proceed with its inquiries, but we say that that clash is not inevitable. We say, with proper advice, conjoint inquiries can be run.

As to the amendments, Senator Murray's really asks for a more considered view to be established and put back to this chamber with the ultimate decision to be made in that chamber. We accept that point of view put forward by Senator Murray. We think Senator Hill's amendment is more appropriate to be put when that Senate Privileges Committee report comes back to this chamber. He would still have a legitimate opportunity to put his delay mechanism in place at that time, on the 29th, or whenever that report is considered. Of course, what they basically want to do is to say, effectively, `If we can put it off now, there'll never be an inquiry.' If they have a belief that the police inquiry and any potential court cases will take a couple of years, this is something they can just push off forever. Therein lies the motivation, in part.

The other motivation is that they desperately do not want any cross‐examination as to what role they may have had—I am not asserting that they did have—in the construction of the Smith‐Colston defence that appeared here on 24 March. They desperately don't want that. As I said before, as for Senator Hill's paranoia about this inquiry going broader into political deals, I can put his mind at ease. That is not the intention of senators. Mr Crean said that. He was in error, the same as Mr Reith was in error, in his comments on this particular matter. This is a matter to be determined in the Senate and not in the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Robert Ray talks a lot about transparency. The one thing that we could not accuse Senator Robert Ray of since the beginning of the first session is a lack of transparency because, quite frankly, Senator Ray's efforts in trying to make sure that Senator Colston is brought down have been very transparent. You have even admitted that it is a vendetta, that nobody rats on the Labor Party and that you will go to the ends of the earth to make sure that you get your man.

SPEECH.PARA: You also accuse this government of a lack of transparency. Senator Carr interjected earlier, `What about 1982?' You also said, `What about 1982?' It is a fact that the Minister for Administrative Services in 1982, Mr Kevin Newman, has confirmed in recent times that nearly $4,200 was repaid. He has also said that he wanted to call the police in but that he had advice from DAS that there was no legal cause to do so. He believes that at the time he told the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Bill Hayden, and the Acting Attorney‐General, Mr Neil Brown.

You talk about a lack of transparency, but compare that with what happened in 1983 when advice was given that the matter should be referred to the Federal Police. And yet the Attorney‐General at the time, Gareth Evans, only recently on 6 April went on that program to defend the manner in which the Labor government had handled the Colston matter in 1983. Where was the transparency then? Where was the need to make things public?

The former senator Gareth Evans even had the gall to say that Labor had no problem with reopening the investigations because it happened at the time Senator Colston was a young mistake maker. `A young mistake maker' was the term used by former senator Gareth Evans when referring to Senator Colston when he already knew in 1982 that money had been repaid and there was a request for the Australian Federal Police to investigate a matter. But he was a young mistake maker. He was a young mistake maker: he had been in the Senate for only eight years at the time.

You will be right, Senator Forshaw. You have been here for only three or four, so you can make mistakes for the next three or four years and you will only be a young mistake maker. I am not suggesting you would make mistakes, of course, but your colleagues have been here for less than eight years; they can make these sorts of mistakes. Former Senator Evans would not refer anything to the police if you did, because if you have been here only eight years you are only a young mistake maker. Against all advice, the government of the day showed a complete lack of transparency and kept the matter under wraps to make sure that the public did not have any idea of what was happening.

Then that same Senator Gareth Evans was prepared in 1990 to support Senator Colston for the deputy presidency. Senator Ray says that he himself was not in possession of that knowledge and that if he had been he would not have supported him. I believe Senator Ray. Senator Ray has proved in this place to be an honest man, but your former leader in this place, then Senator Gareth Evans, in 1990 knew and had to know. And I remain to be convinced that there were not other people in the Labor Party who knew that in 1983 in particular, and even possibly in 1982, Senator Colston had been forced to repay money because of misclaiming of travelling allowances. That is the sort of person you put up to be Deputy President, and you then criticise this government for supporting him as Deputy President when they were not in possession of any of those facts as to what occurred in 1993.

I agree with Senator Ray and Senator Hill when they say that the matters that have been raised may be matters that the Privileges Committee should consider. But it is all a matter of timing, and we just happen to disagree as to when that should take place. I support the amendment that has been foreshadowed by Senator Hill that we should let the police investigation take its course and, at the conclusion of that police investigation, the Senate should then decide whether or not there is a matter to be referred to the Privileges Committee and a case to answer as to whether or not there has been contempt of the Senate or in some other way there has been a breach of privilege of the Senate.

BREAK.PARA: It is totally appropriate to allow the Australian Federal Police to finalise their investigation without being hampered in any way whatsoever and at the conclusion of that for this Senate to then decide whether there is a case to answer or whether there is a matter that should be determined by the Privileges Committee, taking into account anything that may have happened as a result of the Federal Police investigation that is currently taking place.

Senator Murray, I hold you in high regard—I have seen many of your contributions at committee level—but let me say that I think today's effort when you moved your amendment was rather pathetic. In suggesting that the Senate is the only place that ever gets it right, you tended to agree with Senator Margetts, who in her contribution talked about practically everything except this particular motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —When have you talked about the motion?
—Senator Ray in his part of the debate talked about transparency.
—Talk about the legal advice.

—Senator Ray talked about transparency, and I am trying to tell you that they had legal advice in 1983 and did not carry it out. And that is why I am trying to show you that they have shown a complete lack of transparency. But, Senator Murray, you then condemned the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) for not speaking out when you said that the Senate is the place where these matters should be determined. You said it is a matter that is really in the province of the Senate to decide—this marvellous place, the Senate, that always gets things right, in stark contrast to the House of Representatives, of course, which in your opinion always gets things wrong. Of course, it just happens to be the house that provides the government of the day, but that is just a minor matter. If it is a matter for the Senate to decide, then the whole Senate will decide, and we will do so when we vote later on on this matter.
—Transparency in the House of Representatives was the point.

—I was replying to Senator Ray's comments about transparency and just showing the lack of transparency that was shown by that former government. Senator Faulkner trotted out the usual diatribe that we have heard day after day on this matter and a repeat of previous things that were said and have been said since February, which do little to advance the argument that was being put forward as to the urgency of this matter going to the Privileges Committee right now.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Faulkner's effort to expand the inquiry—and it is obviously the intent, despite what Senator Ray says—beyond Senator Colston's alleged travelling rorts would result in something that is difficult to control because, once the matter gets before the Privileges Committee, there are lots of other things and extraneous matters, I am quite sure, that will be debated, as happens in other committees.

It is fair to say, from the initial efforts of Senator Ray in particular but also of Senator Faulkner to expose alleged rorting of allowances by Senator Colston, that events have overtaken their original intent, which was by any means at their disposal to get rid of Senator Colston both as Deputy President and as a member of the Senate.

Events have overtaken that. The matters that have been raised by them have been dealt with in ways that have been described by Senator Hill and others. Those events have led to an investigation by the Australian Federal Police. I think it is important for us to remember that that investigation by the Federal Police should take precedence now that it has been asked for.

The government has called in the Federal Police and it should be allowed to go on unhindered. It should be allowed to take its natural course. At the end of that time, this Senate will still have the opportunity to decide, bearing in mind the results of the police inquiry, whether or not there is a case to be referred to the Privileges Committee. That is the time that these matters, if neces sary, should be dealt with by the Privileges Committee and not before.

It does not matter how often we hear Senator Ray and Senator Faulkner repeating events of the past. Many events have come to light, of course, which they did not care to mention in the earlier stages of this debate over these particular allegations, but I want to put it on the record that their total lack of transparency in earlier times belies their intention at this stage to try to bring forward matters for the purposes of transparency.

When they were in government they had no interest other than protecting one of their own. Once that person who was their own defected and resigned from their party, they then had no other intention other than to destroy that person who chose to resign from the Labor Party. Their intention has been quite obvious since the beginning of February—carefully planned, carefully stage managed so that, day after day, these matters were brought forward.

We have now reached the stage with the introduction of a Federal Police inquiry where this Senate should allow that Federal Police inquiry to continue. It should allow it to complete its findings. Once it has made its findings public, this Senate should then decide whether or not there are still outstanding matters that should be referred to the Privileges Committee for their deliberation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I think no issue in recent years has galvanised public interest about the standards of parliamentary behaviour and commitment to high standards of public office than the motion we are debating here today. There is enormous alarm amongst the Australian public right across the political spectrum about the falling stocks of parliamentary representation in an honest and aboveboard manner of the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Everywhere I go in the electorate of Tasmania and, indeed, on the mainland, the so-called Colston affair is a matter of high debate. There is a lot of joking about it and there is a lot of cartoonery about it, but the fact is that the average Australian sees this matter as one of enormous importance, sees this matter as serious, and wants it cleared up expeditiously. They want action.

We are here today really deciding, firstly, whether there is going to be action and, secondly, how quickly that action is to be taken. That is the matter before us. We must keep the public in mind and not just sectional political interest within this Senate chamber in dealing with this matter.

The question here is whether the Privileges Committee, by looking into whether or not the Senate has been misled by statements from Senator Colston and Mrs Smith, is going to infringe on a police inquiry which is looking at whether or not fraudulent claims were made by Senator Colston. I agree with Senator Robert Ray that the Privileges Committee has the nous and the wherewithal to proceed carefully enough so that it does not infringe upon the police inquiry and does not hamper or curtail the police inquiry into whether or not fraudulent claims were made by Senator Colston.

I am concerned that three weeks from now we are simply going to have a report back from the Privileges Committee, if Senator Murray's amendment is carried—and I think it will be carried—which is going to leave this matter no clearer than it is now. It is simply going to be a case of duelling legal opinions.
