Therefore, I would favour the motion jointly put forward by Senator Margetts and Senator Bolkus being adopted by the Senate this morning and carried into effect so that the Privileges Committee can get on with the business of determining who misled the Senate. That is the matter at hand.

In determining whether or not we are going to get that far, we have to look at the government's proposed amendment. Senator Ferguson, who spoke before me, asserted that it would be a good thing if we waited until after the police inquiry before the Privileges Committee looked into who has misled this Senate—was it Senator Colston or was it Mrs Smith. But that is not what the government's amendment does. It says, `Let's not have Senate action to look into that matter until after the police inquiry and any consequent court proceedings.' That in my book means forever.

BREAK.PARA: If this government amendment is passed, forget a Privileges Committee inquiry into who misled the Senate. I believe, if that motion is passed by the Senate, we can forget the Privileges Committee and we can forget ever finding out who it was who misled the Senate in the diametrically opposite submissions that were put to the Senate in the earlier months of this year.

I believe it is critical that we do go to the heart of that matter, that we do find out whether it was Senator Colston or Mrs Smith, and only the Privileges Committee can determine that matter. Therefore, it is imperative that the two inquiries proceed in parallel with the Privileges Committee taking all due caution, otherwise we will have a de facto miscarriage of justice by no justice being done at all in the matter of the misleading of this place.

Let us not underestimate that. It is fundamental, as Senator Margetts has said, for good government and for good government being seen to be done and for the sterling representation of the people of Australia that this matter be clarified and that, if people in high office mislead this place, that be discovered and those people be dealt with appropriately.

Pivotal to some of the votes that are going to occur in this matter will be the votes of the Independents themselves—Senator Colston and Senator Harradine. With their votes, the government has the numbers. Incumbent upon those two senators is a very high responsibility in how they vote today on this motion, the amendment and the foreshadowed amendment.

Senator Colston has indicated that he will vote against the government as a matter of procedure. It will be very testing indeed to see whether he will vote against a government amendment that has been put here today and, therefore, against what may be seen as his own interests. I do not know. I reckon that it would be extraordinarily untoward were he to vote on the matter at all because of the self-interest that is involved.

As you know, Madam President, I have been punctual in drawing the Senate's attention to the relevant section of the rules which says that if we are dealing with a matter in which we have a personal stake at least we must declare that stake to the Senate, even though there is no means to prevent a vote being taken. There is a very high responsibility on Senator Colston to consider whether he should vote at all in these matters.

Senator Harradine is also in a very difficult position. It appears to me that Senator Harradine has been deceived to some degree by Senator Colston. We must remember that in August last year, when Senator Colston won the deputy presidency, it was Senator Harradine who was a chief advocate for him winning that position. Indeed, Senator Harradine spoke to me about the good attributes of Senator Colston in his run for the position of Deputy President. That did not win my vote on the occasion. But Senator Harradine took on the Labor Party over the matter. He said that they had a problem on their hands—a matter that they ought to look at with some degree of honour.

Sadly, for Senator Harradine, it appears now that the reverse is true and that there is an enormous test of his own honour in ensuring that Senator Colston's affairs are properly investigated, discovered and dealt with by both the Senate and the police, without infringement on the police inquiry.

I find it a matter of great sadness that Senator Harradine, in 21 years of working with Senator Colston in this place—and I had the presumption that no-one knew him better than Senator Harradine—in fact knew nothing of the apparent past infractions of Senator Colston. Indeed, Senator Harradine said last year that he looked forward to working with Senator Colston in his role as Deputy President of the Senate and as a fellow Independent and said, `We have actually doubled our numbers overnight.'

Senator Harradine was the primary advocate for Senator Colston taking this high office. Apparently, Senator Harradine had no knowledge whatever of the past behaviour of Senator Colston. I find it tremendously sad that that can be the situation, that in such a long and distinguished career as that which Senator Harradine has had he was nevertheless not able to pick up on what was happening to a fellow senator for whom he had become chief advocate. That is a matter of history now.

I assert again that there is an enormous weight of responsibility on both Independent senators as to how they vote. This must not be a political matter. This is a matter of fair action, of establishing proper behaviour and of resetting the standards of parliament in the eyes of the Australian electorate. It is hugely important. It must not be just a matter of political ping‐pong.

I believe that expedition and prudence are called for. I support the motion before the Senate. I would prefer that Senator Murray's amendment did not delay this action, but it is going to. Maybe that will have a good outcome; it certainly is not in any way meant to do other than ensure a better outcome—and I accept that, Senator Murray. I may well live to very soon congratulate you on assuring that we went the right direction.

I totally oppose the amendment flagged by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill). All it will do is ensure that the Privileges Committee never meets during the term of this parliament to discover who has deceived the Senate and, effectively, who has deliberately, I believe, set out to deceive the people of Australia in a matter of great importance. That would be the worst of all outcomes. I would inveigle the government to withdraw that amendment. But, if it is put and comes to a vote, there is a very heavy responsibility on the Independent senators to see that it does not pass this morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon, Sen David

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I would like to deal with a matter raised by Senator Ray since he has circulated his letter. It relates to the matter of whether this is a free vote or whether it is a party vote. I accept Senator Ray's point that it is up to the Senate to decide what happens here but it clearly has been the practice in all the time I have been in the Senate for matters of privilege to be a free vote. That is certainly my own position this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: If you read Odgers, the seventh edition, page 247, chapter 11, it says that matters in relation to sessional orders, standing orders and matters of privilege have traditionally been a matter of a free vote. Searching through the files for the last 13-odd years, I find several references. On 2 October 1984 Senator Georges says, `I am moving a motion which indicates that I have got a free vote.' He was a Labor Party senator. In April 1986 Senator Gareth Evans says: `The government has taken the view that matters of privilege are not party matters but traditionally free vote matters.' On 24 February 1988 there is another such statement by Senator Evans. On 25 February 1988 there is a statement to that effect by Senator Puplick, for the Liberal Party. I accept that it is for the Senate to change its mind on these matters but I certainly—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone—
—That was because she was allegedly quoted in Senator Ray's letter. I did not hear that. That cannot have been in this chamber. I think the date was 20 April.
—It was on the mass media, unfortunately.

—Anyway, put that aside. That is the reason why I am addressing this matter. To say that sometimes a party vote has been used misrepresents the situation in so far as there are clearly issues; one that comes to mind was the reference of the former Premier of Western Australia, Brian Burke, to the committee and quite obviously the Liberal Party had a united view on it. We did not have to caucus in any way at all to see that as a matter of such gravity that it should be referred.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to the substance of the motion before this us this morning. I have no disagreement at all that we have a prima facie case here for the Senate to investigate. Certain allegations were made about travel allowances. One senator submitted an explanation. A staff member of that senator submitted a corroborating statement. Some time later a statement which was in conflict with the corroborating statement was submitted by the staff member. Clearly, there is a conflict of evidence put before the Senate. Both parties cannot be right, or the same person cannot be right on two separate occasions. So we certainly have to determine where the truth lies in this matter.

BREAK.PARA: It is hard to have a matter of graver importance to the parliament than the veracity of witnesses and evidence given to it. We accept in committees when we are holding public hearings that, even if a witness is not sworn on a Bible or takes an oath of affirmation, the evidence they give is the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth. The Parliamentary Privileges Act reflects that.

We similarly demand of ministers that they tell the truth. In fact, we go further than that. The parliament would be unworkable if ministers in question time had a licence to fabricate the truth. As Senator Faulkner knows very well, they do tell the truth. What they do not do is tell the whole truth. They tell a small amount of the truth. But again, they are very cautious not to mislead. The practice before the Senate is that people do not mislead, and that is a much wider ambit than the charge of lying, of telling falsehoods. That illustrates the gravity with which the Senate takes the matter of truth before it. So there is no argument at all that we have a prima facie case here of contempt before the Senate, and that is a matter which must be investigated.

The question which the Senate is wrestling with at the moment is the matter of timing. I have two concerns about this. My primary concern, and the concern which overwhelms everything else, is the fact that investigations are now under way on a matter of criminal action. That is a very grave charge. It is quite different as to whether a minister has made a misleading statement to the parliament. It is quite different to evidence being given to a committee. We are dealing here with criminal matters. I believe in the separation of powers. I do not believe that the parliament is the court and the judiciary. I think that we make the laws. It is for other bodies to investigate the application. When we move beyond civil actions into criminal actions then we have to approach our interference at that point with a great deal of gravity.

The second point is the matter of the perversion of justice. Since it is not our primary objective to be a court, then the actions of the Senate must be very carefully judged so that we do not pervert the course of justice. That is my primary concern.

My secondary concern relates to the politics of the situation. No-one in this chamber today would claim that this was not an intensely partisan political exercise. I have grave doubts about the outcome because of the emotionalism that surrounds the matter in the run-up to the legal proceedings.

I am certainly not known as a rabid, partisan political dogfighter. My credentials, I would hope, as a Liberal are beyond dispute. I do not have to defend my political philosophy. I do not become involved in the more passionate and mindless debates on matters of political dogma. But I am very concerned about the way the politics of this are being handled.

The statement of Mr Crean at the weekend where he was clearly pursuing Senator Hill and Senator Alston as a primary objective of a privileges inquiry is clearly a statement of political intent. It is not a question of determining the justice of the situation or the truth of the matter in any way at all; it is a witch‐hunt. I accept unreservedly that Senator Hill and Senator Alston acted with complete probity in this matter. While I admire Senator Ray immensely—I think he is worth the rest of the Labor Party put together with respect to his political skills and his stature as a parliamentarian—Senator Ray's initial attack on Senator Colston was clearly a partisan political attack of a magnitude that I have never seen in nearly 20 years in this chamber. I have never seen a person attacked with the ferocity with which Senator Ray went for him.

I find it impossible to believe that Senator Ray is not speaking alone on that, that his views are not shared by the rest of the Labor Party. Whether he is chairing the committee or sitting on the sidelines to me is irrelevant. So I have very grave fears about the objectivity of an inquiry.

I have to say, from my own side, that, if it went to an inquiry, I would be very surprised if it could be confined to the terms of reference and not turn into a political dogfight, which would lead us nowhere at all. Quite clearly, the Liberal Party would want to know the truth about the allegations we have seen about all the years of the Labor administration. We have had evidence, which has never been refuted, that the head of the Department of Administrative Services advised a minister of the Labor government that police inquiries should have been instituted and that that advice was overruled. We saw the allegations when two staff members—I think in 1992 and 1994—wrote to the Department of Administrative Services complaining about irregularities in the way Senator Colston made some claims on the department, and those complaints were squashed.

It would be a matter of concern for the Liberal Party to check those things out. So I do not see that there is very much chance that, in the present climate, you can proceed with an impartial inquiry restricted entirely to the matter as to which of those two parties I was referring to at the outset misled the Senate. That is not a political matter. That is a matter of fact that we have to determine. It is a matter of contempt of the Senate.

I would like, in public, to put a hypothetical case for the Senate to consider. If Senator Colston, as a consequence of these police inquiries, is charged and if he is convicted, then it follows logically that the ministers of the former Labor government—Beazley, Evans, Bolkus and Walker—should also have their day in court under section 44 of the Crimes Act because they would have a case to answer that they conspired in a defrauding of the Commonwealth.

Having reviewed the whole matter, I think our primary concern is the administration of justice within this chamber. I think that you must come to the conclusion, at the end of the day, that the criminal proceedings must proceed, and proceed in a fair and impartial manner without any perversion from partisan politics in the Senate today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of comments, mainly because Senator Ferguson misrepresented Senator Murray's comments on the matter of transparency. Senator Ferguson spent a great deal of his contribution focusing on the transparency of past actions and heavily emphasising what he sees as the failure of previous Labor ministers to be honest about the advice they were given by bureaucrats and to act on that advice.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ferguson was critical of Senator Murray's comments which linked the leadership of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) with the failure of the House of Representatives to take action to table information on their own entitlements. That is what Senator Murray said. He said that it is wrong to insist on transparency in one house of parliament and to avoid the issue in the other.

The Independent member for Calare (Mr Andren) has asked for that information to be tabled and the Senate has sent a request that the House of Representatives table the same summaries of travel allowances, dates and moneys paid in the way it has been tabled and is tabled annually here in the Senate. But the House of Representatives, for obvious reasons, has declined to answer that request. I think that is wrong. It is not only senators who have these entitlements, it is not only senators who carry out their duties to their constituents according to the guidelines set down, and it should not only be senators who are scrutinised, to the exclusion of other members of parliament. That is the point Senator Murray was making. He was simply saying that he would have thought the Prime Minister may have shown some leadership by requiring the House of Representatives to table the same information.

Of course, you could put another construction on it, and I will do that. I actually think it is part of the longer term coalition agenda to wallow a little in the odium that is attached to the Senate at the moment via Senator Colston because of what we have seen revealed in the past few days about desires to change the Senate voting system. I do not know how Australians feel about this, but I cannot bear the way in which the sides have changed over, the faces are different, but the script is the same. When you are in government and you do not like the scrutiny of the house of review, you want to change it; you want to change the rules, you want to go back to the days when the Senate was a rubber stamp.

BREAK.PARA: I think the politics of this are very interesting. The focus on the Senate exclusively, while we might all protest about it, actually serves a more devious political purpose for this coalition government in its longer term anti‐Senate campaign, and I want to take a moment to draw attention to that.

Not much has been said by government speakers about the legal advice, and that is why I want to look at Senator Murray's amendment. The Australian Democrats want to give no comfort at all to Senator Colston and no way at all in which he can avoid the scrutiny of the Privileges Committee about his actions and the actions of Mrs Christine Smith. But it is the same situation that we face here on many occasions. We have some legal advice proffered by the opposition and we have competing legal advice proffered by the government.

I have only been here seven years, but my experience is that legal advice proffered by governments is very often written to the government's brief. That is why I think it is much better to give the Privileges Committee the opportunity to take both those pieces of advice and get some other advice on whether their actions in instigating a committee inquiry there and then prejudice further action.

That is all Senator Murray's amendment seeks to do. It says that by all means we want the Privileges Committee to get on with this matter, but let us make sure that we first assess the potential risk that such an inquiry may present to any legal proceedings and let the committee recommend whether the inquiry should proceed and bring it back to the Senate by 29 May.

The point in that is, I think, that it is a much better motion than the motion foreshadowed by Senator Hill which, as other speakers have said, is a great way of taking us to the next election, perhaps in the hope that you may get Senator Colston's vote back in the meantime. It is unacceptable, if you are serious about the reputation and the integrity of the Senate, to say that we cannot do anything about looking into the misleading of the Senate until the end of all consequent court action. If Senator Colston were to be charged and were to be found guilty and were to appeal, you can be certain this would take us beyond the next election date, and that is totally unacceptable.

I would just conclude by saying that, while we wish to proceed to the Privileges Committee inquiry, we must make sure that we do not act in such haste that we actually do not jeopardise ways by which Senator Colston is saved from the consequences of his actions. It is better to have a couple of extra weeks now, give the Privileges Committee the opportunity to get the range of advice, bring it back to the Senate and act on that. I am sorry there is a bit of a delay because I know the Australian people want us to get on with this, but we must make sure we do not cut off our nose to spite our face. I think that is really important. No extra protection, just a little certainty on the basis on which we are proceeding. That is why the Democrats have moved this amendment, although we have great sympathy with the opposition motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, you have quite properly, I believe, given precedence to a matter of privilege. This clearly is a matter of privilege on the face of it, as has been acknowledged around this chamber. There is a prima facie case for the matter to be referred to the Privileges Committee. I think around the chamber there is agreement as to what the next question is: when should this be dealt with by the Privileges Committee? That is the issue that we have before us today, I believe. The motion itself would enable the matter to continue immediately and to be dealt with by the Privileges Committee. The motion assumes that the Privileges Committee will meet immediately to deal with the matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Incidentally, I am just wondering whether the movers of the motion have considered whether or not at this particular stage it would be sensitive to involve Mrs Smith, from whom we have a letter, in the painful job, I suppose, of appearing before the Privileges Committee, because I assume that Mrs Smith will be requested to appear before the Privileges Committee. I am not in the position to know whether or not she would wish this matter to be before the Privileges Committee or not. But that is an aside.

What Senator Murray has proposed to us is that the Privileges Committee not commence its inquiries until the committee has presented a report to the Senate, firstly, assessing the potential risk that such an inquiry may present to any legal proceedings arising out of matters in relation to Senator Colston currently being investigated by the Australian Federal Police and, secondly, recommending that the inquiry should report, and until the Senate has made a determination in relation to the recommendation.

In regard to the original motion of Senator Bolkus and Senator Margetts, if it is referred to the Senate Privileges Committee, the Privileges Committee could deal with it straightaway. It is not an overworked committee by any means. There have been only three references to the committee over the last 12 months and they were fairly simple types of references, so it is not a very hard worked committee, although the chairman of the committee is entitled to $8,293 per annum for being chairman of that committee, plus superannuation on top of that. It would be interesting to see what that works out at as an hourly rate, just as an aside.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're a cynic, Senator Harradine.

—Oh no, I think the Privileges Committee is an important committee. But I am just making the point that it is not a dreadfully overworked committee and I assume the chairman of the committee is not a dreadfully overworked person. For the few hours that he puts in he does get 8,293 bucks, plus superannuation on top of it. But there again I hear that Senator Ray is going to stand down for this particular inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to Senator Murray's proposal. It would be an attractive proposition, if it were not a fact that we are in a highly charged political environment—a matter raised by Senator MacGibbon. This is what worries me about this whole issue. The parliament should not set itself up as the prosecutor, judge and jury on the issue of Senator Colston. I do not believe that would be regarded very well by the public.

BREAK.PARA: This matter has been referred to the Australian Federal Police for thorough investigation and action. It is my view, and has been for some considerable time, that the question of illegality which has been raised is of such importance that it ought to be dealt with, and dealt with by the application of judicial principles. To refer this matter to the committee, to see whether dealing with it by the Privileges Committee would involve a potential risk that the AFP inquiries may be jeopardised, is not going to get you anywhere, because, I assume, the government is not going to change its views on the advice that it has been given. It is only going to mean further time wasted by this chamber on this matter.

In any other circumstances, I would feel that the matter ought to proceed immediately to the Privileges Committee. On this occasion, justice demands that the procedures take their course. That is how I view this matter. That is how the matter would be dealt with if the person who had allegedly committed offences were simply a member of the public. I agree that the matter has got to be dealt with by the Privileges Committee at some stage, but the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) has indicated that the Privileges Committee not commence its inquiries into this matter until a statement is provided, in accordance with paragraph 2, indicating that the AFP investigations of payments made to Senator Colston and any legal proceedings consequent on those investigations have been concluded. The question of how long that will take has been raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may take forever.

—It has been suggested that it might take forever. I assume that people have got more respect for the efficiency of the Australian Federal Police, particularly as they will be under the spotlight on this matter. I believe that they will certainly not be dilatory in pressing the issues. That is where the matter ought to be.

BREAK.PARA: If we continue to deal with this matter, it is only going to exacerbate the situation we have at the moment. That situation is an atmosphere of hatred around this place, the like of which I have not seen in all the time I have been in this chamber. It is that which concerns me most of all. The vitriol that has been engendered as a result of this situation has to be heard to be believed. Indeed, it is very hard to believe that there should be such vitriol and hatred. That hatred is eating into the soul of this chamber and of everyone in it. The best way to deal with that is to put the matter into the independent hands of the Federal Police, for them to act with all due diligence to ensure that the matter is properly resolved. I defy anyone to deny that you can actually feel the hatred that is around this place at present. This matter ought to be out of the political arena, and determined in accordance with the legal principles of justice.

Whether or not at some stage Senator Colston may believe that, in order to assist in settling down this place, he ought to ask for leave pending the outcome of any charges that may be laid, that is presumably up to him—or to us. That is a slightly different question from the one currently before us. But sending it to the Privileges Committee is not going to advance the cause of this chamber one iota at this time, while the matter is being dealt with by the AFP. Therefore, Madam President, I will be supporting Senator Hill's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Let me commence my contribution in reply by reminding the Senate of what has been moved. The motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges:

Whether statements by Senator Colston and Mrs C Smith, relating to payments of travelling allowances to Senator Colston, tabled in the Senate on 24 March and 6 May 1997, were false or misleading in any particular, and, if so, whether a contempt of the Senate was committed by the making of those statements.

That and only that is the matter that I propose be referred to the Privileges Committee. We have heard a lot of paranoia today from some members of the government, including from, for example, Senator Ferguson who used the words, `Senator Faulkner's attempt to expand the inquiry.' This is a matter before the Senate. I have actually offered the govern ment and other party leaders the opportunity to meet together around the table to work out the terms of reference and the parameters of such a privileges inquiry.

If the government had genuine concerns—and, of course, the government has depended on the advice of the Chief General Counsel of the Attorney‐General's Department, Mr Burmester—why did they not agree to sit down with other parties in the chamber and work these issues through? The truth of the matter is that the opposition, for its part, does not want to extend or expand the Privileges Committee inquiry. It is also true—and I am not going to be dishonest with anyone in this chamber—that the opposition has a range of other issues that it wants to see progressed. We do, and we intend to continue to progress those at the appropriate time and in the appropriate forum. That might go to the issue of the nature of the deal that was done between Senator Colston and the Howard government. We want to know what the parameters—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. Again an opposition senator who claims to care about the way in which this place is regarded by the people of Australia and claims to want to lift the standards will not uphold the standards, as he should be doing, in the standing orders. I refer particularly to standing order 193(3) which states that imputations of improper motives and personal reflections on members of this house or any house are out of order. I would ask you to rule that Senator Faulkner should withdraw those remarks that make an improper imputation of improper motives and that he should keep his remarks within the standing orders if he truly respects the institution of the Senate and the rules that all senators have agreed to.

—I think it is a standing order that is very important, but this morning there have been a number of matters put in a similar fashion about groups around the chamber. I think Senator Faulkner would be aware that he needs to be cautious how he expresses himself. But in this debate it has been one of the features that people have referred to others as groups and referred to the motives of each of them.

—Thank you, Madam President. Can I continue. The issue of the deal that was done by Mr Howard with Senator Colston is of the utmost importance to us. I think it is important to place again on record the fact—

—Madam President, I refer you again to standing order 193(3). Are you ruling that it is within your interpretation of that standing order in this debate that an improper motive can be attributed to a member of the other House, specifically the member for Bennelong and Prime Minister of Australia? Are you ruling that that is in order during this debate and that we will ignore standing order 193(3) for the purposes of this debate?

—I am listening particularly carefully to the way this argument is being developed and the way that the Prime Minister is being referred to. Senator Faulkner would need to be most cautious about how he refers to him and the language he uses in doing so.

—These arrangements are going to be progressed and investigated by the opposition. We will not be backing away from that at all. Senator Harradine has said that there is a lot of hatred around the chamber at the moment. I think that is probably true to the extent that there is probably a little more hatred around than there has been during the short time that I have been a member of the Senate. I think you need to ask yourself why that is the case, Senator Harradine.
—Because you have come.

—It may be because I have come as Senator Patterson suggests. I have been here since 1989. I think the point that Senator Harradine is making is that he thinks that it is far more intense than it has been since my arrival in 1989. I suggest to you that the reason for that is the consequences of Senator Colston's defection from the Labor Party, his promotion and elevation to the position of Deputy President of the Senate by the government and the arrangements that were come to as a result of that process.

SPEECH.PARA: The consequences of the elevation of Senator Colston to the deputy presidency of the Senate have been enormous in terms of public policy in this country. Perhaps the best example is the partial privatisation of Telstra which would not have occurred unless these arrangements were come to and unless such a deal was done. Senator Harradine may well reflect on those consequences in relation to so many pieces of legislation that have been dealt with by this Senate and what might have occurred if the Howard government had not promoted Senator Colston to this position.

We will progress the issue of the deal. We will progress the issue of the arrangements. We will progress the issue of the role of Mr Howard's liege men in the Senate—Senator Hill and Senator Alston. We will explore their role. Finally, we will probably establish why Senator Alston was found wandering the corridors of the parliament going apparently to Senator Colston's office. We will probably find out when he went. We will probably eventually find out why he went. We will probably eventually find out whom he talked with. We might even find out what he said. It will probably take some time, Senator Harradine, but we will be working on it. I give you that commitment. We do want to know what role senior government members had in relation to Senator Colston's defence and in relation to Mrs Smith's part in preparing Senator Colston's defence.

Senator MacGibbon raised a couple of substantive points in his contribution. He raised the issue of matters that occurred between 1982 and 1984 and suggested a possible course of action. As to the Labor ministers that Senator Ferguson and Senator Hill mentioned were involved at that time—that is, Mr Beazley and Mr Gareth Evans; of course there was at least another minister involved in that, Mick Young, who has since died—both of those gentlemen have been approached by the Prime Minister and have agreed that those matters be subject to investigation by the Australian Federal Police.

BREAK.PARA: We say that the matters relating to Senator Hill and Senator Alston and their arrangements with Senator Colston should also be dealt with by the Australian Federal Police. We have not had the benefit or the courtesy of a response from Mr Howard. We asked for a confidential briefing on the matters the government was referring to the Australian Federal Police. We have not had the benefit of that response. You might also consider that, Senator Harradine, as you consider the way you vote on this particular matter.

The politics, as has been raised by other speakers in the debate, are that we know that the Howard government resisted calls for the Colston travelling claim issue to be referred to the Australian Federal Police until the eleventh hour—until it just got too hot, until the public and media pressure, the clamour from the community, the electorate, became so great. It took an awfully long time for Mr Howard to reluctantly come on board with the view of the Labor Party that the police should be called in.

We called for a full-scale police investigation in February. It was not until 8 April, when Mrs Smith actually put out her extraordinary second statement, that Mr Howard came on board. I suspect that that was not the reason at all, Madam President, because you know we have the weakest Prime Minister in this country since Sir William McMahon. He is possibly even weaker than Sir William McMahon because at least he stood up to the then Country Party. It will be very interesting to see how Mr Howard's relationship with the National Party develops.

The reason I am quite sure that Mr Howard changed his mind on an AFP referral is that 85 per cent of the Australian public supported a referral to the Australian Federal Police. You might also ask yourself, Madam President: why wouldn't Mr Howard come on board with the opposition's calls for the resignation of Senator Colston from the deputy presidency of the Senate? Again we called for that in January, February and March of this year. We called for it in April of this year. It only again was at the last gasp when Mr Howard came on board.

Mr Howard tolerated Senator Colston as Deputy President of the Senate far longer than the Australian community was willing to tolerate him. Mr Howard still tolerates Senator Colston's presence in this chamber. The Labor Party again wants him out. Even Mr Howard, weak and wimpy as he is, could join the opposition and demand of Senator Colston that he resign as a senator.

While we are at it, perhaps in other forums we might care to progress the issue of Mr Howard's involvement in the upgrade of Senator Colston's staffer before the vote on Telstra. We might continue to progress those issues. As Senator Hill and others in this chamber start to think about the sliding of the government's standing in the published public opinion polls, perhaps it is because of the approach of our parliamentary institution to parliamentary standards that the hypocrisy of Mr Howard—who did come to office with a solemn promise to do something about lifting the standards in the parliament and who did say he would do something about lifting standards of not only parliamentary behaviour but also individual parliamentarians—has been exposed.

Perhaps this has been responsible for what has occurred in relation to the very significant diminution in his own public standing. I suspect that until he has the courage and the capacity to stand up and be counted on some of these issues, to actually show some leadership in the best interests of the parliament—but, more importantly, in the best interests of the Australian community and the confidence that community has in our parliamentary institutions—it won't change.

Here is an opportunity for Mr Howard to do that right now. Here is an opportunity before us in the Senate for Mr Howard to start to rebuild confidence in the parliament, to rebuild the damage to this institution, to rebuild the standing of the Senate and of senators in the eyes of the community, which is at an all‐time low.

Mr Howard rode into office on a white charger, saying, `I'll do something about the parliament. I'll fix the standards in the parliament; you can rely on me.' He has presided over the standing and the standards of this parliament being at the lowest level we have seen since federation. That is the achievement of this weak and wimpy Liberal Prime Minister. Today, he has got another opportunity. Today, with this Privileges Committee reference—even with the caveat that I accept is a majority view in the chamber, that is embraced by the amendment proposed by Senator Murray—we do not have to cop the Liberal Party cover‐up on this Privileges Committee inquiry.

What the Liberals say is this: `We don't just want a Privileges Committee inquiry after the police inquiry, after the Australian Federal Police have investigated Senator Colston's travelling claims rorts and reported on them. Oh no; we want to see a Senate Privileges Committee inquiry after a court case, if there is any. We want to see a Senate Privileges Committee inquiry only after a court case, if there is any, and a sentence, if there is any, or after an appeal, if there is any.'

What Mr Howard is really saying is that they only want to see the Senate Privileges Committee deal with this matter after the next election. That is what they are really on about. They want to cover this up. They are probably ashamed of their role. They are probably ashamed of the behaviour of Senator Hill and Senator Alston, as Mr Howard's agents in this matter.

In fact, it is very interesting that Senator Alston has not come into the chamber to participate in this debate. I well recall Senator Alston's contribution to the debate, which I am sure he will be reminded of from time to time—not by members of the opposition but probably by journalists and others in the media—when you, Madam President, brought down your report containing statements from Senator Colston and Mrs Smith. I expect that even Senator Alston, thick‐skinned as he is, is probably ashamed of what he said.

But it is proper, given the consequences of the direction of public policy in this country, given what has occurred in the Senate in relation to legislation, given the impact that has had on the lives of ordinary Australians, that the Labor Party takes this matter seriously. We will do so, and we intend, in other fora, to continue to explore Senator Hill's and Senator Alston's roles.

I make the point that we are not proposing to do that through the Privileges Committee. We have proposed tight terms of reference. We have proposed mechanisms such as the support and advice of an officer from the Attorney‐General's Department to assist us in this. We will consider any reasonable request to ensure that the Senate Privileges Committee does not in any way trespass in the areas that would be subject to police investigation. We do not want to do that. I think the motion in this form absolutely rules it out.

But if you genuinely believe there is a problem, surely you would have adopted at least one of the possible solutions that I put forward, such as briefings, such as meetings to have agreed terms of reference, such as agreeing to have advice to the Privileges Committee from an officer of the Attorney‐General's Department. I have more confidence in the members of the Senate Privileges Committee—on which the government has a majority, I might say—than, clearly, the government does. I think it is sensible enough to be able to work these matters through.

The opposition is in no way going to be any part of a cover‐up. You stand exposed again for not doing anything at all to stop a proper inquiry into matters that can only be dealt with by the Senate Privileges Committee. It is only the Senate that can deal with the matter of whether the Senate has been misled. It is only the Senate that will deal with the issue of whether there has been a contempt of the Senate. It is for that reason that this motion should be passed by the Senate, the government's amendment should be rejected and we start to do something serious about rebuilding community confidence in the parliament. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Murray's ) be agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Jacinta Collins did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

BREAK.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.
Amendment (by Senator Hill) put:
At the end of the motion, add:

(2) That the Committee of Privileges not commence its inquiry into this matter until a statement is provided in accordance with paragraph (3), indicating that Australian Federal Police investigations of payments made to Senator Colston, and any legal proceedings consequent on those investigations, have been concluded.

(3) That, for the purpose of paragraph (2), the Attorney-General provide to the President, as soon as possible after the conclusion of such investigations and any such legal proceedings, a statement indicating that such investigations and any such legal proceedings have concluded, and the President immediately provide that statement to the Committee of Privileges.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Hill's ) be agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Jacinta Collins did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

BREAK.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Faulkner's ), as amended, be agreed to.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

(b) the routine of business shall be:

(ii) Motions to take note of answers
(iii) Petitions
(iv) Notices of motion
(v) Postponement and rearrangement of business
(iv) Notices of motion
(v) Postponement and rearrangement of business
(vi) Formal motions—discovery of formal business

PROCTEXT.PARA: (vii) Any proposal to debate a matter of public importance or urgency
(viii) Government business

PARA.TAB: (ix) At 7.30 p.m., Budget statement and documents 1997‐98
(x) Adjournment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (2) That on Thursday, 15 May 1997:
(a) the hours of meeting shall be 9.30 a.m. to 6 p.m. and 7.30 p.m. to adjournment; and
(b) the routine of business shall be:

PARA.TAB: (i) Petitions
(ii) Notices of motion
(iii) Postponement and rearrangement of business
(iv) Formal motions—discovery of formal business
(v) Consideration of committee reports under standing order 62 (3)
(vi) Government business

PROCTEXT.PARA: (vii) At 2 p.m., questions
(viii) Motions to take note of answers

PARA.TAB: (ix) Any proposal to debate a matter of public importance or urgency
(x) Not later than 4.30 p.m., general business,
(xi) Consideration of committee reports and government responses under standing order 62

PROCTEXT.PARA: (xii) At 7.30 p.m., Budget statement and documents 1997‐98—party leaders to make responses to the statement and documents

(3) That the question for the adjournment of the Senate on 13 May and 15 May 1997 not be proposed until a motion for the adjournment is moved by a minister.

TITLE.XREF: SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS SURCHARGE (ASSESSMENT AND COLLECTION) BILL 1997

BREAK.XREF: TERMINATION PAYMENTS SURCHARGE (ASSESSMENT AND COLLECTION) BILL 1997
SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS SURCHARGE (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1997
SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS SURCHARGE (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH—REDUCTION OF BENEFITS) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 6 May.

PARA.XREF: SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS SURCHARGE (ASSESSMENT AND COLLECTION) BILL 1997

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge (Assessment and Collection) Bill 1997 as a whole.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek clarification from Senator Kemp as to when we can expect the amendment that is currently being prepared between the Democrats and the government on the issue of excluding lower and middle income earners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, this is a very important amendment. The Democrats are very keen to proceed with an amendment along these lines. I do not seek to speak for the Democrats—Senator Allison may wish to make some comments—but it is a very technical amendment. As a consequence, we have had to look very closely at it and get some advice to make sure that the full intention of the amendment is fulfilled.

SPEECH.PARA: At this moment that amendment has been drafted, and we would be keen to give you a copy, Senator. It is a Democrat amendment, and I am sure they would be happy to give you a copy as soon as it is ready, in a form which will perhaps meet the intention of the Democrats, be workable and be one that the government is prepared to accept.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps Senator Allison can enlighten us, because it is a very important issue. On that, I do agree with Senator Kemp. But time is marching on. We are not halfway through this surcharge package of bills yet and it is important for the Labor opposition to know that the exemption of lower and middle income earners is going to occur. Will we get a copy of the amendment by the end of the lunch break perhaps at 2 o'clock? We do need to have a look at this very closely indeed. I appreciate, Senator Kemp, that the government needs to. So perhaps Senator Allison could give us some indication whether it is going to be available by lunchtime or is it going to be available by dinner time, because time is marching on, as I say.

—As I understand it, the department officers are looking at that amendment right now. There are some complexities that they still need a little more time to resolve. So, from our point of view, we are ready to have that amendment circulated as soon as it gets the okay and the final wording is agreed. It might be useful, Madam Chair, to perhaps move on to other parts of the legislation while we wait for that amendment.

—Senator Sherry, according to the running sheet that I have, your amendments 22 and 25 have to be moved, and amendments 27, 46, 50 and 51 remain to be moved in groups of 22, 23 and 50 together, then 24, then 25 and then 27.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendments 22, 23 and 50 deal with what is termed `vesting issues'. I certainly hope we do get a copy of that amendment by the lunch break, because it would give the Labor opposition—and, I am sure, the Greens and Senator Harradine, who are also vitally concerned about that issue of exclusion of lower and middle income earners from the new tax—an opportunity to look at that amendment in some detail. We do need to get some advice about the effect of it to ensure the stated intentions are met.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to move amendments 22, 23 and 50 together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (22) Clause 16, page 29 (line 26), after "debit.", insert "where the employer funded component of the benefit is more than 5% less than the notional employer benefit, the payment is to be reduced in proportion to the difference between the employer funded component and the notional employer benefit".
(23) Clause 16, page 20 (after line 27), after subclause (6), insert:
Note: For notional employer benefit see section 43.
(50) Clause 43, page 47 (after line 8), after the definition of member, insert:

PARA.TAB: notional employer benefit is an amount determined by a provider in respect of a superannuation (defined benefits) scheme when a benefit becomes payable, in accordance with a formula established for the purpose by an eligible actuary and normally involving salary and years of service. The notional employer benefit ascribes the value of the employer funded benefit implied by the surcharge liability against the actual employment history of the member.

TALK.START.PARA: —This goes to another very important aspect of the legislation that we are considering today, namely, the issue of vesting. There are many superannuation schemes in this country that have an arrangement known as vesting. When a benefit vests, it increases in size quite dramatically. However, once a benefit has vested until retirement age, it is actually quite difficult to access the money. If individuals do not take their superannuation benefit prior to it vesting, the benefit may in fact be substantially less than it would otherwise have been.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been raised with Labor that many members of the Commonwealth Public Service employee schemes, for example, may find themselves in this situation, particularly in situations of early retirement or redundancy. Certainly, Senator Harradine and Senator Lundy have raised aspects of this issue earlier.

I might just say as an important side issue on this matter that we touched in part on the problems that face armed services personnel with respect to retention bonuses, but they also face some problems in regard to the two military personnel funds—the pre‐1991 and the post‐1991 funds. I think 1991 was the date of the new military personnel fund.

They face a peculiar set of problems with members who were in the old fund, because of the foreshadowed massive redundancies that are to occur in the armed services. And that is an issue that Labor is very concerned about. We have had numerous representations about this issue. It is not an issue that we can deal with in this package of legislation before us today, but is a matter that, in the context of widespread redundancies that are to occur in the military and of the very special nature of their two funds, we will be seeking to address as soon as possible at some future date.

I might say in the same context that military personnel alerted us to the particular problem of retention bonuses being included as part of income. That issue has unfortunately not been excluded from a definition of income, but that was an issue that we lost yesterday due to the failure of the government to accept our amendment in that area. But it is a broader issue that affects and is worrying a great many members of superannuation funds and, in particular, Commonwealth public sector employees.

The surcharge unfairly applies to these people, due to the notional surcharge contributions factor. Their surcharge debt will have been calculated on the basis of that amount of money remaining in the fund. Thus, if they take the money prior to it vesting, the surcharge debt will apply to money that they have never received.

On this basis, Labor has introduced the concept of the member's benefit being reduced in accordance with their actual employment history. This is a measure that we believe the government should have moved itself. As has been the case continually with this bill, the government is either relying on the opposition to address these fundamental concerns being raised by many members in the community or, in fact, getting so pilloried and criticised about this package of bills it finally has had to do something about the particular errors that are highlighted, and this further exemplifies the general problems that have surrounded the preparation of this legislation over the last seven or eight months since the budget announcement last year.

Very little thought was given to the detailed, complex requirements to introduce and implement the government's new surcharge tax. Unfortunately, not a lot of notice has been taken of many of the very positive suggestions that have come from a range of very knowledgeable people who do understand the dramatic consequences of this legislation as it applies to particular groups of workers.

Despite the continual assertion—we believe an incorrect assertion—and claim that this legislation is fair, the general approach of the government is that this measure really does have little to do with equity considerations. We believe the government has been driven overwhelmingly by the need to raise revenue and institute a new tax.

The three amendments we are considering simply ensure that the government is consistent with the position that it announced in the budget on 20 August 1996—namely, to increase equity in superannuation. These amendments are important. They should be approved by the Senate. I am disappointed that the Australian Democrats have foreshadowed they are not supporting these three amendments relating to vesting issues. I do not want to unfairly quote Senator Allison, but she has foreshadowed that general approach in all areas except for three critical areas, and this is not one of them, unfortunately.

Labor does see it is incumbent on the Senate where there is a problem that is highlighted by superannuation fund members and their representatives to at least try to address some of the significant consequences that we are advised will occur that will be to the detriment of significant groups of employees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to respond to comments made by Senator Sherry in relation to his amendments Nos 22, 23 and 50 which deal with vesting issues. Senator Sherry made a number of general comments which I will deal with first.

SPEECH.PARA: A great deal of thought has been given to the implementation of the surcharge. I suspect there have been very few bills which have gone through this chamber in which more effort has been made to consult with interested groups—and I have been involved in some of those—to ensure that the particular concerns of interest groups are taken on board. This does not mean, of course, that the particular groups welcome the surcharge. I am not asserting that at all. I am asserting that, once the concept of the 15 per cent surcharge on high income earners was accepted, again, it is difficult to get a precise handle on the Labor position.

BREAK.PARA: My understanding of Mr Beazley's comments was that the Labor Party supported the 15 per cent superannuation surcharge; certainly former Minister for Finance Senator Walsh said it was a great pity that the Labor Party had not introduced such a measure itself. So it is not surprising that groups who see themselves affected by the surcharge would not be happy. I do not think anyone ever expects anyone who has a surcharge imposed on some particular aspect of their income or superannuation would be happy, but we are about fairness and this surcharge is about fairness.

Once having adopted that position, we then set out and worked with groups involved in the industry to let them list their concerns so that we could work through those lists. So your statement about a lack of consultation is just plain dead wrong. It is not accurate. I believe that the government, through the officers of the department, has been particularly assiduous in addressing issues which have been brought to the government's attention.

The amendments that Senator Sherry has moved, again, reflect the problem of the Labor Party's approach. Amendments to tax acts and superannuation acts are inevitably very complex and require a great deal of working through to make sure they are consistent, they fulfil the intention of the amendment and they do not cause problems in relation to the overall workings of the bill.

Regrettably, once again, the amendments that Labor has moved—and which were done without any consultation with us, I might say—are very vague and complex. They bring in new concepts, concepts which have not been tested before. People would not know how they will work. They bring in the concept of the employer funded component and the notional employer benefit. The notional employer benefit is not an actuarial concept. What are the guidelines that Senator Sherry is proposing for identifying this amount?

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us your guidelines.
—Senator Sherry says, `We want you to develop the guidelines.'
—No, no, I said, `Give us your guidelines.'

—I will come to the guidelines. What I am saying is that we can address this issue but it would not be addressed in the context of the amendment which you have moved, Senator. Again, your amendment is poorly drafted and, frankly, it is unclear as to precisely what is intended. The important point is that the advice we have received from the Australian Government Actuary is that vesting issues will be dealt with within the guidelines relating to the notional surcharge contributions factor. We believe that those guidelines will deal effectively with this issue which you have raised.

BREAK.PARA: We are aware of the concerns. The Government Actuary is aware of the concerns. It will be dealt with within the guidelines which will be established. Senator, we do not ignore the problem. We are aware of the problem. Your amendments, on my advice, will not answer the problem—they will add further complexity to the act. Therefore, it is our position that we cannot support the amendments which you have moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This gets back to the incredible complexity of the operation of some of this set of bills. We are dealing with Labor amendments 22, 23 and 50. I say again that this package of superannuation bills is an atrocious way to deal with what is essentially a simple issue, that is, calling on the rich to make a fairer contribution to tax. Doing it by stomping through superannuation with jackboots is not a good way of doing things.

SPEECH.PARA: The present superannuation system, with its diversity of funds and arrangements with employers, has been framed under an immensely complex system of legislation and regulations. Superannuation issues always seem to take a long time because there is such a wealth of detail to address. It is appropriate that things are taken slowly since the diversity of schemes means there is no simple way of doing things, and almost anything the government wishes to do will have unintended consequences in other areas. This is why there is a permanent Senate Select Committee on Superannuation and why it issues frequent reports. This is why superannuation legislation is usually done with drafts and extensive industry consultation.

These bills were not done in quite this way. I will not blame it on the Australian Taxation Office. I think most of those people would have preferred solutions requiring a few lines in tax legislation. I think this is the direct result of cabinet and ministerial advisers—not departmental advisers—coming up with a bright idea of how to tax, without calling it a tax, on some dark night, after too many cups of coffee, too many sweet buns and not enough sleep. One of my staff was unkind enough to suggest other influences, but I would not suggest that. This was probably dreamed up by people who normally do not deal with superannuation. It was given the quick rubber stamp in the House and has been pushed into the Senate. It went to the superannuation committee, which reacted with horror, as anyone reading the report can pick out.

The recommendations of the committee were ignored, and the legislation was foisted on the Senate with demands that it be handled urgently. I wonder why we have not seen Senator Watson in the chamber defending the government's position on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very good question.

—I have to say that this would be a very good question for the government to answer. The person on the government backbench who has probably done the most work on, and has the most in‐depth knowledge of, superannuation issues is not here defending the government's position. Why?

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate was very compliant, perhaps too compliant. Senators did not want to be seen to be obstructive. So debate was truncated and amendments were limited to a few areas. However, the government, in its wisdom, chose to wait to debate this bill until the last hours of Wednesday before Easter, after being given several extra weeks and altered sitting hours to give it some more time for debating legislation. Because the government chose to wait until the last moment, the bill did not get dealt with, and it is a long and involved bill.

BREAK.PARA: One of the most complex and obviously unconsidered aspects of this bill is the treatment of unfunded defined benefit schemes—typical of government as an employer. It is awful to see the weight of the government's slipshod approach to this legislation falling most heavily on the public servants, whom they have done their best to make enemies. Perhaps the government attitude towards public servants has something to do with the area where this bill has inadequacies. I cannot say.

What is clear is that, in spite of various attempts by the opposition parties to rectify inadequacies pointed out in the committee report, the area of unfunded defined benefits is complex and difficult. It is very difficult to work out exactly what, in terms of the way this government has established its tax on superannuation, is taxable under this legislation and how it will be assessed.

Our understanding of this amendment is that unfunded defined benefits include an employer contribution and then various benefits that can be assessed only at the end of service, and they include factors like length of service and final salary. The question is that, since all this comes ultimately from the employer, but some of it is clearly from investment and increase of funds or its equivalent in these schemes, how is that to be taxed and at what rate, what bits are taxed when, and where are they paid? These are the issues, and there are no clear answers.

Fitting into the government's hasty legislation is trying to force a square peg into a much smaller round hole. It may be possible but not without creating a lot of distress. And guess what! The government is trying to fit a square peg into a round hole right now with an amendment. It is very difficult to get the wording, so it actually works, I imagine.

I believe the intent of the Labor amendment is simply to try to separate the benefits that accrue ultimately at the end of service from what can legitimately be considered a benefit given by the employer, which will be assessed as income for the purpose of this new income based tax. As I understand it, the amendment will try to establish that, where there is a differential of over five per cent between notional benefit and employer funded benefit, some cognisance of this will be taken in this new tax regime and the employee will not be taxed for notional income that was essentially never supplied by the employer.

I think this sounds fair enough and I move to support it. I will admit that I am not an expert in all of the implications of this. Perhaps the government would be kind enough to bring Senator Watson into the chamber to explain it on behalf of the government. That would be very useful. Also, I have not had the time to consult extensively with experts, so I am still listening to the argument. But on balance I believe will be able to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise on the issue of these amendments. I want to go back to a number of issues that have not been put forward in this forum so far. I recall numerous comments by Senator Kemp with respect to the government saying that this is an equity measure and that somehow it will increase fairness amongst Australians in their earning capacity, it being a tax on the rich. I would like to raise the issue of the very people whom this government claims to represent. Government members

SPEECH.PARA: quite often use the word `battler'. They use it in the context of trying to redefine their own constituency in desperate attempts to pick up support from various groups in our community.

One group in particular that is targeted and that has long been associated with the word `battler' is the blue collar or physical grades type industries. The construction industry, the mining area and so forth all come under this category. Whilst this government claims that this is a tax on the rich, I would like to raise the issue of certain groups within those sectors who may, by virtue of the definition that is now provided for `adjustable taxable income', find themselves at certain periods falling in the category that ropes them in to this definition and therefore subjects them to the surcharge.

I do so in anticipation of Senator Kemp getting up and throwing back at the opposition what he attempted to do yesterday, in saying, `You can see the Labor Party does not support an equity measure.' But I put it to you, Senator Kemp—and I notice the smile on your face—that we have here a tax that will inequitably target groups of our community. Although some of the people whom I have mentioned may find themselves falling into the category of having earned over the $70,000 mark in one particular year, that does not make them necessarily rich. It may be a factor in the structure of their employment. I ask the government to consider this.

Let us look at some of these industries. Let us look at the mining industry. Some miners will be affected by this measure because at certain points in their career their salary packages may show that they have earned over $70,000 per annum. But it is also a fact, conveniently disregarded, that working in this type of employment not only is risky in an occupational health and safety context but also quite often results in early retirement through no other reason than the physical degradation of workers' bodies by virtue of the physical work they have performed all their lives.

The same can be said for many workers in the building and construction industry. Show me a bricklayer who is still laying bricks at 50—not that I know too many bricklayers who earn over $70,000. But by saying in a simplistic form, `This is a tax on the rich' and by broadening out your definition of adjustable taxable income, these are the battlers whom you will rope in. There are probably not a lot of them out there but I felt compelled to at least speak on their behalf because they do not live in big houses and they do not consider themselves wealthy. I am sure they are not comfortable with finding themselves, by virtue of the nature of their industry, launched in your definition of a wealthy person and therefore subject to what you call an `equity measure', which we all know is a flawed tax approach.

The other issue that is worth raising with respect to these people is the nature of their work. The particular circumstances in the last decade have seen moves to create more efficient, more productive industry. Many of the blue collar awards have been through fundamental change led initially by the Industrial Relations Commission towards productivity and efficiency to secure wage increases.

Hence it is not unrealistic that the incremental movements that have occurred in the wages of a lot of blue collar workers in this country have not come about just by magic, and certainly have not come about by the generosity of the employer; they have come about by marked and proven increases in productivity. To my experience much of that means longer hours of work, harder work and changes in work structure that may to a large degree involve factors like shift work. And shift work, as you know—although you probably do not agree—usually attracts some sort of penalty rate. If you are required to work from 10 p.m. at night to 6 a.m. in the morning you would agree that that is a fair and reasonable thing.

It is fair and reasonable to assume that a significant proportion of people for a period of their lives due to productivity increases might earn more money, but that is certainly not sustainable in their working life cycle. So why should these people be penalised in this way?

The other issue is transient work. I look particularly to the building industry in this regard. A couple of years ago surveys were done about the actual duration of employment of tradespeople and non-tradespeople in the building industry. The survey at that time showed that a labourer in the building industry, on average, could only expect to be employed for 50 per cent of the time. A tradesperson could expect to be employed for 75 per cent of the time. In each case, the workers in those industries, on average, had to expect to be unemployed between 25 per cent and 50 per cent of their time.

This is one of the arguments that was used to support the introduction of a severance or redundancy pay system in the building and construction industry. It is a legitimate argument, again, in the context of how you determine what becomes an adjustable taxable income and therefore falls under the auspices of this particular piece of legislation and the application of this new tax.

BREAK.PARA: We all know that that industry is a cyclical industry. It has booms and busts and they are pretty devastating when they occur. So, when building workers get work, they do every scrap of overtime that comes their way and they take on every job that comes their way, quite often for a couple of years at a time, knowing very well that they face maybe a year or two of unemployment until the next cyclical boom comes around in the property market, in the construction industry and so forth.

So, for that period of time, because of the cyclical nature of the industry, those building workers' incomes might get up around that area. Are they rich? What is equitable about their paying the surcharge at that point because their income happens to be up around that level at that point in their lives? What about the fact that they only earn superannuation and can only grow superannuation in their accounts when they are actually employed? So it is a double penalty. The only time they are actually getting employer contributions is when they are employed. During the period of unemployment, not only do they have no income but also their capacity to improve their superannuation is vastly diminished.

I think the nature of transient work with respect to battlers—as the government likes to call them; I would rather call them what they are, which is building workers, physical grades workers, miners and so forth—is that they are all subject to these trends in their industry and they have no control of that. They expect, unfortunately, to have periods of unemployment during their working cycle. For the most part, it is a reasonable generalisation to make to say that on occupational health and safety grounds they will not have the standard life cycle of work that, for example, workers in the white collar industry do. All these issues impact heavily on their superannuation earning capacity.

I have to say that, if it were not for the support that those workers in the industry gave to the establishment of their industry superannuation fund in the first instance, some of the groundbreaking progress that has been made for workers in transient industries would not have been made, and we would not be at this point today where building workers and other workers can stand up with pride and look towards their industry fund for a viable retirement income.

This legislation undermines their ability to secure a viable retirement income. I ask the government to take into account these factors—of transient work; of the nature of the work, including shift work; of peaks and troughs in the work life cycle of these workers; and of the fact that they generally may well have a shorter working life—in its considerations when it seeks to impose this tax upon those battlers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I think my colleague Senator Amanda Vanstone expressed it rather well when she came into the chamber, listened to Senator Lundy on these superannuation bills, and gasped with some amazement that Senator Lundy was under the impression that the Labor Party supported the concept of the 15 per cent surcharge on high income earners. As the debate has ebbed and flowed I have had my doubts from time to time, but I think the concept that the Labor Party has attempted to put out to the public arena is that it believes in the 15 per cent superannuation tax surcharge.

SPEECH.PARA: There are debates over the implementation, but there is still not one hint in any remarks that Senator Lundy has made that she even accepts the principle of the 15 per cent superannuation surcharge. There is a debate over implementation and there are complexities, but there has never been one solitary hint. Even Senator Sherry, who has ducked and weaved on this issue, has attempted to portray an impression that he supports the principle. But Senator Lundy, I must say—not uniquely—reflects a strong element in the Labor Party that is essentially opposed to the 15 per cent surcharge and would like to have it dropped entirely.

Senator, you are quite right: the Howard government is the representative of the battlers and that is the difference between our party and your party. You are the representatives of the union leaders and we are the representatives of the battlers. That is why they vote for us and do not vote for you. One of the symbolic reasons you have found it so hard to grapple with this issue is that you are actually opposed to the surcharge on high income earners. Battlers are not opposed to the surcharge on high income earners, because battlers will not be paying the surcharge.

In that way your remarks express the dilemma of the Keating Labor Party, in my view—that it is a party far removed from its traditional base. Even on equity matters such as this, I do not believe that any other Labor Party pre‐Keating would have had any difficulties with this issue. But you are a part of a new party, a different party, and a party that finds it difficult to come to grips with some of these important equity issues. I will make a couple of comments on the substance of what you said.

What I think you were really concerned about is whether the threshold was at the right level and whether there should be averaging. Senator Sherry, on your behalf, has essentially signed onto the $70,000 threshold. Senator Sherry has not, quite rightly, proposed amendments relating to averaging because Senator Sherry knows the complexities that such amendments would involve. The substance of your argument was that the threshold should be higher and that there should be averaging, but the Labor Party has not proposed any amendments in those areas, quite rightly. So it is passing strange that you would get up and run that line of debate.

We are cognisant that we have to look at a variety of issues in this bill. For example, we have made adjustments to taxable income. This has been done, for example, by removing for surcharge income threshold purposes things like bona fide redundancies.
Senator Lundy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lundy, you have had a good go. I was very quiet. Madam Chair, would you like to intervene?
—Order! I would like the minister to continue.

—Madam Chair, I am trying seriously to address the issues that Senator Lundy has put forward. I have made the point that the substance of the issues is that Senator Lundy thought that effectively the threshold was too low and that there should be averaging. Senator Lundy felt that some people could be caught up in the surcharge who she felt should not be caught up. I am putting out that the government has made adjustments in a number of areas—bona fide redundancies, unused leave payments, superannuation benefits paid to members, ETPs and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: We have addressed particular issues as they have emerged. We think the threshold is right. My understanding is that the Labor Party thinks the threshold is right. The Labor Party is not proposing averaging—I think correctly—because, apart from anything, it is hugely complex. These are issues which have been carefully examined.

In relation to comments made by Senator Margetts, she implied on a number of occasions that this bill has been done without any proper consultation. An implementation advisory group was established with industry associations, including bodies like LISA, ASPA and the Australian Society of CPAs. A great deal of work has been done. That is not to suggest that those groups want a 15 per cent surcharge—in fairness to them, they probably do not—but people were prepared to sit down and work through these issues and the government was very keen to ensure that the matters they raised were effectively addressed.
