So it is wrong to create the impression that somehow the government's intention, announced on budget night, was hidden from the public and that there was not enough time for proper consultation. There was a great deal of consultation, more than occurs with most bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —But there were so many mistakes.
—Senator Lundy, I reject your comments. I think you are the symbol of the new Labor, the Keating Labor Party—
—New Labor—we like that.
—You like that, do you? Senator Mackay, you have to do the work and there is no evidence—
—It worked for Tony Blair; it will work for us.

—Oh, it is going to work for you. Have you changed your name officially? I think that you have a lot of work to do to shake off the Keating legacy to your party. Let me make it absolutely clear: any Labor Party pre‐Keating would not have waited for us to bring in the 15 per cent surcharge but would have brought it in themselves, because it is about equity. Your difficulty with this issue, Senator Lundy, and maybe Senator Mackay, is the symbol of the difficulty that the Keating Labor Party has with its traditional base and equity issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to spend the same amount of time that Senator Kemp spent on general issues that do not relate to this amendment, but I do have to respond yet again to a number of comments he has made. Labor, in principle, does not oppose the concept of a 15 per cent tax.
—Supports the concept?

—Supports the concept of a 15 per cent tax on people earning more the $70,000 a year. Let us put aside the fact that you, Senator Kemp, Mr Howard and Mr Costello gave a pledge not to introduce a new tax at the last election. You gave an absolute pledge: no new taxes and no increase in existing taxes. You asserted at the last election that this was an absolute promise. And what do we have? The government's biggest revenue raising measure in the budget is a new tax that is supposed to apply to people earning more than $70,000.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Howard felt a bit nervous about calling it a tax. In the cabinet discussions we can all imagine Mr Costello saying, `We need to get some revenue, half a billion dollars, and where can we get it from? We will tax super, but we had better not call it a tax because we did give a promise at the last election that we would not introduce a new tax.' So Mr Howard is still going around the country calling it a surcharge. He is about the only one who has not called it a tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even Mr Costello has called it a tax.

—Exactly. The Treasurer, Mr Costello, has called it a tax. The Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, has called it a tax on occasion. It is called a tax in the budget papers. What you have to realise, Senator Kemp, is that there is extreme anger—including from many people in the Liberal Party and some of your own colleagues—not only about you breaking your promise but about the Prime Minister continually calling this provision a surcharge. It adds to the insult. People are upset enough about you introducing a new tax, but trying to call it a surcharge—and the Prime Minister continues to call it a surcharge—was one of the issues that led to your predecessor's demise. He was struggling with trying to justify calling a tax a surcharge. But enough has been said on that issue.

BREAK.PARA: The other fundamental concern of Labor—and we have enunciated this in this debate—is that the 360,000‐odd people who earn more than $70,000 a year were not the only people who were going to be affected by the tax. That is not Labor's assertion: the evidence provided to the select committee was that a significant number of lower and middle income earners were going to have to pay the tax. That is one of the two principles on which Labor has said very clearly, `We are going to make a stand.' We are not going to tolerate one lower or middle income earner—let alone one million—being hit by this new tax at the full 15 per cent rate. That is a fundamental principle for Labor.

To touch briefly on the averaging issue, Senator Lundy quite rightly pointed out some of the difficulties for people who earn a low or middle income one year and a high income the next. Building workers and mining workers are in that category on occasion during their employment. There are others. We have had representations from AFL footballers. In the first 10 years of their football career, they earn substantially above $70,000, but it is pretty tough for a lot of them after their football career is ended. We have had representations from people in the theatrical and the film industries. But Labor came to the conclusion that it is not our job to attempt to provide some protection for those people. We thought about it and we tried to look at an averaging concept but, like the collection mechanism, we would have to sit down and design hundreds of amendments. It is not that we do not have any sympathy for those groups in society; we do.

On the issue of consultation, Senator Kemp continues to assert that there has been extensive consultation. But the important point is not just that there has been extensive consultation; the consultation occurred after the government announced the measure—not before—and the point is there has been very little listening and acting on the advice given. I have challenged Senator Kemp time and time again. He has referred to LISA, ASFA and the CPA, who are on the implementation advisory group. The point is: were they happy about the government's response to this consultation? The fact is they were not. They were not happy about the government's response and reaction or about the amendments to the set of legislation we have before us today.

I have challenged Senator Kemp to name one individual and one group that say they are happy with the outcome of the consultation process. Senator Kemp still cannot name any. Searching to find a member of industry, he did give us the name of our leader yesterday—Mr Beazley. I did not know that Mr Beazley was from the superannuation industry, but Senator Kemp was searching to find someone who would support it—and he still cannot find someone who will.

But that is the point. There has been no satisfactory outcome and no listening. Why? Because we have a Prime Minister who insists on calling a tax a surcharge and who, in addition to that, fundamentally does not understand or has not sought to understand the concerns of the industry—and this includes everyone in the industry, from lawyers to accountants to the funds to the life insurance industry. Senator Kemp, even your great mates, the banks, have said in the conversations I have had with them on RSAs—and we will get to that later in the day—that they are astounded by this set of legislation.

It has been up to Labor to alert the so‐called battlers—those earning less than $70,000—to the fact that at least a million of them are going to be whacked by this new tax. That is the evidence we have. That is what the funds who have the members and do not have the tax file numbers advise us. We are going on evidence, not on blarney, bluff, arrogance and refusal to listen.

I will not attribute ignorance to the Treasurer, Mr Costello, nor a lack of understanding of at least some of the difficulties associated with this new tax on superannuation. In Mr Costello's case, it is sheer blind arrogance: `Don't back down, never retreat until you have to. Go through the facade of listening, but never back down.' That is the sheer arrogance of the Treasurer. It oozes out of him on this issue. Members of the Liberal Party opposite who are very upset about this package of legislation know that.

In your case, Senator Kemp, I will attribute it partly to the fact that you have only had the job for three or four months. This measure contributed in part to the demise of your predecessor, Senator Short. It does take some time to get up to speed and I sympathise with you, Senator Kemp, being dropped in the middle of this shambles—halfway through the consultation process—and having to justify the government's position. You have to answer to Mr Costello, who has been calling the shots on this. He is your boss. He says, `No compromise—do not act on legitimate industry complaints,' and you do what he says. I have some sympathy for you in that position of Assistant Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do as you're told!

—Yes, just do as you are told, Senator Kemp. I can see Mr Costello in your meetings in the office saying, `Do as you are told. We are not going to back down. All these industry groups are lackeys of the Labor Party. Just tell them it is all Senator Sherry's fault. He has been running around the country.' I have been misleading lawyers, tax accountants, actuaries, economists, superannuation funds! It is all my fault!

BREAK.PARA: Progress reported.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 1.00 to 2.00 p.m.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Senate Vacancy: Representation of Western Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, are you aware of continuing order of the Senate No. 33 of 3 June 1992 which requires a Senate vacancy to be filled as expeditiously as possible? Has the government made representations to the West Australian government to fill the vacancy caused by the death of the late Senator Panizza in accordance with that resolution? Given the fact that Senator-designate Lightfoot was pre-selected on 5 April 1997 and became eligible for a $466,000 lump sum superannuation payout on 21 April 1997, has the Premier of Western Australia proffered any reasons as to why the vacancy has not been filled? Minister, when the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Faulkner, offered a pair until the late Senator Panizza's replacement could arrive, did you anticipate this pair being in place for four months?

—I think it is fair to say that the pre-selection in Western Australia was a somewhat tortuous affair. Is that the right word? Anyway, whatever the correct word is, it has taken a little longer than we would have preferred. Yes, I do believe—and I think I supported the resolution to which you referred—that these positions should be filled as soon as possible. A candidate has been selected in Western Australia.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Senator Cook interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had trouble in the past with getting governments of your persuasion to hold the relevant sessions to get people to this place, but this one has taken a little longer than others. The Western Australian parliament must resolve to fill the casual vacancy with Mr Lightfoot. I am hopeful that will take place soon. Yes, we have had discussions with Western Australian authorities on that. We are anxious to have Mr Lightfoot here as soon as possible—
—Not all of you!

—All of us, Senator Ray; we are very much a team. I think there is a problem under the West Australian constitu tion in that his position, in effect, cannot be filled until 22 May. You may understand the intricacies of this matter better than I. But as I understand it, because candidates on his ticket at the previous election have been exhausted, his position cannot be filled until 22 May. What all this means is that I am extremely hopeful that the matter will be settled in the very near future and we will have Mr Lightfoot among us.

—I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. I certainly agree with the minister that the pre-selection process was tortuous, but I cannot agree with him when he says that he is anxious to have Senator-designate Lightfoot join him in the Senate. However, the intent of the question was to elicit what you had done about ensuring that this enormously lengthy delay was overcome and Senator-designate Lightfoot took up his position. You have not made clear what you have done to secure his appointment to the Senate or what the Court government's excuse is for failing to appoint him in accordance with past practice and the requirements of the Senate.
—I thought I had answered the latter part of the supplementary question. The problem as I understand it is that his position cannot be filled until 22 May.
—That is nonsense.

—No, his position in the Western Australian parliament cannot be filled. What have I done? I have expressed to relevant Western Australian authorities my concern on the matter and my desire to have Mr Lightfoot among us as Senator Lightfoot as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, all senators are aware that the former Labor government was a high spending, high taxing and large debt government. Will the minister explain what reforms the Howard government has made to ease the tax burden on families and businesses while at the same time working to end Labor's legacy of deficit and debt?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Gibson, for that important question. Senator Gibson was right in saying that the former Labor government was noted for high spending, high taxes, big borrowing and a big debt. Senator Gibson, you would know and some of the public would know that between 1989 and 1990 and to the year 1995-96 outlays went up from $89 billion to a whopping $132 billion, with spending growing at nearly five per cent above inflation on average each year.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator, you will know that in the last five years of the Keating government the Labor Party racked up debts. Total deficits were in the order of $70 billion, which, according to my maths, works out at about $4,000 for each man, woman and child—or persons, if you like, Senator Sherry—as a result of the massive spending program of the Keating government.

We know that the Keating government put up taxes in a whole range of areas. Wholesale sales tax rose and not a word of protest; the Keating government substantially increased petrol excises and not a word of protest from the failed ministers on the front bench. They increased the Medicare levy, the wholesale sales tax on cars, the fringe benefits tax, departure tax and a raft of taxes. That was the role of the Keating government—tax, tax and tax. After all that, despite those very substantially increased taxes, what in fact happened was that Labor left office $10 billion short of balancing the books—a major black hole which Labor refused to acknowledge in the election period.

In stark contrast, we have provided substantial tax relief and in our first budget made major progress towards eliminating the budget deficit. Our tax reforms, in contrast to Labor's tax increases, have provided relief in the following areas: the well‐known family tax initiative that will benefit some two million Australian families; a tax rebate for eligible people who have taken out private health insurance; reduction of the provisional tax uplift factor; CGT rollover relief for small business; reforms to the fringe benefit tax areas; and a tax rebate for eligible lower income aged persons.

Despite the huge deficit left to us by Labor—the huge deficit of the spend, spend, tax, tax, borrow, borrow Labor government— we have been able to address the fiscal problems which have been left to the government and, at the same time, make major strides forward in bringing in a range of tax measures which have been to the benefit of the Australian people. Just yesterday, what did the one remaining Australian Labor government left in this country do with their budget? It was taxing time again. A hotel tax was brought in, the rate of land tax has been increased and its scope widened, city car parking—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My supplementary question to the minister is: how does the current government policy of tax relief contrast with the position of the opposition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party is a party which wishes to increase taxes and, as I was saying, if anyone was in doubt you only had to see what Premier Carr did with his budget. A whole raft of new taxes have been brought in by the New South Wales government. Of course, Labor has always attempted to deceive the electorate by claiming that they would not increase taxes. In fact, they have; taxes have risen sharply.

ANSWER.PARA: As a warning to the public, it is interesting to note that the shadow treasurer—who, if people have already forgotten, is former Senator Gary Evans—is on record as believing that Australia is under taxed by what he calls relevant international standards. He thinks there is some case for having overall revenue increases. I say that as a real warning to the public that the ALP believes in more taxes. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron. I ask: which section or sections of the constitution is the government relying on for its 10‐point plan in respect of Wik?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Bolkus for the question, because it is important to understand what the 10‐point plan is about and it is obvious that Senator Bolkus needs a little bit of instruction in that regard. The Prime Minister has been consulting with all the interest groups in the community and the government released a 10‐point plan, which we believe will achieve a fair, practical and workable outcome to the uncertainties created by the Wik decision.

ANSWER.PARA: The plan is based on the non‐extinguishment of native title on pastoral leases, but meets the legitimate concerns of pastoralists for certainty while respecting the principles of native title. Broadly speaking, the plan will allow pastoralists to get on with their business, confirm that native title on freehold, residential and commercial land and on some agricultural leases is extinguished and allow the states to carry out their land management functions and facilitate development on leasehold land.

TALK.START.PARA: —My point of order, Madam President, is this: Senator Herron was asked a very specific question. He is now receiving a note from Senator Campbell. The question was: what section or sections of the constitution is the government relying on to legislate on its 10‐point plan in response to Wik? It is a very specific question. I know that Senator Herron has a prepared dorothy dix answer, but I would ask you to direct the minister to answer what even he would have to acknowledge is a very specific and simple one‐sentence question.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CAMPBELL

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, anyone who comes in here and claims that the problems caused firstly by the Native Title Act that the Keating government brought in and secondly by the High Court is a simple problem is a fool. Maybe the native title question that was asked was a dorothy dix by Senator Bolkus. Perhaps Senator Herron and Senator Bolkus did have a chat beforehand and perhaps Senator Bolkus was kind enough to ask the dorothy dixer. I doubt that.

INTERJECT.PARA: These matters are complex and it is quite ludicrous to suggest that in answering a question about native title you should have to stick to one narrow interpretation of it. It is a big issue and Senator Herron is doing exactly what he should do in answering it.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the point of order, I make the point that there is no dorothy dixer here. This is a question without notice to the minister. In terms of the 10‐point plan, a fundamental aspect of it is to actually get to understand how the government is about to implement that plan and what constitutional basis it is working on. It is something that I would have thought that any minister involved in discussions would have a very deep knowledge about. You cannot work out what you are going to do unless you know on what constitutional basis you are going to do it. As far as I am concerned, it is a fair question that goes very much to the heart of the government's Wik 10‐point plan.

—It is a quite specific question, but it covers a wide ranging area of interest in the community. I think the minister must be entitled to have some latitude in the way he comes to the point of the question.
—I think the question is: where does the Labor Party stand on the 10-point plan? What is its reaction? There is an absolute deafening silence.
—Order! Minister, the question is to you, not from you to the Labor Party. I think you should develop the answer in that way.

—Now that Senator Bolkus has had his instructions from Senator Faulkner, I suppose he will know what to do. It is obvious that the power exists and Senator Bolkus knows that, but where is the Labor Party's response? Where do they think the power has come from, because it was they who passed the Native Title Act in the first place? We opposed it, as you know.

ANSWER.PARA: I would like to know where the Labor Party stands on this because they have not issued any statement, they have not brought out anything. To say that it is all simple and pretend that it is simplicity itself—

TALK.START.PARA: —Answer the question you moron!

—I have answered the question. Senator Faulkner was not listening to what I just said. I did answer it; I said that it existed under the Native Title Act. If Senator Faulkner was not listening, then that is his problem, not mine.

ANSWER.PARA: Now that Senator Bolkus has been given the supplementary question by Senator Faulkner, I suggest that it is now time for him to get up and have another go.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister will know about this supplementary question. Minister, which section or sections of the Australian constitution is your government relying on to legislate your 10-point plan in response to Wik—which section or sections?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The same section the then government used when it passed the Native Title Act.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are not going to be many questions this question time if we continue with so many interruptions.

—My question is to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Now that the Century Zinc saga seems to be finally drawing to a close, will the minister please inform the Senate how this reflects upon the workability of the Native Title Act? Will he please outline to the Senate the cost to Australia of the last two years of negotiations on this proposal? Will he please tell the Senate how the Prime Minister's 10-point Wik plan and the previously proposed native title amendments will prevent a repetition of such unnecessary delay?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Ferris for that question. I am pleased to announce to the Senate that at long last Century Zinc has received the approval of all parties to proceed. The fact that Century Zinc is ready to go is a triumph for perseverance by the company and the local Waanyi community and yet another indictment of the previous government's Native Title Act.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order and it relates to relevance. When this minister tries to answer a question in respect of the Century Zinc mine and claims that the Native Title Act had nothing to do with it, then I think he shows once again a total ignorance of his portfolio. It was done under the Native Title Act and you should know it.
—Senator Bolkus, that is not a point of order.

—Senator Bolkus cannot hear. I said it was done under the Native Title Act, which showed how the Native Title Act was actually unworkable. I might tell Senator Bolkus that initially it was not done under the Native Title Act. Do you know why, Senator Bolkus? Because Premier Goss, the Labor Party Premier of Queensland, told the company not to use the Native Title Act. I have a copy of a letter from Premier Goss to Century Zinc advising that, if you want to see it.

ANSWER.PARA: There were two years of unnecessary delay and extraordinary high cost. What a waste of time. What an extraordinary waste of totally unproductive moneys. It meant that 3,200 direct and indirect jobs available during the construction stage of the zinc mine have been denied—an area where there are few jobs. Another 4,000-odd direct and indirect jobs in the production phase have been delayed two years.

At the end of the day, the Aboriginal communities of the gulf will receive the same $60 million package offered by the company in August 1995, when it was thought that native title over the mine had been extinguished. For two years, local and regional economies, small businesses and hundreds of Aborigines in the area who were looking for jobs have been denied the training and financial benefits from this mine all because the system failed. Australia lost badly needed export income essential to address Labor's mammoth foreign debt.

The now proven unworkability of the Native Title Act puts question marks over the vital investment we must attract domestically and from overseas to get the bank of major proposed resource projects—$55 billion worth—under way. Investors must have certainty. It is a very competitive industry investment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your legislation wouldn't have given it.
—Senator Bolkus, you are persistently interjecting. If you wish to comment on this matter, you can take note of the answer at the end of question time.

—Century Zinc has shown that, under the present system, investment certainty is not there. The implementation of the Prime Minister's 10‐point Wik plan will ensure that a farce like Century Zinc will not be repeated in Australia. The plan leaves no doubt as to the rights of all parties and prevents fringe opportunists interfering and virtually vetoing the project.

ANSWER.PARA: It is interesting that I was visited, as was my colleague Senator Herron, by the Wanyi people who represented the mine area. They were the ones who pointed out to us that the system was not working. In fact, they said that a single person who was a non-claimant could virtually, under the current system, veto the process. The plan allows pastoralists to get on with their business, while allowing indigenous people to maintain traditional access to land.

Finally, I congratulate the company officials, the leaders of the Gulf Aboriginal communities and the ATSIC members who have preserved in their commitment to this project. It will be a great relief to the Waanyi people. We can now get on with the job of establishing a mine that will bring enormous benefits to the Aborigines, small business, Queensland—and to Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can I ask Senator Parer to further explain in particular how the right to negotiate changes in the native title proposal will assist in the process?

—I think one of the important things from the mining industry point of view—and this is covered in the 10‐point plan—has been that the right to negotiate in respect of mining areas will only occur at one point, and that will be at the production phase. For those people who have any knowledge of and interest in the mining industry, they will be aware of the fact that, in the main, exploration projects are just what they are—exploration projects; and very few of them actually find a resource.
—Exploration is exploration? You could knock me over!

—Yes. I am glad to see that we have an intelligent person on the front bench. I would like to welcome you, Senator; nice to see you there. Madam President, the actual ability to negotiate at the exploration phase, the production phase, was pretty stupid really. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, can you confirm that in 1991 the now Prime Minister signed a petition which endorsed the following statement:

QUESTION.PARA: We ask you to oppose the sale of the Fairfax group to any individual or consortium that would result in a greater concentration of media ownership and thus a diminution of competition in and diversity of information sources in Australia.
In his recent public statements, has not the Prime Minister totally reversed his position on this issue? Did not the Prime Minister say on 24 April 1997 that:

If you have to have a presence in the region and a presence around the world, if you are to have a company that can in a sense be a flag waver for Australia, then you need to have a very strong domestic base.
Was not this selfsame argument totally rejected by the Wallace inquiry in the case of banks?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what the honourable senator is seeking are the Prime Minister's current views on cross-media ownership and foreign ownership matters. There is no doubt that the government supports diversity of ownership in the Australian media; the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, always has. We support foreign ownership up to the limits that are currently provided for.

ANSWER.PARA: The matter is being reviewed, particularly the former, as you know, and it has been subject to a somewhat detailed inquiry by Senator Alston. When the government has finished its consideration of the matter, no doubt a statement will be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, is it not a fact that 13 of the current 15 cabinet ministers, including Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications and the Arts, signed the 1991 petition? Given that Mr Fahey was not in the federal cabinet and apparently you were out of the country at the time—
—I read that and I do not think that is right!
—would you confirm that you were out of the country; and, if you were in the country, why did you refuse to sign it, and are you therefore out of step with the other 13 current cabinet ministers?

—It was very rare that I would be out of the country—and, regrettably, it is even rarer these days. I saw the report this morning and it has interesting historical value. The important thing to consider is the correct position for the country to adopt at the moment. And that is being determined by the cabinet at this time.
—Would you have signed the petition?
—Probably.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, the Courier‐Mail has named three Queensland National Party government ministers and the state and federal National Party presidents as holders of pastoral leases, several of which are under native title claim. And a search of the register of members of federal parliament reveals that no fewer than 20 members and nine senators, representing the Liberal, National, One Nation and Labor parties, have interests in farming, grazing or pastoral activities.

QUESTION.PARA: Minister, I ask: can you give the Senate an undertaking that no coalition members who are pastoral leaseholders were involved in government policy development or the finalisation of the Wik 10‐point plan that will see them receive a personal financial benefit from the watering down of the Wik decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —An illustrious premier of Queensland once said that you cannot legislate for morality—and neither can you legislate that members of the Labor Party, or any political party for that matter, will not infringe laws. Everybody who is elected to a federal parliament uses their judgment and their own conscience, if you wish, in the decision‐making process and in the development of policy. If there were any sort of pathetic argument used in that regard, it would have to come from Miss Goody Two Shoes down the road there who will trot these things out and say that anybody who has any sort of vested interest should not enter parliament in the first place.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course I cannot guarantee anything in relation to any decision and whether people let that influence them in developing policy in any regard. In fact, I would think that it should, because I can confidently say that those people on this side of the parliament have had careers of one kind or another that develop their personalities, develop their judgments and allow them to bring them to bear, instead of all of the unionists on the other side there who have never had a career outside of the union movement, who have never had a real job in their lives.

The backbone of this country, I am proud to say, are the pastoralists. I have no doubt that the wisdom they will bring to the judgment they deliver in the development of policy will be to the betterment of this country as a whole. The pastoralists are the real workers in this country and produce the wealth of this country—unlike the Democrats, who have, except Senator Murray, been secretaries of one kind or another of previous Democrat senators or have been teachers. That has been their life experience.

I am quite proud of the fact that there are so many pastoralists on our side, in both the Liberal Party and the National Party—Senator Heffernan, for example, is an outstanding member on our side—who bring to the development of policy background and knowledge instead of a lack of knowledge. How many pastoralists are on the other side, Madam President? Is there one? Not one! And they are the ones who are determining what will occur in this country. None of them have had any experience whatsoever in the pastoral industry—not one!

The Democrats also have had no experience in the pastoral industry. Senator Kernot, what experience have you had in the pastoral industry? I am absolutely surprised that you should have the hide to get up and ask a question of that nature and say that that should in some way influence their judgment. Of course it will influence them in developing policy, Senator Kernot—and I am quite proud of the fact that they are here to do so.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question.
—Cheryl, this isn't going well out in the bush.

—I would not talk about it if I were you, Senator Boswell. We all know that, apart from the Lyons Forum, this government has given up on any legislation for morality, but it can legislate for transparency. That is why we have a register of interests: to make sure that, along with developing our personalities, we do not develop our own financial benefits as well. Minister, one of the 10 points is to upgrade pastoral leases to freehold. Surely you have to concede that that will result in often significant financial benefits to some members of federal parliament. Doesn't the Australian public have a right to know exactly who profits and who loses from the government's proposed amendments to native title, particularly if they are members of parliament?

QUESTION.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise in the chamber. Senators are entitled to hear questions and answers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I like the little snide remark about the Lyons Forum. I am proud to be the father with more children than anybody else in this chamber. And, yes, I am a member of the Lyons Forum and I helped that family policy get through. I am quite proud of that. The substantive question related to whether the public are entitled to know. Of course the public are entitled to know, and I am sure that they will. As you well know, Senator Kernot, we are still developing the process. The 10‐point plan has been released for discussion and debate, and within that context it will come about.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, can you guarantee that information stored on behalf of the Department of Social Security will not be stored and processed overseas by multinational companies in countries such as the UK, the USA and Singapore? What guarantee can you give to self‐funded retirees who are moving into nursing homes and who are being assessed by your department that their private income and health details will be secure? Does the minister not agree that personal data of Australians is more secure when it is under government control? Minister, surely you would agree that, if a citizen gives information to the government, the contract is between the citizen and the government and not between the citizen, the government and a giant multinational such as IBM.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lundy was not here, of course, when the previous government, the Labor government, outsourced information technology for the first time in the Commonwealth's history. The private affairs of veterans, who fought for this country, were outsourced. It did not seem to be beyond the wit of the previous government to make sure that veterans' privacy was protected. I draw honourable senators' attention to the fact that the social security legislation is probably tougher on privacy than any other act in the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, the reason that that legislation is so tough on privacy issues is that the previous opposition, the now government, was so determined to see that that was the case. Given our track record, and given your government's history of outsourcing, I think you are unnecessarily and unfairly scaremongering in relation to older Australians. It seems as though members of the Labor Party believe that frightening old people is the smartest way to try to get themselves re-elected in the future. It is pretty stupid. It is just as stupid as the previous Prime Minister referring to old people as `silly old buggers'. It is a concern on this side of the parliament that you are so dismissive of older people and so cruel to them.

I think the other side of politics are incorrigible on this matter and there is no persuading them, whatever logic we might use. I appeal above their heads to the people of Australia and say that this government is determined to protect their privacy. No action which will harm their privacy will be taken. The Privacy Commissioner has traditionally been involved in any activity undertaken by the social security department and, under my stewardship and that of this government, that will be the way of the future. Australians' privacy will be protected both by government policy and by the close involvement of the Privacy Commissioner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given those big statements, Minister, do you agree with your department's major concerns about your government's proposals to hand over the Commonwealth's computer services to multinational companies, including the data held on those computers? Have you raised these concerns with Mr Fahey?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lundy is suggesting that my department is not ready to go on with IT outsourcing, which is government policy. Having said that, the true situation—and it is important that Senator Lundy at least keeps quiet long enough to hear the answer to the question she has asked—is that my department is probably one of the biggest—if not the biggest—users of information technology in the Commonwealth. It has every reason to need convincing of the privacy protections that we can put in place as well as the financial savings that can be achieved by outsourcing before such an undertaking is actually put in place. Because of those concerns, which I think are quite properly held by a responsible organisation to look after Australians—(Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Minister representing the Prime Minister. It refers to reports from impeccable sources that thousands upon thousands of abandoned Chinese babies continue to suffer and die whilst prospective adoptive parents in Australia stand by helplessly. Firstly, is it a fact that there is still no intercountry adoption between Australia and the PRC after six years of negotiations? Secondly, is it a fact that the Chinese government is very anxious to conclude such an agreement, and should be praised for that decision, and that in fact the view of NGOs is that the fault is on the part of the Australian negotiating team? Thirdly, whilst we in this chamber rightfully criticise the PRC for violations of human rights in various areas, shouldn't we be encouraging their particular attitude on adoption so that the agreement can be concluded? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —This is, I think, the third time Senator Harradine has raised this important matter with me in the chamber. I agree we should be encouraging the Chinese in the development of this intercountry adoption agreement and I believe that we should be making every effort to seek to get the agreement concluded as quickly as possible. Yes, it is frustrating and disappointing that it has taken so many years and is still not concluded.

ANSWER.PARA: After the last question from Senator Harradine, I undertook to raise the matters with the Prime Minister, who had his visit to China then pending, to see whether he could unlock the difficulties. I did that. I have now received a response from the Prime Minister. He was unable to discuss the matter with appropriate officials in China. However, he has pursued this matter in the domestic sense. He has raised it with Mr Ruddock. It is one of these issues that is very much a cross-portfolio issue. Mr Ruddock has certain responsibilities, Mrs Moylan has responsibilities, Mr Downer has responsibilities and Mr Williams has responsibilities in relation to it.

But the Australian negotiating team, after all that, is headed by the Victorian government and that team has been unable to complete the agreement. Mr Ruddock has now written to me also and confirmed that that is the stage. He has said that he has written to Dr the Hon. Denis Napthine, the Victorian Minister for Youth and Community Services, bringing to his attention Senator Harradine's interest in the matter. Dr Napthine has agreed to send him a letter detailing the current state of negotiations. I understand that a meeting between officials of the department of human services and the relevant Chinese authorities is being arranged for early August which is following the next meeting of the community services ministerial council on 4 July. When he gets that response, he will let us have it as well.

But I have to agree with the sentiment of Senator Harradine. This matter is just going on forever without a satisfactory conclusion. I will speak to Mr Ruddock. I will suggest to him that perhaps I might have a go and speak to the Chinese authorities and see whether there is some way we can circumvent the road block that is apparently currently present in these negotiations, because as a long-time supporter of intercountry adoptions I would like to see this matter completed as quickly as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, have you been able to ascertain on what date you met with Senator Colston in his office in mid-March? Has your memory been refreshed as to the purpose of your visit? Could you be confusing this visit with the several meetings you had with Senator Colston in your office on 3 March? Did Senator Colston tell you on 3 March that Mrs Christine Smith had met with Mr Nankervis and Mr Holt from the Department of the Senate and had indicated that she would be taking the blame for the irregularities in his travel claims, or is it a fact that Senator Colston withheld this information from you? Did Senator Colston show you a rough draft of the statement that Mrs Smith proposed to make? Did you comment on the proposed draft in any way? Were you ever informed that Mr Douglas Colston was in fact the author of the statement submitted to the Senate in the name of Mrs Christine Smith?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, there were a lot of questions included in that. Can I say for a start that I did read in the Sunday Age a suggestion that Senator Colston had been in my office—I think `in and out all day' was the expression—on Monday 3 March.
—The source was your staff.

—It certainly was not from my staff, because I have checked with a number of members of my staff. They have the same recollection as I do, and that is that Senator Colston was nowhere near my office at all on that day. In fact, that day was a cabinet day, so I would be very surprised if I somehow had been given leave by the Prime Minister to sit in my office accommodating visits from you or anyone else.

ANSWER.PARA: I would like to put this in context, because there seems to be some selective memory loss on the part of the opposition about the events in March. The fact is that, in the lead‐up to the debate on the telecommunications bill, which involved something of the order of 300 amendments—indeed, Senator Schacht put out a press release after it was all over saying that there were at least 10 major issues—I had discussions with a number of people: a number of people visited my office and I visited their offices. All right? Nothing improper about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You never visited my office!
—You certainly visited mine!

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not divulging confidences to say that I had a number of telephone discussions with Senator Schacht—as quite properly we ought to, because these were very important issues. Your office was provided with a large number of briefings. We provided briefings to Senator Harradine and to Senator Colston. I have a note of 17 March saying that I was accompanied by a member of my staff when I visited Senator Colston's office to provide him with a briefing on a number of issues.
—You couldn't remember that yesterday.

—If you want to know what they were about—none of these things would mean anything to you, I am sure—they were things like untimed local calls; powers and immunities, which was a matter of particular concern; uniform local call prices in the bush and the city; untimed local data calls for business customers; transitional provi sions; and digital data capability for the year 2000. They were all issues that took up an enormous amount of time, and in the course of which I had discussions with all relevant senators.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not see that there is anything about that that anyone should apologise for. The fact is we would not be doing our jobs if we did not test all these issues and explore where senators were likely to go and whether they had particular concerns that could addressed. As Senator Schacht would well know, there was quite a deal of negotiation, withdrawing of amendments and substitution of refinements. All those things are part and parcel of the business of conducting legislation through this chamber.

There can be no doubt that that occurred in that period of time, and certainly there is no doubt that in the lead‐up there were a number of issues swirling around regarding Senator Colston's travel allowance and the allegations that were being made. Quite understandably, those matters would have been discussed as well. I am sure they were discussed on your side as much as they were discussed on our side. As we have seen, you have made a determination to spend as much time as possible in this chamber talking about everything except the legislation; everything except what really matters to the people of Australia. As a result, the Bulletin poll shows you at about your lowest level in the last 20 years, because you are obsessed with the Senator Colston affair. Rampaging Roy Ray obviously wants to pursue the matter at the expense of all other issues. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, you have admitted that on one occasion you met with Christine Smith of Senator Colston's staff. You have also admitted that in your discussions with Senator Colston the issue of Mrs Smith's statement was discussed. I would ask you to inform the Senate on how many occasions you discussed Mrs Smith's statement with Senator Colston, when those discussions took place, who was present at those discussions and what was the nature of those discussions with Senator Colston?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already said that I do not recall the precise date. I indicat ed to Senator Robert Ray that it was prior to 24 March. To my recollection, there was only one occasion on which I discussed the matter with Christine Smith or about Christine Smith. You asked me questions about who drafted the statement. You say Doug Colston drafted it. I have no knowledge of that at all. You asked me whether I was made aware that Senator Colston—was it Senator Colston?—had spoken or Christine Smith had spoken to some Senate officers. It is the first time I have ever heard of that suggestion.

ANSWER.PARA: In summary, the fact is that what Senator Colston presumably wanted to do was make us aware that he had a defence. I regard that as knowledge that is proper for me to have. Beyond that, I have no knowledge and I make no comment or judgment about the accuracy of that statement or any subsequent statement. That is not a matter for the Senate. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, I refer to tomorrow's national day of action by some university students. Is it not a fact that places for full fee paying Australian undergraduate students will be additional to increased government funded places and will not exceed 25 per cent up to and beyond the year 2000? Why does the Labor Party continue to mislead students, which gives rise to unnecessary fears and concerns?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Senator Troeth. I do not know why the Labor Party continues to mislead students on these matters. I am pleased to confirm that the full fee paying places next year will be in addition to additional government funded places, that they will be limited to 25 per cent and that that limit is set in concrete in legislation passed in this chamber. It is not transitional up to the year 2000 at all.

ANSWER.PARA: I noted yesterday that Senator Carr interjected saying, `Oh, but you've used transitional.' They are trying to create the impression out there in student land that there is some doubt about whether the 25 per cent limit stays. I need to explain to him, because he was either being deliberately deceptive or he lacks the cognitive capacity to read the regulations. Now there is some confusion out there that needs to be cleared up.

Let me make this point: without the rules that phase in 25 per cent of the student load being full fee paying a large and prosperous university could next year sell 25 per cent of its first year places to fee payers as well as 25 per cent of the total of its second and third year places to new third year students. If you do not understand what that means—I say that because Senator Carr looks like he does not—I will explain. It means that a big prestigious university could siphon off final year students from other smaller universities and they could do that next year. Having done the first year at another university, those students could complete their degree at one of our most prestigious universities for the cost of one year's up‐front fee.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you'd let them!

—I hear Senator Carr saying, `And you'd let them,' indicating that he has not read the guidelines because the whole point of the transitional arrangements is to stop exactly that. The whole point of the guidelines is to protect the smaller universities that Senator Carr claims to champion. The 25 per cent limit is set in stone, in legislation. Senator Carr was here when that legislation was passed. But he often has the capacity to put his mind in neutral and his mouth in overdrive as we full well know. Senator Carr has real difficulty with comprehension and with hearing anything other than that which he wants to hear and the sound of his own voice.

ANSWER.PARA: Mark Latham, the new shadow minister, fell into the same trap, as did the National Union of Students, either misreading the guidelines or deliberately misleading students on them. We give them the benefit of the doubt and say that they are so stupid they were not able to read the guidelines properly. But where is the sweetest irony in this? The sweetest irony is this: over here we have a Labor leftie screeching, flapping his wings, puffing out his feathers like a rooster, complaining we are going to let the rich pay.

BREAK.PARA: I would have thought that a leftie like Senator Carr would be crowing with glee at the prospect of the so‐called rich paying more money to universities. Is he really seriously saying that he would prefer to see a wealthier student in a government funded place than see that place freed up for a student who would otherwise have missed out on the chance to go to university? The fellow blusters away like Foghorn Leghorn but his message is really that of Chicken Little. Just as the sky did not fall on Chicken Little, neither will academic standards nor the number of government funded places at that our universities drop as a result of this policy.

Melbourne university has already passed a motion indicating the entry requirements will not drop. I only hope that the students protesting tomorrow realise that there will be more government funded undergraduate places next year than this year and more this year than there were last year, that the full fee paying places are additional to those additional government funded places and that wealthy students will move out of government funded places leaving spaces for students who otherwise would not have got in—in other words, a policy for greater access to university. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Can you confirm that Mr McLachlan authorised the payment of $75,000 to a Brisbane public relations company to help sell the defence efficiency review? Was the Office of Government Information and Advertising, OGIA, consulted as to which company was the best suited to the task? Did the contract go out to tender? What services did the public relations company provide and how much is allocated in the defence budget to the defence public relations unit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer. We will see how much of Senator West's question gets answered by it. If it does not cover it in full I will go and ask the minister for some more.

BREAK.PARA: The defence efficiency review secretariat elected to engage a consultant rather than use internal staff arrangements as it was important to have a communications strategy in place prior to the release of the review. The scale of the task was considered to be beyond available resources. Defence public information staff were largely committed to existing tasks including exercise Tandem Thrust and the Blackhawk inquiry. The review has enormous implications for defence personnel. A strategy for communicating these implications within Defence as well as externally was necessary.

The firm Turnbull Fox Queensland was selected by restricted tender from three companies with a track record in Defence in communications strategies and change management. They were selected on the basis of capacity and key personnel, past experience and price. Their task was to prepare an issues management and communications strategy which would include a presentation to be used by commanders and managers to brief their staff; prepare fact sheets, articles and letters to assist defence personnel comprehend the scope of change; anticipate a range of questions that could be posed by stakeholders both within and external to Defence, together with appropriate responses; and ensure stakeholders were appropriately informed of the recommendations of the efficiency review.

The vast majority of the consultant's work was directed by and delivered to the defence efficiency review secretariat. There were approximately four consultations with the minister's staff to discuss a communications strategy for defence interest groups such as the RSL, defence commentators and other former senior officers. Two formal meetings were held with the minister at which defence public relations personnel were present to discuss media arrangements.

The service cost the department some $81,000. You might also like to note that as at mid‐April total expenditure on the review including this service was only some $240,000 of the allocated $450,000. This compares with planned annual mature savings from the review of $770 million to $1 billion.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, in light of results of the Telstra research study released last week in which mice exposed to digital mobile phone emissions developed tumours at twice the control rate—

QUESTION.PARA: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections on my right.

—Minister, will you now withdraw your claim that there is no substantiated evidence of health risk from electromagnetic radiation? As a matter of urgency will you call for a review of the current mobile phone emission standards given that the Telstra study of cancer in mice occurred at power levels similar to those allowed under the Australian standard? Minister, will you on behalf of the government take responsibility for guaranteeing that 4.5 million Australian mobile phone users are not exposed to increased risk of tumours?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The weight of national and international scientific opinion is that there is no substantiated evidence of adverse health and safety effects from radio frequency emissions at typical levels. The government's $4.5 million program consists of a public information dissemination strategy, continuing participation in the World Health Organisation's project to assess the health and environmental effects of EME exposure, and an independent Australian research program.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of results of the study announced last week which found that mice which were genetically predisposed to develop lymphoma, when exposed to EME developed lymphoma at a higher rate than those in a controlled group not so exposed, but at a much lower rate than would come from exposure to a known carcinogen. I understand that the researchers have emphasised that their results cannot be extrapolated to humans. Indeed, I think about the most one can say at this stage is that if there are mice in the community who are genetically predisposed to developing lymphoma they would be well advised not to use mobile phones. I take it that if you have concerns you will not be using mobile phones, either.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That applies to rats as well, I should say.

ANSWER.PARA: We are not in the business of trying to tell everyone that there are unacceptable risks attached to using mobile phones, or of trying to frighten everyone out of using mobile phones. What we are very concerned to do is to ensure that Australia keeps up with world's best practice in this area. That is why we commissioned that additional research. You would have heard my comments on the Standards Committee some time ago. From memory, it has something like two out of 17 or two out of 24 representatives of the carriers on it, so it is a very widely based industry standards committee. The Standards Committee met earlier this year and agreed to retain the present scientific basis and the derived exposure guidelines.

Of course, there is always the capacity for them to review those standards. We expect that all responsible scientists in this area will be constantly monitoring the results of research around the world. To simply jump on one survey, when the researchers themselves emphasise that the results cannot be extrapolated to humans, is yet another example of trying to turn this into an issue that might frighten some people unnecessarily. You would be much better advised to play a constructive role in ensuring that the research does cover all of the projects that have been undertaken around the world. I know that Senator Allison has a very extensive library on this subject. It is one of her grand obsessions. She cannot, therefore, have any difficulty in ensuring that the Standards Committee is fully apprised of all those surveys which she regards as important.

At the end of the day we are not going to be driven by what she would like to see out there in the community by way of levels of apprehension. We are going to be driven by the scientific and expert advice that we can get. That is why we have an expert committee. It is a matter for them to advise the government, as I am sure they will.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the minister why it is that he too has adopted the industry line, which says that this study cannot be extrapolated to humans, when for at least 150 years the scientific community has used mice in such research. It has formed a very fundamental part of our knowledge of medical issues. So I ask the minister again why he is attempting to whitewash this study. I also ask him to acknowledge that he should take responsibility for those 4.5 million mobile phone users in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry. I don't quite know what you mean by me `taking responsibility for 4.5 million mobile phone users'. They can make their own decisions. If they want to continue using mobile phones then I am sure they will—in droves. If they somehow want to take your advice then presumably they will put them in the nearest wastepaper basket. I am sure you will be setting a high example in that regard and making sure that none of your colleagues ever use mobile phones again.

ANSWER.PARA: But in the meantime we will not be making decisions on the basis of the views of unqualified individuals, and that includes both you and me. We will be taking advice from the experts. If the experts tell us that this research study cannot be extrapolated to humans, who am I to get out there and tell them they are wrong? You are on a very slippery slope if you appoint an expert committee, if you get advice on matters that are beyond the scientific understanding of most of us, and if you then superimpose your layperson's view simply because it fits in with your preconceived prejudices on the issue. We will not be doing that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 March Senator Crowley asked me a question as minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs relating to financial support for various human reproduction programs. I am sorry it has taken a little while, but I seek to incorporate the answer in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The answer read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crowley asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice, on 25 March 1997:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) Is the Minister aware that in 1997 no financial support will be provided by the Australian Government to the United Nations/World Bank Special Program of Research Development and Research Training in Human Reproduction (HRP), the only United Nations program conducting research on the reproductive health problems of developing countries.
(2) Does the Minister realise that this marks the end of 17 years of staunch Australian support for HRP.
(3) What is the rationale for the Government's decision and what impact will it have on our relations with our Asian neighbours.
(4) Will the Prime Minister be explaining the Government's decision to his Chinese hosts during next week's visit.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hill —Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the follows answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) The Minister is aware that in 1997 no financial support will be provided by the Australian Government for the United Nations/World Bank Special Program of Research Development and Research Training in Human Reproduction. In 1995-96 Australia provided a grant of $747,000 to this program.
(2) The Minister is aware that Australia had supported this program for a number of years.

(3) The overall level of aid funding for population and family planning activities is expected to be maintained in 1996-97 at around $37 million, despite the overall reduction in the aid budget. Within this amount, the Government has to make some difficult decisions in allocating limited aid resources amongst competing priorities. The Government saw as its first priority, funding for bilateral and regional family planning activities in the Asia-Pacific region where we can draw directly on Australian expertise and more closely monitor our assistance AusAID‐funded family planning activities adhere to the principles of voluntarism and freedom of choice.

The Government does not believe that this decision will impact on our relations with our Asian neighbours. The Government believes that this approach would be appreciated by developing countries in our region, particularly as several large aid-funded women's health and family projects are expected to begin this year in China, Indonesia and Papua New Guinea. Funding for international programs, while important, could not be maintained at past levels. Those international agencies which focus on direct family planning services, the United Nations Population Fund and the International Planned Parenthood Federation, continue to receive funding.
(4) These matters were not raised by the Prime Minister during his recent visit to China.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Also, questions were asked yesterday of me by Senator Bolkus and Senator Ray relating to Senator Colston. I have some answers from the Attorney-General which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The answers read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that Senator Robert Hill was asked by Senator Nick Bolkus and Senator Robert Ray a series of questions about events surrounding Senator brat Colston during the proceedings of the Senate yesterday.
The answer to the questions, as I understand them, is as follows:

(1) On the evening that the Prime Minister received a copy of Mrs Smith's statement he contacted the Attorney-General who was not at Parliament House. The Attorney returned to the House and attended a meeting in the Prime Minister's office where a copy of Mrs Smith's letter was provided to the Attorney. The Attorney advised the Prime Minister to the effect that in light of the statement, a prompt reference to the AFP of allegations against Senator Colston was appropriate. After his meeting with the Prime Minister the Attorney immediately contacted the relevant senior AFP officer and formally referred the allegations to the AFP. Following the Prime Minister's press conference the Attorney issued a news release indicating that he had referred the matter to the AFP and that relevant supporting documentation would be forwarded the next day.

(2) Under the procedures circulated by the Attorney last year any Minister wishing to refer a matter of this nature to the AFP is expected to do so via the Attorney- General's office. This procedure was complied with.

(3) The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and others of his colleagues apparently seek a briefing from the AFP with respect to investigations of allegations against Senator Colston. It has been a standing practice of successive governments not to reveal details of ongoing AFP operations. The Attorney-General has acted and intends to continue to act in accordance with that practice. It would be inconsistent with that practice for briefings on details of AFP operations to be provided to members of Parliament. The Attorney will therefore not agree to Senator Faulkner being given a briefing by the AFP on matters relating to Senator Colston.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Senate Vacancy: Representation of Western Australia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer provided by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) in response to a question by Senator Evans today, relating to the filling of a Senate vacancy in the representation of Western Australia.
It is now 96 days since Western Australia has been unrepresented by a Senate position in this chamber. We have had for 96 days only 11 senators—not the constitutional requirement of 12 senators.

When the government is asked why it is allowing this situation to drift as it is, the only excuse that can be offered by the Leader of the Government in this chamber is that there is some constitutional problem in selecting the successor for `Senator Fruit Loop' or Senator-designate Lightfoot in the—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook, you might like to use language that is a little more respectful and withdraw that.
—`Fruit loop' was the term used by the Liberal Party's Mr Eoin Cameron, the member for Stirling, to describe Mr Lightfoot. If that is unparliamentary, I withdraw it.
—Senator Cook, whilst he is not technically in the Senate yet, he is the member of another state parliament.

—I am happy to withdraw, but it was the term used in the other place by Mr Eoin Cameron, the member for Stirling, to describe Senator-designate Lightfoot. The only explanation that the government can offer is that there is some constitutional problem about selecting Mr Lightfoot's successor in the Legislative Council of Western Australia. That is a red herring. That has nothing to do with this chamber. It has nothing to do with this question. It only has to do with the Liberal Party's sleazy manoeuvring to maintain their numbers in the Legislative Council in Western Australia. It should be rejected by this place as misleading, as diverting and not in fact answering the question at all.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been 96 days since this vacancy has occurred. The Senate has sat for 25 days and will probably sit for a further 29 days before this vacancy is filled. That, on both occasions is a record—96 days is a record, it has never happened before in the history of the Australian constitution, and 25 days is also a record. Western Australians have been unrepresented for that length of time. We have, of course, extended a pair and done the right thing.

But the real reason for this delay is the most shameful thing of all. The real reason is that Mr Lightfoot, who was preselected on 5 April and remained in Western Australia until after 21 April, stood to gain $466,000 in a superannuation payment. Reason one for the delay is a massive kick to his superannuation entitlement—don't mind the constitutional conventions at all.

But the other reason is even more serious. Mr Lightfoot himself said in the Legislative Council just the other week that the reason he was remaining was that he wanted to vote for the divisive and iniquitous Western Australian industrial relations legislation. He is, in fact, flouting the constitutional conventions to vote for a piece of legislation that divides my state of Western Australia sharply and which is condemned on all sides except the small cabal of right wing extremists led by the industrial relations minister, Graham Kierath, in the Western Australian parliament. That is the reason why he is delaying and not filling the vacancy that has occurred here.

That is contemptuous of Western Australian electors; that is contemptuous of the constitu tional conventions; that is contemptuous of this Senate; and it is contemptuous of the fair and democratic procedures that Western Australians expect their state government to uphold and this Senate to reflect. The state government in Western Australia is ramming through this industrial relations legislation using the gag and the guillotine in the Legislative Council because it does not have a mandate. It does not have the numbers if the properly elected Legislative Council takes its seat on 22 April—and never in the 100-year history of the Legislative Council has that been done.

Senators Campbell and Knowles, who spoke out about the delay in this, have been silent. They spoke out on 5 March when they attacked the Western Australian government for a 41-day delay. There has now been a 96‐day delay. The failed numbers man over here, Senator Campbell, who said, `A vote for Lightfoot is a vote against me,' when he was canvassing for Michael Huston in the preselection process in Western Australia, has remained silent about this travesty of constitutional convention when he was outspoken several years ago—a hypocritical action.

That is the same with Senator Knowles. They have not stood up for their state of Western Australia at all. They argued that this was a travesty several years ago. Now they remain silent and are hypocrites as a consequence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Cook, would you withdraw the use of the word `hypocrite', please?
—Their actions are hypocritical. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President West, this is the first time I have been able to stand up and officially congratulate you on obtaining your position. What is this all about? Why do we have this here before us today? It is purely and simply because we have seen in Western Australia, since the Court government came into power, very successful, for the state and the work force, changes to labour market arrangements in Western Australia. I will not use the word `fruit loop' to describe Senator Cook, but I think it may well have been, had it not been withdrawn, a fairly appropriate term to describe his contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the facts as to why they are jumping up and down and complaining about the fact that the Hon. Mr Lightfoot MLC, before obtaining his position here, finished his tour of duty in the Western Australian parliament. First of all, we need to deal with the workplace agreements. This is what this is about—nothing else. All the rest is a charade.

Let us look at the workplace agreements in Western Australia and what has occurred there. What is happening here is an absolute charade. The only reason this is happening is that further reform has gone through the Western Australian parliament and your mates have told you to kick up a stink about it. There is no other reason whatsoever for what you are doing today.

Back in 1993 you said that wages would be cut by 25 per cent. Remember? What has happened? In 1995, Western Australian workers received the largest increase in average weekly wages of any state in this country. You said that workers would have to sign or resign. What a falsehood—absolutely untrue. You said that state awards would be abolished. Not one single state award has been abolished.

What else did you say back then? And Senator Chris Evans, through you Madam Deputy President, was one of the people who gave adjournment speeches here night after night. We listened to the sorts of things he was saying. He said that penalty rates and leave loading, et cetera, would be abolished. None of these conditions has been abolished. You know, Senator Evans, they have not been abolished.

Before we won government you know that some of these conditions were traded off into enterprise agreements. That is no different. Exactly the same thing has occurred, and you know that. We will test you if you get on your feet to refute that. You also said that minimum conditions would become maximum conditions. The fact is that workers cannot be paid less than the Minimum Conditions of Employment Act prescribe. But we find in the survey work that has been done that there is less than one‐quarter of one per cent whose wages have stayed static or decreased in a minor fashion.
The other 99¾ per cent have all increased—and increased significantly, as the figures show—and that is borne out by what I said earlier in terms of that.

I will move on, in the time that I have left, to look at some of the allegations that have been made. You do not want these lies to be exposed—and this has been spelt out very clearly. We are told, `The minister refused to negotiate.' In fact, it was not the minister who refused to negotiate; it was the TLC which refused to negotiate even before it had seen the bill. We are also told, `There is no community support for the legislation.' First of all, this has been around since 1993; there is nothing new about it. Who won the election? That is a good question.

Above and beyond that, a recent independent survey showed 55 per cent of the people polled supported secret ballots before industry action. Other surveys have been, as Senator Bishop over there knows, as high as 90 per cent. That is the reason why you brought this issue up in here today—you did not want this to be exposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a red herring.
—It is not a red herring, let me tell you. This is no red herring. What were they campaigning on?
—Senator Crane, would you like to address the chair and Senator Bishop will then be silent.

—Certainly, Madam Deputy President. I love addressing the chair, particularly when a bit of truth settles on some of my Western Australian colleagues over there. We are told, `Secret ballots before stop‐work meetings are compulsory.' Why don't they tell us that employers may decide to approve a stop‐work meeting because it could prevent a balloted strike? We are then told, `Union dues can't be deducted from pay.' Union dues deductions can no longer be forced on employers by the WAIRC. If there is an agreement between employer and employees, union dues can be deducted just like HBF payments.

BREAK.PARA: My concluding comments, in terms of what has been thrown up here today, are that the noises that have been made by those opposite are more to do with the instructions from their masters to keep up a smokescreen because of the success of the workplace agreements legislation. Their aim is to prevent further reforms of the Western Australian industrial relations system, which has proved to be very successful. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to take note of Senator Hill's answer to my question to him today regarding the filling of the Senate vacancy caused by the death of Senator John Panizza. Firstly, in response to Senator Crane I say that, despite what I thought was a fairly confused contribution, he did make one crucial point: that this is all about the Western Australian industrial relations legislation. I thank him for doing that because he totally undermined his leader's position and proved our case.
