What we are saying today is that this is all about the Western Australian industrial relations legislation, and your confirmation of that, Senator Crane, at least was an honest contribution. It was far more honest than that of Senator Hill, who tried to pretend that there existed some constitutional difficulties and that was why there had been a delay in the appointment. But you, Senator Crane, at least were honest. You said this was about the exercise of political expediency and I thank you for that. As for the rest of your contribution, I think any further comments are best left unsaid.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting, as Senator Cook pointed out, that the Liberal senators opposite have been very quiet on this issue considering the outrage they expressed when the vacancy of Senator Vallentine was debated in this place. Senator Campbell and Senator Knowles made very telling contributions at that time as to the need for Western Australia to be represented fully in this chamber and to have a replacement senator appointed as quickly as possible. They made a compelling case, so much so that the Senate carried a motion supporting that outcome. Now we have a situation where, in my view, the federal Liberal Party is abusing the decency of the opposition by continuing to exercise a pair in the Senate when it is, for political motives, failing to fill the vacancy.

We offered a pair to the Liberal Party on the death of John Panizza, as we would normally do, on the basis that they would obviously move to fill the vacancy with a senator‐elect from their party. What we have seen since is an abuse of that arrangement, an abuse of the convention, and an abuse of the goodwill and the decency of the Australian Labor Party by your using that offer by the ALP to delay the replacement, allowing yourselves to exercise your full voting entitlements in the Senate without any price being paid in terms of loss of a vote, while at the same time you are refusing to appoint the replacement senator because of the Western Australian government agenda. I think the federal Liberal Party and the senators here are complicit in what is going on in Western Australia. They ought to be ashamed of themselves because that really is abusing the arrangements that have been made in terms of the pairing of a now deceased senator.
We are not going to break our deal in terms of pairing. We are committed to upholding that principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about Western Australia? How about the pairing arrangement in Western Australia?

—That will be honoured as well, Senator Knowles. You are more worried about whether Clive Griffiths MLC will vote your way. What I want to say is that we will not break that deal. In any event, it does not matter, because Ross Lightfoot has made it very clear he is not coming. He has said in the Legislative Council of Western Australia that he is not coming because he will stay, under Premier Court's instructions, to exercise the vote because you are not sure that the present Legislative Council would vote with you on the bill without him. You are not sure in your claim that the state Labor opposition would continue to extend the pair despite making that offer to you if Senator‐designate Lightfoot took up his position in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Court government is trying to do is avoid the scrutiny and review of its legisla tion. They know that on 22 May the composition of the Legislative Council changes and that, for the first time in the history of the Western Australian parliament, conservative legislation will be reviewed by the Legislative Council in a proper way.

There will not be a Labor majority. There will be a Legislative Council which has Democrats, Greens, Independents and Australian Labor Party members. They will expose this legislation to scrutiny, and the Liberal Party and Premier Court know that it cannot survive that scrutiny. It is malicious. It cannot survive any sort of independent or proper scrutiny, because it is politically motivated and it is designed to attack the interests of working people in this state and to attack the WA trade union movement. It does not stand up to any tests in terms of our international labour obligations or international law, and it does not stand up to the standards of common decency and fairness that have been applied by Western Australian citizens.

Everybody who has looked at the bill in Western Australia, bar those who are members of the Liberal Party, has rejected the bill. You have no wider support for the bill. This is a grubby attempt to abuse the relationship in terms of pairs here, and to abuse the constitutional conventions. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eggleston, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to take note of Senator Hill's answer to a question that was put to him on the timing of the arrival of Senator‐elect Ross Lightfoot in terms of the constitution of Western Australia. It is the point which Senator Hill made, and that is that there is a constitutional problem in bringing Mr Lightfoot here before the date that has been accepted as the date on which he will come.

SPEECH.PARA: I might explain that the Western Australian constitution provides that if there is a vacancy in the upper house, instead of a by‐election for an upper house seat, the next person on the ticket for that upper house province is brought in to the Legislative Council. The end of the term from the election at which Mr Lightfoot was elected to the Legislative Council is 22 May, and the relevant election is not the 1996 election, it is the 1992 elec tion. It just so happens that there is nobody left on the Liberal Party ticket to replace Mr Lightfoot if he is admitted to the Senate before that date. Thus a legal question arises as to how he could be replaced in the Legislative Council before the beginning of the new term for the Legislative Council which, as I said, is 22 May.

That is just a fact. There is no question of shonky politics or funny deals. The fact is that there is a legal issue, a constitutional issue, involved and that Mr Lightfoot, out of a sense of responsibility to the people of Western Australia, is ensuring that the Western Australian Legislative Council continues to operate as it should with a full complement of Liberal Party members until the constitution provides a mechanism by which he can be replaced.

That mechanism will be that after 22 May he can be replaced by the next person on the Liberal ticket for the North Metropolitan province, which is the ticket on which he was elected, and that person, I believe, will be Mr Ray Halligan. That is the point of Mr Lightfoot's delay in coming to Canberra—that is, respect for the Western Australian constitution and a sense of responsibility to the people of Western Australia which I, for one, think is very commendable.

I will speak about Mr Lightfoot and the kind of senator he will make. He will bring to this Senate a great wealth of life experience. Mr Lightfoot is a very successful man. He has had a very broad experience in Western Australia. He has been in the army. He has been a successful pastoralist and miner. He has a great knowledge of the eastern goldfields and the pastoral areas of Western Australia and, as well, he has other business interests. Furthermore, he has been a state MP for many years and he will bring to the Senate a wealth of experience in terms of representing Western Australia in this place.

The kinds of comments that have been made about the industrial relations legislation are of interest but, nevertheless, the fact remains that the principal reason why Mr Lightfoot's arrival in Canberra has been delayed is a matter of the Western Australian constitution and the need for him to wait until the new term of the Legislative Council begins before he can be replaced in the Western Australian Legislative Council. As I said, I see that as an act of great responsibility on the part of Mr Lightfoot and the Liberal Party to the people of Western Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —In taking note of Senator Hill's answer, I want to make a few comments concerning the failure of the Western Australian Liberal government to appoint a successor to the late Senator Panizza. It is now some 96 days, as outlined by Senator Cook, and will be well over 110 days before Senator‐designate Lightfoot takes his place in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: That delay has occurred despite the Liberal Party endorsing Mr Lightfoot on two occasions. It has occurred despite the Western Australian parliament sitting for some weeks, and that delay continues despite many opportunities to fill the vacancy. That delay, as we all know, is occasioned because of crass political opportunism by the Western Australian government. That political opportunism arises from defiance of the will of the electorate of Western Australia.

Last December, the electorate voted and chose to alter the composition of the upper house in the Western Australian parliament. For the first time since its creation last century, the electorate has refused to give a mandate or control to the government in the lower house. The electorate chose a raft of Independents and minor party representatives to advance its interests. The government did not fall; however, its control in the upper house was removed. The electorate deliberately determined to apply a brake, a caution to the feared excesses of the coalition government.

What has been the reaction of the Western Australian government to that decision? Has it heeded the message? Has it become more balanced in its approach? Has it had due regard for the will of the people? The answer is no, no and no again. It has put forward a piece of legislation that is biased, unbalanced, divisive in approach, partisan in outcome and contemptible in its abuse of process.

It has refused to allow full and open debate on the bill. For the first time in 100 years, it will use the guillotine on Thursday to prohibit discussion on the bill. What is so important about this bill, this third wave of industrial legislation, that requires the guillotine? A lot of the content of the bill—secret ballots, right of entry, penalties and limitation of federal award coverage—is already covered by the federal act. Indeed, the Australian Labor Party and the labour council in Western Australia have indicated a willingness to negotiate around these issues.

These matters, however, are not the crux of the bill, because the government changes its position and issues draft amendments almost on a daily basis. The heart of the bill is the intent of the government to isolate one sector of the not for profit community in Western Australia.

The bill seeks to regulate the political activities and political expenditures of trade unions, which, after all, are not for profit institutions. So if you are a charity, registered or otherwise, a church, university, non‐profit hospital, a voluntary association like the scouts, Red Cross or St John's Ambulance, you are free to engage in political activity, political lobbying or political expenditure. Those organisations and institutions are expected to seek to play a role in the political processes to advance the interests of their constituency.

However, if you are a member of a voluntary, not for profit registered organisation known as a trade union, you are not permitted—indeed, it would be illegal—to engage in political lobbying or expenditure of a political nature. So if you are a shop assistant, your union may not lobby on issues that are critical, such as extended trading hours, despite the government appointing your union to the relevant trading hours committee. If you are a construction worker, you may not lobby about portable long service leave or workers' compensation, despite the government creating a special tribunal comprising your union to address those issues.

If you are a member of a registered employer organisation in industries like mining, petroleum, milk vending, hairdressing or abattoirs, you cannot engage in political activity or political lobbying. By contradistinction, if you are a member of an unregis tered, non-profit employer organisation like the Chamber of Commerce and Industry of Western Australia, you are free to raise funds, supply your building to the Liberal Party for election purposes and provide the services of paid employees to engage in political activity of the kind outlawed in the bill for trade unions or other registered employer organisations.

What have been the results of this political thuggery by the Court government? Most importantly, there has been a further loss of faith in the institution of parliament. There has been further disenchantment of the arrogant attitude of the Court government as it defies the political will of the electorate of Western Australia. All of this is because of partisan, divisive, non-productive and sectional hatred of the trade union movement by the Court government. All of this is about petty power and mean politics. None of it is about principle. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, yesterday I failed to congratulate you on your elevation to the high office of Deputy President. Congratulations.

SPEECH.PARA: I am a little flummoxed at the fact that we are even having this debate from the point of view—Senator Cook is obviously not awake enough to realise—that Senator Evans has actually put down an urgency motion on this very subject today. I am blowed if I know why we are having the debate twice. However, as I intend to speak on the debate later, I will cover a different subject area to that which I will cover later. I will focus on some of the things that people from the opposition side have said in this debate.

Senator Evans made the point that the opposition in Western Australia had guaranteed a pair for the Hon. Mr Lightfoot to leave the Legislative Council and come here. Senator Evans is obviously living in fairyland as well because he does not know that the Labor Party did last night what they always do when industrial relations is debated in the Western Australian parliament. They called off pairs. That is exactly the reason why Mr Lightfoot is not in the Senate now. We knew exactly what the Labor Party would do in the event that he left.

Let me give another example. We have had the industrial relations package before the parliament in Western Australia. Senator Bishop just talked about the result in Western Australia last year. I will come to that in a later debate. Senator Bishop just happened to overlook the fact that the coalition government in Western Australia was elected with an increased majority, not a decreased majority. But he very conveniently forgot to mention that when he spoke about the will of the people. Is it not fascinating that he decides to forget about the result and just interpret the result in a way which is convenient for the purpose of this debate?

What we are talking about is protecting a government agenda which is clearly to be sabotaged by a Labor Party that had its worst result in Western Australian history. That is not a bad effort. Here they are sabotaging it. I will come to the question of the other part of the result in a later debate. I think it is important that we focus on some of the `will of the people', as it is now being termed by the opposition in this place and in the Western Australian parliament.

The whole purpose of the legislation over there is to give effect to secret ballots. The people of Western Australia happen to want secret union ballots. They are sick of the thuggery that is going on. In Western Australia today we have the tanker drivers going out. So they are now going to hold the state to ransom. This is all at the directive of the trade union movement and the Labor Party in Western Australia.

Is it any wonder that we want to get the legislation through the Western Australian parliament? Is it any wonder that the Labor Party was not trusted with the pairing arrangement? There was another informal pairing arrangement that was evidently made with the former leader of the Legislative Council. It happened to be the former leader of the Legislative Council who called pairs off on previous industrial relations debates. Is it any wonder that they are not trusted with their word?

BREAK.PARA: Fortunately Senator Evans gives every indication to this chamber that he is a trustworthy person with his word in the Whip's position. No-one but no-one can question that. He has given his commitment and he has honoured that commitment but what a pity he does not have people of his ilk in the Western Australian parliament who can honour their commitment. They have clearly not done the honourable thing that Senator Evans has done. Had they honoured that commitment, we would not be having this debate today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Industrial Relations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should recognise that any reform to Australia's system of industrial relations should acknowledge the special needs of employees to be protected from disadvantage, exploitation and discrimination in the workplace.

Your petitioners oppose the Coalition policies which represent a fundamentally anti‐worker regime and we call upon the Senate to provide an effective check and balance to the Coalition's legislative program by rejecting such a program.
Your petitioners request that the Senate reject the proposed reforms to the area of industrial relations as outlined in the Workplace Relations Bill 1996.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Calvert, Sen Paul; Woodley, Sen John
PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia, call on all Senators to support implementation of the following:

PARA.TAB: a requirement to label with the production process, all foods from genetic engineering technologies or containing their products;
real public participation in decisions on whether to allow commercialisation of foods, additives and processing agents produced by gene technologies;
premarket human trials and strict safety rules on these foods, to assess production processes as well as the end products.

PETITION.PARA: Precedents which support our petition include several examples of foods already labelled with the processes of production; irradiated foods (here and internationally); certified organic foods; and many conventional foods (pasteurised; salt‐reduced; free‐range; vitamin‐enriched; to name only a few).
We ask you all to accord a high priority to supporting and implementing our petition.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Calvert(from 145 citizens)and Senator Woodley(from 36 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate your petitioners' appreciation of the vital role the ABC plays in the development of Australian culture and in the provision of quality news and information services, including in regional Australia.
Proposed alterations to the ABC charter and cuts to its funding and staff levels will have an extremely adverse effect on the ABC's performance of these roles.

Your petitioners express their grave concern that the Government proposes to break its unequivocal election promise to maintain current levels of ABC funding and proposes to redefine the ABC's role so that it has a narrower focus and is more politically acceptable to the Howard Government.

Your petitioners request that the Senate ensures the current ABC charter, funding and staffing levels are maintained so that the ABC retains its independence and viability as an effective national broadcaster.

PETITION.TITLE: Holsworthy: Proposed Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petitioners respectfully draw the attention of the Senate to the Fact that the quality of life of the citizens of the Sutherland Shire will be severely and adversely affected by the construction of an airport at Holsworthy. The petitioners therefore call on the Senate to urge the Prime Minister and Government to prevent the construction of any airport at Holsworthy.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Bourne, Sen Vicki; Calvert, Sen Paul; McKiernan, Sen James
PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bourne(from 37 citizens), Senator Calvert(from 25 citizens)and Senator McKiernan(from five citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We the undersigned request the Australian Senate implements the following:
A Senate enquiry into the use of genetic engineering in the Australian Food Supply, including the ethics of its use.
That consultations be undertaken with the general public to ask if we want this technology in our food supply and consent to its use.
That consumers be resourced to attend these consultations.
Any food that is genetically engineered or contains components that are genetically engineered are required to be labelled, including the origin of the genes.
That meaningful right to know legislation be enacted to guarantee public access to toxicology data.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned recognises the importance to Australia's retirement income policy of a stable and secure superannuation system in which people are encouraged, not penalised, for taking steps to provide for their retirement and asks that:
1. Coalition Senators honour their 1996 election promise, namely that `The Coalition is fully committed to engendering stability, security, simplicity and flexibility into the superannuation system'.

2. The Liberal/National Government acknowledge that the inclusion of superannuation assets and roll‐over funds in the social security means test is inequitable, erodes public confidence in the superannuation system and penalises those who have attempted to provide for their own retirement.
3. The Government repeal legislation including superannuation assets and roll‐over funds in the social security means test.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, may I congratulate you on your elevation. On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that on the next day of sitting I shall withdraw the following disallowance motions:

SPEECH.PARA: Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No.1 standing in the name of Senator O'Chee for four sitting days after today for the disallowance of the Airports (Building Control) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No.292 and made under the Airports Act 1996.

Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No.2 standing in the name of Senator O'Chee for four sitting days after today for the disallowance of the Bankruptcy Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No.263 and made under the Bankruptcy Act 1966.

Business of the Senate Notice Motion No.3 standing in the name of Senator O'Chee for four sitting days after today for the disallowance of the Family Law Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No.265 and made under the Family Law Act 1975.

Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No.4 standing in the name of Senator O'Chee for four sitting days after today for the disallowance of the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports)(OECD Decision) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No.283 and made under the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989.

Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No.4 standing in the name of Senator O'Chee for seven sitting days after today for the disallow ance of the Federal Airports (Amendment) By‐Laws No.1 of 1997 made under s.72 of the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986.

Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No.1 standing in the name of Senator O'Chee for thirteen sitting days after today for the disallowance of the Airports (Environment Protection) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No.13 and made under the Airports Act 1996.

Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No.2 standing in the name of Senator O'Chee for thirteen sitting days after today for the disallowance of the Airports Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No.8 and made under the Airports Act 1996.
I seek leave to make a short statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5, 18 and 26 March 1997, I reported to the Senate on the committee's concerns with these instruments, which related to discretions which may not be subject to merit review, possible infringement of personal rights without adequate safeguards, reversal of the usual onus of proof, defective procedural provisions, absence of the right to respond to adverse material, and defective drafting. The relevant ministers have now provided the committee with information which meets our concerns. The committee is grateful for this cooperation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the committee's correspondence concerning these instuments.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The correspondence read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Airports (Building Control) Regulations Statutory Rules 1996 No 292

SPEECH.PARA: 20 February 1997
The Hon John Sharp MP
Minister for Transport and Regional Development
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the Airports (Building Control) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1996 No 292. The Committee would appreciate your advice on the following matters.

Regulation 2.03 provides that in certain circumstances the airport‐lessee company must grant consent, grant consent subject to conditions or refuse consent, in relation to building approvals. This is a discretion with important commercial consequences which appears to be exercisable by a non‐government company with the decision reviewable by the AAT. Also, under r.4.01 the Secretary may appoint as airport building controller not only an authority of the Commonwealth, but also a State or local government body and, in specified circumstances, a corporation, a body or an individual. Regulations 5.02 provides that certain decisions of the airport building controller are subject to AAT review. Thus the Regulations appear to envisage that decisions of Commonwealth, State and local government authorities and bodies, corporations, bodies and individuals could all become subject to review by the Commonwealth AAT. The Committee asks whether there are any legal or administrative problems with this.

Although the rights to review by the AAT provided for by r. 5.02 are quite extensive, there appear to be a number of possible gaps. Regulation 2.13(2) provides the building controller with the discretion to allow building to be carried out without complying with the Australian building standards. Regulation 2.16 provides for amendment of a building approval by the building controller. Neither discretion is included in r. 5.02. Also, r.5.02 includes review of decisions made under rr.3.04 and 3.10 but not under the related rr.3.12 and 3.14. The Committee considers that all of these discretions should be subject to AAT review.

Regulation 2.11 deals with decisions by the airport building controller on applications for approval of building activity. Subregulation 2.11(6) places an effective limit on the time within which a decision must be made. The Committee suggests that it may be appropriate to apply similar provisions to other decisions made by the building controller under rr.2.16, 3.04 and 3.10.

The definition of `building approval' in r.1.04(1) refers to an approval under r. 2.14 when the appropriate reference may be to r.2.11. This appears to be confirmed by references in r.3.06 and Items 1, 2 and 3 of Part 1 of the table to r.5.02.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chairman

SPEECH.PARA: Minister for Transport and Regional Development
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee

Thank you for your letter of 20 February concerning the Airports (Building Control) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1996 No. 292. I agree with most of your suggestions and will be making amendments to implement them.

I note your comments in relation to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) of decisions under regulations 2.13(2), 2.16, 3.12 and 3.14, and agree that decisions under these provisions should be reviewable by the AAT.

I agree that time limits should be imposed on the making of certain decisions under the Regulations, because of the possible commercial impacts that failure to make timely decisions will have on applicants. I will seek advice on reasonable time limits to impose in regulations 2.16, 3.04 and 3.10, and have them amended accordingly.

You note an error in the cross‐reference in the definition of "building approval" in regulation 1.04(1). I will have this definition amended to cross‐reference to regulation 2.16 at the same time as the above mentioned amendments are made.

I propose to have these amendments made now that the Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997, which makes some amendments to the Airports Act 1996, has completed its passage in the recent Parliamentary sittings.

You have asked whether there are any legal or administrative problems with review by the Commonwealth AAT of decisions by public and private bodies and individuals. I am advised that this is a valid arrangement in terms of both legal policy and practice.

The Regulations put in place a system for the approval and certification of building and demolition works on Commonwealth‐owned and privately‐operated airports. This is the direction that approvals processes of this kind are taking in most fields and the States are adopting systems which allow relevantly qualified bodies and individuals to approve and certify buildings.

As "airport building controllers", the powers that relevantly qualified local government bodies and individuals would utilise are powers under Commonwealth legislation, namely the Airports Act 1996 and the Regulations. It is legally possible for the Commonwealth AAT to review decisions made by persons other than the Commonwealth if those persons are lawfully authorised to exercise powers under Commonwealth legislation (for example, see subsection 25(3A) of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975).

Contracts put in place with airport building controllers will require them to operate under the same legal principles and administrative procedures as are applied to the Commonwealth and its agencies, including merits review. This is standard legal policy and practice. Further, the performance of airport building controllers will be closely moni tored by my Department during the initial contract period (1 year).
Should you require further background on the above matters, I would be happy for Departmental officers to provide a briefing.
Yours sincerely
JOHN SHARP
4 April 1997

PARA.EMPHASIS: Bankruptcy Regulations Statutory Rules 1996 No 263

SPEECH.PARA: 20 February 1997
The Hon Daryl Williams AM QC MP
Attorney‐General
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the Bankruptcy Regulations, Statutory Rules 1996 No 263.

Regulation 15.06 provides that the Inspector‐General may terminate the membership of a member of certain statutory committees. This course of action may have serious consequences for the reputation of a member removed for the reasons in subparagraphs 15.06(1)(a) and (f), where a subjective judgment must be made about a person. The Committee would appreciate your advice as to whether a member is given a formal right to respond to any allegations before removal and whether written reasons for the removal must be given.

The Committee would also appreciate your advice on the drafting of r.16.11. Although the Explanatory Statement advises that the intention of the regulation is to provide for Administrative Appeals Tribunal review of decisions made under r.16.10, the regulation refers to decisions made under r.13.04(1). Thus, it would appear that the regulation does not cover the review of decisions under r.16.10.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chairman

SPEECH.PARA: The Hon Daryl Williams AM QC MP
Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice
26 March 1997
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee
I refer to your letter of 20 February 1997 seeking my advice regarding certain aspects of the recently tabled Bankruptcy Regulations.

You have asked whether a person removed from a registration committee has a formal right to respond to allegations that have led to the removal. While there is no special mechanism provided for in the Regulations, the general provisions of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act (AD(JR)Act) would apply to decisions of this nature. These provisions confer a right on a person affected by a decision to be given the reasons for the decision and to seek a review of that decision in Court.

I consider that the provisions of the AD(JR) Act are adequate to guarantee a formal mechanism for persons affected, by a decision to remove them from a committee, to air their concerns. However, as a matter of good administrative practice, any person who is removed from a committee will not only be provided with reasons for their removal but will be given an adequate opportunity to respond.

I note for the Committee that a decision to remove a person from a committee would not normally be made public as the committees are convened ad hoc to deal with specific applications for registration and do not continue on foot after this duty is performed.
With regard to the second matter you raise, I am pleased to advise that, as a result of the Committee bringing this to my attention, this typographical error will be corrected in the near future.
I trust the above advice is helpful.
Yours sincerely
DARYL WILLIAMS

PARA.EMPHASIS: Family Law Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1996 No 265

SPEECH.PARA: 20 February 1997
The Hon Daryl Williams AM QC MP
Attorney‐General
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the Family Law Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1996 No 265.

Regulation 21D provides for a laboratory accredited by the National Association of Testing Authorities to carry out parentage testing procedures in accordance with standards of practice that entitle the laboratory to be so accredited.

The Committee would appreciate your detailed advice on the process of accreditation. The Explanatory Statement advises of extensive negotiations, of concluded arrangements, of specified criteria, of evaluated standards of practice and of laboratories entitled to be accredited. In this context the accreditation of a laboratory appears to be a commercially valuable privilege. Also, the results of parentage testing are admissible as evidence in proceedings under the Act.

In particular the Committee would appreciate your advice on whether the NATA is a government body or a private organisation, on whether the Act permits giving NATA the authority to accredit laboratories, and on the nature of the arrangements, the criteria and the standards. Finally, what rights of review exist for laboratories which are refused the apparent commercial and financial advantages of accreditation?
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chairman

SPEECH.PARA: The Hon Daryl Williams AM QC MP
Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice
10 April 1997
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee
I refer to your letter dated 20 February 1997 and your subsequent notice of motion given in the Senate on 5 March 1997 regarding the Family Law Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1996 No. 265.

You have asked for my advice in relation to a number of aspects of the process of accreditation of a laboratory by the National Association of Testing Authorities (NATA) to carry out parentage testing.

The new regulations are intended to ensure that scientific and technical standards for parentage testing for use in the Family Court are such that parentage tests can be relied upon to have a high degree of accuracy. It is therefore directed to ensuring that recognition is based on appropriate scientific and technical standards.

NATA was established by the Commonwealth Government in 1947, and now operates as a non‐profit company incorporated in Victoria. NATA is recognised as Australia's national body for the accreditation of laboratories. An association of members, who are the nominated representatives of accredited laboratories, NATA is governed by a Council made up of nominees of Commonwealth and State governments, industry groups and the professions, as well as elected representatives of accredited laboratories.

Neither the Family Law Act 1975 nor the regulations themselves provide NATA with the authority to accredit laboratories. Rather, the regulations simply provide that a test carried out at a laboratory accredited by NATA in accordance with the standards that enable the laboratory to be so accredited are taken to be carried out in accordance with the regulations. The regulations therefore recognise the role of NATA in setting appropriate scientific standards and criteria for the carrying out of particular tests. The regulations do not purport to prevent parentage testing procedures being carried out by a laboratory which is not accredited by NATA. There could, however, be evidentiary difficulties and it would be necessary to prove, in such a case, that the test had been carried out in accordance with appropriate scientific criteria and standards, and that the procedures were such that the results could be relied upon.

You have asked about the nature of the arrangements, the criteria and the standards for accreditation of a laboratory as a parentage testing laboratory. NATA accredits laboratories across a wide range of scientific fields, including biological testing, chemical testing, electrical testing, mechanical testing, medical testing, optics and radiometry, and wool testing. I am advised that in order to be accredited, all laboratories must meet the criteria set out in the "General Requirements for Registration" booklet. A copy of this booklet is attached for your information.

In addition, requirements related to the specific field of testing are set out in supplementary documents for each field of testing. I attach a copy of the "Supplementary Requirements for Registration—Parentage Testing". I am advised that the criteria for accreditation for parentage testing were developed by a steering committee comprising six scientists from medical and forensic fields who held ministerial appointments to undertake parentage tests and prepare reports under the then regulations, a representative from NATA, and a lawyer from my Department. In addition, I am advised that all parentage testers holding ministerial appointments and working in the field at the time were consulted in the development of the new scheme.

As you will see from these 2 documents, the criteria for registration are directed to ensuring that an accredited laboratory can be relied upon to provide test results that are accurate and reliable. In order to ensure this, the general requirements for registration cover a range of matters including laboratory staff qualifications, equipment, maintenance of records, testing equipment and sample identification. The Supplementary Requirements for Registration—Parentage Testing provides specific requirements relating to technical aspects of the conduct of parentage testing, staff qualifications and training, test method validation, quality control, security and specimen management.

You have asked for my advice as to what rights of review exist for laboratories which are refused accreditation. I am advised that an applicant for registration is assessed by a team, comprising a NATA staff officer, and at least 2 specialist assessors, selected from the relevant field of expertise. Assessors may not be drawn from laboratories in competition with the applicant, and an applicant has a right of refusal in relation to assessors. I am advised that this method of assessment allows for assessment by peers who are technically competent, and who do not have a conflict of interest.

I am advised that the assessment covers all aspects of the laboratory's operation, and addresses each of the criteria set out in the 2 registration criteria documents. I am advised that NATA does not refuse registration on the basis of an unsatisfactory assessment. Rather in such circumstances the applicant is provided with a written report at the completion of the assessment, detailing which, if any, criteria are not met satisfactorily, and any remedial action required to enable registration to be granted. Should a laboratory disagree with the assessment, I am advised that if the area of disagreement cannot be resolved by discussion, a review by another assessor would be available.

I am advised, therefore, that a refusal of registration would be relatively rare. Rather, an applicant for registration is provided with information as to what action, if any, is necessary in order that it meet the criteria, and further assessment carried out once that remedial action has been taken.
I trust that this information meets the Committee's concerns. I would be happy to provide any additional advice should the Committee desire it.
Yours sincerely
DARYL WILLIAMS

PARA.EMPHASIS: Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports)(OECD Decision) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1996 No 283

SPEECH.PARA: 20 February 1997
Senator the Hon Robert Hill
Minister for the Environment
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) (OECD Decision) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1996 No 283.

Regulations 16, 23, and 29 set out matters which the Minister must consider when dealing with applications relating to hazardous waste. These provisions, among other things, require the Minister to be satisfied that the applicant is a suitable person to be granted a particular permit and that for these purposes the Minister must consider both the applicant's financial viability and previous record on environmental matters.

These are important matters and the Committee suggests that it may be appropriate for the Regulations to provide for applicants to be given notice of any adverse material received by the Minister under these two heads and to respond to it before a decision is made. The Committee accepts that the enabling Act includes wide review provisions but considers that the personal rights of applicants would be enhanced by such an amendment.

Similarly, rr.34 and 41 provide, among other things, for the Minister to revoke or vary a special permit if the Minister becomes aware that the applicant gave false or misleading information or did not disclose information that ought reasonably to have been disclosed. Here again it may be appropriate for the Regulations to provide for permit holders to be made aware of any adverse material and to respond to it.

The Committee was assisted by the helpful Note to r.43 about provisions in the enabling Act for review decisions. The Committee also noted the appropriate restriction in r.44 of the power of the Minister to delegate.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chairman

SPEECH.PARA: Senator the Hon Robert Hill
Leader of the Government in the Senate
Minister for the Environment
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
9 April, 1997
Dear Senator O'Chee

Thank you for your letter of 20 February 1997 on behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances regarding the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports)(OECD Decision) Regulations.

In your letter, you indicate that the Committee would like applicants for a permit under the above Regulations be given the opportunity to respond to any adverse material that I receive as the Minister before I make a decision to grant or refuse the permit.

While these Regulations were drafted to reflect as much as possible the principle Act, the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989, I have no objections to amending the Regulations as you have suggested. When assessing applications Environment Australia currently gives applicants the opportunity to respond to any adverse material to ensure that decisions take into account all relevant and accurate information. Amending the Regulations will give formal recognition to that process.
I have therefore instructed my Department to take the appropriate action to amend these Regulations as soon as possible.
Yours sincerely
Robert Hill

PARA.EMPHASIS: Federal Airports (Amendment) By-Laws No.1 of 1997 made under s.72 of the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986

SPEECH.PARA: 26 March 1997
The Hon John Sharp MP
Minister for Transport and Regional Development
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the Federal Airports (Amendment) By‐Laws No 1 of 1997 made under the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986 , which establish a series of public order offences.

By‐law 15J.1 provides that a person who, without reasonable excuse, proof of which lies on the person, acts in certain ways at a Federal airport, is guilty of an offence punishable by a fine of up to $500.
The Committee would be grateful for your advice on the reasons for this reversal of the usual onus of proof, which on its face may be a breach of personal rights.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chairman

SPEECH.PARA: The Hon John Sharp MP
Minister for Transport and Regional Development
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee

Thank you for your letter of 26 March in which you seek advice for the Committee on By‐Law 15J.1 of the Federal Airports (Amendment) By‐Laws No. 1 made under the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986.

By‐Law 15J.1 provides that a person who without reasonable excuse, proof of which lies on the person, acts in certain ways at a Federal airport, is guilty of an offence punishable by a maximum fine of $500.

The FAC has advised that the phrase "without reasonable excuse (proof of which lies on the person)" was inserted on the recommendation of the Office of the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP). Following your inquiry, the Commonwealth DPP has further advised that the phrase "proof of which lies on the person" is in fact unnecessary, as Section 14 of the Crimes Act 1914 would, in any event, have the effect of casting a persuasive burden of proof on a defendant with respect to these matters.
On this basis the FAC has offered to remove the phrase "proof of which lies on the person" from By‐Law 15J.1.
I trust that this meets the Committee's concerns.
Yours sincerely
JOHN SHARP
23 April 1997

PARA.EMPHASIS: Airports (Environment Protection) Regulations Statutory Rules 1997 No 13
Airports Regulations Statutory Rules 1997 No 8

SPEECH.PARA: 26 March 1977
The Hon John Sharp MP
Minister for Transport and Regional Development
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister

I refer to the Airports (Environment Protection) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1997 No 13, which provide for the environmental management of airports. The Committee would appreciate your advice on the following matters.

1. Regulation 1.08 provides that tests for the Regulations must be carried out by a laboratory accredited by NATA. The Committee would appreciate your detailed advice on the process of accreditation. As the accreditation of a laboratory appears to be a commercially valuable privilege, what rights of review exist for laboratories which are refused accreditation? Regulation 1.08 also provides that testing must be carried out in accordance with a method approved by NATA or, where no such method is approved, in accordance with methods approved for tests of that type by USEPA, the American Public Health Association or the American Society for Testing Methods. In contrast to those possibly changing approved methods, r.6.11(3)(b) and Schedule 4, 2.05(2)(a) and 4.01(2)(b)(i) and (iii), correctly provide for the incorporation of material as it exists at a particular date. The Committee asks why this was not done for the apparent incorporations in r.1.08.

2. Although some decisions made under the Regulations are subject to full AAT review a number of provisions set out in regulation 9.01 appear to provide only for review of discretions by the Secretary and not by the AAT. These discretions vary in importance, but some are significant. The Committee suggests that it may be suitable to provide for AAT review, even if a preliminary review by the Secretary is appropriate. In addition, some direct or implied discretions do not appear to be subject to any review, such as decisions under rr.2.01‐.04, 6.09‐.11 and 10.01. These include commercially valuable discretions. Here again, the Committee considers that it may be appropriate to provide for review by the AAT.

3. Subregulations 6.05(2)‐(4) provide in effect that an airport‐lessee company has a right of entry to an occupier's premises and access to any document, under the control of the occupier, with penalties for non‐compliance. These appear to be very wide powers, which even the police do not have without a warrant. Also, the provisions do not appear to include the usual safeguards under which the people entering must produce photographic identity passes. In addition, the people entering do not appear to be employees of the Commonwealth or a Commonwealth agency and therefore may not be subject to the safeguards provided under, for instance, legislation relating to privacy or the Ombudsman. The same considerations apply to entry under r.6.19. The Committee would appreciate your detailed advice.

4. Part 8, Division 2 provides for infringement notices. Some such system may be appropriate, but the provisions appear effectively to confer power on a non‐Commonwealth body to impose fines. In addition, regulation 8.03 does not appear to include the usual and necessary safeguard that infringement notices should advise that, if the fine is paid, then payment not only discharges the liability and prevents any prosecution for the matter, but also that the person concerned is not to be regarded as having been convicted of an offence.

5. Paragraphs 10.04(1)(a) and (b) provide that notices to people by, presumably, the Secretary or the airport environment officer, may be given by pre‐paid post. However, subregulation 10.04(2), which provides for giving notices or applications by people to the Secretary or an airport environ ment officer, does not include this concession, which may be unfair.

6. There are possible reference errors. Paragraph 6.06(1)(b) refers to a report in regulation 6.01, although subregulation 6.01 does not refer to a report. Paragraph 9.01(1)(d) also refers to a report under r.6.01(2). Schedule 2, 1.01 refers to the definition of `waters' in regulation 4.02, although it appears that this should be r.2.02(3). Schedule 2.1.02(1) refers to subregulation 4.02(1) but there does not appear to be any such provision.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chairman

SPEECH.PARA: 26 March 1997
The Hon John Sharp MP
Minister for Transport and Regional Development
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister

I refer to the Airport Regulations, Statutory Rules 1997 No 8, which implement a regulatory regime for Commonwealth‐owned and privately‐leased airports. The Committee would appreciate your advice on a number of matters.

First, r.2.02, which sets out grounds for refusing to transfer an airport lease, includes a number of subjective and vague expressions. Two provisions of r.2.02 are not only subjective but also confer a discretion upon the Minister. The Committee accepts that the enabling Act provides for AAT review of a decision not to approve a transfer and that this is an important safeguard, but would welcome your advice on why the provisions are so broad and subjective.

Second, r.2.03(2)(b) provides that, if an airport lease is terminated, the Minister may direct that the Commonwealth or a person nominated by the Minister be substituted for the former lessee. Although this appears reasonable, r.2.03(2)(c)(ii) then provides that the person nominated is not liable under the agreement for liabilities arising before the Commonwealth or person is taken to have become a party to it. The Committee would appreciate your assurance that this provision will not prejudice the creditors of a terminated airport‐lessee company.

Third, r.2.04(1) prohibits specified subleases and r.2.04(2) prohibits certain licences. In both cases, however, the provisions confer a discretion on the Secretary to permit a sublease (or licence) to a State or Territory government or an authority of a State or Territory government. These are commercially valuable discretions with no indication whether there is independent review of their merits.
Finally, there are three references in r.1.03 to `that Schedule' when defining Melbourne (Tullamarine), Brisbane and Perth Airports, although it would appear that `the Schedule' is intended.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chairman

SPEECH.PARA: The Hon John Sharp MP
Minister for Transport and Regional Development
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee

Thank you for your two letters of 26 March 1997 (cttee/53/97 and cttee/49/97), on a number of matters relating to the Airports (Environment Protection) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1997 No. 13, and the Airports Regulations, Statutory Rules 1997 No. 8. I agree with most of your suggestions and propose amendments to implement them. My comments are as follows (I have adopted your numbering for ease of reference).
Airports (Environment Protection) Regulations

1. The requirement at regulation 1.08 that testing for the purposes of the regulations be carried out by a laboratory accredited by the National Association of Testing Authorities, Australia (NATA) was based upon expert advice of the need to ensure tests can be relied upon as evidence. The regulations do not provide NATA with the authority to accredit laboratories. Rather, they provide that a test carried out at a laboratory accredited by NATA, in accordance with the appropriate scientific protocols and standards that enable the laboratory to be so accredited, are taken to be carried out in accordance with regulations. Non‐compliance with this regulation does not result in a sanction, it merely means the test is invalid for the purposes of the Regulations,.

NATA was established by the Commonwealth Government in 1947, and now operates as a non‐profit company incorporated in Victoria. The organisation is recognised as Australia's national body for the accreditation of laboratories. An association of members, who are the nominated representatives of the accredited laboratories, NATA is governed by a Council comprised of nominees of Commonwealth and State governments, industry groups and the professions, as well as elected representatives of accredited laboratories.

NATA is party to a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the Commonwealth (through the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism) in which the "Commonwealth recognises NATA as the national authority for accreditation of laboratories performing tests, measurements, calibration and related services to standards of good laboratory practice" (Clause 1.1). The Commonwealth has agreed that, "where it requires testing to demonstrate compliance with laws, technical specifications, regulations purchasing and similar instruments shall normally specify use of laboratories accredited by NATA" (Clause 3.4).

While NATA accreditation may be of commercial value, it is the only suitable accrediting agency in Australia and the criteria for registration of laboratories are directed to ensuring that an accredited laboratory can be relied upon to provide test results that are accurate and reliable. Should this change it would certainly be appropriate to amend this regulation.

You have sought my advice on the rights of review that exist for laboratories which are refused accreditation. I am advised that an application for registration is assessed by a team, comprising an NATA staff officer and at least two specialist assessors, selected from the relevant field of expertise. Assessors may not be drawn from laboratories in competition with the applicant, and an applicant has a right of refusal in relation to assessors. I am advised that this allows for assessment by peers who are technically competent, and who do not have a conflict of interest.

I understand that the assessment covers all aspects of the laboratory's operation, and addresses each of the criteria set out in the registration documents. I am advised that NATA does not refuse registration on the basis of an unsatisfactory assessment. Rather, in such circumstances the applicant is provided with a written report at the completion of the assessment, detailing which, if any, criteria are not met satisfactorily, and any remedial action required to enable registration to be granted. Should a laboratory disagree with the assessment, I am advised that if the area of disagreement cannot be resolved by discussion, a review by another assessor would be available.

I am advised that a refusal of registration, therefore, would be relatively rare. Rather an applicant for registration is provided with information as to what action, if any, is necessary in order that it meet the criteria, and a further assessment is carried out once that remedial action has been taken.

The Committee's advice that regulation 1,.08 should provide that testing standards should be those which were in force at the commencement of these regulations is noted, and the regulations will be amended accordingly.

2. The process of review by the Secretary under regulation 9.01 of various decisions of the Airport Environment Officer provides those affected by such decisions with a low‐cost, accessible initial administrative review process. This does not compromise or affect any appeal rights provided for under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975. To ensure that this is clear, regulation 9.04(e) specifically identifies decisions made by the Secretary under regulation 9.02(1) as being amongst those which are AAT `reviewable decision(s)' under Division 2 of Part 9 of the Regulations.

Your Committee also noted that some `direct or implied' discretions in the Regulations do not appear to be subject to any review, and that this affects some areas involving commercially valuable discretions. The initial selection of decisions which would be subject to AAT reconsideration was reviewed by the Civil Law Division of the Attorney‐General's Department. Following your advice I have requested a further review of the identified Regulations to be undertaken and the regulations will be amended to reflect its findings.

3. Under Division 2 of Part 6 of the Act, it is clear that the airport‐lessee company is to bear ongoing responsibility for the environmental quality of the airport. To satisfy that responsibility, it must monitor pollution and take steps to prevent, control or reduce the environmental impact of airport operations. These are generally operations conducted by other parties. The airport‐lessee company needs to have adequate powers to carry out these responsibilities.

There are a number of safeguards relating to the airport‐lessee company's right of access to a sublessee or licensee's site for monitoring purposes under regulation 6.05. These include a requirement for prior notification in writing and a `reasonableness' test. The regulation is merely intended to codify rights that an airport‐lessee company would have as head lessee of all airport land and is not intended to provide for additional powers. However, your points will be referred to the Attorney‐General's Department for advice.

You have suggested a link between regulation 6.05 and regulation 6.19. While the limited powers of access provided under regulation 6.05 would be exercised by a private entity (the airport‐lessee company), the powers to enter and perform remedial work on sites which are exercisable under regulation 6.19 rest solely with the statutory office‐holder known as the Airport Environment Officer (AEO). The AEO will be subject to a comprehensive framework of accountability, as set out in these Regulations and the Airports Act. As an appointee of the Secretary, the AEO will be required to comply with legislation relating to privacy and the Ombudsman.

4. The infringement notice penalty system provides an alternative and inexpensive means for a person accused of a contravention to dispose of the accusation. The ability to issue infringement notices under Part 2 of Division 8 has been limited to the statutory office‐holder (AEO), within this accountability framework, with the penalty paid to the Commonwealth. While the issues of discharge of legal liabilities and release from prosecution are dealt with in section 138 of the Act, I agree with the Committee's advice that an additional safeguard should be provided in regulation 8.03 covering immunity from criminal conviction (where the fine is paid) and propose to amend the regulations accordingly.
5. The inconsistency which the committee notes regarding the acceptability of giving notice under the regulations through pre‐paid post will be rectified through an amendment to this regulation.

6. The cross‐referencing and labelling errors noted by the Committee have been reviewed and changes to regulations 6.06(1)(b) and 9.01(1)(d), as well as clauses 1.01 and 1.02(1) of Schedule 2 will be made.
Airports Regulations

1. The grounds for refusing to transfer an airport lease set out in regulation 2.02 ensure that the Government's sale objectives used to assess the bids for airport leases will also apply to any transfers of those leases. The regulation aims to ensure that any subsequent airport‐lessee company will be able to meet the obligations of the lessee under the lease and will be able to effectively operate a key national infrastructure asset. Compliance with these obligations is a condition of the sale by the Commonwealth and it is important that these obligations continue to be borne by the airport‐lessee company. It is critical that the public interest objectives pursued in the sale process are not lost in any subsequent transfer of the lease.

Paragraphs (d) and (e) of the regulation aim to ensure that the company to which the lease is proposed to be transferred will be responsive to the environment, the region in which the airport is located and to the interests of airport users. These provisions have been drafted to confer a discretion on the Minister, on the advice of the Attorney‐General's Department, as the matters concerned would need to be considered in the context of the specific transfer proposal and may involve issues that could not be foreseen.

2. Paragraph 2.03(2)(b) has been drafted to ensure that in the event of an airport lease terminating, the Commonwealth has the widest range of options to keep the airport operating when it resumes the site. This includes taking over any airport‐management agreement, so that the airport‐management company can continue to operate the airport. Paragraph 2.03(2)(c) makes a number of modifications to this agreement that are designed to protect the Commonwealth, should it have to exercise these rights. It ensures that the Commonwealth does not become liable for management charges or liabilities other than those which relate to the period the Commonwealth is party to the agreement. This provision will not affect any creditor's rights or the normal legal options in relation to any obligations owed to a creditor by the airport‐lessee company.
3. The concern of your Committee about this discretion is noted and regulation 2.04(1) will be amended to provide for AAT review of decisions by the Secretary under this regulation.
4. The typographical errors in regulation 1.03 have been noted and the regulations will be amended accordingly.
Should you require further background on the above matters I would be happy for Departmental officers to provide a briefing.
Yours sincerely
JOHN SHARP
23 April 1997

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, this is the first occasion on which I have risen when you have been in the chair and I also congratulate you on your recent appointment. I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) the recent announcement by BHP that it will close its steelworks at Newcastle within the next 2 years,
(ii) that more than 2 000 employees will lose their jobs as a result of the closure, and
(iii) that this decision will have drastic consequences for the employees and their families, as well as for business and the wider community of Newcastle and the Hunter region;

SPEECH.PARA: (b) recognises:

PARA.TAB: (i) that the steelworks has been an integral part of Newcastle since 1915, and
(ii) that the workers of BHP Newcastle have, over all those years, contributed to the growth of the BHP group into a major and successful national and international corporation;

SPEECH.PARA: (c) believes that BHP and the Government have a responsibility to the work force and the community to assist them through these difficulties; and
(d) calls on:

PARA.TAB: (i) BHP to immediately negotiate with the unions representing the workers about its future at Newcastle, particularly employment opportunities, and
(ii) the Federal Government to implement appropriate labour market training and other support programs to enable the employees and their families to withstand this terrible decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the leave of the Senate to make a very brief statement in relation to general business notice of motion No. 525 standing in my name.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The notice of motion is in relation to the Senate's legislative program and sitting pattern. It has been there for a little while and there has been some discussion with the government. It is a problem, and it is a problem that has been recognised by not only senators and their staff but also the staff of the building. They find it very difficult, when there is a very heavy legislative program, to catch up, prepare amendments and prepare for debates so that we can operate efficiently when we are sitting in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an extremely important issue; it is not a minor issue. It also is extremely important to be able to keep in touch with your electorate in the interim weeks and especially, of course, if you are one of those people who cannot easily get home in the interim weeks—being from Western Australia, don't I know it!

I have discussed this issue with Senator Ian Campbell. He has indicated that he will table a copy of a letter sent to me which gives some guidelines, some indication that the government is taking on board those considerations and incorporating, where possible, fortnight sittings followed by a fortnight break. I thank Senator Campbell for that consideration. Hopefully, when I sit down he will table the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a copy of the letter I wrote to Senator Margetts yesterday, outlining the government's principles in relation to the setting of sitting patterns for the Senate, which does incorporate the principle that `two weeks on, two weeks off' is preferable, wherever possible.

PARA.EMPHASIS: In division—

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the Senate's attention to the standing order that says a senator shall declare any relevant interests as soon as practicable after a division is called for in the Senate. This matter relates to North Broken Hill and export woodchipping of rainforests from Tasmania.
—Thank you, Senator. When you rose I was just about to mention that there may be.
—Against the tide, I probably have shares that are somehow related to these matters. Against that prospect, I declare an interest.

—I certainly have some shares. All mine are disclosed in the Senate register of interests. I have no idea whether I have any of the ones you mentioned, but I do have some shares affected by woodchips.

—Madam President, I seem to recall that a short while ago Senator Short did write or address some remarks on this subject and about the necessity for senators to effectively repeat what is in their declaration of interests.
—He did, and Senator Gibson also made a speech about it. There has been no change to the standing orders at this stage.

—I am simply saying that my declaration of interests does, I think, disclose Amcor shares. I do not know whether people regard Amcor shares as being somehow relevant to woodchipping, but it just highlights, I think, the difficulty of anticipating what might be regarded as being somehow a tangential conflict, particularly because when you come into the chamber you are sometimes not even sure of precisely what is the subject matter of the issue. I am grateful to Senator Brown for drawing our attention to these issues but the fact—
—Well, you are welcome any time.
—I have declared earlier that I have trees which are destined for the woodchip market in some years time. I feel I should declare that as an interest.

—I must declare that, like Senator Troeth, I have some trees that maybe one day will make the grade. Seriously, I declare, as I have done before, including on my declaration of interests—I am not sure whether this matter relates to this—that I hold shares in Wesfarmers Cooperative and Wesfarmers Ltd. Bunnings is a subsidiary of those two companies. To make sure that I am covered I declare that particular interest, but I suspect in this case I do not need to.
—I assume that I still have shares in Boral, which were the subject of previous declarations of interests. I would not have a clue whether or not they are relevant, but if they are I declare them.
—At some future date I might be a purchaser or a user of a woodchip product, so I declare an interest.

—To end these successive farces, Madam President, could I suggest that on your authority you refer this sort of procedure to the Procedure Committee, maybe with a view that if it is declared as pecuniary interests we do not have to go through this farce every time and that only when the question is in doubt in someone's mind do they get to their feet.
—Thank you. That will be done.

—As Senator Alston said, I made some comments on this some time ago. From memory, it was referred to the relevant committee. A response was tabled in this place which refused to do what we had asked be done.
—It was referred to the Senators' Interests Committee, which reported to the Senate, recommending no change. But it will now be looked at by the Procedure Committee.
—Madam President, to help my deputy leader, could you indicate the nature of the motion before the chair?
—The motion is No. 545 in today's Notice Paper , which should be on every desk. It has been moved by Senator Brown. If you want all of it read out, I can ask the Clerk to do so.
—I can help, Madam President—
—No, I think it would be better if the Clerk reads it out rather than the Senate getting a precis.
—The motion reads:

PARA.TAB: (a) the Senate notes that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson), in consultation with the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), has given approval for North Forest Products to export woodchips from pure rainforest in Tasmania under a so-called `degraded forest licence'; and

(b) there be laid on the table, by the Minister for the Environment and the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Parer), no later than 12 May 1997, the following documents:

TAB.TAB: (i) all material held by the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories, the Australian Heritage Commission, Parks Australia—Wildlife Australia, and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy relevant to the application, assessment and approval of the application by North Forest Products for a degraded forest licence to export woodchips from the Surrey Hills Estate, Tasmania, issued on 28 February 1997,
(ii) advice provided to the Minister for the Environment or the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy relevant to the application, assessment and approval of this licence, and

(iii) in particular, all documents listed in paragraphs 14 to 38 inclusive of the statement of reasons under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 relating to the decision to issue the licence.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Brown's ) be agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Bolkus did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that general business notice of motion No. 543, standing in my name and relating to the logging of old‐growth forest in Western Australia, be taken as a formal motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I object. I deliberately missed the last vote by reason of the fact that this system of the government agreeing to a notice of motion going formal and then voting against it is a farce. It is a farce with regard to the Senate procedures and it is a farce because those of us who want to hear the arguments cannot hear the arguments.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the notice of motion by Senator Brown which was put forward as formal, it was agreed to by the government that it go formal. I was not aware that there was going to be a situation for that to take place. Had I been here, I would have refused the motion. I intend from here on in, if I happen to be in the chamber, to refuse every single request because I do not believe it is proper to have a situation where a notice of motion is declared formal unless the text of the notice of motion is agreed to throughout the whole of the chamber.

On this particular occasion I am sorry that it is Senator Margetts, because she is a stickler for the rules and her office does do their homework and provide information; but that is not the point. The point is how am I to make up my mind about those particular matters unless I can hear the arguments. That does not only go for those particular matters but, in my view, for every matter. So I put everybody on notice that that is the way I am going to go about it from here on in.

I do not think it is fair to the subject matter for matters to be determined outside of this chamber as to whether you are going to, under the whip, vote one way or you are going to vote the other way.
