I think there should be a proper discussion about the matters. There was no proper discussion about the matters with respect to the last matter—that was Senator Brown's motion—and there is not going to be able to be a proper debate on the matters on this particular issue.

Of course, it is entirely up to senators, when leave is denied, to seek suspension of standing orders. I understand why the government has taken this view. It wants to short‐circuit things; that is fair enough. But, so far as I am concerned, and I believe so far as other senators are concerned, we ought to be entitled to hear the arguments for and against a particular motion which we are bound to vote on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I do not disagree with anything that Senator Harradine has said. Last time we had this problem I approached Senator Harradine and suggested that, on a daily basis, we would approach him and advise him personally as to which motions we were prepared to allow to go formal and then to vote against. I am informed by the Parliamentary Liaison Officer that Senator Harradine was indeed contacted last night but had indicated to her that he was too busy to talk at that time. That is not an unusual thing; we are all very busy, and Senator Harradine is busier than most.
—That's not the point.

—I know it is not the point, Senator Harradine, but what I want to say is that I agree with you in principle. The government has made a decision that when an issue requires debate—some of these issues do require debate—we will often debate it. We made the decision, and you are within your rights to refuse formality. That is always a risk. You know we have an informal arrangement that we will tell you what we are doing. You always let us know what you are doing as well.

SPEECH.PARA: The matters raised by Senator Brown about returns to order in relation to anything to do with woodchipping are a weekly occurrence. Senator Brown has it marked in his diary that every week he is going to raise a matter to do with woodchipping. It usually involves a return to order in relation to documents. Quite frankly, to have a two‐hour debate or a one‐hour debate—or any debate, quite frankly—about whether or not it is in the Senate's interests, Australia's interests or anybody else's interests for the department of the environment or any other department to put together thousands of pages of documents is something that I do not think requires debate, quite frankly.

This motion is no different from the last 50 motions Senator Brown has moved; he has actually succeeded in getting this one through. I suspect that the motion in relation to logging in old‐growth forests is quite similar. I do not make any imputation against Senator Margetts, because she cares deeply about the issue. It is very similar to a whole range of motions that have been moved by Senator Margetts and others in relation to logging in old‐growth forests.

We made a decision that we do not need to put the government's position or any of our positions in relation to these issues any more. If Senator Harradine needs to hear debate, then he can exercise his right to refuse formality, which he has done today. We do respect that right. We say to the Senate that we seek to inform the whips how we will go in relation to all the motions where that is possible. For Senator Harradine's benefit I have put in place other arrangements which ensure that he is personally advised. That did fall down through a lack of communication overnight—we were not able to get in contact—but that can happen sometimes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Margetts moving a motion relating to conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 543.

There is no doubt about the urgency of this motion today. If we wait any longer we will see further destruction of a forest in Western Australia which is an interim listing on the Register of the National Estate. People in the community wonder just why we have those listings if they are ignored. It is urgent that we debate this. It is urgent that the message gets through. This message is coming back again and again to the parliament because it is happening again and again in our forests. It is very urgent that, in the case of the Giblett block, an area adjourning the Beedelup National Park, the level of concern within the community is brought to the attention of governments.

It is urgent for those people who think it is so important that they are currently in the forest, probably in miserable conditions, trying to save that which is dreadfully important to them. It is urgent for the thousands of people in the region whose jobs depend on the forests remaining old‐growth forests that the forests do not end up as glossy paper in Japan or Korea. It is urgent for them because that resource, that growing forest, cannot be plonked back together again. Their jobs are at risk. We are not just talking about the people at BHP—though that is a very serious concern. But how is it that, although there are thousands of people employed in the tourism industry in Western Australia, there are no top level summits? It is probably urgent that we do have top level summits about the implications for employment.

It is urgent that we should talk about how we can shift to a mechanism which will not continue acting in this unsustainable way. And, of course, it is urgent in relation to the ecosystem which will be destroyed in our lifetime. You cannot grow back an old‐growth forest—we have no example of that happening. The best that the Department of Conservation and Land Management can cite is what they call the 100‐year forest. Guess what? They are aiming to go into that again. Even though the forest is growing back, they are saying, `Give them leave to go back in again.'

It is urgent that we protect our national heritage. It is urgent because the chainsaws are in there now; sites have already been started. It is urgent because people are desperately trying to bring the situation to attention. They are desperately trying to stop the heavy equipment and the chainsaws in the middle of the forest as we speak. It is only fair that we bring this debate forward. If it is boring to the government to keep hearing these messages then it should stop the rot. Stop this dreadful desecration urgently. That is what I am here today to argue. Please let us have the debate. Please support this in the Senate. I urgently ask that this motion be passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the opposition, I indicate very briefly that the opposition will be supporting this motion of Senator Margetts which calls upon the Commonwealth to urgently intervene and force a halt to logging in the Giblett block in the karri and jarrah forests. We will be supporting the suspension of standing orders accordingly.

—I rise to indicate the Australian Democrats' full support for Senator Margetts's motion. I personally have been heavily involved in lobbying for the Giblett block. What is happening there is a tragedy: it is a tragedy on environmental, economic, small business and tourism grounds. The urgency that Senator Margetts has expressed is quite true. Once you have chopped down a tree that is it. It is permanent. It has gone from that area. I urge the Senate to accord with the remarks made by Senator Margetts and support her motion fully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I also support this motion by Senator Margetts. The Giblett block contains some of the most majestic trees on the face of the planet. These karri and jarrah trees are a remnant part of the world famous south‐west forests of Western Australia. I visited the Giblett block a couple of years ago when local residents and others were protesting against a previous round of incursions by the chainsaw brigade into these magnificent life‐filled forests.

SPEECH.PARA: It was apposite that just on dusk as I arrived for a walk in these forests the news broadcast in the car in which I was being ferried spoke about Premier Court's new regulations to punish youngsters in Western Australia who were involved in graffiti, defacing public buildings and so on. But here we were in a forest which the same Premier, who was outraged by visual graffiti in the city, was totally destroying at his own behest, as a legal matter, as something that apparently had no consequence as far as environmental aspirations are concerned. It highlighted the perverse view that the Western Australian government has towards this monumental natural asset in the south‐west.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I am not sure what motion Senator Brown is attempting to address but he certainly is not addressing the motion which relates to a suspension of standing orders. These remarks would probably be most eloquently put if this current motion before you is passed and we actually do debate the motion.
—Senator Brown, I have been listening and you are straying a little from the motion moved by Senator Margetts. I ask you to address yourself to the motion that she moved.

—Thank you. The point here is the urgency of the matter. Senator Campbell has so far refrained from addressing this issue at all and this would have passed without his contribution. It may not be urgent to him but it is urgent to Senator Margetts, it is urgent to me and it is urgent to those people who are sitting in the forests trying to defend those forests from the actions of the Western Australian government, the logging corporations involved and the inaction of Senator Campbell and this federal government.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a matter which ought to be debated and dealt with. This is a matter which requires action by the federal government, remembering, as Senator Margetts has said, this grand forest is on the interim Register of the National Estate. If this government means to do anything about its national responsibilities to the environment, surely it is going to defend the National Estate as adjudged by the Australian Heritage Commission. The reality of the situation is that we do not even have the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, in the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's not going to come in just to listen to you. He happens to be the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Do you expect him to be here all the time?

—He is very rarely able to face up to his environmental responsibili ties. He is absent. This is a critical matter because this is happening now as we debate the issue in this chamber. What Senator Margetts is trying to do through this motion is to get some fibre, to get some responsibility, to get some action into this government who otherwise must take total responsibility for the destruction which is occurring right now to these grand karri and jarrah forests in the Giblett block.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion is trying to stir them to action—and I am referring here specifically to Senator Hill, having responsibility as the chief environmental officer in the nation, and Mr Howard, the Prime Minister of this country and therefore in the most politically powerful position to defend the national monuments of this country. The reality is that those two gentlemen, far from levying the people of Australia, Western Australia and particularly those in the south‐west of Western Australia who would want to see these forests defended, are licensing the destruction which is occurring. They are actually the agents of destruction.

What Senator Margetts is saying through this motion is that here is a last chance to rectify the wrongdoing, here is a last chance for responsibility to seep back into the government benches, here is a last chance to back the 80 per cent of Australians who oppose the export woodchipping of these grand forests in Western Australia and elsewhere around the country where they are so threatened.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Margetts) agreed to:

That General Business notice of motion No. 543 standing in the name of Senator Margetts for this day, relating to logging and woodchipping, may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business this day till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—

PARA.TAB: (a) notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i) logging of old-growth Karri and Jarrah forests has begun in the Giblett block north-west of Pemberton, Western Australia,
(ii) this area is an interim listing on the Register of the National Estate, adjoins the Beedelup National Park and should be permanently protected from any logging activity,
(iii) woodchips from Giblett block were illegally exported in 1995 by Bunnings without any sanctions being imposed by the regulatory authorities,

(iv) there are currently community protest actions in the area being logged highlighting the outrageous decision by the Department of Conservation and Land Management to proceed with logging in this highly important area,

(v) the insanity of the current logging activity is highlighted by the felling of centuries old trees which shatter when felled, destroying both the important ecological contribution of such ancient trees and an important tourist resource, and
(vi) tourism employment in the Pemberton region has increased by approximately 600 per cent in the past 5 years, while employment in the timber industry continues to decline; and

PARA.TAB: (b) calls on the Commonwealth Government to urgently intervene and force a halt to logging in the Giblett block.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that there is a time in Australia's history when there are decisions being made that need to be responded to. The context of the situation in relation to the logging of old-growth karri and jarrah forests in the Giblett block north‐west of Pemberton in Western Australia is that the federal government is currently moving to throw away its responsibility to the environment, which includes the monitoring and approval of export licences for woodchips.

So we have a situation where the federal government think they can throw away responsibility for the environment, despite the fact that they use various federal powers in lots of different ways for taxing, exporting and so on when it comes to corporations. When it comes to the environment, they do not want to take that responsibility.

We are in the middle of a very big debate in relation to superannuation. There is no problem at all with the federal government getting involved with corporations. There is no problem with the federal government getting involved with telling you how to save for your retirement, what you do with your money and what you do in relation to corporations, taxing and so on. There is no problem at all with getting involved with issues right around Australia that affect various parts of Australia, but there seems to be a little part that says, `If it's to do with protecting the environment, we don't want to use these powers and we will pretend they don't exist or throw them back to the states.'

At this point, we need to make it very clear that, as we speak, this area of interim listing on the Register of the National Estate is not just being prepared for logging. They have already done groundwork and we are at the stage where people are risking their lives by actually setting themselves up in trees to try to save the forest because they believe it is so important.

I know people who live in and around the Giblett block who are very disturbed about losing their precious forest, that area that they love. That is why they live there. The area around the coast in the south‐west of Western Australia around Bunbury and so on is much more recognised these days as an industrial area. It is not really considered a country town anymore. It is another urban area. Bit by bit those areas of refuge, if you like, from city life become more and more precious to us.

But, as they become more precious to us in our urban environment, it means that those people who live in urban areas who need to seek the refuge of forests, who need to be able to remind themselves that life is not just about freeways and smokestacks, who need to be able to re-establish that connection with nature, are finding they want to go to those areas. Guess what? When they go there, they have to stay places, they have to eat, they then spend money at local businesses. In fact, far more employment is actually being created by people who are enjoying the forests in their natural form—that is, not in their glossy paper form.

Far more people in Western Australia are gaining employment in that source of the forest as a resource than they are putting whacking great logs through the woodchipper. It does not actually take a lot of people to put a forest through a woodchipper. You can watch it go through, and I have watched them go through. They are not talking about cut off branches. I have watched entire trees going through the woodchipper and it does not take a lot of people. It is not the same as industries which actually create highly value added goods.

There are people in the area around Pemberton—and there is plenty of information on people living in and around the area of Pemberton—who use the forest products, who use wood from the forests that has fallen down, who use all sorts of trees, including fruit trees, to make beautiful things that will last lifetimes. That is value adding, yet it is extremely difficult to even get hold of wood like Jarrah in Western Australia for those kinds of crafts, for furniture work and for those kinds of businesses which can employ lots of people.

It is difficult to get hold of those woods. It is difficult for those people who want to create employment, and often that is because what is left on the forest floor after a clear fell for woodchipping gets burnt. So, instead of allowing craftspeople to use that for value adding, it gets burnt.

So we are not talking about a choice between jobs or no jobs; we are actually talking about what is by far a very poor solution. It is particularly poor because the woodchips that you gain from old‐growth Karri is not even considered to be prime product by those people buying the goods. If you made a list from Nos 1 to 8, the woodchips gained from the logs of very old Karri would probably be about No. 7 on the list. They are not the preferred product of the industry. Because they are not the preferred product of the industry, they do not actually attract a particularly high price.

BREAK.PARA: They would prefer to use globular trees, Australian blue gums, which are grown in a number of places throughout the world. They are growing in South America, South Africa and various parts of Asia. These have been growing for some years now and it is well known in the industry that we are reaching the point where those crops are ready for harvest. The industry knows very well that they are reaching the end of the point where you will be able to push Karri logs off to the market and expect them to be bought. The prices of Karri logs will go down through the floor because they are not the preferred product and because plantations of Australian blue gums are now on stream in many places throughout the world.

We are seeing a very hasty exploitation of remnant old‐growth forests before the market dwindles. I have seen graphs from the Department of Conservation and Land Management which looked at how much was being cut. I asked them whether they understood what was meant by `ecologically sustainable production' and they said, `Yes, this is sustainable yield.' I said, `How come the graph goes along and then dives down?'—which is funnily enough around about now—and they said, `This is the yield that's sustainable this year and then we'll run out of those kinds of forests that are easy to get to and then that is the yield that's sustainable then.' I do somehow doubt whether they had a real concept of what sustainable yield was.

It is about looking into the future. Instead of blaming the greenies, instead of blaming the people who value the forest, perhaps they could have looked at themselves to see whether it was particularly wise planning for the industry, for those people who were employed in the industry and for the forests and those people who need the old‐growth forests for their employment, to be going along in that way so that you can stand and look at a woodchip mill and say, `Look, this particular mill is under threat for these four weeks if we don't have access to this particular coupe of old‐growth forests.'

How can you call an industry a sustainable industry when you must have access to a forest which is an interim listing on the Register of the National Estate or the industry or people will be put off? How can that be called in any way sustainable?

We have plantations of other kinds of trees in Western Australia. We have had, in my opinion, the Department of Conservation and Land Management sitting on their hands in many respects with regard to promoting agroforestry—that is, the ability to incorporate farm forestry and cash crops for farmers which they can use as their superannuation. There are lots of things that can be done. There are experiments being done to try to grow hardwood trees as cash crops in a fairly fast growing manner. There are lots of things that can be done and there are some things I know the Department of Agriculture is trying to do in Western Australia.

It is ironic that the Department of Conservation and Land Management are trying to attract funding for so-called salination projects when, in fact, they are just using their same programs over and over again. How can we look at what is happening in Western Australia, how can we see what is happening with old-growth forests and interim listing forests, which are valued not just by the people in that area but by people right around the state, and then say as a parliament that it is okay that the Commonwealth gives up that ability to be an overseer on whether or not states are doing the right thing in exporting woodchips or are doing the right thing with respect to greenhouse? Think of the greenhouse effect of cutting down old-growth forests. How much CO2 will a little seedling use up compared with a huge tree?

What is the current situation? I think we currently have people who are putting their lives on the line to try to save these forests. We have century old trees and ecosystems which are impossible to replace in anything like our lifetimes. It is impossible to think that it would be possible to replace ecosystems—the mixture of hollow logs, the mixture of trees that have fallen down, the mixture of the necessary underforest as well as the nesting places for birds and the places for other creatures to live—in anybody's lifetime, if you ever could.

Sometimes it is the little things within the ecosystem—the not so cutesy things, the not so warm and fuzzy things—that are just as important if not more important than those furry creatures which are often used on posters. You never get `Save the blue‐toed slug' campaigns because it is not going to catch the public appeal. However, sometimes it can be the blue toed slug—if there is one that exists—which is in fact the vital link within the ecosystem.

Funnily enough, some time later you will find situations with dieback where people try to find a nice little reason why things start happening, a nice little reason why the rest of the trees we have in our forests are dying back. Often the reason is a combination of reasons that we have been developing over time—that we have cleared too much around, that we have used too much clearance for farmland, that we have logged too much, or that we have left a remnant by itself.

So it seems to me that we have to take responsibility for species. We have to take responsibility for the ecosystems. We have to take responsibility for the people who rely on those natural systems for their livelihood and for the people who rely on those systems to be there to know with certainty—and isn't that an over used word—that that natural heritage that has been there for hundreds of years will continue to exist and not end up on the garbage heap of another country overseas as glossy paper, maybe not even used.

It is important that we stand up for what is right here. If it is boring for the government, I just hope that some of this message is getting through. The community no longer believes that it is acceptable. That is why it is necessary for us to put this motion today to the Senate. I urge all senators to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, I totally support what Senator Margetts has had to say. This is a vital issue. I think it is very remiss that the government is not responding to this matter. It is, after all, this government which has set the scene for—
—Who said the government is not responding?
—You aren't for one.
—I beg your pardon? Who is not responding? Why don't you tell the truth, Senator Brown—try very hard.
—Senator Campbell.
—Through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, I might tell the honourable Western Australian senator opposite that interjections are disorderly. He has the opportunity—

—I will manage the business of the chair, Senator Brown. I have already told you once, you manage your speaking and I will manage the business of the chair. I have called Senator Campbell to order, so proceed with your contribution.
—I will proceed with my contribution, but I hope it will be free of gratuitous interjections across the chamber. If I get those, I will respond to them. Having said that—
—Well try not to tell lies, Senator Brown.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I ask that Senator Campbell is asked to withdraw that statement.
—I was concentrating on what Senator Brown was saying. I did not actually hear what Senator Campbell said. If it was inappropriate, I would ask Senator Campbell to withdraw the statement.
—I did not say anything that requires a withdrawal, Madam Acting Deputy President.
—I suggest you withdraw it, Senator Campbell.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek your ruling. I said to Senator Brown, `Try to stop telling lies.' It was not accusing him of being a liar; it was asking him to undertake a manner of behaviour. If that is regarded as unparliamentary, I think it is an unusual ruling. I will, of course, respect it. But Senator Brown did say that the govern ment is not responding in this debate. I am ready to respond.
—Senator Campbell, would you resume your seat. I have been advised it is unparliamentary. I have asked you to withdraw it. You have withdrawn it.

—As I was saying Madam Acting Deputy President, we have heard far too little from the government in defence of the fact that it is actually the agent of this destruction. Senator Hill, who is absent from the chamber, has the environmental responsibility for protecting the grand forests of south‐west Western Australia. This Giblett block is made up of magnificent statuesque eucalypts—some of the tallest of hardwoods, and amongst the tallest flowering plants on the face of the planet—but they are being handed across to the chainsaws, mainly to be trucked to the woodchip depots to be sent to the Northern Hemisphere to be converted into paper and ultimately to end up on the rubbish dumps of countries on the other side of the world. That is the stream of action which this minister for the environment, Senator Hill, this Prime Minister, Mr Howard, and this government are designating for natural monuments of this nation of ours. It is an utter disgrace.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the best that can be done for these forests? It is left to citizens who feel in their hearts that they have to run the risk that Senator Margetts spoke about. They have to run the gauntlet of legal action and possible imprisonment to peacefully oppose the violence which this government has organised against these natural living forests, their panoply of species and the persistence, despite the odds against them, of rare and endangered species. These include the chudditch, the native cat, the red‐tailed black cockatoo, the numbat and a whole range of other species, to which Senator Margetts referred, which do not get such publicity because they are not in the same league as far as attracting immediate human sentiment.

Where is Senator Hill? Why isn't he here? Why has he got such disdain for a key component of the natural heritage of this nation that he does not feel that he even should come in here to defend his appalling record and his irresponsibility as far as the environment is concerned? What a disgrace this minister is. What a blight this is on the reputation of this country for environmental excellence. What a thumbing of the nose this is by Senator Hill and Prime Minister Howard to that 70 to 80 per cent of people in this nation who believe it is high time that we took a lead in the world as far as protecting wild forest is concerned, instead of being renegades amongst the developed nations and putting ourselves in league with the worst of deforestation in poorer countries or areas like Thailand, Papua New Guinea, Siberia and the Amazon.

That is exactly the league that Senator Hill and Prime Minister Howard put themselves in and they are flouting national sentiment on this matter. They are against what the majority of people in this country think about the defence of such grand forests as the Giblett block. It is those citizens down there today—trying to peacefully ward off the machinery that Senator Hill and Mr Howard have sent in—who deserve the accolades. Unfortunately, because the feelings of those politicians who have the power in this place are reflected by Premier Court and his government, it is the people who are doing the right thing and standing by the environment who face the penalty, who face the punishment, and who have to put up with the discomfort and the potential long‐term litigation in defending themselves for doing the right thing by the natural heritage. It is a pretty black spot amongst a pretty grey performance by this new government, which has so rapidly accrued such a rotten record of apathy at best and downright hostility at worst towards this nation's great, wild and scenic forest heritage.

We have the fastest rate of destruction of our wild forests in this country at a time when we have fewer of them left than ever before in history. That is the record of Senator Hill. That is the record of Prime Minister Howard. Australians did not vote for that. Sadly, they did not get much better previously out of the Labor government. But this government has gone from bad to worst.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Campbell, who is sitting opposite, tried to make some snide remarks about my getting up to bring this issue up in this place according to some diary. I will tell you what the diary is, Madam Acting Deputy President. It is his minister's series of regulations coming through this place to dismantle any checks at all to protect our forests, the wildlife and the public interest against those woodchip companies making a quick buck out of the destruction from which the forests can never recover.

Why shouldn't I respond? Why shouldn't we, who feel strongly about these forests, get up in this place and take this issue up to the government which is so remiss in allowing this destruction on the altar of a few dollars by Bunnings and other like companies, which have been caught in the act of illegal logging in the past and which would be able to get away with what this government now makes legal in an area that should be sacrosanct? It is an area that should be a national park and that should be celebrated by a government reflecting the feelings and the sentiments of the people of Western Australia and of this country as a whole towards these grand remnant forests of south‐west Western Australia.

It is disgraceful, appalling behaviour, by Senator Hill and it shows a lack of responsibility by Prime Minister Howard. It is the worst behaviour, I submit, considering that there are Western Australian senators in this place who will have seen this Giblett block—if they have not, they have a responsibility to do so because it has been a matter of contention for years. I take my hat off to the women and men who are doing their job for them against the odds that they have set up in the Giblett block in Western Australia. I totally endorse Senator Margetts's effort to try and get this government to do the right thing, instead of aiding and abetting this destruction which should have no place in the mind of a civilised society's government in 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take a different tack, if I may. I am aware that Senator Campbell has visited the Giblett block. I would like to focus on the Giblett block and the sur rounding area rather than the broader and very important issues already raised by other contributors.

SPEECH.PARA: I am aware, as Senator Campbell is, that there is debate within his own party as to the wisdom of the route that is being taken in a number of our forests. That debate is not carried out on purely environmental grounds; it is carried out on economic grounds. There are Liberals, and perhaps members of the National Party too, who believe that our old‐growth forests and our magnificent south‐west forests are worth more standing up than lying down, on purely economic grounds.

They are being chopped down by the organisation I refer to as Genghis CALM because they are both pillagers and conservationists. The trees are being chopped down far too cheaply and without any regard to their alternative use. The alternative use is not just their intrinsic natural beauty—all the eco‐ and botanical matters that Senator Margetts alludes to. Their alternative use is as a long‐term feature of human use, of human attachment.

The Giblett block is in an area of the south‐west which is experiencing greatly increasing tourism. We know that tourism in that area is a result of the natural environment. Visitors come there specifically because of the attractions of our forests and of our rivers and of the general environment. Chopping down all the trees in that particular area is not a particularly smart economic move, and I deplore it on environmental grounds. But on economic grounds it is one opposed by tourism and small business, who have strongly pleaded with the Western Australian government not to carry on the activities that are going on there.

There is a proposal which has been put before the state government, which has sought to enlarge the national park there, which is some 1,700 hectares, my memory tells me, to about 19,000 hectares and bordering the Donnelly River. That would then take in the Giblett block. That would relieve the stress of nearly 70,000 people currently visiting that small national park and would provide an opportunity for a significant growth in tourism and in facilities in the area.

BREAK.PARA: I am also advised that the total economic value that will be generated as a once‐off from that destruction of the Giblett block will be about $3 million. That is not a sum of money which is to be sneezed at, but it is certainly not the value that should be gained from leaving those forests alone and allowing them to be developed and used in a tourism manner and in a long‐term sustainable national park.

Unfortunately, the conflicts that have arisen in this issue are those between very strong backers of very strong factions within the coalition government of Western Australia, and the alternative forces of those who wish to preserve and protect the Giblett block on both environmental and economic grounds. It is for that reason that I plead with those members of both this government and the Western Australia government who hold an alternative view to continue to argue for that view, particularly with regard to this particular block.

I know that members across the chamber feel very strongly and somewhat aggrieved about the entire woodchipping and forestry argument but this particular debate, this particular motion, is about the Giblett block. It is about a small area which we are trying to get preserved. I have the plans if any of you need to see them. In fact, I recall tabling them in the parliament. The proposal has been prepared on very sound grounds. I would like those of you who are strong supporters of the woodchipping and forestry industry to set that issue aside and just look at the preservation of the Giblett block. I urge you to support Senator Margetts's motion.

I close by complimenting Senator Margetts. She has argued very forcefully and very fully for this motion in a manner which, I believe, puts the case very clearly. I hope my remarks add to the strength of support for her motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few remarks in regard to Senator Margetts's motion, more on the point of the proposal that the government has been pursuing over the removal of export controls on woodchips and what that will actually lead to. The minister has commented on this on a number of occasions and, in a most recent report in a local paper in Tasmania, he said that the removal of such export controls would lead to greater employment generation, greater investment et cetera.

SPEECH.PARA: That was in part looking at the granting of a licence, which was put up in a previous motion by Senator Brown that related to some private forest at Surrey Hills south of Burnie which was granted a degraded forests licence. The unfortunate thing about that, which I believe also has some connection with what happened in WA and I suppose has, in part, led Senator Margetts to moving her motion, is that the particular forest in Tasmania, by way of example, is rainforest and did contain sawlogs. The company, North Broken Hill, did call tenders for the processing of those sawlogs. There were tenders put in with the company.

To the best of my knowledge and from what I have been able to ascertain, the company never responded to any of those tenderers. Indeed, one of the tenderers rang up to see whether or not their tender had been successful or otherwise. At that time they were asked, `How much timber do you wish to purchase?' From memory, it was 11,000 cubic metres per annum of myrtle and sassafras timber, which are rainforest species, that they wished to purchase. The company, North Broken Hill, replied, `Sorry, we're not interested; that's not enough.'

That tenderer would probably have provided about 35 jobs in the Burnie region. The timber would have been processed into solid timber pieces right down to a finished product and exported to Japan at around $5,000 per cubic metre. Now the timber from that area will be woodchipped and probably sold off to Japan for somewhere in the order of $150 per cubic metre.

It is these sorts of things that have to be and should be of significant concern. I can remember when we debated the disallowance motion on the regulations relating to export woodchip controls. I made some points about how woodchip export companies come along every year with a plethora of proposals for downstream processing in Australia. I made the point at that time in a plea to Senator Harradine, in part, and Senator Colston in the hope that they would vote against the government's proposed regulations for export woodchips because they simply did not protect employment or provide for employment generating investment in this country.

I said at the time that one particular company, namely Boral, had on the table some $160 million worth of projects for Tasmania. I said at that time that I believed that that company would ultimately withdraw all of those projects. Having said that, I received a fairly vigorous letter from the manager of Boral accusing me of misleading the public and saying that I should actually apologise. They sought for one of their officers to visit me here in Parliament House and to put the record straight and to actually give me the facts and to say that they were committed to these proposals. I wish I had brought the letter into the chamber to read it.

I will refer to another newspaper report of 20 March 1997. It is headed `Timber giant scraps plans for $160 million mill'. I have not had any more phone calls from Boral. I have not had any explanation from Boral as to why they are not proceeding with those developments that would have created a significant number of jobs for Tasmanians. I would suspect that some companies in Western Australia—I note that Bunnings could be one—export woodchips without a licence and this poses a very interesting question. I can recall when we were in government that a person who exported one boatload of woodchips suffered significant financial cost as a result.

It seems to me that the coalition government is bending over backwards to serve these major companies who have no interest whatsoever in downstream processing in this country. The Commonwealth government really has only one power—that is, the Export Control Act. It can actually force some change on this industry. It is an essential change. I say that in particular in relation to my own state because we do not have too many things going for us down there at the moment. We have seen Coats Patons close and we saw Stanley Tools close. We have the ships bounty that looks like being scrapped by the current government. That would possibly lead to the closure, at least a significant downgrading, of Incat, which is one of the major employers in Tasmania.

We do have an industry in the state that has real potential. But it will only have potential if governments, particularly at a Commonwealth level, take decisions that give the right sort of encouragement. If the encouragement is not there, they need to take the stick out and force the change because there are people out there who would like to invest in the timber industry in this country, turn it into a much better industry than it is and provide much greater employment than it does.

Whilst I do not agree with all of the points in Senator Margetts's motion, I do believe that it draws to the attention of the parliament some very important points. I propose an amendment to Senator Margetts's motion. It has not been distributed, but I will read it out. It would go at the end of (b), which says:
. . . calls on the Commonwealth Government to urgently intervene and force a halt to logging in the Giblett block.
I would then add the words:

. . . until assessments are made on whether or not the logging is in breach of the Regional Forest Agreement process and whether or not the timber harvested from such forests is being utilised in a way that maximises the employment opportunities in the Pemberton region of Western Australia.

I do that because of the very points that I have just made. I may not have the same sentiment and may not agree with some of the pursuits of Senator Margetts with regard to forests, but I do believe that if we cut trees down we ought to ensure that the maximum benefit—both socially and economically—is achieved by this country. That certainly is not the case at the moment. Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek your guidance in regard to what I have just proposed as an amendment, whether I can do that and whether it has to be circulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —We need it in writing, we need it signed and we then need to circulate it.
—I have it in writing, and I will sign it. I move:

BREAK.PARA: At the end of paragraph (b), add "until assessments are made on whether or not the logging is in breach of the Regional Forest Agreement process and whether or not the timber harvested from such forests is being utilised in a way that maximises the employment opportunities in the Pemberton region of Western Australia".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay the Senate for too long. I think these are issues that are important to debate. I know that they are issues that are taking up an enormous amount of time of the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, part of the reason we are debating this issue today is that processes that are put in place to ensure the orderly management of the Senate have not been observed. One such process is that at whips meetings members of parties, minor parties and Independents are encouraged to inform other members of the Senate what they are likely to do, particularly in relation to matters like notices of motion.

The message we received—second‐ or third‐hand, as Senator Margetts was not at the whips meeting last night—was that it was likely that this motion would be deferred. That did not come from Senator Margetts, because she was not there; it came through another source at the meeting. The best they thought would happen was that it would be deferred. If the whips, and therefore members of other parties, are informed that you intend calling the motion formal, other people can make informed decisions as to whether they would allow formality—and, therefore, the motion would be put without a vote—or refuse formality, and then risk a suspension of standing orders. It also gives the party the chance to allow the motion to be called on in general business.

The coalition's best advice, through our whip Senator Calvert—and it was not good advice; Senator Calvert admits that it was through second‐hand sources—was that you were to defer the motion. As I said to Senator Harradine, these breakdowns in communication can occur. It is very hard, I know, par ticularly in your own position at that end of the chamber. Senator Harradine, as you were involved in the superannuation debate virtually all day yesterday—as I was—you would realise that it is often hard to get messages backwards and forwards.

I am sure that, if Senator Hill could be here to debate this matter, he would. I am here both as the Manager of Government Business and as a former parliamentary secretary to the Minister for the Environment. I had a very close involvement with the Minister for the Environment in the months between the election and the middle of November when I was transferred to Treasury. I took the opportunity—indeed, I saw it as my responsibility—to involve myself as closely as possible in the forest issues, particularly in my home state of Western Australia.

I agree with Senator Bob Brown about the importance of all members of the parliament, particularly Western Australians, visiting the south‐west forests. I encourage all people of Australia, if they have the opportunity to come across to Western Australia—encouraged by people like Elle McPherson, I suspect—to travel south. It is a magnificent part of the world. It is a long way away from the rest of the world, and that in many respects is a way in which the environment is protected.

While I am referring obliquely to the tourism aspects of that region of the world—which I know is very close to Senator Murray's heart—I should mention that I took the opportunity, in preparing to debate his motion on the Greater Beedelup National Park late last year, to get some figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics in relation to tourism in that region. I will not incorporate or even table this document, because it is all over the place, but if Senator Murray or other honourable senators want to get information about tourism in that region, the ABS publication that applies is ABS Cat. No. 8635.5. It relates to the number of guest arrivals and commercial accommodation in the shire of Manjimup.

The document may not be all that encompassing for the south‐west, but it certainly relates to the region where the Giblett block, the Greater Beedelup National Park and the other magnificent areas of old forest are nearby. The figures show that, between the years 1986-87 and the latest year for which we were able to get figures, there has been close to a doubling in the number of tourists travelling to that area.

Having visited the area over Easter—I do not know whether this is due to CALM or good management or whatever—I noticed that there was an incredible number of people. I was quite pleased to see that, because of the infrastructure and because of the way businesses are developing down there, it seemed—particularly in the Margaret River through to Pemberton area—the area was able to cope with that tourist influx. I guess Easter would be a fairly heavy time for people travelling down south in Western Australia. It did not seem to be inconvenient anywhere we went.

I do not know how much tourism activity we can take in the south‐west without putting pressure on both the infrastructure and, most importantly, the environment. I am sure that the many small businesses and tourist operators in the Pemberton, Manjimup and south‐west region would love to see more and more tourists visit the region so they can share in the delights of south‐west Australia.

I make the point because many commentators, Senator Murray, Senator Brown and Senator Margetts have on occasions said that you really have to protect all of Giblett block or all of the old‐growth forests in that area to ensure that tourism is viable. The figures on native forest harvesting in that area, particularly in relation to jarrah and karri, show that the harvesting that is taken on there has stayed almost constant—it goes up and down year on year, but in terms of the amount of forest area that is harvested from 1986 to 1995 it has remained constant.

Again I refer to the source of the figures rather than table this document. The source is the CALM 1995-96 annual report. It shows that the areas harvested do fluctuate up and down, but the total amount of karri and jarrah forests felled has for all statistical purposes stayed fairly constant.

BREAK.PARA: I will pluck some figures out to make my argument more cohesive. For example, in 1996, 19,340 hectares of jarrah forest and about 1,090 hectares of karri forest were felled. In 1989, 15,000 hectares of jarrah—give or take a few hectares—and about 1,500 of karri were harvested. In 1994, about 14,000 hectares of jarrah and about 1,400 hectares of karri were harvested. So there were fairly consistent levels of harvesting of those native forests, but in the meantime tourism nearly doubled—from 66,000 to over 116,000. The point I am making in a tortuous way is that tourism potential—that is, the broadening of economic activity in the region—and native forest harvesting are compatible. One does not exclude the other.

That brings me to the Giblett block. It is a very important part of that region. I had the great pleasure of visiting the area with Roger Cheeseman. Senator Brown referred to the people who were fighting to save the forests in the south-west as great Australians. I share his sentiment particularly in relation to Roger Cheeseman. I think he is a great Australian. I also think he is very dedicated to his cause and that he is a most reasonable man.

As far I can, I have tried to keep lines of communication open between him and the Minister for the Environment, both in Western Australia and in Canberra. I am sure that we will never deliver everything that Roger wants nor deliver everything that the Greens (WA) would want in relation to Giblett block.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're supporting the motion, are you? All this leads to you supporting the motion, does it?

—No, it does not. I am just about to say why this motion does not help either Western Australia or the cause. I am trying to say that it is compatible to have tourism operations and a whole range of other activities in the south-west of Western Australia with native forest harvesting. The reality, which you would not be able to glean from what has been contributed to the debate to date, is that, under the deferred forests agreement, something like 4,000 hectares of Giblett block have been set aside and that 460 hectares in the Giblett block—about an eighth of the whole block—will be available for logging.

BREAK.PARA: The other point honourable senators should be aware of is that the comprehensive regional assessment process that is being undertaken in south‐western Australia is designed to move that part of Australia into a reserve system which will create a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system—which is the CAR acronym. The aim of that is to create a world-class forest reserve system. Its aim is to look at all of the factors—scientific factors, biodiversity factors, all of the various attributes of forests and their ecosystems—and to create a comprehensive system across Australia—in this case, in Western Australia—to bring about a preservation of 15 per cent of pre-1750 distribution of forest communities.

Quite contrary to what Senator Brown said about making Australia an international pariah in relation to protecting forests and wild forests, that puts us 50 per cent above the IUCN's benchmark. As Senator Brown would know better than just about everybody else in this place, that benchmark was that you should save 10 per cent of those forests. Australia has sought to preserve 15 per cent—50 per cent higher than the international standard. Senator Brown may wish to see 100 per cent or a much higher level achieved, but to say that Australia's forest management systems and the Commonwealth's way of trying to coordinate them between the states make us an international pariah is simply not accurate.

The system, which we believe will create a world-class forest reserve system, will also achieve 60 per cent protection of old growth, 90 per cent protection of wilderness and 100 per cent protection of rare and endangered plant communities. They are the objectives. To get back to the mandate argument that Senator Brown put into his contribution, they are objectives that were set out quite clearly in the coalition's policies before the last election. We said that we supported the national forest policy statement. We said that we would proceed down this track of doing a comprehensive, scientifically based analysis of the forests.

Regional agreements will allow for sustainable use of the forests for generations into the future. That will be an incredible achievement when it is pulled off by the Minister for the Environment and his state colleagues. It will see an outstanding set of agreements and arrangements in place to protect forests in perpetuity and to ensure that business and harvesting can take place at the same time.

That process is tedious. It requires an enormous amount of work on the ground, an enormous amount of work in negotiations with the industries, conservation groups, scientists and state governments. But we do hope to achieve it.

I do not want to hold the Senate up any longer but, before concluding, I would make these remarks. This process was put in place by the previous government. Therefore, I would be very surprised if opposition senators were to support a motion which effectively condemns a policy that was established by Paul Keating when they were in government. The Keating government sought to negotiate a regional agreement in this area with the Court government, but failed to do so.

That agreement was put in place within about four months of this government coming to power. It ensured that significant areas were deferred from logging activity. Indeed, when Minister Cheryl Edwards in Western Australia announced recently the fact that logging would proceed in this relatively small part of Giblett block—and I will put it in context: of 4,000 hectares, just over 460 hectares are to be logged—she announced the protection of a further 10,000 hectares of forest in the Blackwood valley, pending assessment under this process. And I did not see Senator Brown getting up in the Senate and congratulating Minister Cheryl Edwards for making that announcement.

In conclusion, Mr Acting Deputy President Murphy, I state that the coalition will not support the amendment you have moved. I am informed that logging is occurring in only one-third of the block, which is allowed under the deferred forest agreement and the voluntary agreement and, therefore, it is fully in accordance with the RFA process. So that makes your motion somewhat redundant.

We will be opposing the motion moved by Senator Margetts. We believe that it is quite possible to have logging take place within the Giblett block and still preserve the very important biodiversity and other qualities of that forest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —In winding up this debate, I would thank all of those senators who have participated in it. I did not necessarily expect there to be a debate. I would apologise in relation to the whips meeting. Yes, I was in the chamber and, as to our lateness in advising people, we obviously circulated the motion asking for support for formality. But our lateness in advising was due to the fact that it really, literally, was not until I got to the chamber that I found out whether or not the opposition would support the motion. So I do apologise for not giving earlier notice; it was not intentional.

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator Campbell) gave some interesting figures: 460 hectares out of around 4,000 hectares. He also gave some figures for the logging of Giblett jarrah and karri over the years of 1986 to 1994. It does not take too much maths to work out that, if you were to log a 4,000‐hectare block at 460 hectares a year, within 10 years you would have no block left.

So it is an important area, and Senator Campbell has agreed that it is an important area. But even at over one‐tenth of that important area being logged a year, it does not take 10 years to get rid of the whole lot. What does that mean for those in the tourism industry? They do not accept the fact that they should put up with more than one‐tenth of their precious resource going each year. They are just watching with horror and grief.

And it really is a grieving process when people realise that we are speaking of trees that have been growing for hundreds of years—trees that were growing as forest way before European settlement of Western Australia. That is what we are talking about. There is very little that can console people with that form of grief when they see these sorts of figures being thrown around and they are told, `Don't worry, it's only 460 hectares out of a 4,000‐hectare block.' That is a terrible thing to say to people who actually believe they are part of their environment and the land around them.

I would indicate that Pauline McLeod from the South‐West Regional Tourism Association has issued her own statement condemning the logging in Giblett. Obviously, she does not share the confidence of Senator Campbell that, in fact, this level of logging is not damaging the tourism industry. Personally, I do not know that we should aim for lots more tourism; we should aim to have a properly managed tourism industry, like any industry. However, we are talking about an existing industry that already employs thousands of people, so we are talking about resource security for those people who already exist and work in the industry.

As mentioned in the motion, in 1995 woodchips from the Giblett block were exported illegally by Bunnings, and there were no sanctions. One wonders whether or not the companies involved in Western Australia feel that they can do whatever they like, despite the ecological implications—and sometimes despite the legal implications—if governments will not act. This is the challenge that exists right now.

Of course, 1995 was a different government. Therefore, this government can show their spots and say, `Okay, this is what we're going to do: we're going to go in and say, yes, if it's an interim listing on the Register of the National Estate, destroying more than one‐tenth a year of a forest that takes, by conservative estimates'—if you ever could replace it—`150 years to develop its values to the extent they can even support parrot life'—for heaven's sake—`then we have to say that this is not in any way, shape or form under anyone's definition sustainable.'

The mention of Manjimup and Roger Cheeseman was interesting because there are people who obviously are very, very concerned about their future employment in the area. But there are areas like Pemberton where you have the Gloucester tree which, for some reason, has been pulled out of use. Some people unkindly suggest that the reason the Gloucester tree is not being used as a tourist resource any more is that, when you go up the Gloucester tree, you can see how much destruction there has been to the surrounding forest. So you cannot take tourists up there. It is not like the side of the road where you can have tourists driving along, observing a relatively narrow band and thinking that they still have forests. If you go up the tree and look from there, you can find out how much is being destroyed. This cannot be replaced in the near future. So, yes, the resource that this industry needs is being destroyed in front of their eyes.

Perhaps Senator Campbell might like to talk to, if he has not already done so, Pauline McLeod from the South-West Regional Tourism Association. People are having to cope with grief. I understand people are concerned about their future in relation to the forest industry.

I have always been willing to talk to groups—perhaps meetings of shop stewards—in relation to the industry. In the south-west we have had some meetings with people from the community, but so far I have never had a meeting where there has been access to the people who represent the workers in the industry and been able to talk to them, listen to their concerns and answer their questions. I would be very happy to do so.

I know that Dr Christine Sharp, a newly elected member of the Western Australian Legislative Council who represents the south-west, is also vitally concerned about issues relating to the environment and employment in that region and would like to do that. In public I put on notice that I would love to face a room full of shop stewards from, for instance, the forest products union in the south-west and talk through the issues and about their future, what lies ahead and ways we can all work together for a more sustainable future in the south-west.

Senator Murphy's amendment deals with `until assessments are made on whether or not the logging is in breach of the regional forest agreement process'. I understand what is behind Senator Murphy's amendment. I also understand that the RFA process in Western Australia is considered to be very problemat ic. The environment movement have, in large part, pulled out of the forest assessment process is Western Australia. That process has two parts: an advisory committee, which is largely ignored in the process, and a main committee. And guess what? Neither tourism nor the environment movement are part of that main committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nor is small business.

—Nor is small business, as Senator Murray has indicated. If a process is looking at the impacts on industry, surely it must involve industries that have some connection with the forests concerned. Even the wine industry could have because the people who come down to see the forests also go to the wineries to buy a bottle of wine—and they do other things at the same time. For some reason tourism, small business and the environment movement have been cut out of that process.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an assumption that there is only one industry that is important, and this is not necessarily the industry that is creating the most employment in the region. We are talking about the need for resource security in the industry, yet a whole lot of people have been cut out of the process. The process is certainly flawed. I would find it difficult to go along with `until assessments are made on whether or not it is in breach of the regional forest agreement process' because I know that from many people's viewpoints the RFA process in Western Australia is in deep trouble. We would like to see something done about that.

The second point is `whether or not the timber harvested from such forests is being utilised in a way that maximises the employment opportunities in the Pemberton region of Western Australia'. Of course, 460 hectares a year coming out of a 4,000 hectare block will not employ many for very long anyway, so I find it difficult to support that as a particularly value-adding prospect.

I believe we should look at the many ways—and I have indicated this in part to Senator Murphy—we can create employment and value add in the forest industry and timber industry in Australia, especially in relation to timber products. That needs to be worked up. I would be happy to work with Senator Murphy or other senators to put a motion on that issue to the Senate in the future. I do not think this will help if the government is, through the Department of Conservation and Land Management, unsustainably harvesting this forest, as it obviously is, because there will be no jobs, sustainable or otherwise, for this forest in the future.

I thank once again those people who participated in the debate. I would like to think that the Commonwealth will heed the call not to dodge their responsibilities in the forest process and that this debate has enabled some of those issues to be aired. I hope it will not stop here and there is still a chance of saving Giblett block in Western Australia.
Amendment (by Senator Murphy) negatived.
Motion (by Senator Margetts) agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That the Senate—

PARA.TAB: (a) notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i) on 30 April 1997, Mr Kim Young, Mr Steven Evans, Mr Tony Kelly and Mr Peter Ballard were arrested by police and removed from land which is part of the property of the Western Australian Parliament House, and have been charged with the offence of unlawfully remaining on the premises, based on a complaint by a parliamentary officer,
(ii) the above four persons, along with thousands of Western Australians, had been at the State Parliament House protesting against State Government amendments to the State Industrial Relations Act,
(iii) at all times and in the case of all individuals their protest had been dignified and peaceful, and
(iv) the Federal Parliament has long recognised the right of proper and peaceful protest;

PARA.TAB: (b) believes that peaceful protest is the right of all citizens in a democracy and an appropriate place to express that protest is on the grounds of the Parliament, in particular, when the Parliament is dealing with legislation against which the protest is directed;
(c) declares that, if the right of peaceful protest is lost, then the quality of democracy in Australia is degraded; and
(d) calls on the Western Australian Parliament to instruct its parliamentary officer to withdraw the charges.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 7 May 1997, from Senator Chris Evans:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to standing order number 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The failure of the Western Australian State Government to appoint Ross Lightfoot to replace the late John Panizza, which is motivated by nothing more than political expediency and is a desperate attempt by the Court Government to pass oppressive industrial relations legislation before the will of the people as expressed at the December election is reflected in the composition of the Western Australian Legislative Council.
More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific time for each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clock accordingly.
—On behalf of Senator Chris Evans, I move:

BREAK.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The failure of the Western Australian State Government to appoint Ross Lightfoot to replace the late John Panizza, which is motivated by nothing more than political expediency and is a desperate attempt by the Court Government to pass oppressive industrial relations legislation before the will of the people as expressed at the December election is reflected in the composition of the Western Australian Legislative Council.

I, of course, speak in favour of this matter of urgency. The editorial of the West Australian newspaper today, a newspaper not noted for its Labor sympathies, was headed, `A cynical and autocratic decision'. It said, and I quote in part:

The Court Government is tossing parliamentary convention on the scrapheap and wrecking its credibility as a fair-minded government by ruthless ly ramming its industrial relations legislation through the Upper House.
It goes on and describes this as `a breathtaking display of arrogance and contempt for the people's vote in December and for the proper role of the council as a house of review'. Further, it says:

The Government's contempt for what is proper procedure is further illustrated by its decision to keep Senator-elect Ross Lightfoot in the Legislative Council long after convention says he should have resigned and gone to the Senate. The only reason is that it needs his vote to beat the May 22 deadline.
It goes on:

The Court Government—elected by voters who wanted to restore integrity and quality to the State's political and financial systems—is the only government in the history of the Upper House to use the guillotine.

There it refers to the introduction of the guillotine to force through the industrial relations legislation before the democratically elected members of the new upper house take their seats on 22 May.

This matter of urgency today deals with this as far as the Australian Senate is concerned. We are now in the 96th consecutive day in which the Western Australian government has not filled the constitutional vacancy created when Senator Panizza, a distinguished Liberal senator in this place, passed away in January of this year. Ninety-six days have passed with Western Australia being represented not by the statutory requirement of 12 senators but by a lesser requirement of 11 senators. This is the 25th day of the sitting of this Senate chamber in which that situation has remained.

It has to be said that this is, by the Liberal government here nationally as well as by the Liberal government in Western Australia, a cynical and contemptuous approach to the needs and wishes of Western Australian voters, to the constitutional conventions that underpin our democracy, to the Australian Senate itself in the need to be representative of the states' interests and to fair and democratic procedures in Western Australia. We canvassed this a little earlier today, so I will do this in summary.

We know there are two real reasons why the Western Australian government is behaving in this manner. Senator-elect Lightfoot was pre-selected on 5 April by the Liberal Party in Western Australia after two attempts to pre-select him. He was pre-selected on 5 April. He could have then been notified and could have been here in this parliament for this sitting. He hung on, and he hung on until at least 21 April in order to achieve a superannuation payment of $466,000, after being a member of that chamber for seven years. There was clearly self-motivation in his hanging on for that part.

But just in the last weeks Senator-elect Lightfoot, member of the Legislative Council, said that he was going to remain in that chamber so he could vote for the industrial legislation that the editors of the West Australian have condemned in their editorial today as cynical and autocratic. On advice to me this afternoon as well, the Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Western Australia, I understand, have called upon the Court government to withdraw that legislation from the Legislative Council. In other words, legislation which is inherently undemocratic, which is inherently anti-union and which is inherently anti-ordinary working men and women in Western Australia is being asked to be withdrawn by the employers' organisation in that state so that a Liberal government can cease the divisiveness that that legislation is causing.

What are the facts of this matter? The facts are these, plainly. No mandate was sought by the Liberal Party in Western Australia for the third wave of industrial legislation when they presented their credentials to the electors in that state for the December 1996 election. In fact, they denied it was their intention to come forward with the third wave in the election. So there is no mandate, clearly, from the Western Australia people for this legislation to proceed. The legislative councillors who were elected at that election take their seats on 22 May. The will of the electors in that state in that election composed the Legislative Council in a manner in which the government in that state has no majority and in which it is clear that if that legislation were presented to that chamber under those people who were elected at the last state election it would not pass. So the government has attempted to ram this legislation through, taking advantage of the temporary expediency of a one‐seat majority between now and the 22nd.

But, as I say, Ross Lightfoot was pre-selected on 5 April. The Liberal Party, if we are to believe the Premier of Western Australia, have not yet told the Western Australian government that Ross Lightfoot has been elected. As a consequence, the Western Australian government say that they cannot call the required meeting of joint houses to nominate him to fill this Senate vacancy.

Why have the Liberal Party deliberately delayed? Quite clearly in order to maintain their majority in the Legislative Council, to maintain a majority to ram this undemocratic, anti-worker legislation through, to divide the opinion in that state and then at their leisure to send Senator-elect Lightfoot to Canberra to represent the interests of Western Australians. This is, as I say, contemptuous of the interests of Western Australians and of Western Australia's need to be properly represented in this place. In other words, Lightfoot has not taken up his seat because the Western Australian Liberal Party have directly manipulated the constitutional conventions and the votes both in Western Australia and here in order to score a point on their political agenda.

This is not a new matter for the Senate. The Senate has debated this matter in the past when state governments were tardy in nominating their representatives for Canberra. Indeed, in the most recent debate, many Western Australian senators who now sit opposite spoke long and passionately about the need for the Lawrence government to speed up the process of filling the vacancy created by then Senator Jo Vallentine so that Senator Chamarette could take her place. There was a 41‐day delay between the vacancy created by the retirement of Senator Vallentine and the appointment of Senator Chamarette. There has now been a 96‐day delay in the appointment of a replacement for Senator Panizza.

Have these same Western Australian senators expressed themselves with the same urgency and passion as they did when they attacked the former Labor government? Of course not. In fact, on the contrary: they have defended the actions of the Court government. They did so earlier this afternoon in what to me was a disgusting reversal of their earlier position, and one which does them absolutely no credit. The facts of this matter are best explained by going to what those senators said. Senator Campbell, who represents the government as Manager of Government Business in this chamber, had a lot to say back when this debate was on. He said:
I conclude by saying that there are only three possible motivations:—
referring to the alleged delay of the Lawrence government—

the first, bloody minded obstruction; secondly, mismanagement and disorganisation of the sort that was shown recently in relation to the sewerage plant under the One nation program; or, thirdly, a total disrespect for the Senate and the people of Western Australia and their representation in this place. I join Senator Coulter in condemning the actions of the Premier of Western Australia . . .
Have we heard Senator Campbell condemn the actions of the Premier of Western Australia and his even more blatant abuse? Of course we have not. He went on to say:
If Western Australia does not have full representation in this place, it has been let down.
In that same debate he said:
The notice that the Western Australian Parliament and the Western Australian Government have given makes it even more of a disgrace.

We know that Senator Campbell lobbied long and hard not for Mr Lightfoot but for Michael Huston to become the replacement senator. In fact, we know that when ringing his Liberal Party cronies to get the vote for his favoured nominee—the one supported by the Howard government—he said:
A vote for Lightfoot is a vote against me!

On two occasions the Western Australian Liberal Party voted for Lightfoot and, on the last occasion, voted in greater numbers than previously. I guess I have to say there seems to be a crisis of confidence in Senator Campbell in Western Australia. If he puts up next time and the same votes come out, he will not be in this place again.

Senator Susan Knowles had a lot to say in that debate as well. In the debate earlier today she spoke in defence of the actions of the state government and tried to draw a red herring across the path. But what did she say when she spoke last time? Hansard reveals she said:

The next time there is a Senate vacancy may well not be a time that is chosen by a retiring Senator—it could be due to ill health, death, or a number of other reasons. On that occasion, it may be politically convenient for a State Government to leave a Federal Government or, in fact, a Federal Opposition, short of a Senator for as long as possible when contentious legislation is before the Senate.

Prophetic remarks: there is contentious legislation before the Western Australian Legislative Council. Senator Knowles knows full well and said many years ago—back in 1992—that in those circumstances a government may be rendered vulnerable. I wonder out loud whether that is the sort of thinking that has now been incorporated in the Liberal Party's actions over Ross Lightfoot. Referring to the decision of the Lawrence government, Senator Knowles went on to say:
. . . an insult to the Senate, a denial of representation to all Western Australians, injustice to certain individuals and a sinister precedent in defiance of the constitution.
Her words. But have we heard that from her in condemning this action of the government? Of course we have not. We have heard a contrary view—a defence of the government.
