The reason this urgency motion must be carried is for the sake of this Senate stamping its seal of consistency upon the filling of vacancies in this chamber, and not allowing its honourable motives in pairing senators in this place to be held up to abuse and manipulation for gross, and in this case divisive, state political purposes. That is what is happening. The industrial legislation in Western Australia is divisive in that state. A demonstration by some 30,000 workers occurred on Wednesday last week, indicating mass support against this legislation. This senator elect should be brought to this place as quickly as possible. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to respond to some of Senator Cook's remarks because they seem to be ill‐informed. I will not go past saying that. He did say that the Western Australian Liberal Party had not informed the state government, via the Premier, of the endorsement of Ross Lightfoot MLC. That is quite contrary to the facts. I understand that in the West Australian newspaper—
—That is what the Premier said. I am just quoting the Premier.
—He said that weeks and weeks ago—something like four weeks ago. The fact is he has received the letter and he received it many weeks ago.
—Why hasn't he acted?

—As to why he is acting or not acting, you have got your own theories on that. Senator Eggleston put some other theories forward. There are probably lots of theories, but I am here to debate the motion. Delays of 78, 85 and 90 days have occurred fairly regularly in the recent past. Senator Conroy's endorsement, I understand, was delayed in excess of 80 days. My endorsement—or should I say ratification—
—A federal election intervened.

—That is true. I think it is fair to say that Senator Knowles and I have even this day supported, by agreeing to formality, motion No. 544 standing in the name of Senator Faulkner which reaffirms the motion passed on 3 June 1992. We have reasserted our support to that today by agreeing to formality and supporting without dissent that motion. We have reaffirmed the principle that these matters should be dealt with as quickly as possible.

BREAK.PARA: The WA preselection process did take longer than it normally would have because there was a technical default in the calling of a meeting, which was rectified. That gave most of the state councillors of the Liberal Party who sit on that preselection body a pain in the neck to put it lightly because they had to come back from all parts of the state to do the process again because of a default. In fact I am informed by Mr Wells, the state director of the Liberal Party, that if that default had not been corrected then the nomination of Mr Lightfoot would have been technically incorrect and voidable. They are matters I would like to clear up.

One other more light‐hearted matter is that Senator Cook says that I lobbied people in relation to the preselection, that I said words to the effect that a vote for Lightfoot is a vote against me. I am not sure whether that was ever published in the West Australian or whether the walls in No. 2, The Esplanade, Perth are thinner than I think. I certainly do not recall saying words to that effect. They are words that I do not believe because I know they are not true.

In relation to the details of the motion moved by Senator Cook, one of the core issues that has not had a lot of focus put on it is the issue of the legitimacy of the Legislative Council of Western Australia dealing with legislation before 21 May. Between 29 April 1996 when the Senate resumed last year after the March election when there was a landslide victory to the coalition parties in the House of Representatives—and a very good Senate vote, might I add—and 28 June 1996 when the Senate adjourned for the last time prior to the expiration of senators' terms on 30 June last year a number of senators retired from this place.

You will recall our dear former colleagues Michael Beahan, Brian Burns and John Coates all retired at 30 June 1997 as did Senator Robert Bell, Senator Sid Spindler and my good friend Christabel Chamarette. Not once in that period—and that is a period of something like 25 sitting days—were any doubts raised as to whether it was valid for people who had not been elected at the 1996 election, who had been elected at previous elections or, in Christabel's case, brought in on a casual vacancy, to vote.

The Democrats who are making a big hullabaloo in Western Australia about the fact it is immoral that the Legislative Council as it is now configured should be discussing any legislation at all is quite amazing when you note that in that period last year—I remind senators and anyone else who happens to be tuned in listening to this debate—after the March election when you had this massive landslide to the coalition and we sat up to the expiration of terms of senators on 30 June 1996, these people voted and voted regularly. What did they mostly do in divisions, Senator Knowles?

TALK.START.PARA: —Voted with the Labor Party.

—They voted with the Labor Party. They voted against the government. Senator Murray will be following me and he may have a defence for this. I would be interested to hear it, but the Democrats are making such a great fuss about this in Western Australia saying that it is undemocratic. What they are really saying is: close the Legislative Assembly down till 21 May.

BREAK.PARA: They believe in having fixed terms for both parliaments so you cannot have early elections and everything. You have a fixed term in the Legislative Council in Western Australia. The new terms begin on 22 May—it is a very important date in Australian history because it is my birthday. Here in the Senate the terms expire on 30 June and the new terms start on 1 July. We have fixed terms. What the Democrats and I presume others, Senator Cook and Senator Evans, are saying in this motion is that perhaps the whole place should be closed down after the election and before the new senators take their place because they have no legitimate democratic right to vote on a piece of legislation.

The reality is that when people go to the ballot-box, legislative councillors are elected for a fixed term. I am not so silly as to suggest that every time someone casts a ballot they know all the provisions of the Electoral Act and the Western Australian and federal constitutions. The reality is that that is what is being done.

I say to Senator Murray that on 27 occasions in that short time last year the Democrats voted in divisions against the government on a whole range of crucial issues. The Greens (WA) voted against the government in 26 divisions and the ALP senators voted in 24 divisions against the government in that period. The same ALP senators who voted on 24 occasions this time last year against the government, which had been elected by the second biggest landslide in Australian history, who voted against legislation that was part of our mandate, part of our agenda, are now coming in here today saying that it is undemocratic, wrong, unconstitutional or even immoral for the Legislative Council in Western Australia to consider legislation that is before it.

I look forward to Senator Murray's rebuttal of that argument. I do not think there can be one. There is clear hypocrisy for someone who says that you cannot deal with legislation. These issues are not new matters. These matters have been before the Western Australia people for a long time. Everyone says that the secret ballot issue is irrelevant, that it is just a red herring.

There is one thing that most Western Australians agree on, regardless of where they come from—there is absolutely overwhelming support for it. When it comes to taking industrial action that closes down the whole of Western Australia, which is what the trade union leaders did to Western Australia last week—schools were closed down—they do not choose the day off after schools are meant to come back, last Monday—

TALK.START.PARA: —Pupil free day.

—They do not choose the pupil free day to strike. This is not the school teachers of Western Australia. They virtually unanimously are very good people who are dedicated to doing their job of teaching young Western Australians.
—Who went on strike.

—They did not have a vote, Senator Bishop. They were told, `You are going to go on strike.' They were told what day to go on strike. Of course, that is a joke. They were told that by some union leader. One thing that has been part of the WA Liberal Party policy year after year—probably 25 years or longer—is that there should be secret ballots before strikes. They think that there is something undemocratic about the Liberal Party putting its policy into a bit of legislation and having it debated. There could be nothing more fair. There could be nothing more democratic. It is absolutely ludicrous for members opposite and people sitting on the crossbenches to say anything other than that.

BREAK.PARA: There are other aspects to the legislation. There are aspects in that bill, which we do not need to debate in this place, that ensure that people who do not want their membership details given to a union shop steward do not have to give them out. There are provisions which provide a lot of other protections for people who are not members of unions. There are also provisions to ensure that if you are a member of a union you do not have to send your donation to the ALP and you do not have to have your union dues automatically deducted from your wages. There are all sorts of provisions that virtually no‐one would disagree with, except the unionists, whose livelihoods are affected by it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The first matter to refer to is the history of the Democrats in the Senate, which has been to complain about any delays or impropriety in the appointment of senators. I would like to request that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, ask the Senate President to refer the matter to an appropriate committee to make recommendations as to how these long delays can be avoided in future.

SPEECH.PARA: I did not know the man well, because I was a new senator, but my belief is that this long delay is an affront to the memory of the very diligent, committed and hardworking Senator Panizza. I know that Senator Panizza had the view that Western Australian senators needed to be here, they needed to be here in numbers and they needed to be here representing their state's interests. It is quite wrong for Western Australia to be without one of its senators for nearly 100 days.

I turn to some of the remarks made by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator Campbell). First of all, he has started with a premise which is utterly wrong. He said that the Democrats have said that no legislation at all should be debated in the Legislative Council. We are not allowed to say that that is a lie, so I think I would have to say that it is a misrepresentation. If you wish to misrepresent us, please misrepresent us correctly. We have said that, if there is to be legislation which is utterly divisive and is going to cause a great deal of `aggro' in the community, then it should be delayed until such time as the new Legislative Council sits.

I want to deal with the issue of 22 May. It is undoubtedly true, as everyone in the chamber and the community at large recognises, that after 22 May this legislation in Western Australia would not have got through in its current form. I want to look at this legislation just briefly in the short time available to me. It was introduced as a third wave. The very conservative Sunday Times describes the third wave of 4 May as a bad wash. I mean, you were even criticised in the Sunday Times, which is really getting quite difficult.

The reason it was not needed is that the previous changes to the legislation, by both the Labor government and then the Liberal government following, had resulted in a change in the industrial climate. We had a period where there was remarkably low industrial unrest. What did Premier Court and Mr Kierath do? They managed to turn the place upside down and strike a match to the fires of industrial passions. You have to say to yourself, `What extraordinarily incompetent people. What an extraordinarily unnecessary action to take.' Not only was it incompetent and unnecessary; it also is going to cost businesses and workers hundreds of millions of dollars.

I want to contrast that with three other people: Premier Carr, Premier Borbidge and Prime Minister Howard. The three of them introduced far more far‐reaching industrial legislation without one single moment of industrial unrest. Do not quote to me the awful riot that occurred here in the parliament, because that was a riot by a minority of people at a rally. It was certainly not industrial unrest.

The Prime Minister and those two premiers introduced legislation which managed to get through their parliaments without the kind of upset we are seeing in WA—solely because they understood process, they understood consultation, and they understood how to deal with the conflicting aims of the various parties concerned. The result is that all three of them were able to introduce very far‐reaching legislation without the appalling and unnecessary uproar—and incompetence—that has gone on in WA. Really, if you as Liberals want to indict your Premier, you have to do so based on his being an appallingly poor manager of this situation.

It is a fact that it was only following the visits of Minister Peter Reith to WA that they then—once Graham Kierath was away—started to call in other people to consult with them about changes and amendments. This was after they had inflamed passions with their poor legislation, and the poor provisions of the legislation, to such an extent that it has become almost impossible to manage.

We hear Senator Campbell talking with passion about secret ballots. The unions do not oppose secret ballots. The community does not oppose secret ballots. The Democrats do not oppose secret ballots. Labor does not oppose secret ballots. The Liberals do not oppose secret ballots. The Nationals do not oppose secret ballots. The difference is about the process—it is incompetent; it is useless; it is pathetic. They have introduced legislation which was unnecessary. But they could have got it through if they had managed process properly. I think the real disgrace in this whole exercise is that the beating of their respective manly chests is going to result in a cost to WA of hundreds of millions of dollars of wasted money.

Now let us turn to Senator-elect Lightfoot. If Senator-elect Lightfoot had been elected by the members of the Liberal Party, I would have thought that would be a great feat. But he was elected, I understand, by a little over 100 people in the extremely rigged, factionalised, divided group. Why on earth was Senator-elect Lightfoot not elected by the entire 7,000 to 10,000 members—however many there are—of the Liberal Party? Why do you not exercise democracy and give your senator-elects the proper legitimacy they should have when they come to this place?

TALK.START.PARA: —He was elected by as many Democrats.
—We make sure that every one of our people are elected by the entire membership. We make sure that our leader is elected by the entire membership.
—That's what I mean. About a hundred people.
—Oh, yeah! The reason you have difficulties on that side of the house with the people coming to represent you is that you allow yourselves to be overridden by that factionalised mess. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —In opening my comments tonight, I draw attention to the motion we are discussing. It relates to the vacancy for a Senate position from the state of Western Australia. We are not debating the industrial relations bill that is before the Western Australian parliament. I wish we were. I, indeed, would have something to say about that.

SPEECH.PARA: In the short time available to me, I am not running away from that debate. I am going to concentrate on the matter that is before the Senate. That is, of course, the following motion put forward by Senator Cook on behalf of Senator Chris Evans:

BREAK.PARA: The failure of the Western Australian State Government to appoint Ross Lightfoot to replace the late John Panizza, which is motivated by nothing more than political expediency and is a desperate attempt by the Court Government to pass oppressive industrial relations legislation before the will of the people as expressed in the December election is reflected in the composition of the Western Australian Legislative Council.

That is the subject matter before us. However, there is a diversion—Senator Campbell's red herring when he tried to draw an analogy between what happens post‐elections in the Legislative Council in Western Australia and the Senate of the Parliament of Australia.

Senator Campbell conveniently forgot to tell the Senate and those people who are listening that last year was the first occasion when the Western Australian elections were held early. The Western Australian elections are normally held—and have been since the parliament of Western Australia was established in a democratic fashion—in February-March and on one occasion in April. This year, the election was held in December. Mr Court picked a good time and he was justly rewarded with an overwhelming victory in the lower house. But he did not have an overwhelming victory in the upper house.

The other thing that is unique about Western Australian elections is that they are normally held in February‐March—and as I said, on one occasion in April—and then the new parliament generally does not meet until after the new Legislative Council is sworn in. On this occasion, all of the conventions have been broken, as they have been broken on previous occasions by the Court government in Western Australia.

In 1993, for the first time ever, in a house that has never been controlled by other than a Liberal Party in Western Australia, they used a gag and a guillotine to get legislation through. On that occasion, the legislation they were seeking to get through had to do with the Mabo legislation. It was subsequently tossed out as being wrong and bad legislation by the High Court of Australia. They have tried it again with the second wave of industrial relations legislation.

Last evening in the upper house of the parliament of Western Australia, to the continued disgrace of the Court government, they tried it again. They have again broken all the conventions that are in existence. But last night there was a cost. The cost, which Senator Knowles came and reported to us in an earlier debate in this place, is that the pairs have been withdrawn. No pairs exist because the convention has been broken. It has not been broken by the Labor Party. It has not been broken by the other Independents in the upper house in Western Australia. It was broken by the Court government in the Legislative Council in Western Australia. It was broken and they are suffering the consequences of it.

That red herring has to be firmly put to bed. There is no direct analogy between what happens following the election of the Legislative Council in Western Australia and the election of senators to the parliament of Australia. On a number of occasions we have had elections in December of one year with new senators not taking their position until July of the next year.

I actually take some pleasure in the honourable Ross Lightfoot MLC coming to this place. He is, after all, currently one of my local members of parliament—together with Ian Maclean and Richard Evans. I do not know what we have done wrong over in Wanneroo, but we are paying for some mistakes in the past. I hope we enjoyed the sins we have probably committed.

I look forward to Ross Lightfoot coming into this place. Any person who is brave enough to publicly call their leader a traitor and who is on the opposite side of parliament to me is probably somebody you would listen to when he finally takes his place in the Senate where parliamentary privilege is attached. That is one of the many things that the honourable Ross Lightfoot is on the record for. He has called people—including his leader and most of his colleagues in the Western Australian parliament and some here—traitors because they support the imposition of a royalty on the mining of gold.

As I said, I look forward to Ross coming here. I think that, whilst he is a virulent debater—and we will certainly test his mettle on this side of the chamber—at the end of the day he will create more problems for that side of the chamber than he will for this side of the chamber. That is probably the reason why so many of my Western Australian parliamentary colleagues worked so vigorously in the two preselections in March and April of this year to try to get a different person preselected to come to Canberra as a representative of Western Australia. That was a bit of fun on my part, but it is not really fun at all—as the editorial in today's West Australian went on to point out.

We are becoming a pretty sick state in Western Australia when the will of the people, as expressed democratically in the elections that were held in December last year, has just been turned over for blatant political reasons. That has not gone unnoticed. The demonstration last Tuesday by the trade union movement, workers and the community in Western Australia vividly brought that to the notice of all Australians. What the West Australian had to say today, and I want to quote only a small part of it to make the point about Mr Lightfoot, is this:

It is a breathtaking display of arrogance and contempt for the people's vote in December and for the proper role of the Council as a House of review. It completely ignores recommendations of august bodies, such as the WA royal commission and the Commission on Government, which urged that the review role of the Upper House should be strengthened to help prevent the executive riding roughshod over Parliament and the people.
The Government's contempt for what is proper procedure is further illustrated by its decision to keep Senator‐elect Ross Lightfoot—
it should really be Senator‐designate Lightfoot because he has not been elected—
in the Legislative Council long after convention says he should have resigned and gone to the Senate. The only reason is that it needs his vote to beat the May 22 deadline.

The other matter that could have been inserted in that editorial is the little matter of $466,000 in a superannuation payment which became available to Mr Lightfoot after he had served till 21 April this year. Mr Lightfoot can now legitimately and lawfully put that in his pocket.

What is being done to the standing of parliament—not only this house, which has taken its fair share of battering in recent weeks and months, but all parliaments and indeed the whole parliamentary process—when you see incidents like this happening? Lumping the two together, is it any wonder how low the people of Australia hold us as professional elected politicians? Is it any wonder indeed?

I look forward to Senator Knowles's contribution to the debate because I too, like Senator Cook, went to the old Hansard and revisited the debates that occurred at the time that our colleague, Senator Chamarette, came into this place. Senator Knowles, I know how we felt at that time, some 34 days from when the vacancy arose, about the fact that that vacancy had not been filled. We, as Western Australians, felt distraught that there were only 11 of us to do the work of 12. That time frame has now doubled and there are more days on top of it. I have got a list of the vacancies that have occurred in the last 20 years or so, which I will seek to have incorporated into Hansard. This list explains how long it has taken at various times to fill casual vacancies of the Senate, whether they have been caused by resignation or by death. I seek leave to have that list incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The document read as follows—
CASUAL VACANCIES IN THE SENATE 1977-1996

BREAK.PARA: * A.C.T. Senator
Note: Court of Disputed Returns found W.R. Wood had not been elected validly (12.05.88).
I.P. Dunn was elected on 21.07.88 pursuant to s. 360(1)(vi) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —In joining the debate, I have to say that this motion has everything to do with the attitude of the Labor Party not being able to come to grips with losing elections, both federal and state, and little to do with any deeply felt and long‐abiding concern for full Liberal Party representation in any parliament of Australia. We have seen bullying and blocking and a misuse of committee tactics in this parliament by this opposition since its members were comprehensively wiped out last year in the election. We are now seeing them refuse to accept the will of Western Australian voters for the Western Australian parliament. That is where Senator Evans's motion is remarkable. In the second‐last line, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . before the will of the people as expressed at the December election is reflected in the composition of the Western Australian Legislative Council.

The Senate deserves to be reminded of the election result because last December the election saw the number of Liberal seats increase by three, from 26 to 29, whereas Labor lost five seats, resulting in the number reducing from 24 to 19. The National Party maintained its six seats in the assembly. That is the worst result the Labor Party has ever had.

Let us look at the Legislative Council. While we might have lost 0.3 of a percentage vote in the Legislative Council, we actually lost only one seat in the council; the Labor Party lost two. Here we have a combination of the Labor Party and the trade union movement blocking the will of the people. It was a resounding victory for a coalition government, and what have we seen since? Anything to stop it. The other substantive thing that the motion has at its core is the subject of the much‐needed industrial relations overhaul. Let us not forget that the Hon. Ross Lightfoot would be here with us today if the Labor Party could ever be trusted to keep its word on anything, and that includes the question of pairs.

Let me remind the Senate of what the Labor Party did back in 1993 when an industrial relations bill was being debated in the Legislative Council in Western Australia. They called off pairs. It just so happens that the very person in question today, Mr Lightfoot, was affected by Labor's actions then. He was in hospital with pneumonia. He had to have a drip taken out, get out of hospital and into the chamber, vote and return to hospital. Is it any wonder that the coalition believed that the Labor Party would do exactly what it did last night, and that was to call off pairs, because, in every industrial relations debate, that is exactly the course of action that it has taken.

In Western Australia, there is a mechanism for the replacement of a member who, for whatever reason, leaves the Legislative Council. Due to a number of circumstances—sadly, including once again another death—the Liberal Party has run out of eligible people to fill such a vacancy if Mr Lightfoot were to leave. I might add that the person who has filled the vacancy for the Liberal Party over the last few months is the Hon. Alan Carstairs. The Labor Party and trade unions have had the gall to say that Mr Carstairs should not exercise his vote in this debate on the industrial relations bill. What they have failed to mention is that they have actually replaced three people and have three people in the Legislative Council filling vacancies. At no stage have they said that those three people should not exercise their vote. So, yet again, we deal with a double standard, and the double standard from the Labor Party just never seems to stop.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a triple standard in that case.

—Exactly, Senator Campbell. However, there is a further demonstration of Labor's refusal to accept that defeat. As I mentioned, they got walloped at the state election in December. In fact, it was the biggest defeat that they had ever suffered in Western Australia. Yet two Labor senators have come in here tonight and said that we should be looking at exercising the will of the people.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said in a debate earlier this afternoon, I am pleased that Senator Evans, as Labor whip in the Senate, has taken an honourable course in pairing the late Senator Panizza, and I have no doubt that he will continue that course of action, because he is honourable. We are confronted with a great contrast in Western Australia. They have simply said, `No pairs in industrial relations—it is sacrosanct.' We now have here the other people taking the balance of power—a couple of Greens and a Democrat—with no representation in the Legislative Assembly at all, holding Western Australia to ransom. It can hardly be suggested to me or accepted by me that that is exercising the will of the Western Australian vote in the December election.

That is how we are in the situation that we are in today. It is just a quirk of the electoral system for the legislative council that the number of government and non‐government members is now equal. The Labor Party believes that this entitles them to demand that the business of the government not proceed until the new term of the tied upper house commences on 22 May. What an abuse of the electorate wishes. As Senator Campbell has clearly put up, it did not stop them last year, from March to 30 June, in using every vote that they could possibly muster, with a minority of people in this chamber in terms of each individual party. On their own, the Labor Party cannot defeat the government coalition senators; the Greens certainly cannot; the Democrats certainly cannot. But it did not stop the combination defeating the will of the people in a landslide victory for the Commonwealth government in the March election.

What an abuse of the electorate wishes, as I said before. Mind you, one can never win with the Labor Party. Had the government in Western Australia decided to sit on its hands until 22 May and do nothing, the Labor Party and the trade unions would have been brimming over in their criticism of a government that was inactive. So no matter what the government do, they cannot win, because they have a minority combination that only has a tied vote—it does not have a majority—that is demanding that they, single‐handedly, exercise the will of the people.

In summary, if the Labor Party's word could ever be trusted in the Legislative Council or had there been any mechanism for ensuring that pairs that had been promised would be maintained, the Hon. Ross Lightfoot MLC would be Senator Lightfoot today. So do not blame the Liberal Party for the games that the trade unions and the Labor Party play. It is the mates of the Labor Party in the trade union movement who are creating all the problems that we are seeing today.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's the most pathetic argument that I've heard all day.

—Isn't it interesting that Senator Cook says that it is the most pathetic argument that he has heard all day? He does not have the faintest clue or respect for the will of the people. It is hypocrisy to the extreme to even have it in the wording of the motion, with absolutely no regard whatsoever for the actual vote at the end of the day of the election in December 1996.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I had actually listened to at least part of the contribution that Senator Knowles made when she spoke on taking note of answers today after question time. Apart from the time that I was walking down to the chamber, I was trying to listen to her contribution. The reason I took particular interest was that at least Senator Knowles was honest enough to say that the decision at the moment in relation to Senator‐elect Lightfoot is about the Liberal Party running out of eligible people to fill vacancies.

SPEECH.PARA: We heard a number of issues as to why it is necessary to take the political action that is being taken in Western Australia in relation to the industrial relations bill. I put it to you that this is quite different from the official response that has been given by the party which is citing Western Australian constitutional problems. There is a political reason, and that has been stated, as I say, quite honestly, by Senator Knowles.

Therefore, the Senate should well be debating this today. The Greens (WA) are well aware of the implications of a situation where a casual vacancy is not filled promptly. Of course, on 3 June 1993, the Senate passed the following resolution, reported in Odgers' Australian Senate Practice:
That the Senate—

(a) believes that casual vacancies in the Senate should be filled as expeditiously as possible, so that no State is without its full representation in the Senate for any time longer than is necessary;

(b) recognises that under section 15 of the Constitution an appointment to a vacancy in the Senate may be delayed because the Houses of Parliament of the relevant State are adjourned but have not been prorogued, which, on a strict construction of the section, prevents the Governor of a state making the appointment . . .

In this case, the parliament of Western Australia has, in fact, been meeting. None of that actually exists, because the election was in December and, of course, the parliament in Western Australia is meeting and trying to push through the industrial relations legislation as has been mentioned. Part (c) of this says:

. . . recommends that all State Parliaments adopt procedures whereby their Houses, if they adjourned when a casual vacancy in the Senate is notified, are recalled to fill the vacancy, and whereby the vacancy is filled;
(i) within 14 days after the notification of the vacancy, or
(ii) where under section 15 of the Constitution the vacancy must be filled by a member of a political party, within 14 days after the nomination by that party is received . . .

Obviously the Liberal Party has run out of eligible people, but I am sure that as part of the process within the party they would have the ability to know who they are going to use to replace Mr Lightfoot in relation to the state party. Therefore, the relationship with the state constitution is really immaterial. It is a political process that is occurring here.

TALK.START.PARA: —They had to face the election in 1993, Dee.
—I am not making any comment on whether the people who are in the parliament in Western Australia now were voted in. I have no problem with people in the parliament voting on legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: However, getting back to that perhaps, there is a new process—new standing orders—in the parliament of Western Australia. That process, put in by the government in Western Australia, shows that there are standing orders indicating how bills will be dealt with. It is like a triage system so they can better deal with their workload. It basically says that if a bill is complex or controversial, there is an automatic referral to a committee so it can be dealt with better and get community feedback. The irony is that not only do we seem to have the legitimate standing orders of the Senate being ignored but the new standing orders put in by the government in Western Australia, which say that we are going to deal with complex and controversial bills through a committee process, are being ignored as well.

Here we have a bill that will affect all working people and most businesses in Western Australia. It will have ripples throughout other parts of the country. We have a situation where, for admitted political reasons, a vacancy is not being filled. I do not think that that is acceptable, I do not think that is proper parliamentary process and I think it is showing contempt for both systems of parliament—state and federal. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset let me say that this motion is really in two parts. The first relates to the delay in the appointment of Mr Lightfoot to this chamber and the second is in relation to the fact that the Western Australian government is relying on the votes of upper house members whose term expires on 21 May this year. I will deal with each in turn.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, Senator Campbell adequately outlined the aspects of process in the selection of Mr Lightfoot and the process that has been followed by the state government. I think he did that most adequately, and I will not enhance that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Adequately? Brilliantly!

—As Senator Campbell said, brilliantly—perhaps that as well. The gravamen of this motion is really about the fact that the opposition objects to the state government relying on upper house votes from members whose term will expire on 21 May this year. It is nothing strange to democracy in Australia that you have upper houses with fixed terms. This chamber enjoys such a situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Campbell pointed out that last year we had senators who voted both for and against the government whose terms ran out at the end of June last year, despite there being a change of government some three months before that. I point to former Senators Beahan, Bell, Burns, Jones, Spindler, Teague and Wheelwright. In those situations you had senators participating in votes, particularly Senator Chamarette, who I failed to mention, who exercised a somewhat crucial position in her casting position, yet there was no objection raised then by the opposition in relation to this.

I point out that in Western Australia at the moment you have Legislative Council members from the ALP in Mr Graham Edwards, Val Ferguson and Doug Wenn whose terms expire on 21 May this year but who, nonetheless, will be voting on this state legislation. How does the opposition base its objection to Mr Lightfoot casting his vote in relation to the WA Labour Relations Amendment Bill 1977? I fail to see how they can rely on any basis at all for such an objection. There is a longstanding practice that in upper houses and in this chamber—the Senate—you have members and senators continuing to vote even though their term is shortly to expire. That is in accordance with democracy in this country.

We have a situation where the Western Australian government is six months into its term of office. Is the opposition saying that it should wait until all upper house members from the pre-existing government have left the Legislative Council before it embarks on its legislative program? I think not. To do so would be highly irresponsible.

There is another aspect to this motion which deals with the legislation itself, which it cites as being oppressive. I bring to the Senate's attention the fact that the state government in Western Australia went to the polls in December last year telling Western Australians that they intended to complete any incomplete industrial relations reforms. Indeed, the exposure to these bills has therefore come in the form of two sets of election policies in 1992 and 1996. In two election campaigns these have been canvassed. I put it to the Senate that the bill currently before the Western Australian parliament has had a good deal of process, consultation and exposure.

Senator Campbell made a very good point earlier in relation to secret ballots. In response to an address by Senator Murray from the Democrats, Senator Campbell mentioned that in the prior governments—the Burke, Dowding and Lawrence governments—in Western Australia, we did not see any move by them for secret ballots in relation to union votes. It is interesting now to see that everybody says they support them, but where was the legislation then?

There are other aspects in relation to the legislation which I believe the Senate should be aware of. Among the various measures there are those that provide union members to direct their political donations to a political party or election candidate of their choice. They will be protected from having their moneys applied for political purposes without their consent. There is also the aspect of employers and employees being able to enter into voluntary WA collective workplace agreements to override relevant federal awards. I put it to the Senate that the state government in Western Australia has been open to consultation and suggestion—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—It has amended, Senator Bishop, a number of aspects of its bill in relation to secret ballots, so there have been concessions from the government. That was noted in the editorial of the West Australian newspaper of today's date.

SPEECH.PARA: The comments made in relation to the industrial relations legislation of Western Australia fall flat on their face. I note that Senator Knowles said, quite pointedly, that what the opposition cannot come to grips with is the poor performance that they put up in the last state election. It was a resounding success for the Court government, it increased its majority and it did so on the policies that it put to the people of Western Australia. One of them was its process for industrial relations reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The coalition has expressed its views on this matter. We do not intend to delay this matter any longer by calling a division.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE EUROPEAN INSTITUTIONS, UNITED KINGDOM (NORTHERN IRELAND) AND THE REPUBLIC OF IRELAND

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the European institutions, United Kingdom (Northern Ireland) and the Republic of Ireland, which took place between 13 September and 8 October 1996. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to that report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Last September and October, I was privileged to lead the Australian parliamentary delegation to the European institutions, the United Kingdom (Northern Ireland) and the Republic of Ireland. Today I am pleased to be able to table the delegation's report.

The visit to the European institutions came at an important phase of Australia's relationship with the European Union. At the time of the visit, a number of key issues relevant to that relationship were being debated. The visit provided a timely opportunity to put forward Australia's views in relation to many of those issues. During the numerous debates, meetings and briefings we attended, the delegation highlighted Australia's desire to strengthen its relationship with the European Union. The delegation reinforced Australia's commitment to formalising and expanding that relationship within a properly established agreement.

From the government side, I was pleased to hear today the announcement that the European Union has dropped its insistence on including a human rights clause in the proposed framework trade and cooperation agreement with Australia. Instead, it now will be dealt with in a separate political declaration annexed to the agreement. This accords with the position argued for by the government members of the delegation in Europe.

Issues of concern within the Australian‐European Union relationship were also raised by the delegation during its visit. Time and again the delegation promoted Australia's support for further trade liberalisation, particularly in relation to agriculture. I thank the members of the delegation for their participation. At every opportunity we reiterated the need for further reform of Europe's common agricultural policy.

At the Council of Europe, the delegation represented Australia's interests in the annual debate on OECD activities. We were success ful in moving a number of amendments to the final resolution on OECD activities which were adopted at that debate. Those amendments emphasised the importance of labour market reform in tackling the problem of unemployment; the need for a comprehensive and forward looking work program for the World Trade Organisation; support for Secretary‐General Johnston's reform strategy for the OECD; and the importance of limiting OECD membership to major players in the world economy, with outreach activities to non-members to be focused on mutual benefit rather than eventual membership.

The parliament will be interested to know that Secretary‐General Johnston is eager to increase contacts between the OECD and parliamentarians. His ideas are discussed in our report and should be given more detailed consideration. The delegation also gained a better understanding of the issues currently receiving attention in Europe, including economic and monetary union, European Union enlargement and NATO expansion. The delegation is hopeful that the issues in our report will provide a useful insight into these issues.

During its visit, the delegation detected growing European interest in the Asia-Pacific. Chancellor Kohl's recent visit to Australia is a clear example of the increasing importance with which Europe views its relationship with the Asia-Pacific region. In meetings with European parliamentarians and officials, the delegation took every opportunity to emphasise Australia's potential as a bridge between Europe and the Asia-Pacific. The delegation's considered view is that Australia's focus should be neither exclusively east nor exclusively west. Instead, our efforts should be directed to ensuring that we are able to take up the challenges and opportunities offered by a stronger Asia‐European partnership.

While visiting the European institutions, the delegation also was privileged to attend commemoration ceremonies at World War I and World War II battlefields and cemeteries in Belgium, including the moving Last Post ceremony at the Menin Gate. That was a special moment of the visit and, in its own small way, rekindled the spirit of the Australia Remembers campaign.

As the delegation notes in the report, each of the ceremonies we attended carried special meaning for the participants. For the local community, such commemorations are a reminder of the sacrifices which were made in their hour of need and an opportunity to continue expressing their gratitude. Despite the passage of time, it is clear that the people of Belgium have not forgotten the assistance which was provided to them by Australia and other allied soldiers. An inscription on one memorial states:
They gave their soul to God, their heart to their country and their body to Belgium.

For the young people who attended the ceremonies but have not experienced the horrors of war, such commemorations are both a warning about the immense cost of conflict between nations and a message of hope that the freedom and peace which was so bitterly fought for will be preserved. For the delegation, the ceremonies provided the opportunity to join with the local Belgian community in paying tribute to those who sacrificed their lives. By doing so, we delivered the simple message that Australia still remembers.

After the visit to the European institutions, the delegation travelled to Northern Ireland where we sought to gain a better understanding of political and socioeconomic developments there, including the peace process which is under way. To achieve this objective, the delegation held detailed discussions with political, church, community and business leaders.

We have come away from Northern Ireland with mixed views about its future prospects. During our visit, the delegation's levels of optimism and despair tended to fluctuate depending on the last person to whom we spoke. Nevertheless, it is clear that among the wider community in Northern Ireland there is a strong desire for peace, even though some political elements are yet to appreciate this.

A key to the future of Northern Ireland will be the extent to which the next generation of well‐educated youth can be harnessed to overcome political hurdles and build a more cooperative community which looks forward to shared commitments rather than divided loyalties. Much also will depend on the continuing support for the peace process from the Irish and the British governments and the broader international community. The message from the community through projects such as the International Fund for Ireland must be loud and clear: there is no dividend in continuing conflict; there is only a dividend in peace.

In the Republic of Ireland, the delegation not only gained a further perspective on the future of Northern Ireland but also examined ways of broadening the relationship between Australia and Ireland. During its visit, the delegation discovered that Ireland has moved beyond the divisions of the past to forge a strong relationship within the European Union. In economic terms, it has become a Celtic tiger with impressive growth and investment figures. Australia could well be advised to consider the experience of Ireland as an island nation located near a major world economic power.

The delegation was pleased to find that a number of Australian companies already have a significant presence in Ireland. The delegation was fortunate to meet with representatives from the Irish subsidiaries of the National Australia Bank and Michell Leather. The delegation also detected strong interest in Australian products, including wines and foods, with various companies already finding a gateway to the larger European Union market through Ireland. The experience of such companies should be considered by those looking to boost Australia's trade with the European Union.

The delegations's visit would not have been possible without the hard work of so many people both in Australia and overseas. The delegation is grateful to all those who contributed to the visit. We are hopeful that our report will contribute to a better understanding of European affairs both in this parliament and in the wider Australian community. This in turn will help to build on the strong relationship which already exists between Australia and the nations of the European Union. I commend the report to the Senate. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Employment, Education and Training References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Employment, Education and Training References Committee on trends in long‐term unemployment. I seek leave to have the response incorporated in Hansard and to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: REPORT ON THE INQUIRY INTO LONG‐TERM UNEMPLOYMENT
INTRODUCTION

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee set up the Senate Inquiry into long‐term unemployment in November 1994. The terms of reference directed the Inquiry to report on trends in long‐term unemployment and patterns of work and unemployment among older workers. The Inquiry was to examine the causes of long‐term unemployment, evaluate established programmes for helping long‐term unemployed people return to work, and consider alternative innovative strategies to increase employment. The Report on the inquiry into long‐term unemployment was tabled in the Senate on 26 October 1995. Preparation of the Government Response to the Report was delayed for a number of reasons, including the Federal election in March 1996 and the need to incorporate new policies and initiatives announced in the 1996‐97 Budget.

The Report has two sets of recommendations, one of which reflects the views of the majority of the Committee members consisting of Coalition and Democrat Senators, and the other presents the views of the Labor Committee members who were in minority. This Government Response addresses both the majority and minority recommendations.

At the time the Senate established the Inquiry, long‐term unemployment numbers were falling, having peaked at a trend level of 349,000 in September 1993. Even at its most recent low point of 215,000 in May 1996, however, the trend level of long term unemployment was almost twice its level prior to the last recession. Moreover, the recovery in long term unemployment could not be sustained. The pace of economic growth weakened and by June 1995, short term unemployment was growing again. The flow on effect of this growth in short term unemployment is a major reason for the increase in trend long term unemployment numbers which has occurred since May last year.

The Government's goal is to return the nation to full employment, so that everyone who wants a job will be able to find one. Major elements of the Government's Job Creation Strategy have been implemented or are under development. The Budget is being placed on a more stable footing, which should see the underlying balance return to surplus by 1998‐99. Cutting the deficit in 1996‐97 has reduced pressure on interest rates, and will increase national saving and enhance future Budget flexibility.

The Federal Budget also addressed the needs of Australia's small business sector, which is a major source of employment growth. Small businesses have been provided with capital gains tax rollover relief. Other measures will help small firms gain better access to investment capital and create more small business training opportunities. More Time for Business , The Prime Minister's response to the small Business Deregulation Task Force report, has delivered further benefits to small business. Red tape will be reduced, a new Small Business Innovation Fund established, fringe benefits tax compliance costs addressed, and the capital gains tax rollover relief for small business further enhanced

The Workplace Relations and Other Amendment Act 1996 came into effect at the start of this year. It will take time before its full effects, notably improved labour market flexibility, are felt. The New Apprenticeships and Traineeships which depend on the workplace reforms, specifically target young people and aim to make training, especially at entry level, an attractive proposition for a much wider range of enterprises.

In March 1998 the Government will introduce comprehensive reform of labour market assistance to help ensure that long‐term unemployed people have access to the new jobs generated by the Job Creating Strategy. These reforms give priority to placement of unemployed people in real jobs rather than participation in ineffective labour market programs. The key features of the reforms are set out below.

. Services currently delivered separately by the Commonwealth Employment Service and the Department of Social Security will be provided through a new single integrated service delivery agency. This will be more convenient for jobseekers, and will enable the closer linking of payment of income support with active employment assistance measures.

. Assistance for jobseekers will be far better tailored to their individual needs and circumstances, and focused on gaining sustained employment. This will be facilitated through a new competitive market for Employment Service Providers. Jobseekers will be able to receive employment assistance from the Employment Service Provider of their choice. Payments to Employment Service Providers will be based on their success in placing people into jobs and reducing reliance on income support, rather than on putting people into programs.

. A public Employment Service Provider will be established to succeed the Commonwealth Employment Service, and will compete on equal terms with other Employment Service Providers. It will provide services on a cost recovery basis in regions where other Employment Service Providers do not operate.

. A new Community Support Programme has been established to ensure that the most disadvantaged job seekers who are unable to benefit from Employment Assistance will have access to more appropriate forms of assistance from other agencies.

The Government's labour market, training and other reforms address many of the concerns raised in the Report, particularly those relating to access to training, the effectiveness of labour market programmes and the need to increase the demand for labour. It should be borne in mind that the Report addresses the previous Government's policies and programmes which clearly had failed to deliver a sustained reduction in unemployment.

There are considerable areas of agreement between the Report's recommendations and Government objectives. These include the recommendations concerning assistance and training for Indigenous Australians and jobseekers from a non‐English speaking background. Overall, the Government supports seventeen of the recommendations, at least in principle or in part: twelve from the majority report and five from the minority report.

The extent of the Government's reforms means that some of the recommendations made in the Report are no longer applicable. Indeed, some of the reforms are designed to correct those same structural weaknesses and inefficiencies which prompted the recommendations in the Report. Other recommendations are too narrowly focused, and ignore the bigger picture. For example, proposals to expand assistance or income support to some categories of jobseekers must be balanced against the competing needs to target assistance to those most in need.

Section A of this document contains the Government's response to each of the majority recommendations, and Section B contains the Government's response to each minority recommendation. All recommendations are presented as they appeared in the Report. Each one is immediately followed by an indication of whether or not the Government supports it, followed by a more detailed discussion of relevant considerations. The only exceptions occur were some similar recommendations have been combined and responded to as a single recommendation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: THE GOVERNMENT'S RESPONSE TO THE SENATE EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING REFERENCES COMMITTEE'S REPORT ON THE INQUIRY INTO LONG‐TERM UNEMPLOYMENT
SECTION A—RESPONSE TO THE MAJORITY REPORT
Recommendation 1:
Mature age workers (35+) who become unemployed be eligible to access LMPs (labour market programmes) within 3 months of becoming unemployed.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Not supported

The Government's policy is to concentrate assistance on those jobseekers most disadvantaged in the labour market, namely the long term unemployed and those most at risk of joining this group. Targeting of assistance will be based both on job seekers' individual needs and the level of difficulties they face. Where it is deemed that job seekers' difficulties are so severe as to prevent them from getting a job, they will be eligible for assistance that directly addresses these difficulties under the new Community Support Programme.

Eligibility requirements relating to particular LMPs have recently been streamlined and simplified in line with the recommendations of the Commonwealth Employment Service Advisory Committee (see recommendation 15). Eligibility for LMP assistance is now generally based on job seekers' access to case management and their duration of unemployment.

Long‐term unemployed jobseekers who are in receipt of a Department of Social Security (DSS) unemployment allowance or some other type of income support are eligible for case management and LMP assistance, as are new registrants with the Commonwealth Employment Service who are assessed as being particularly disadvantaged and therefore at `high risk' of becoming long‐term unemployed. In most cases, new registrants who are selected for case management in this way will be receiving some kind of income support assistance from DSS.

The Jobseeker Screening Instrument (JSI) is an important part of this assessment process. Under the JSI, factors which predispose jobseekers to being at `high risk' are given a weighting to reflect the varying effect each has on the jobseeker's employment prospects. The more significant the factor, the higher the weighting it receives. These factors include educational attainment, birth in a non‐English speaking country, being an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander and being aged over 45 years. Other `supplementary factors' which may also be taken into account when assessing whether an unemployed person is at `high risk', include poor motivation, low self esteem and substantial time out of the workforce.

There is no evidence to suggest that unemployed jobseekers aged between 35 and 45 years old are particularly disadvantaged solely because of their age. Consequently, this is not one of the factors influencing the assessment of whether or not a jobseeker is at `high risk'.

Mature age jobseekers who are found to be at `high risk' are, however, immediately eligible for case management and most labour market programmes, including the Jobstart wage subsidy programme which has proven to be particularly effective in assisting mature age people into work. Data from the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs' 1995‐96 Annual Report show that 61.3 per cent of Jobstart participants aged 45 years and over had a positive outcome, compared to 56.3 per cent of all Jobstart participants.

LMP eligibility for jobseekers who are not eligible for case management depends on their duration of unemployment. These jobseekers are immediately eligible for some LMP assistance, such as job search and ancillary assistance. Jobseekers in receipt of a Department of Social Security benefit are immediately eligible for self‐employment assistance under the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme. After six months unemployment, all job seekers are eligible for Jobstart.

From March 1998 more flexible forms of assistance that are tailored to the individual needs and circumstances of jobseekers will be available. Employment Service Providers will be contracted to provide competitive labour exchange services (matching, referral and placement of jobseekers into real jobs), job search assistance and Employment Assistance for eligible clients. It is currently proposed that organisations which focus on assisting mature age jobseekers will be encouraged to tender to become Employment Service Providers in order to provide specialist services to mature aged jobseekers.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 2:
In cases where the retrenchment is foreseen, mature age workers be eligible to access case management assistance and advice in the months preceding the loss of employment.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Not supported
The recommended assistance would move responsibility from the employer to the taxpayer before it was apparent that long term unemployment would necessarily ensue.

If a person registers with the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES), receives an unemployment allowance or another type of approved income support from the Department of Social Security and is assessed as being at `high risk' by the CES they are eligible for case management. Under existing criteria, retrenchment, in itself, does not ensure that a mature age client will be identified as being at `high risk'.

The Training and Skills Programme (TASK) can assist employers faced with moving to a shortened working week or retrenching staff, to upgrade the skills of their workers. Under the Forestry Industry Labour Adjustment Package (FILAP), funds can be provided to establish `Enterprise Based Committees' to provide pre‐retrenchment assistance and re‐training for workers about to be retrenched.
It is not proposed to provide access to Employment Assistance through Employment Service Providers to people preceding the loss of their employment.
See also the response to majority recommendation 6.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 3:
More Mature Workers' Centres be established in country and regional centres.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 4: In areas where Mature Workers' Centres cannot be established, SkillShare centres should have special funding made available to cater to the needs of the over 35 age group.
Response: Neither recommendation is supported

The Mature Workers Centres sub‐programme ceased on 1 October 1996, as part of the process of simplifying the administration and delivery of the SkillShare programme. The Department, however, will continue to contract for services tailored to meet the needs of the local labour market and jobseekers, including those in the mature age group. This will be done through Skillshare up until the new arrangements take effect from March 1998, after which it will be done through Employment Service Providers (many of which are likely to have previously been Skillshare organisations).

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 5:

Consistent with the principle of treating people as individuals within Government funded programmes, mature workers who have been unemployed for 3 months or more be given access to LMPs (labour market programmes) regardless of their partner's employment status and income.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Not supported

Mature age clients registered as unemployed with the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) will continue to have access to labour market programmes in accordance with the details provided in the response to recommendation 1. This is irrespective of their partner's employment status or income. It should be noted, however, that eligibility for case management is closely tied to receipt of a Department of Social Security (DSS) benefit.

In the period up to March 1998, mature age job seekers who are not in receipt of a DSS benefit can still access most labour market programmes. In general, the number of labour market programmes for which a person is eligible increases with their duration of unemployment.

The New Enterprise Incentive Scheme (NEIS) is the only programme for which a client must be in receipt of a DSS benefit. In the case of NEIS, the Government pays the job seeker an allowance equivalent to the Newstart rate for twelve months while the business is being developed. The Government does not consider that a CES registrant, who does not receive a DSS benefit because their partner is a high income earner, should have access to the substantial levels of training assistance available under NEIS, at the taxpayers' expense.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 6:

The CES (Commonwealth Employment Service) adopt a pro‐active role in approaching firms engaged in restructuring and downsizing their work force to make those employers aware of programmes available through OLMA (the Office of Labour Market Adjustment) for staff facing retrenchment. For employees of small enterprises, pre‐retrenchment assistance should be available at the local CES office.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Supported in part

Under changes announced in the 1996‐97 Budget which are to be implemented in March 1998, most current labour market programmes will be `cashed out' together with funding for case management services, to create a single pool of resources for use in the new system. Under the umbrella of the Enterprise Adjustment Programme, however, OLMA will continue to provide programme assistance through the Forestry Industry LAP (FILAP), which will continue until June 2000, the Training and Skills programme (TASK) which will continue, but with reduced funding and OLMA Regional Strategies. LAPs for the Passenger Motor Vehicle and Textile, Clothing and Footwear Industries were abolished in the recent Budget.

Under the FILAP and TASK programmes, both of which are promoted through the CES Network, funds are available to establish Enterprise Based Committees to provide pre‐retrenchment assistance and re‐training for workers affected by restructuring and downsizing.

Under the OLMA Regional Strategies, Area Consultative Committees provide advice to the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs on strategies to improve the responsiveness of the CES to local employers and regional labour markets, to improve CES links with the regional development organisations and to foster better use of programmes, particularly through developing close working relationships. These Committees will continue to be promoted through the CES Network.

Where practicable the CES has always offered pre‐retrenchment services to small enterprises. The service ranges from registering workers before retrenchment, to providing on‐site placement services, sometimes on a fee‐for‐service basis. These services will continue to be provided following the commencement of the new employment placement market in March 1998. It has not yet been determined, however, whether they will be provided by the Service Delivery Agency or Employment Service Providers.
See also the response to majority recommendation 2.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 7:

The Government to fund an advertising campaign to encourage employers and the wider community to see the very real and positive contributions made to the national output by workers aged 40+. In particular, the advertising campaign should aim at breaking down the stereotypes of older workers as being too rigid for change and for learning new skills.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 8: The Commonwealth negotiate with the States and Territories to introduce uniform Australia‐wide discrimination legislation.
Response: Neither recommendation is supported
The Government recognises the very important contribution that older workers make to the community and is seeking to encourage older people to remain in the workforce in the following ways:

. The Government announced measures in the 1996‐97 Budget that will allow people to continue contributing to a regulated superannuation fund after the age of 65 where they maintain a bona fide role within the workforce. Reforms introduced in the Government's industrial relations legislation will outlaw the termination of employment on the basis of age.

. Based on recommendations of the Age Discrimination Task Force chaired by the Attorney‐General's Department, the Government has decided to abolish the compulsory retirement age for the Australian Public Service. This will take effect with the enactment of the new Public Service Act, scheduled for introduction to Parliament in 1997.

. The Government is examining further initiatives such as the Pension Bonus Plan which will allow people who wish to continue working to defer the Age Pension for up to five years, and receive an increased rate of pension when they eventually choose to retire.
The Government has no plans at this stage for an advertising campaign similar to that mentioned in recommendation 7.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the Attorney‐General's Department, in consultation with other Agencies, have been examining the desirability of introducing uniform Australia‐wide age discrimination legislation. There are no plans at this stage, however, to enter into negotiations with the States and Territories on this issue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 9:

The Commonwealth consider funding a number of Traineeships for Aboriginal nursing aides and teacher assistants currently working through CDEP on remote Aboriginal communities, so that they may become fully qualified and eligible for award wages. Traineeships in other vocational areas, such as carpentry and motor mechanics, where opportunities for employment may exist within local Aboriginal communities, should also be funded.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Supported in principle

A range of initiatives is currently in place to address this recommendation. Competency standards for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health workers are available at final draft stage and are awaiting official endorsement by the Community Services and Health Industry Training Advisory Board. These will provide a structured catalogue of the work elements which Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health workers should be able to perform, and are an important step in developing structured training which leads to a recognised vocational qualification.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people can apply for all apprenticeships and traineeships and can generate training incentives for their employers as well as wage subsides which are provided under the Training for Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders Programme (TAP). There is also a range of initiatives under both TAP and ABSTUDY which include the following:
. negotiations for a pilot programme to train Indigenous Health Workers in remote communities in Cape York;

. an arrangement with the Australian Medical Association in Western Australia for a five year employment strategy, involving recruitment of cadet nurses, orderlies, patient carers and receptionists (the latter receiving a four to six week training course);
. a twelve month part‐time Certificate Course in Primary Health Care for employed health care workers in Queensland; and
. aged Care Pilot Projects in the Northern Territory.

An Australian Vocational Training System pilot project includes a trial of traineeships for Aboriginal and Islander Education Workers, with the eventual aim of developing a national Aboriginal and Islander Education Worker career structure. The Australian National Training Authority has funded a project through the Regency Institute in South Australia to encourage Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to develop skills that can be applied in communities and which lead to real jobs. Both these projects include the development of competency standards.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 10:

All Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander unemployed people be given the opportunity to consult an Aboriginal case manager or contact officer who will assist in determining the most appropriate course of action for the unemployed person involved. A number of Aboriginal case managers/contact officers should be available to visit those CES (Commonwealth Employment Service) Offices where the numbers of Aboriginal unemployed people are too small to warrant the employment of a full‐time person.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Supported in principle

In its recent tender round, the Employment Services Regulatory Authority (ESRA) has increased the opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander unemployed people to consult a specialist case manager. ESRA has contracted 35 organisations to provide specialist services to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people from 53 sites across Australia. These organisations will provide services to around 4 700 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the period 1 December 1996 to 30 November 1997. This represents an increase from the previous contracts with specialist Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander providers, under which they were able to provide services to some 1 500 Indigenous Australians.

Selected CES Offices with significant numbers of registered Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander jobseekers employ Aboriginal Contact Officers. In addition, every effort is made to ensure that mainstream Employment Assistance Australia (EAA) case managers have an appropriate knowledge of the Indigenous community and are sensitive to their particular labour market situations:

. Aboriginal case managers can assist their non‐Aboriginal colleagues to develop an understanding of the cultural and other issues which impact on the employment potential of their Aboriginal clients;
. Non‐Aboriginal case managers who live in communities with high Aboriginal populations are in a position to acquire a good understanding of Aboriginal culture and norms;
. EAA case managers receive cultural awareness training to assist them in responding to the needs of their Indigenous clients; and

. Case studies which cover a range of disadvantaged client groups including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander clients are presented in the context of case management training, mainstream Departmental training and the Case Manager's Handbook.

As a result, a quality case management service can be provided, in particular where a team approach is adopted, for Aboriginal clients without specialist Aboriginal case managers necessarily being appointed. This is an important consideration in cases where, for example, some Aboriginal clients living in urban areas may prefer to be case managed by a non‐Aboriginal case manager.

For clients who live in remote regions, the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (DEETYA) has in place Remote Area Field Service (RAFS) staff who deliver CES and other Departmental services. Around three quarters of RAFS staff are either Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander people, and all but one of the 106 RAFS positions is identified, which means that the incumbent must have the ability to communicate sensitively and effectively with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, and to understand the issues affecting them. RAFS staff are fully equipped to visit registered clients in remote areas, and are trained in community development principles and the importance of community and ATSIC Regional Council Plans.

From March 1998 the functions of the CES will be replaced by Employment Service Providers and a Commonwealth Service Delivery Agency (SDA). It is anticipated that the SDA will employ specialist Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander officers along similar lines to the current CES Aboriginal Contact Officers, and Indigenous organisations will be encouraged to tender to become specialist Employment Service Providers. Along with other potential Employment Service Providers, interested Indigenous organisations will be assisted in preparing tenders by the measures below.

. The release in December 1996 of a `Tender Information Kit' consisting of draft tender documentation, conditions of tendering and contractual arrangements, regional information, an overview information paper and a survey form. The early release of the information kit will provide potential ESPs with the opportunity to develop appropriate strategies, analyse their own resources, capacity and suitability and seek external assistance as required.
. Ongoing access to advice from DEETYA staff at both a national and regional level.
. Following the official call for tenders in June 1997, information sessions for potential bidders will be held at a regional level.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 11:

The Government re‐examine programmes of language instruction for skilled migrants and long‐term unemployed persons of non‐English speaking backgrounds, with a view to increasing the present level of free or subsidised tuition and the skill‐specific component of language training, and combining language training with other training programmes.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Supported in principle

The Government recognises that functional English is a key to economic and social well‐being. Under revised arrangements announced in the 1996‐97 Budget, English as a Second Language (ESL) assistance to migrants is provided under the Adult Migrant English Programme (AMEP), the Jobseeker Preparation and Support Programme (JPS), the Advanced English for Migrants Programme (AEMP) and the Workplace English Language and Literacy Programme (WELL). The Government will also continue to provide funding through the Australian National Training Authority to State and Territory governments for ESL assistance.
