ESL assistance provided by the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (DEETYA) has been streamlined as part of an overall rationalisation of labour market assistance. Up until the introduction of the new employment placement market in March 1998, ESL assistance under JPS will focus on preparatory training which will allow jobseekers to participate in the labour market. Additional higher level ESL assistance will still be available under the AEMP, but will be increasingly linked to particular vocations or occupations.

The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA) is introducing more flexible arrangements under the AMEP to meet the needs of clients. For example, the 510 hour limit on tuition under the AMEP may be varied on an individual basis and clients may be given greater choice in taking up and completing AMEP tuition.

The new competitive labour market arrangements to be introduced from March 1998 will be client‐focused rather than programme driven, with labour market programme assistance provided by Employment Service Providers. Employment Service Providers will be responsible for providing basic vocational language and literacy training to clients as required, with more advanced ESL assistance provided under AEMP and WELL. DIMA and DEETYA are liaising about ways to ensure that jobseekers from non‐English speaking backgrounds continue to receive assistance which is tailored to their individual needs and circumstances.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 12:

DEET (now the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, or DEETYA) further develop the community‐based choices available to NESB (non‐English speaking background) migrants in programmes involving individual case management, searching for a job or creating self‐employment.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Supported, action under way

DEETYA has been developing the community‐based options for people from non English speaking backgrounds for some time. The Employment Services Regulatory Authority (ESRA) has contracted case managers who provide specialist services to this and other groups. Last year ESRA had contracts with 22 organisations to provide specialist services from 37 sites across Australia. These organisations provided services to approximately 8 500 job seekers from a non‐English speaking background. ESRA has increased the accessibility of specialist services to job seekers from non English speaking backgrounds and has contracted 34 organisations to provide specialist services to these job seekers for the period 1 December 1996 to 30 November 1997. These organisations will provide services to around 8 800 job seekers from 49 sites across Australia.

The Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) has a network of Migrant Liaison Officers whose duties include working with case managers to identify problems and to develop strategies to improve services to migrants. DEETYA also assists with the placement of Employment Liaison Officers (ELOs) in ethnic organisations, particularly ethnic Chambers of Commerce. ELOs facilitate linkages between ethnic communities and the CES with a view to increasing employment and training opportunities.

DIMA is liaising with DEETYA about ways in which a community‐specific approach may complement proposed labour market assistance arrangements targeted to meet individual needs of job seekers from non English speaking backgrounds. This includes the establishment of Specialist Employment Service Providers.

In relation to the issue of creating self‐employment, pilot projects using ethnic organisations (including Migrant Resource Centres) as managing agents for the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme (NEIS) were undertaken and evaluated in 1994‐95. Following these pilots, assistance to migrants has become a mainstream NEIS priority. The proportion of migrants establishing new businesses with assistance under the scheme continued to increase in 1996‐97.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 13:

The recently announced programme of a Job Offer Guarantee for eight selected regions of high youth unemployment be expanded to other regions to facilitate pathways between vocational education in Years 1l and 12 and young people's first full‐time jobs. Such an expansion should be set within the development of State Training Profiles, thereby recognising the role of schools in vocational training at the post‐compulsory level, and allowing them to have formal access to ANTA (Australian National Training Authority) growth funding.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Supported, action under way

The Jobs Pathway Programme (JPP) provides assistance to students who have completed vocational education programmes as part of their Year 11 and 12 schooling, to make the transition from school to work by giving them access to an employment broker in their local area. The programme, which began in 1995, was targeted at eight regions chosen because of their high unemployment rates. Difficulties were encountered, however, because not all of these regions had substantial numbers of students completing vocational education programmes in schools.

The Programme has been expanded in 1996‐97 to include twenty regions across Australia. Regions have been selected where significant numbers of students are completing vocational education programmes in local schools. This will resolve the difficulties noted above and will align JPP to school‐industry priorities for vocational preparation of students.

The ANTA Ministerial Council agreed on 20 September 1996 to the provision of $20 million of Vocational Education and Training funds in each of the next four calendar years for vocational education and training in schools. Funds will be provided to State and Territory Training Authorities to allocate to school authorities.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 14:

DEET (now the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, or DEETYA) widely publicise the monitoring of breaches of agreements by employers in their use of subsidised labour and the subsequent action taken by DEET(YA).

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Not supported
The Government has serious reservations about publicising breaches of agreements by employers because of confidentiality and privacy concerns, which may have legal implications.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 15:
The Government review current LMPs (labour market programmes) with a view to simplifying, as far as possible, the administrative and regulatory requirements placed on employer participants.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Supported, action under way

In 1995, the Commonwealth Employment Service Advisory Committee (CESAC) examined administrative arrangements for the delivery and monitoring of LMPs. CESAC, whose members are drawn from business and industry, the union movement, welfare interests, the Technical and Further Education sector and the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (DEETYA), consulted widely with interested parties and presented its report in August 1995. The key message of the report was the need for simplification, as reflected in the following recommendations:
. rationalising labour market programmes and grouping them into strategic categories;
. streamlining the administrative arrangements for labour market programmes (including guidelines, forms and allowances);
. simplifying the eligibility criteria underpinning LMPs; and
. using accredited training modules in vocational training courses to meet regional labour market needs.

CESAC's key recommendations were implemented on 7 October 1996. A new, simpler set of labour market programmes will help employers, providers, case managers, DEETYA staff and unemployed people understand the range of assistance available to them. Administrative arrangements have been streamlined and simplified with clearer guidelines, fewer forms and consistent eligibility criteria across programmes. There are now only four categories of programmes. These are:
. Employer Incentives —incentives for employers to employ (and train) eligible people and to arrange placements for more disadvantaged clients;
. Enterprise and Adjustment —assistance for individuals, enterprises and regions;
. Training for Employment —to assist unemployed people to gain employment through the provision or enhancement of vocational skills linked to specific employment opportunities; and
. Jobseeker Preparation and Support —to help jobseekers access employment and training opportunities and address barriers which may be preventing this.

These changes to labour market programmes are the first step in making the transition from highly structured programmes with complex rules and regulations to a simple structure where providers have the flexibility to deliver or purchase the individually tailored assistance needed to get a jobseeker into long term employment. With the commencement of the new employment placement market in March 1998, labour market arrangements will become even more client focused, as opposed to programme driven.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 16:

The current programmes funded by DEET (now the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, or DEETYA) be reviewed to ensure that their duration and funding are adequate to enable providers to achieve the planned outcomes.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Supported, action under way

The major goal of the Government's employment strategy is to assist unemployed job seekers into real jobs. From March 1998, Employment Service Providers, including the public Employment Service Provider, will be contracted to provide labour market assistance tailored to the specific needs of individual job seekers. Employment Service Providers will be judged and rewarded on the basis of getting their clients into sustained employment.

Fixed price tendering will be used for Employment Assistance (EA) for the first contract round to facilitate market development. The fee structure will vary prices according to the type of outcome and client category. In view of the additional assistance that will be required to place the more disadvantaged job seekers into employment, there will be higher EA fees paid to Employment Service Providers for successful outcomes for these clients.

The highest level of funding for EA will be for those most disadvantaged clients classified as EA Level 3. Eligibility for EA Level 3 will include all job seekers who are assessed as having serious barriers to employment.

In recognition that EA Level 3 clients may need more than the standard twelve months assistance to help them get a job, all EA Level 3 participants will be entitled to eighteen months assistance. In addition, if the ESP and a job seeker believe they are close to achieving an outcome, they can agree to extend the EA period by up to another six months (without additional funding).

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation l7

In its evaluation of case management DEET (now the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, or DEETYA) monitor the extent to which those not eligible for case management request such support.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Not supported

Although it would be possible to monitor the extent to which jobseekers request case management, it would not be feasible to obtain reliable data concerning their eligibility and need for case management, on a continuous basis.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 18:

DEET (now the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, or DEETYA) and ESRA (the Employment Services Regulatory Authority) give wide dissemination to the first results of their evaluation of case management in the public, private and community sectors, including the methods and data used in such evaluation.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 19: ESRA publish on a regular basis the results of its ongoing monitoring of case management practices and outcomes .
Response: Both supported, action under way

ESRA and DEETYA have jointly conducted an interim evaluation of case management. The results of this evaluation, together with a discussion of the evaluation methodology, were included in the broader report of the Working Nation evaluation, entitled Working Nation: Evaluation of the employment, education and training elements.

This report has been widely disseminated, with copies provided to all contracted case management organisations, other stake holders, and all other public, private and community sector organisations which requested a copy. It is now available through Australian Government Publishing Service Book Shops to ensure maximum community access to the evaluation findings.

ESRA will continue to evaluate aspects of the case management system during 1996‐97. Priorities for evaluation include case management processes and practice which will lead to a report on `best practice' in this field. ESRA will continue to disseminate the results of its evaluations widely.

ESRA provides case managers with quarterly monitoring reports on the performance of the case management system. These reports include data that enable case management organisations to compare their performance at the outlet level with that of similar, but unidentified, providers.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 20:

DEET (now the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, or DEETYA) and ESRA (the Employment Services Regulatory Authority) give high priority to developing formal coordination between CES (Commonwealth Employment Service) offices, case management organisations and EAA (Employment Assistance Australia) in negotiating with local employers. It further recommends that an evaluation of such arrangements be conducted within the next twelve months.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Not supported

While contracted case managers have access to Jobsystem vacancies through DEETYA's Jobsystem employment data base, they are expected to build and develop their own networks and links with employers, rather than rely on a centralised approach. A key objective in introducing competition into the delivery of case management services is to improve outcomes by enabling employers to choose from a range of case managers offering different services in terms of cost, quality and timeliness as well as varying levels of expertise with different types of employers and jobseekers.

. An interim evaluation of case management found that employers express a strong prefer ence for working with employment assistance agencies which have in‐depth knowledge of their business and the industry in which they are located.

As part of its market development role, ESRA is giving priority in 1996‐97 to the implementation of an employer strategy to improve contracted case managers' understanding of the training and recruitment needs of employers, and to raise employers' knowledge of the case management system. It is expected that the implementation of this strategy will improve case managers' skills in working with employers.

The Government is actively promoting competition between case management providers through ESRA, and will therefore not support coordination arrangements that restrict or impinge on contracted providers' access to employers, or on employers' freedom to choose the providers with whom they want to work.

Under the new arrangements for the delivery of employment services which will take effect from March 1998, the labour exchange function currently carried out by the CES will also be subject to competition, from private and community sector providers. These new arrangements will be evaluated as part of the broader evaluation of the new employment placement market.

Area and Regional Managers of DEETYA have responsibility for establishing the most effective linkages between Employer Servicing Units (ESUs) in the CES and EAA case managers, particularly with regard to identifying relative responsibilities for vacancy gathering, referral procedures and vacancy servicing. ESU officers can assist case managers to liaise with employers by providing support at meetings, assistance in negotiating subsidies, and advice on using out‐posted officers as intermediaries between the case manager and employers/industries.

Other mechanisms by which the EAA Unit in DEETYA National Office assists EAA case managers to increase the level of successful employment outcomes achieved for their job seeker clients include: the organisation of workshops to develop effective job referral and placement strategies; the monitoring of referral activity with feedback provided to individual outlets; and Jobs First , a continuous improvement project aimed at enhancing placement performance by refining, improving and designing core business processes.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 21:

DEET (now the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, or DEETYA) place a high priority on the rapid introduction of systems able to produce monthly or quarterly disaggregated statistics on the results of employment programmes, distinguishing, on a regional basis between those placed in training, those placed in subsidised work, and those gaining unsubsidised employment.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Supported

Statistics on employment program commencements disaggregated by geographical location can be obtained from existing Departmental management information systems. This information, which distinguishes between the types of assistance provided and includes information relating to unsubsidised employment outcomes, is updated weekly and is available within the Department on a regular basis. Geographically disaggregated information will continue to be available under the new employment assistance arrangements. It is important to note that disaggregated information can be reported only in accordance with the geographical units that DEETYA uses for administrative purposes. This means that information is generally not available for closely defined specific locations, such as parts of metropolitan areas or rural areas.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 22:

COAG (the Council of Australian Governments), in consultation with ALGA (the Australian Local Government Association), develop a major programme of public investment in social and physical infrastructure.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Not supported.
The Government recognises that the quality and quantity of a nation's infrastructure plays a significant role in its overall economic performance.

There is no conclusive evidence, however, in support of the need for a broad, untargeted programme of public investment in social and physical infrastructure in Australia. The National Commission of Audit (NCA) recently found that although there is evidence of both shortages and excess capacity of particular types of infrastructure, `there is no evidence of overall infrastructure inadequacy in Australia'.

The NCA's findings are supported by the Economic Policy Advisory Commission's Private Infrastructure Task Force (Interim Report, May 1995) which also found examples of both under and over investment but concluded that sectoral analyses `do not provide strong support for the argument that Australia's level of spending on infrastructure is insufficient to meet its longer term needs'.

Consequently, a major programme of public investment in social and physical infrastructure is not supported. Where potential needs for infrastructure development are identified, they should be evaluated on a case by case basis, with regard to the alternative uses of funds, including the economic benefits of fiscal consolidation.
Even where a clear need for infrastructure development exists, there is a range of options for funding the development, from total public funding through to full private entrepreneurship.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 23

Divert some part of existing expenditure on unemployment to programmes designed to provide training and work experience through employment in the construction and repair of physical infrastructure at the State and local government level.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Supported in part
The key objective of providing labour market assistance is to help those job seekers who are disadvantaged in the labour market into continuing paid employment.

Under now discontinued brokered programmes, particularly the Landcare and Environment Action Programme (LEAP) and New Work Opportunities (NWO), many job seekers were provided with project based work experience and training. This was utilised extensively by both local and State governments to undertake infrastructure and environmental work.

Outcomes data suggest that such project based programmes do not produce good employment outcomes for participants. The Government therefore replaced LEAP and NWO with a new and more tightly targeted programme called Special Employer Support. The programme provides eligible clients with twenty weeks of work experience and training with employers who have the intention and the capacity to retain the job seeker at the end of the placement. The Special Employer Support programme does not have a project orientation. Rather, it relies on individual placements with employers.

Complementing this approach, the recently announced pilot youth `work for the dole' scheme would involve participants in community‐based projects. Rather than being "employed" in the project, participants would continue to receive their unemployment allowance from the Department of Social Security. Participants would work the number of hours necessary to earn their unemployment allowance as if they were being paid award rates. The focus of the scheme would be to expose young people to a work environment and to develop a work ethic. Projects would be assessed according to their benefit to the community.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 24
The

Government allow employers, as an alternative to accessing job subsidy schemes, a 150% tax deduction (at the company rate) on new (ie additional) permanent employment of people who have been unemployed for 6 months or more.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Not supported.

To be effective, labour market assistance needs to be targeted at those most in need and tailored to the particular circumstances and employment barriers faced by individual jobseekers. The proposed tax deduction scheme would make it very difficult to effectively target assistance, and would be inconsistent with the Government's aim of simplifying and streamlining labour market arrangements. The proposed tax deduction scheme would also compromise the objectives of simplicity, clarity and efficiency for the taxation system.

Many businesses would not be able to benefit from the 150 per cent tax deduction as a result of carrying over financial losses from the previous financial year. Furthermore, even profit making businesses would not be able to make a claim against their incomes until the following financial year. The delivery of assistance through the tax system would therefore provide a much smaller incentive for business to take on new workers, as opposed to a wage subsidy through which businesses receive immediate assistance.

The National Commission of Audit (NCA) identified a number of problems with the use of the tax system to deliver assistance. The NCA argued that this approach was less visible than outlays programmes, and therefore less likely to be critically assessed and reviewed to ensure that the benefits of assistance outweigh the costs. They also noted that programmes that deliver assistance through the tax system are generally uncapped, open‐ended and susceptible to cost blowouts.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 25
The
Commonwealth propose the abolition of payroll tax and negotiate an appropriate revenue compensation to the States and Territories.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Not supported.

Payroll taxes currently amount to around $6 billion Australia‐wide, which is a significant proportion of the States' and Territories' own‐source revenue. The Commonwealth would therefore need to raise this amount (assuming it fully compensated the States and Territories for foregone revenues) by either imposing new taxes, increasing existing tax rates or reducing outlays accordingly.

The recent report of the Small Business Deregulation Task Force recommended that the States and Territories increase efforts to harmonise payroll tax arrangements with a view to achieving national consistency in the 1998‐99 financial year. In line with the Task Force's recommendation, the Commonwealth will support and encourage this process.

PARA.EMPHASIS: SECTION B—RESPONSE TO THE MINORITY REPORT
Minority Recommendation 1:
Incentives to income beneficiaries for workforce participation and other self‐help measures be enhanced through:
1) aligning allowance taper rates, currently up to 70 per cent, with the taper rates of 50 per cent applying to pensions;
2) aligning the earnings credit available to allowees with that available to pensioners; and
3) moving towards aligning the single adult allowance rate with the pension rate.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: None of these measures are supported

The Department of Social Security has been examining the potential to align the pension and allowance systems and simplify arrangements relating to both customer groups. While maintaining different payment and income test taper rates for allowees and pensioners makes the system more complex, the economic and financial costs of changing allowee payment rates, income test taper rates and the earnings credit to align them with those of pensioners would be significant.

In setting the taper rates for the allowance and pension systems it is necessary to have regard to work incentives effects, effective marginal tax rates and replacement rates. The principal aim behind the reduction of the 100 per cent taper rate to 70 per cent was to encourage more unemployed clients to take up increased amounts of paid work. Further reducing the taper rate to 50 per cent, however, could result in some income support recipients receiving significantly higher incomes than some full‐time workers. This would discourage such people from seeking more work, diminishing full‐time work incentives and undermining the integrity of the social security system.
The Government announced in the 1996‐97 Budget that the Earnings Credit Scheme for pensions and allowances is to be abolished.
Aligning the rate for the single adult unemployment allowance with the pension rate would also have an impact on work incentives.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Minority Recommendation 2:
The Government give consideration to expanding emergency mortgage relief.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: No longer relevant

The proposed new Commonwealth/State Housing Agreement (CSHA) will give State Governments greater flexibility in how they use their share of CSHA funds, including the option of increasing mortgage relief where this is considered necessary.
Minority Recommendation 3: Extension of the pilot projects on the Community Information Network and the Action Research Projects, if appropriate, to a national basis.
Response: No longer relevant
The Community Information Network was closed on 4 October 1996, and the Action Research Pilots concluded at the end of 1996.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Minority Recommendation 4:
Consideration be given to the possible liberalisation of the criteria for pension age to enable voluntary early retirement.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation: Not supported

The age pension is payable to men at age 65 and to women at age 60 years and 6 months, with the age pension age for women being progressively raised by 6 months every two years until it reaches 65 in July 2013. Male and female retirement ages are being aligned in recognition of the increasing participation of women in the workforce and the importance of ensuring that men and women are treated equally in the labour market.

Demographic projections point to a significant ageing of the Australian population by the second decade of the next century. The number of people over the age of 65 is projected to increase from its current level of 1.9 million to 3.9 million by 2021 and the proportion of the population aged 65 and over is expected to increase from 11 per cent to 18 per cent. The spread of private superannuation should reduce reliance on the age pension in future, but this will take several decades to take full effect. Current projections envisage a continuing significant dependence on the age pension.

Lowering the qualifying age for the age pension could therefore seriously jeopardise Australia's ability to provide sustainable and adequate income support for older people in the community who have been unable to save for their own retirement. Similar pressures are being experienced in other developed countries and many, like Australia, are looking to encourage continued labour market participation of mature age workers to help meet the cost of retirement.

There is a range of alternative income support arrangements which address particular needs of people aged 50 years and over who are either unable to find employment or who are unable to work. These include payments which do not require job search activities by the recipient, as well as payments which have modified job search requirements for people over a specified age limit.

The non‐activity tested payments include Partner Allowance, Mature Age Allowance (MAA), Widow Allowance, Carer Pension, Disability Support Pension and Sickness Allowance. Although Newstart Allowance (NSA) is activity tested, there are special provisions for those over 50 years. Newstart Allowees aged 50 and over can lodge their NSA continuation forms every 12 weeks instead of fortnightly, and have the option of seeking and/or participating in substantial part‐time work instead of seeking full‐time work.

Single Newstart Allowees aged 60 or over receive early assessment and access to labour market training and wage subsidy placements. Where such allowees have been on income support for at least 9 months, they receive an allowance equivalent to the pension and access through the pensioner concession card to the full range of Commonwealth fringe benefits.

In applying the activity test, the interpretation of what is suitable paid work has regard to the specific circumstances of older NSA recipients. Activity agreements also have regard to a customers age and re‐employment prospects.

The MAA was implemented in recognition of the disadvantages faced by older people in the current labour market environment. It is available to people aged 60 years and over but under age pension age who have no recent workforce experience and who have received a social security pension or allowance or a service pension during the previous 13 weeks. People who have been receiving a Newstart Allowance only qualify if they have been receiving income support for a continuous period of at least 9 months immediately before the date of claim. People on MAA are not activity tested and are paid at the pension rate and receive pension type concessions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Minority Recommendation 5:

The Commonwealth, as a matter of urgency, address through COAG (the Council of Australian Governments) the issue of complementary Commonwealth/State action with regard to the nation's training and education needs. This may involve a consideration of the issue of financial sanctions.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Supported, action under way.

The Commonwealth is addressing the issue of Commonwealth, State and Territory action with regard to the nation's vocational education and training needs through the Australian National Training Authority (ANTA) Agreement. ANTA was established in 1992 by Commonwealth, State and Territory Heads of Government to develop a national system of vocational education and training. It has an industry‐based Board appointed by Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers responsible for vocational education and training.

The Commonwealth directs its vocational education and training funding to ANTA for disbursement to the States and Territories under nationally agreed allocation principles that reflect the Strategic Plan approved by the ANTA Ministerial Council.

COAG established a Review of the ANTA Agreement which reported in February 1996. The Commonwealth and all States and Territories made submissions to the Review. COAG is yet to consider a response to the Report.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Minority Recommendation 6:

The Government confirm a policy setting to encourage long‐term investments by superannuation funds, and that a clear agreement be reached between the Govern ment and the superannuation industry on the future of national savings.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Supported in part.

The Government recognises the importance of encouraging superannuation funds to have long‐term investment strategies. However, it does not consider it practicable or desirable to enter into some form of `agreement' with the superannuation funds on the matter.

The Government encourages the collection and dissemination of financial information which will help trustees and fund managers to develop the best investment choices. For example, from 1995‐96, superannuation fund trustees must report to members on the annual investment returns for each of the past five years and returns on a five year rolling average basis. This will provide members with a focus on the longer term performance of their superannuation funds.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Minority Recommendation 7:
The Government foster an appropriate investment environment which will protect and encourage trustees of funds to invest in small and medium‐sized enterprises.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Supported in principle.

The Government has set in place a range of policy and programme initiatives to help foster an environment which will increase investment in SMEs, and encourage the trustees of superannuation funds to make such investments an integral part of their diverse portfolios and long term strategies.

As announced in the Prime Minister's statement, More Time for Business , the Government is to introduce a new programme aimed at providing `early stage' and `start up' capital to small technology‐based firms. A Small Business Innovation Fund will be established comprising up to six separate funds each investing approximately $30 million to $50 million with the Government providing $2 for every $1 of private capital. In total, the funds will provide investment in over 100 small, technology‐based firms over five years. The investment decisions of each fund will be made by private sector fund managers within government guidelines.

The Government will review the Pooled Development Funds (PDF) Programme with a view to improving its operation. This programme encourages the provision of patient equity capital to eligible SMEs by allowing shareholders in registered PDFs, such as superannuation funds, to receive tax concessions on income from investments.

Superannuation funds may not be investing more in SMEs due to a lack of awareness of quality SME investments. Many SMEs fail to attract investment because of a failure to adequately sell their proposals to potential investors, rather than any underlying problems with the investment proposals themselves. A study commissioned by the Government and conducted by Ernst and Young and the Centre for Innovation and Enterprise has developed a set of investment criteria that apply to the different types of SMEs, stages of growth and investor types. These criteria will assist SMEs to understand the requirements of investors, to help them become `investment ready'.

The Government has provided support to the Australian Development Capital Association and the Australian Institute of Superannuation Trustees to assist them to prepare and distribute information on development capital investment in Australia, to increase trustees' understanding of SMEs as an asset class.

Larger funds are better placed to make use of specialist intermediaries for investing in SMEs, and so superannuation fund investment in SMEs is expected to rise as the pool of superannuation saving grows.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Minority Recommendation 8:

The Government establish a Seed Capital Fund for the purposes of supporting `spin‐off' developments from universities' intellectual property. The fund would assist development both to prototype stage and business concept stage to enable projects to be taken up by industry or venture capital bodies.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Supported in principle.

The Government recognises the benefits of improving the commercialisation of research outcomes from Australia's public sector. There are already a number of programmes and initiatives which address this specific issue. For example, the Cooperative Research Centres Programme strengthens the links between university and other public sector research with users of that research in industry. The Australian Technology Group is a technology commercialisation company that invests in early stage commercialisation of technologies, providing a seed and start‐up capital and management expertise.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Minority Recommendation 9:
A major study be undertaken by the Australian Manufacturing Council into options to expand manufacturing activity. In particular the study should consider the propositions that:
1) the corporate sector put management performance at the focus of microeconomic reform during the 1990s;
2) the unions develop the skills of shop stewards to advance worker empowerment through collective bargaining;
3) the Commonwealth Government establish a National Key Centre on the workplace of the 21st century;
4) firms encourage management development through job experience and not solely on elite business school training;
5) firms restructure training for frontline managers to develop specialist skills in work organisation change;
6) firms develop strategies for promoting more women into senior management and on equal pay.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: No longer relevant

The Australian Manufacturing Council (AMC) ceased operation on 30 June 1996 and has not been replaced by any similar body. In future, the Government will consult with manufacturing industries through sectorally based fora or with industry broadly, as issues arise. The Government has retained support for industry through a suite of AusIndustry programmes aimed at improving business management skills at the enterprise level.

The Government considers managerial skills to be of critical importance to Australian industry's ability to compete and grow in an increasingly competitive global economy. The Frontline Management Initiative (FMI) is a national strategy designed to provide enterprises with a variety of options to develop their frontline managers. Up to one million dollars has been set aside to develop a training infrastructure and stimulate industry awareness of the benefits that will result from such training. The training infrastructure includes the development and endorsement of frontline manager competency standards, an assessment framework, a database on training programmes, accreditation of FMI, review of management development products and a staff development strategy.

The Commonwealth has provided funds to the Australian National Training Authority to develop a national training framework for frontline managers and contracted the Australian Institute of Management to undertake twelve demonstration projects in enterprises in NSW, Victoria, South Australia and the ACT.
. The generic competency standards for frontline managers have been endorsed and the Commonwealth has provided $500,000 to trial the national training strategy.

Regarding gender equity matters, the Department of Industrial Relations funded the Affirmative Action Agency to identify best practice employers in affirmative action. The Best Affirmative Action Employers were announced in the national media on 6 August 1996 and received certificates from the Minister for Industrial Relations on 4 September 1996, at which time a case study book and video on the award winners were released.

DIR is also committed to preparing a self‐audit manual on pay equity on behalf of the National Labour Consultative Council. This manual is expected to assist employers and employees at enterprise level to review existing pay policies and practices to ensure equal remuneration applies. Work on the project is currently in progress.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Minority Recommendation 10:
1) Government should provide leadership and consistent policies in pursuit of clear national objectives.
2) Government should continue to be involved in general trade promotion through targeted programmes.

3) Management should give more emphasis to non‐price factors such as packaging, quality, service, delivery and a prompt response to customers' needs so that even standard products can acquire a brand image in export markets.
4) Government should continue to assist private research through special provisions for tax deductibility and through the Grants for Research and Development (GIRD) scheme.
5) Government direct expenditure on R&D through the CSIRO and other agencies be maintained or increased.

6) The Government's industry strategy should continue to pursue the following three objectives: the restructuring and revitalisation of existing industries; the emergence of new, innovative firms and new industries; and the development and dissemination of generic technologies, such as new materials or information technology, which are vital to the future competitiveness of industries.

7) There should be continued Government support for organisations which promote the development of manufacturing industries including Austrade, NIES, CSIRO, the Technology Transfer Council, AMC and ASTEC.

8) Government should continue to monitor foreign investment in Australia to encourage projects which raise productivity, add to local skills, technology and R&D, involve a minimum of restrictions on export marketing and generate net foreign exchange earnings.

9) Government policy should give priority to assisting industries according to the following criteria: national security (industries such as steel, oil and food, natural competitive advantage); critical mass (established industries like vehicle manufacturing whose loss without replacement would devastate the economy); and strategic characteristics (industries where assistance is likely to generate higher R&D, rising skills, rising productivity and greater innovation).

10) Government should encourage, as likely future high growth areas, information technology, telecommunications, automation systems, new materials and chemicals, biotechnology, environmental management, pharmaceuticals, scientific and medical instruments and high tech fibres.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Each of these ten sub‐recommendations is supported, at least in principle.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sub‐recommendation 1)
PARA.TAB: Response Supported

SPEECH.PARA: Sub‐recommendations 2) and 3) Response: Supported in principle.

The Government has a number of policies and programmes in place to help firms realise their export potential and improve their access to international markets. These initiatives are also designed to develop positive overseas perceptions of Australian products. These measures include the Export Market Development Grants scheme and the support provided by Austrade and Export Finance and Insurance Corporation.

AusIndustry provides a suite of enterprise improvement programmes to assist firms in a range of areas including business planning, marketing, quality improvement, benchmarking and best practice. These services can assist firms to emphasise the various non‐price based advantages of their goods and services. In addition, the Supermarket to Asia programme is designed to develop strategies to overcome impediments to food exports to Asia.

Government purchasing policies allow Australian firms, who meet the set quality standard for endorsement as a supplier to the Australian Government. This endorsement can be used by firms to support their push into overseas markets and promote their products as credible, quality goods and services.
Sub‐recommendation 4) Response: Supported, action under way

The Government supports private sector research and development (R&D) through the 125% tax concession for R&D. The Government has rationalised the R&D grants scheme and established a new programme of strategic assistance for R&D called START. The START programme provides a flexible package of assistance to industry for research, development and commercialisation. The programme provides a mix of support measures based on grants, loans and interest rate subsidies to eligible firms and includes the recently announced Small Business Innovation Fund which will invest in more than 100 small technology firms over five years.
Sub‐recommendation 5) Response: Supported, action under way

The Government has announced a range of initiatives in the 1996‐97 Budget to maintain a world class science and research effort. The initiatives aim to build on Australia's existing strong research base to strengthen industry and develop innovative new industries. The Government has maintained research funds for the science agencies such as the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, the Australian Institute of Marine Science and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). Furthermore, funding for Cooperative Research Centres has been increased, with two new centres to be established in 1997‐98.
Sub‐recommendations 6), 9) and 10) Response: Supported in principle

The Government is committed to building a strong and competitive economy capable of facing the challenges and exploiting the opportunities arising from increasing globalisation. The Government is providing an environment which supports business investment and employment. Its Budget strategy will reduce public sector borrowings, easing pressure on interest rates. Its microeconomic reform programme will increase productivity and lower business input costs.

The Government is building a coherent and effective industry policy which will achieve economic and employment growth. This policy focuses on generic support to address clear instances of market failure and increase firms' efficiency and competitiveness. Encouraging innovation is a critical element of this support.

Generic policies are supplemented by transitional, sector‐specific assistance to facilitate structural change and increase economic efficiency. The Government is reviewing programmes for the information technology, automotive, and textile clothing and footwear industries to ensure that any future assistance arrangements effectively and efficiently promote the development of viable, sustainable and internationally competitive industries in Australia.

The Government is committed to maintaining an internationally competitive environment for its pharmaceutical industry into the 21st century. Two of the most important factors shaping investment in the pharmaceutical industry on an international basis are the extent of price controls and the competitiveness of patents regimes. As a consequence in April 1997 the Government announced $300m over five years for a new program to follow on from the existing Factor(f) scheme and also to the extension of patent terms.
Sub‐recommendation 7) Response: Supported

The 1996‐97 Budget maintains Government support for a range of industry programmes which encourage innovation and skills formations and foster development and growth of firms. AusIndustry remains the Government's central point for business assistance. AusIndustry's Enterprise Development Programmes are targeted at the enterprise level and aim to encourage the adoption of best practice, lifting productivity and assisting firms to enter overseas markets. They seek to develop a culture of innovation throughout Australian Industry and to strengthen our integration with the international economy.

The Government established the Mortimer Review of Business Programs to formulate a more strategic whole of Government approach to business programs and to assess the extent to which existing programs are effective in helping Australian industry become more globally competitive. The
Mortimer Review will report to the Government in June 1997.
Sub‐recommendation 8) Response: Supported

The Government has decided to continue the investment promotion and facilitation programme and the regional headquarters programme to further encourage foreign investment in Australia. These programmes will spearhead the Government's commitment to attract new productive foreign investment to Australia, which brings with it new technology and expertise and enhances the capability of local industry.

ROW.ENTRY: Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs
Training for Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders Programme
Workplace English Language and Literacy Programme

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I rise tonight to address the latest NBEET report, in this case a review of institutional use of Commonwealth higher education funding, particularly in relation to indigenous students. It is a particularly timely report that examines the progress we have made in indigenous students' participation in the higher education sector. More importantly, it does so looking at the context of higher education funding against a backdrop of recent cuts slashing higher education budgets that we have seen as a consequence of the coalition government.

I note that the report makes a number of recommendations, including the need to further examine the impact of cuts, specifically cuts to operating grants, on a number of target equity groups in our community, particularly the target equity group of Aboriginal and islander students.

The report notes that there are certain levels of assistance or measures that are designed to assist participation rates of indigenous students in the higher education sector. They include Austudy, Abstudy, the Aboriginal tutorial assistance scheme and the scholarships that have been promoted by this government.

The report also notes that cuts to those very areas, in particular Abstudy, and the possibility of taxation of Austudy and Abstudy grants to Aboriginal and islander people as well as restrictions or any cuts to ATAS, the tutorial assistance schemes for indigenous Australians, will severely hinder and severely impact upon participation rates of indigenous students in this higher education sector.

The report suggests further examination of the impact of these cuts and also looks at the issue of HECS. The report quite obviously and blatantly states that any cuts to financial assistance, any cuts to operating grants—because a lot of these equity measures are financed directly out of operating grants to university institutions—and any increases to fees and charges—in particular, the HECS hikes that we have seen recently—or up-front and full cost fees, will impact most harshly on Aboriginal and islander students in our community.

The report also acknowledges that there is a broad tension between the trend to use performance as a basis for funding, on the one hand, as well as the possibility of reduced access to other funds such as ATAS and Abstudy, on the other. The report also notes that the provision of equity scholarships are strongly supported.

When I talk about equity scholarships, many of you would be aware that the coalition has promoted the idea of 4,000 equity scholarships over the next four years for those students, on merit, who should be involved in higher education but who, for some reason, cannot afford the fees that are currently being charged. Apart from that, all we know is that the scholarships will be determined by institutions. We do not know of any guidelines surrounding these particular scholarships. But 4,000 scholarships over four years, to me, seems quite a token effort. Many of the indigenous support groups and communities have acknowledged that very few Aboriginal or islander people will have a shot at one of these scholarships. I believe it is rumoured that an Aboriginal or islander person will have a one‐in‐4,000 chance of getting into an institution like Sydney University on one of those scholarships.

The report also notes that indigenous Australian students have consistently raised the need for acknowledgment of all the financial pressures and constraints in sustaining involvement in higher education. These include the significant costs involved with child care, for example, transport costs, and other costs that you perhaps would not normally associate with involvement in the education sector. This report clearly indicates that the impact of other funding and fee charging arrangements must be examined when we are determining or examining participation rates of indigenous people in the higher education sector.
I commend that particular recommendation. It is No. 15 in this report, and it states:

BREAK.PARA: That the Higher Education Council be asked to monitor the impact on Indigenous Australian students of changes in financial arrangements and higher education policy and to report, in the context of its broad equity brief, on the impact of these on recruitment, retention and success of Indigenous Australians.
It is a report that I commend to the Senate, and it is a recommendation which I heartily support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the time, I obviously will need to restrict my remarks on this report: A Review of Institutional Use of Commonwealth Higher Education Funding for Indigenous Australian Students . I have had a look at this report very briefly, and I note the essential recommendations that Senator Stott Despoja has drawn attention to—in particular, the inadequacies of the present arrangements for the monitoring of participation by Aboriginal students and students from a Torres Strait Islander background in Australian higher education institutions. What is quite apparent is that the measures taken in recent years to see that funding is rolled into the general operating grants of universities has had a detrimental effect, as I read this report, on the amounts or effective distribution of those moneys for specific Aboriginal educational purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a general trend operating within education, I think, which needs to be examined more closely. In this regard, the Higher Education Council's report does us a service in drawing attention to this whole concept of broadbanding, which is becoming all too prevalent in education. That is where this Commonwealth allocates, or at least has allocated in the past, moneys for specific purposes. But increasingly we find that they are being rolled into other purposes, and that the level of accountability is therefore reduced.

But there is therefore an issue that I do think we ought be taking up more forcefully. What this council report also indicates—and it does show, I think, quite forcefully on page 37 of the report—is that the council was aware of the many great difficulties which are faced by persons from indigenous backgrounds who are attempting to be successful in the higher education sector. Of course, it draws attention, as I say, to the issues of the manner in which funding is directed to that particular purpose.

What it also highlights, however, is the fact that the problems faced by persons of Aboriginal background go much broader than can be examined purely in an educational context. What this report suggests is that there ought be greater priority in terms of public debate, and greater encouragement given to examination of participation and retention of persons of indigenous background and, in particular, the capacity of particular institutions to provide the strategic plans necessary to ensure the success of all Australians in higher education.

This is a further area of difficulty in terms of the profile processes that are undertaken within the university system in this country where, I think, it is all too often the case that there is just not sufficient detail provided by universities as to the specific measures they are taking to enhance the objective of ensuring greater participation—and success—of persons from an indigenous background in the higher education sector. It is in this broad context that the equity provisions or equity implications this involves, to me, warrant much closer examination by this parliament.

The other more general issue I would draw attention to is that this government is moving to abolish the National Board of Education Employment and Training. This is the measure that this government is undertaking. While it wishes to maintain the Higher Education Council specifically, it will be seeking to abolish all the other councils that make up NBEET.

This is a particularly serious matter, because the very issues that go to questions of the cross‐sectoral relationship—that is, the interrelationship between the various sectors—of education are very important. And there is no device within the education system to provide impartial, objective advice to government and to this parliament on the effectiveness of government programs across the sectors within education. This report highlights just how important that advice really is. It is in that context I think this report has also done us a favour. In having remarked on that matter, I move that this debate be adjourned, and I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 7.00 to 8.00 p.m.

TITLE.XREF: SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS SURCHARGE (ASSESSMENT AND COLLECTION) BILL 1997

BREAK.XREF: TERMINATION PAYMENTS SURCHARGE (ASSESSMENT AND COLLECTION) BILL 1997
SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS SURCHARGE (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1997
SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS SURCHARGE (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH—REDUCTION OF BENEFITS) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS SURCHARGE (ASSESSMENT AND COLLECTION) BILL 1997
Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge (Assessment and Collection) Bill 1997 and amendments 22, 23 and 50 moved by Senator Sherry. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We still have outstanding the critical issue of the exemption from the effect of the surcharge of low and middle income earners—that is, amendments 6 and 8, which we have been deferring on an ongoing basis. The Australian Democrats and the government had announced an agreement in principle on this issue not exactly 24 hours ago but certainly very close to it. I did request a copy of this Democrat‐government amendment on this very critical issue. We do not have it yet. Could we have an update on whether the amendment has been completed yet and when we are to receive a copy of it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot speak for the Australian Democrats—Senator Allison has just come into the chamber—but my understanding is that we are pretty close to or we in fact have an agreement. I think this has illustrated the immense complexity of attempting to make a variety of complex amendments. I have discussed the drafting of the amendments that the Labor Party brought forward, which I do not intend to repeat.

SPEECH.PARA: We have looked very closely of this issue of low and middle income earners. I think we have addressed the concerns of the Democrats on this issue. We are very anxious not to open up a major loophole which high income earners could exploit. It has been very difficult to get the correct balance, and I think that balance has been achieved.

Intense work has been done on this matter, and that forms the amendment which will be moved by Senator Allison. She may be able to give you an update. As far as we are concerned, we are happy with the amendment as it stands. If that is Senator Allison's understanding, we could have it distributed. Perhaps she could indicate to the chamber where it is at.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I would expect the amendment to be available shortly. I have not seen it yet. I seek clarification as to whether we are talking about ALP amendments 22, 23 and 50.
—Yes.

—Senator Sherry, quite understandably, was interested in an update on these earlier amendments. Perhaps we could dispose of the amendments which are before the chair now and then, if Senator Allison is in a position to do so, we could move back to the earlier amendments which were deferred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make comments on those amendments, if I may. As we all know, they deal with the unfunded defined benefits superannuation schemes in circumstances where the actual employer funded benefit is less than the notional benefit. As with so many amendments that have been put, the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation identified this as one of a number of potential teething problems in relation to the defined benefits schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst the government has given us assurances, we are not entirely convinced that the government has these complicated provisions quite right. However, as we have said in the past, this is the government's legislation, it is in effect the government's mess and we wish to see the government wear the consequences of that. For that reason and those I have already outlined, we will be opposing the ALP amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Even though the Australian Democrats acknowledge there are problems with the vesting issue and they believe there should be change, they are not willing to support change in this area. I express disappointment and concern at that approach.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kemp, you have stated you believe this issue, amongst a number of other issues, will be dealt with in the actuarial guidelines. Do you have any further information on when the guidelines will be provided to industry and to the various parties in the Senate?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I have just received some advice that the current expectation would be approximately a month.

—This highlights one of the serious problems that we faced with this legislation: people are naturally concerned about knowing the precise effect of the surcharge, or the tax, in relation to vesting and we have to wait for another month. Will the guidelines to be produced in a month's time be draft guidelines or the final guidelines?
—They will be final guidelines.

—Good. Notwithstanding that, we are in, I think, a very bizarre position. We are expected to pass legislation instituting a new 15 per cent tax and, naturally enough, individuals are anxious to know how this 15 per cent tax will affect them. Normally, when you pass tax legislation in what is a very complex issue, it is very clear how the tax will apply. I have not struck legislation—at least to the extent that this legislation does—where there are people who are asking questions about the application of the new tax and we cannot answer them. We cannot answer them because of the absence of these very important actuarial guidelines which we are not going to see for a month. You say they are the final guidelines; they are not going to be in draft form. What will be the process for persons who are not satisfied with the guidelines to take up particular concerns they have with the final actuarial guidelines?

—The final guidelines, I am advised, will be produced after extensive discussion and consultation within the profes sion to make sure that they are fair and appropriate. Then those guidelines would be presented to the government and the government would then make the decision, presumably, to accept them. We believe we are seeking the best available professional advice on an issue which is a complex issue—no-one denies that. It will be up to the government to accept them, but, I would expect, relying on the advice of the government actuary, who will also advise the government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the sort of consultation outside the actuaries? Are the actuaries themselves consulting with other members of industry about these final guidelines that we are to see in a month? If so, which organisations and individuals have been consulted? I do not want every individual, but who are the sorts of people involved in this process outside the institute of actuaries?

—I am advised by the Government Actuary that, I think, virtually all superannuation actuaries have been consulted in the development of the guidelines. So there has been very extensive consultation. Senator Sherry raised the point that he had not come across this approach before. Just for the record, I am advised that division 9AA of the Income Tax Assessment Act deals with the embedded value of life insurance companies where they demutualise. These calculations are also subject to actuarial calculations provided by an actuary in not a dissimilar manner to the surcharge.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was making the point that I have not dealt with legislation, in my 6½ years in the Senate, that has such extensive reliance on actuarial advice that does affect so many hundreds of thousands of people. We are here passing legislation tonight without that actuarial advice and I certainly do not believe that that is a satisfactory situation. When the actuarial guidelines are published, and if someone is aggrieved by the actuarial guidelines and how they apply in their individual circumstances, what will then happen? What is the process of appeal, if any, for a person to dispute the way in which the guidelines apply to their fund and to themselves as individuals?

—There are two processes which I think explain the way this develops. The guidelines are developed by the actuaries and then it is up to the superannuation funds and trustees to apply the guidelines. If a member is dissatisfied with the results, he has a normal appeal process, which currently exists under the act.
—Is that the disputes tribunal?
—Yes, Senator. That is the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal.
—If the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal determines in the claimant's favour, does it have the final say?
—There is an appeal to the Federal Court, but I am getting a brief note from the adviser so that there is no misunderstanding in this matter. I will read it into the record.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —While you are considering that matter, Labor certainly believes that there will be a level of disputation. I am not aware of the current case load of the tribunal. Is the government prepared to allocate additional resources, if the tribunal so requests, to handle the additional case load if it occurs?

—I have just received some further advice that there has been a reduction in the case load of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. We have of course, as you may be aware, made an announcement about the appointment of some additional part‐time members. But, as a general principle, of course, we are anxious to make sure these things are handled in the most efficient way possible. We monitor the performance of the tribunal closely.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —But I was asking: if the tribunal requests additional resources because of an increased workload as a consequence of particular concerns and disputes in this area, will the government be forthcoming?

—I would always be responsive if a problem emerged on this front. Of course the government would have to make a decision, but let me state that the general principle is that we would want this body—as, indeed, all similar bodies—to have an efficient process and ensure that the case load is not too heavy. I think that provides the assurance that you are seeking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a purpose in asking these questions. This issue goes to our next amendment in respect of the 15 per cent cap on the defined benefit charge, and our amendment No. 46 on actuarial guidelines—the general issue of how the parliament has an input to these actuarial guidelines. We believe that if there is an identified problem conveyed to us by industry, the parliament should attempt to amend the legislation to minimise the potential problems that may arise. That is just a general comment on the reason for our approach in this area. We do not pretend that the amendments that I have mentioned will address all the problems, but we certainly believe it is important that the parliament has the capacity to guide application in some areas of the 15 per cent surcharge.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned about the advice you have just given the Senate, Senator Kemp. I have a press release from 29 October last year issued by the Chair, Mr Neil Wilkinson, when tabling the second annual report. It says:
The report revealed a striking increase in the number of complaints received.
You have just informed us that the number of complaints has dropped off. On what basis is that claim made?

TALK.START.PARA: —As always in these cases I rely on the best advice available. I understand that since then the case load has gone down. Equally, I state again, we monitor these things closely. The government has no interest in a body which cannot handle the workload. I think that we would always ensure that there was not a undue build‐up and, where that occurred, we would move to address it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that in this press release which was issued at the time of the tabling of the second annual report it says that in that year there was a 28 per cent increase in the number of written complaints and a 155 per cent increase in the number of calls taken from the public in comparison with the tribunal's first year of operation. Let us hope, Senator, that there is not a significant increase in that drop‐off you have had reported to you. I do not know whether it is a good or a bad thing if the drop‐off continues. I just want to highlight to the Senate that we believe there will be a lot of disputes about the actuarial guidelines which will lead to an increase in inquiries and written complaints handled by the tribunal.
—As I said, I am relying on advice that has been given to me by the Government Actuary. There has been a reduction in more recent times in the case load and we will monitor that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just make the point that we believe it is important for the parliament and the Senate, where it is possible, to clear up differing interpretations about the actuarial guidelines. There is a great deal of concern about this issue amongst people in defined benefit funds because unfortunately my experience with actuaries on this particular issue is that you get a different answer from different actuaries. No more compelling case have we seen of that in recent times than the information which has been circulating in this parliament. It certainly is a serious problem—different actuaries giving different advice.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not being critical of the actuary profession, although I do not pretend to understand it. It is a very intensive and long-term academic study. I certainly do not pretend to be a numbers man in any way, with my humble background in politics. I do not pretend to be a numbers man, certainly not to the extent actuaries are.

It has been our experience that differing advice is being given by different actuaries. That has led to a great deal of concern by members of various defined benefit funds. As a general principle, Labor is anxious to try to minimise the potential for interpretation and vagueness in the way these actuarial guidelines apply on this particular vesting issue we are dealing with and likewise in respect of the next amendment we will consider and then our amendments in respect of clause 46.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I just make the observation that you do not become the Deputy Leader of the Labor Party in the Senate without being fairly smart with the numbers. I do not say that actuarial skills are needed or the life expectancy of your col leagues would enter into your calculations. We think on this one particular issue you may be unduly modest.

SPEECH.PARA: I will read into the record some advice that I have received in relation to the complaints tribunal. The advice is that a trustee who merely reports surchargeable contributions to the ATO as advised by the fund actuary acting in accordance with actuarial practice is following the act. On the other hand, the trustee's decision on the reduction of benefits is not prescribed by the legislation in this area. The Superannuation Complaints Tribunal would have greater jurisdiction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. There again I know there would be a lot of very worried people. When you indicate that this legislation will have the effect of reducing people's benefits, obviously there is a great deal of concern because we are reducing the benefit of retirement incomes for a significant number of people. Those people when they entered the fund had an expectation of receiving X amount, whatever it may have been, in whatever fund it is. The effect of the surcharge is to reduce their benefit because of the application of the new tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I know the government argues it is fair in respect of people earning more than $70,000 that they should have their benefit reduced because of the application of the new tax—and we can accept the overall principle—I just wonder is it fair when people have entered into a contractual agreement with an employer, become a member of a superannuation fund, with an expectation that they are entitled to X amount when they retire and their benefit is reduced part way through their employment by a new government tax? I think to that extent it lacks fairness.

I can understand the concerns of the significant number of people in defined benefit funds who have expressed that concern to the Labor opposition. Nevertheless, despite the other adverse consequences that we have been dealing with in this legislation since budget night, the government is intent on increasing the effective tax rate for these people in defined benefit funds and cutting their retirement income. That does have an element of unfairness as part of the overall fairness the government has continued to assert on taxing high income earners. We will deal with that in a little more detail when we get to Senator Harradine's amendment a little later.

I believe where we can we should try to deal with some of these definitional issues—and vesting is an important issue—and, in principle, Labor believes that the Senate where it is possible should attempt to amend the legislation. We cannot accept the approach of the Australian Democrats, for example, that they recognise it as a problem but it is not up to us to try and resolve it. I think that is why we are here. If we think there is a problem it is not enough just to say, `Let all the consequences flow. Let them fall and it is all on your head, Senator Kemp.' I do not mind it being on your head but I think we have an obligation as senators to try to correct or at least reduce the massive tonnage that will end up on your head in some ways by trying to minimise the problems you are going to encounter when these bills go through this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry, we are addressing the issue that you have raised but we are not addressing it with your amendment, which we think would be unworkable and unduly complex.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the superannuation surcharge on high income earners, as someone who is prepared to read the Hansard, I think it is worth putting the record straight: it only applies after the budget announcement last year. Your observation, Senator Sherry—that it may have been interpreted that it applied wider than that—of course is not the case at all.

Under any feasible scheme or any option you may have, you would have to face up to the sort of problem and issue that we have faced up to—dealing with the defined benefit funds, those that are unfunded. It cannot be ignored or wiped away. We believe what we are doing is dealing with it in the fairest possible manner. We have taken account of a lot of the concerns and issues which have been raised and brought to our attention and I think the bill reflects that widespread consultation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We can accept some of what you say, Senator, but it is not we who are proposing the new tax. It is not we who gave that commitment at the election not to increase existing taxes, particularly on superannuation. In fact, our principled approach to superannuation is to build superannuation for the future, but we will, I am sure, have a lot more to say about that next week as a consequence of other measures. If there was not a new tax, we would not have the problem. And if it was not presented in the way in which it is in this particular legislation with all the particular problems of surcharge—but I am not going to go over that all again now—many of these problems would not be occurring.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Sherry's ) be agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Jacinta Collins did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

SPEECH.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder where we are up to with amendments Nos 6 and 8, which have been in the drafting stage for some time.

—Senator Sherry, it might assist the committee if we could have some guidance from you or from the minister as to what stage we are at or what you would like to proceed to now. I understand we are still waiting on the amendments to be circulated.

—If the amendments are still to be circulated, we will just move on to No. 6 on the running sheet—amendment 24 to do with the cap on the defined benefit surcharge. That is what I have next on the running sheet.
—If you would like to address that, that might assist the committee while we are waiting on these other amendments.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (24) Clause 16, page 20 (after line 27), after subclause (6), insert:
Payments not to exceed 15% of benefit plus interest
