(6A) Notwithstanding any other provision in this or any other Act, an amount of surcharge payable under subsection; (6) must not exceed 15% of the value of the member's final benefit plus any interest payable on that surcharge.

We believe this is an important amendment. The government has said it is a 15 per cent tax on superannuation for people earning more than $70,000, that no more than that should apply and that this 15 per cent tax on superannuation contributions contained in defined benefit funds is to be calculated by using a notional surcharge contribution factor. This factor is supposed to determine the level of employer contributions that were notionally contributed to the individual's superannuation accounts. When this notional surcharge contribution factor is applied, it determines what level of 15 per cent tax is to apply that year to the member's benefits.

This is very important. Depending on the way in which the scheme is established, it may be possible for members in defined benefit funds to pay in excess of the 15 per cent tax. We have had submissions and concerns raised about this—and I am sure every senator in this chamber is well aware of those concerns. This amendment ensures that where a debit account has been established alongside the superannuation account, which will pay out when the benefit is paid, the member pays no more than 15 per cent surcharge on the final value of the member's benefit and that interest accrued is also paid.

On the point of defined benefit funds, I note that—I think it was yesterday, Senator Kemp—the government issued another press statement indicating that amendments would have to be moved for the trustee to be able to reduce the member's benefit to pay the 15 per cent tax. This will be the fourth set of amendments that the government has had to introduce to these bills in addition to the two new bills that were introduced.

This is really a major example of the government making policy on the run. Just yesterday we got another press release saying that there are going to be further amendments in order for the trustee to be able to reduce the member's benefit to pay the 15 per cent tax. I might say in passing that this is an issue I attempted to ask Senator Kemp about in question time which resulted from the problems that have arisen due to the view of Dennis Rose about the legality of clause 34 on what the government was going to do about attempting to quietly admit that there were problems—and ongoing consequential problems.

But it does concern us very greatly that we get yet more notification, another press statement, with more amendments that have to be moved to the SIS Act. Where are these amendments? It would be useful to have them when considering this legislation. I notice that Senator Kemp does give us slight criticism occasionally about the complexity of our amendments and the technicalities involved, but I think the government's problems surrounding the imposition of this new tax are very substantial indeed.

I want to emphasise, in closing my contribution, that if the government says that no‐one is to pay more than 15 per cent tax, then accept our amendment. There should not be any problem, Senator Kemp, in your accepting that concept and the amendment. No‐one should pay more than 15 per cent. We are advised that in certain defined benefit funds it is potentially possible for a person to pay more than 15 per cent, and we want to assure those people that 15 per cent is the upper limit. It is consistent with government policy. We hope for the support of the chamber on this very fundamental, very important and very simple principle that should be in the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very serious matter that Senator Sherry has raised. I will be supporting the amendment that he has put forward on this. I agree with him. The government should support this amendment if it is true to its word that there shall be a 15 per cent surcharge. It has not said an 18 per cent, a 19 per cent or a 20 per cent surcharge.

SPEECH.PARA: I raised this matter on the last occasion we were speaking and put forward a scenario which Senator Kemp has not responded to. I ask him to do it now. I do not suppose that he has even read what I put forward. I might remind him of what I put forward in respect of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme, which is a defined benefit scheme where the employer does not make contributions during the life of the scheme but pays a defined benefit, usually a pension, on the retirement of the employee. This legislation that we are dealing with requires that a notional employer contribution is actuarially assessed each year in order to calculate the amount of the surcharge owing for that year. Is that right, Minister?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Yes, it is right. The surcharge amounts assessed each year accumulate until the member retires or leaves the fund. Interest is charged on the accumulating amount each year at the 10‐year Treasurer bond rate, which is currently almost eight per cent. That is, the interest compounds annually. The final amount owing is paid by commuting the pension otherwise payable, deducting the amount owing and then recommuting the remainder into a reduced pension. I ask the minister directly through you, Madam Temporary Chairman: is it not a fact that the net result of those requirements is that after the first year the effective surcharge rate will be more than 15 per cent because of the effect of interest charged on the amount, and the total owing will increase rapidly because of the compounding effect of the interest charges? I ask the minister: is that not the net effect of the bill that is currently before us in respect of that defined benefit scheme?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must interrupt Senator Harradine and Senator Kemp. I inadvertently misled the committee. The press release I was referring to was released some five weeks ago. What is of concern to us of course is the foreshadowed legislation to correct the SIS Act, or amendments to the SIS ACT. In the intervening period we have not yet received a copy of them. My other comments stand. We have got the package of bills here. We would like to have seen the foreshadowed legislation of that press release of four or five weeks ago so that we could look at it in the context of this debate. I am sorry to interrupt, Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Senator Sherry, you did cause us a bit of confusion, I can now confess.
—I saw the look of horror on your face.
—When you got up and said `a press release yesterday' I looked around at my advisers and, I have to say, you sowed total confusion in the ranks.
—It was my press release yesterday.

—Because it was your press release, not ours. Of course, you do issue so many press releases it is a bit hard to keep track of them all. We have actually worked out what you were talking about, though we appreciate your honesty in standing up. I think what you are talking about are the benefit standards in the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 and SIS regulation 13.16:

SPEECH.PARA: To restrict such amendments from resulting in an adverse reduction of accrued benefits, this restriction will be removed except that it operates to prevent amendments to a superannuation fund's trust deed required to provide for the appropriate reduction of benefits as a result of the surcharge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you got the amendment there for us?
—This amended regulation is currently being prepared. I am glad that we have sorted that out, Senator Sherry, and you can take back all those nasty comments you made as well.
—We don't!

—If you are going to make accusations that are totally unfounded, we expect you to totally withdraw all aspects of them, including the allegations that we had not given you the information on a press release which never existed.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator, this is a serious point and I want to tell you how the government is addressing this issue. For reasons that I will state, we do not like your amendment. In some ways it will not address the issue which it seeks to address. Again, superannuation and tax law generally are complex issues and careful drafting is always required.

The Government Actuary is here. He has provided me with important advice on this issue, which I think should give comfort to the Senate. The Government Actuary advises that a deduction exceeding 15 per cent of the value of the final benefit is unlikely to arise, and there are two reasons why. The notional surcharge rate will take account of benefit entitlements as they accrue, and in the unlikely event that the debit account exceeds 15 per cent, it would be a notifiable event and the actuary would make an adjustment. I will repeat that: in the unlikely event that the debit account exceeds 15 per cent, it would be a notifiable event and the actuary would make the required adjustment.

Your amendment is more blunt as it has to cover all schemes. An actuary can tailor the events to put the scheme delivering greater equity. Labor's amendment that you have put forward would not, for example, cover private defined benefit schemes. I want to give the Senate that assurance that, if there was an occasion where the debit account exceeded 15 per cent, it would be a notifiable event and the actuary would make the required adjustment. That indicates that we recognise the issue and have provided the assurances that people are seeking.

Senator Harradine has also raised a similar issue, but he has looked at the use of the 10‐year interest rate which is designed to ensure equity between different types of funds. We had this debate earlier on this bill. I think Senator Harradine may be assuming that the notional contribution rate is the same for every member of the fund. The Government Actuary has advised us that the notional surcharge contribution rate will take account of assumed in effect notional contribution interest and the level of benefits accruing to members each year. According to the Government Actuary, this would imply that the situation raised by Senator Harradine is based on incorrect assumptions. Interest is charged so that the members of defined benefit schemes do not receive an advantage over members of accumulation schemes caused by the deferral of payment of the surcharge.

In an accumulation scheme, the surcharge is payable each year for high income earners; in unfunded defined benefit schemes they do not have to pay that each year—the interest is paid at the end of the process, not on an annual basis. In setting the notional surcharge contribution rate, this interest would be incorporated. So we are trying to ensure equity between different types of schemes. Whatever one may think of the method that we have chosen to collect the surcharge—and we think it is the most efficient of the available options—any option, in order to ensure proper equity, would have to address the difference between an accumulation fund and an unfunded defined benefit scheme. In order to ensure such fairness, I believe that any process would have to be the same.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts, is this on the same matter or would you allow Senator Harradine, who is in the process of questioning, to continue?
—Sure. It is on the same matter, but I defer.

—Thank you, Senator Margetts. I know Senator Allison has also indicated that she wants the call. Senator Harradine, would you like to follow this up and then we will take Senator Margetts on the same matter.

—With your indulgence, Madam Chair, and thank you, Senator Margetts. On the point that the Minister, Senator Kemp, mentioned, that is precisely the problem. The problem in the defined benefits scheme, the Commonwealth superannuation scheme, is that there is no option that the payment be made on an annual basis. Therefore, as I indicated and placed on the record last night, the total amount owing will increase rapidly because of the compounding effect of the interest charges.

BREAK.PARA: I gave the example last night—and it is incorporated in the Hansard—that a public servant with 15 years service would pay half as much again in interest charges than he would if he was able to arrange for the surcharge amount to be paid annually as it fell due. You talk about discrimination: isn't that discrimination? With respect, Assistant Treasurer, through you, Madam Chair, I would seriously ask the government to examine what I put forward last night. I do not want to canvass it again—we have not got the time to do it tonight—but I really would like to see a detailed response to the matters that I raised last night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This is really another situation very akin to the situation we saw with the family tax package, where the government mucked around with the area of taxation so that they could claim that a $200 benefit was actually a $1,000 benefit. In fact, it is basically claiming that a 15 per cent tax is just an income based surcharge and does not count. We have the poor old tax office slugged with another complexity. I hope that is also added in to what the Assistant Treasurer was saying about adding resources. I just wonder how many more resources you can give the tax office every time you try to twist around legislation to make it look like something else.

SPEECH.PARA: In this case the lack of clarity is likely to have a negative impact on all those in undefined benefit schemes such as the Commonwealth and state superannuation schemes, because benefits are not funded, as has been mentioned—that is, no contributions are actually made, so the liability is deferred. Because the benefits are only calculated at the end of employment, suddenly the entire liability becomes due at once. This raises a number of problems for the government's superannuation tax scheme. If contributions are taken to be made over a period of years, they want interest on the deferred liability, even though employees have no option of paying, as Senator Harradine mentioned, because the liability is undefined. So it has not been defined what they are going to get so they cannot pay.

BREAK.PARA: If the contributions are taken as being made on termination, employees' notional income for that year is huge, pushing them into the highest tax brackets and making them liable to what is then a punitive superannuation tax, even though their income may have been modest during their working life. In either case it is inequitable.

I noticed that the Assistant Treasurer said it would be a notifiable event. I can only wonder how many big brothers there will be looking over everybody's account. Who will be notifying whom? What will be the outcome when somebody notifies somebody else? Who is going to be responsible? Is it going to be the individual's responsibility to notify? Will the tax department notify? In these days of self-assessment, who is actually going to be the one notifying? Who is going to be the one watching out to see that everybody is treated fairly? I just cannot see it myself.

So the Actuary would make an adjustment, just like magic. I think the capping would be a much better idea. We are all admitting that what we are trying to do is make a bit more of a sensible hash of what is a totally bad lot. It would have been much better for the government to take the package back and redo it rather than have us on the floor here trying to make less of a hash of what is a total mess.

The ALP wishes to ensure that at least those working in the Public Service, or members of similar schemes, regardless of notional interest and so on, will not be hit with more than a 15 per cent tax. I would like to believe that there will be an invisible hand watching over everybody so that nobody is slugged, but I know myself that it is complex to work out what your liabilities are as an individual. I even know that it is difficult for one's tax accountant to know exactly when you may have been charged extra. I really would like the minister to be able to say how this invisible hand will work and how the public can be assured that they will not be charged excessive amounts and then have a great deal of difficulty working out or proving later on that they have been charged too much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts, it is going to be a long night. It is very easy for us to get up and make accusations across the chamber which—
—It was just a question.

—No, it was not just a question. It was a case of saying, `This bill is a total hash, blah, blah, blah.' We have attempted to give you briefing on this bill relentlessly, which you have not been able to accept. It is simply not good enough to walk in and make unsubstantiated assertions. There has been huge consultation on this bill. We would have been happy to consult with you, Senator.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of serious issues were raised. I have addressed how we will be dealing with this issue that Senator Sherry has raised on the need for a cap. I do not want to repeat what I have said, but in our view that gives the assurance that people were seeking in this chamber. I think it is important that I put that on the record. Even if one was inclined to accept Senator Sherry's amendment, there are huge problems with the wording. Again, this is a difficulty when amendments perhaps have not been considered carefully.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had this one for four weeks.
—We have looked at it, and the wording is unsatisfactory.
—Why didn't you propose an amendment to it?

—One of the reasons is because it was very difficult to consult with your office. You can seek advice. Quite a number of phone calls were made in order to speak to you about this surcharge bill. We received very little—
—Last Thursday.

—There were constant attempts, Senator Sherry. In relation to the issue that was raised by Senator Harradine, my understanding is that the next amendment is likely to get up. This will provide where people, if they wish to, can make contributions for defined benefit unfunded schemes. The government will not resist that amend ment. I am seeking advice and assurances to make sure that it does not bump into any of the constitutional or other difficulties. My initial advice is that it does not. To the extent that Senator Harradine wanted what he saw as—
—Excuse me, Minister. For clarification, when you say the next amendment, are you referring to Senator Sherry's No. 25?

—Yes, 25. I think it addresses the issue that formed at least part of the comments that Senator Harradine made. Senator Harradine sees this—I think a number of other senators do also—as ensuring greater equity and more options. As I said, we can read the numbers. The government will not be resisting that amendment. Again, I think that is another way of helping to deal with the problem that Senator Sherry and Senator Harradine have raised.

—The Democrats will not be supporting this amendment. If the advice from the government is correct, this amendment should be unnecessary. The government is relying on advice from the actuary, which says that the tax payable on defined benefits would rarely exceed 15 per cent. Even if it did, the actuary would treat this as a notifiable event and recalculate the liability. On that advice from the actuary, the Democrats are satisfied. I would like to add to what Minister Kemp said about the next amendment, which we will support. I think that perhaps addresses the questions that Senator Harradine has raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are making some progress at last. I understand that Senator Harradine's amendment is to come next. Can I have some clarification on that? Is Senator Harradine's amendment to come next before we get to 25?

—Not according to this list. I note that it mentions Senator Harradine's amendment, but it does not seem to have a place. I understand that it will come at the end of Senator Sherry's amendments 1 and 2, which follow 24, 25, 27, 46 and 51.
—Mine is to clause 10.

—Thank you, Senator Harradine. I think the question was where, in the business of dealing with it, does it come. I have just advised Senator Sherry that it comes at the end of his package of current amendments.
—At this time of night, I do not want to enter into a blow-by-blow description of the contact or lack of contact between the various offices.
—Oh!

—There is no sense in doing that, Senator Kemp. I do not accept your particular version of events. I will be generous to the extent of saying that you have a version, we have a version, and we do not accept your particular view.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister, you have stated that, in the unlikely event of someone effectively being assessed at more than 15 per cent, it would become a notifiable event. We would have attempted to pursue these issues with the government actuary before the estimates hearings. I am not talking about the estimates hearings that will take place tomorrow; I am talking about the last set of estimates. I think it was the proceedings before the committee where we had the deputy government actuary. You might pass this on: we got nowhere. It was hopeless. I am not being personal to the deputy government actuary, but we could not get an answer to anything. It was the least informative witness I have ever had before a Senate committee. And that includes you, Senator Kemp.

You could not get anything out of the deputy government actuary. It was a very frustrating time. This is one of the issues we might have been able to clear up. That is not being personal to the deputy government actuary. I do not know where the government actuary was. I am told that he was on leave. I am not surprised. He would need to be on leave given the pressure he must have been under because of the shambles this legislation was in over the last few months and the difficulties that we have had.

BREAK.PARA: In regard to the notifiable event that the government actuary has referred to, Senator Kemp, can you give the Senate an absolute assurance that no-one will be taxed more than 15 per cent? Secondly, on what basis in law does this notifiable event occur? Can we have drawn to our attention the particular aspects of the pertinent act that give the actuary the power to effect this notifiable event so that no-one can be disadvantaged by more than 15 per cent?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am seeking some written advice for you on that issue. You raised the issue of the appearance of the deputy government actuary. I am glad you were not being personal, Senator Sherry! It would have been a terrible scene if you were. He seems to me to have done a good job. If you inform me in that way, I might take some lessons from him.
—You don't need them.

—I will acknowledge that comment to get it into the Hansard . As I said, I think the issue that you have raised is an important one. We have addressed it in the processes which I have outlined and which I will not repeat. As I said, I am just getting some written advice. When I receive that advice, I will read it to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just going to draw to the chamber's attention what a thrill it is for the opposition to see Senator Watson coming in to chair. It is a thrill for us because we have someone who is extraordinarily knowledgeable in this area. I do not say that in jest, because we have very high regard for Senator Watson's views on these issues. I wish you would take them into account a little more.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a pity that Senator Watson has not been able to contribute. That is not in any sense a criticism, Senator Watson, because I understand you are in a difficult position on this legislation. We have concluded our remarks on this amendment if you have your response and if there are no more questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —In effect a notifiable event invalidates the certificate unless certain action is taken. It would, therefore, place the taxpayer in a position of not having a valid certificate. Notifiable events do exist in other actuarial certificates, for example, superannuation guarantee certificates provided to defined benefit schemes. Where a trustee reduces a member's benefit by more than 15 per cent as a result of surcharge—as we said, that would be a most unlikely event—the member could appeal to the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal and such members could expect the government's full support.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe we have effectively addressed the issue that you have raised. We believe that the amendment that has been put forward does not actually achieve the result that you wish it to achieve. To the extent that people want more options in the way they deal with this issue, I have indicated that we will not be resisting the next amendment, amendment No. 25, which you will be moving.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I am seeking another point of clarification. In terms of that notifiable event, Minister, you said it was once it becomes apparent that the account has been debited by more than 15 per cent. Who actually monitors and checks that? Is it the responsibility of the individual member to make those calculations and determine it? Can you describe who actually makes that calculation, whether it is the fund and whether it becomes a requirement of the fund to perform that checking role?

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, you just said that, once that notifiable event has been identified, the onus is on the member to lodge a complaint. Can you clarify that actual process?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the fund, not the individual taxpayer. It is the fund which is responsible for paying the surcharge and it is the fund which will be responsible for dealing with the certificate. I think that is the process which we adopted.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say, Senator Sherry, we too are very pleased to have Senator Watson in the chamber. We regard him as an excellent senator, too.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Sherry's ) be agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Bolkus did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

BREAK.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (25) Clause 16, page 20 (after line 27), after subclause (6), insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Surcharge debt may be reduced

SPEECH.PARA: (6B) The member may make payments to the provider for the purpose of reducing the deferred amount in the surcharge debt account.
(6C) If a member makes a payment under subsection (6B), the provider must:

PARA.TAB: (a) credit the payment to the surcharge debt account; and
(b) acknowledge receipt of the payment to the member; and
(c) advise the member of the revised balance of the surcharge debt account.

SPEECH.PARA: (6D) A payment received by the provider under subsection (6B) must be forwarded to the Commissioner within one month of receipt.

This is our amendment in relation to unfunded defined benefits which the Australian Democrats have indicated that they are supporting. I will make a few comments about this particular issue for the record and why we have moved the amendment on unfunded defined benefits.

The government's surcharge bills require Commonwealth Public Sector employees to accumulate a surcharge debt, which is payable at the time a superannuation asset is paid out. Labor believes that this is inequitable for a number of reasons—and, before I commence to list these reasons, I acknowledge the comments made by Senator Harradine about similar and like issues that we have tried to address here.

Firstly, these employees, we believe, are being discriminated against by this legislation and by the federal government. The government does not have state‐wide agreement to implement and administer the surcharge. In fact, the only state that has indicated it will attempt to implement the surcharge is New South Wales. We do not believe that that agreement, if it exists in principle, can be relied upon and delivered politically. But time will tell.

BREAK.PARA: In respect to upper houses around Australia, the government does not control a number of them. That is certainly the case in Victoria, Tasmania, South Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —Victoria's the only one.
—I am sorry, that is right; Victoria is the only state where the government has a majority in the upper house.

BREAK.PARA: The levying of the tax at state level with respect to politicians, judges and public servants I do not believe can give any cause for comfort to the government that those respective state governments can give us any certainty on this issue. Of course, we contend that one of the problems the government faces is that, if this tax does not apply across‐the‐board, it will make a mockery of this package of bills, and we have already discussed this to some extent. We believe it is ridiculous that we are considering legislation without state agreement.

The government has this particular problem because of the constitution. It cannot apply this set of legislation to state constitutionally protected funds. We believe there are broader constitutional problems. I am certainly not a lawyer, but the broader constitutional problems were touched on last week—Senator Watson was there—when a serving Federal Court judge, Justice Evans, expressed some concern about the constitutional aspects of this legislation. We believe that, if New South Wales did pass the legislation and none of the other states did, this would have very serious implications. If they are successful in levying a tax in New South Wales—they might attempt to call it a surcharge—there will be serious legal action as a consequence from its own employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I am not sure precise ly what this has to do with the amendment before us. Senator Sherry's reflection on politics around Australia is very interesting, but in the interests of speeding the journey I—
—I think this is a very important issue.
—It is important, but it is not directly relevant to this.

—It is related to unfunded defined benefits, and state constitutionally protected schemes are unfunded. Before I go any further on this, I asked Senator Kemp this morning about the negotiations with the states. Senator Kemp, can you give us any further update? Do you have any knowledge about the status of negotiations with any of the states?
—You asked this last time.
—I did ask it, Senator Campbell, and if you understood the importance of this—
—I do understand.

—The importance will become all too readily relevant to you in the debate once these bills are passed either tonight or on Monday. Senator Kemp, could you give us an accurate update about the status of negotiations? Has anything changed at all since I last asked you this question with respect to the states either agreeing or disagreeing to pass this legislation at a state level?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —If I remember correctly, I said my understanding was that the general position of the states was they were waiting for this bill to be passed before they made their own moves on this in consultation with the Commonwealth. I thought that was not an unreasonable position. We would have preferred to settle these matters earlier, but the states' position is, as I understand it, they are waiting for this bill to be passed. I think there is no basis for me to update a comment which I think gave you the correct perspective.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator, I hope we can pass the bills tonight. My understanding is that you have the numbers for this amendment. We will not resist this amendment and we can perhaps deal with other matters. I wish to see how we can complete this bill in the shortest practicable time, but I do not want to limit people's chance to speak. In view of the fact that this amendment will go through, it may be possible to shorten this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased you have raised the shortening of this debate. I notice Senator Hill and Senator Campbell are here. They may not be aware that we have been waiting for an Australian Democrat amendment about which there has had to be extensive consultation with the government. Perhaps they could facilitate the progress of the debate by ensuring that this amendment—I have just been assured that the amendment is finally here.
—Call in Hill and Campbell and in an instant you've got it.

—That is right. I am pleased you can have more impact on the Treasurer (Mr Costello) than Senator Kemp. That really does indicate a bright future for you, Senator Campbell, just so long as Senator Kemp is aware that it is going to be at his expense.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kemp, I think you should check with your advisers about the position of the states. Have any states indicated they are prepared to legislate at a state level on the surcharge? I give you this last opportunity to check what your position is.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have answered this four or five times but I will give it to you again. My understanding is that the general position is that the states are waiting to see whether the Senate passes this bill—I hope the Senate does pass this bill—and then matters regarding the states hopefully can be finalised expeditiously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —At some point we—certainly Senator Harradine, the Australian Democrats and the Greens—will have to recall this particular conversation about the position of the states. I would like to particularly draw attention to the lack of information that Senator Kemp has given the chamber about the position of the states because it will become of great relevance over the next few days. It is not central to the amendment we are dealing with now but it will become important, as Senator Kemp will discover in the next few days.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kemp has indicated that we have sufficient support on this amendment. Senator Margetts, certainly Senator Harradine and I have touched on in some considerable detail the arguments with respect to the amendment before us and related issues more broadly, so I am not going to take the time of the chamber by continuing to speak on this matter. I am pleased that at least one area of the question mark relating to unfunded defined benefits can be resolved to the satisfaction of the Labor opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with Labor amendment 25, which is the ability to make provisional payments. I understand that many people in the Public Service would like payments not to be deferred. While payments cannot be made with certainty of final liability, as we explained earlier there is an ability to create a notional contribution, therefore a notional liability, along the lines of a PAYE tax payment. Such a notional liability could be collected and then it would require only an adjustment when the actual liability comes due, without prejudice or accrued interest since it is not possible to make the payment before the actual liability is known. At least the option for such a plan should be offered. It also seems a preferential option in terms of government revenue, since it would mean that money would come to Treasury immediately instead of in future years. Therefore, and as people would probably realise, the Greens will support this measure.

—I want to indicate that the Australian Democrats will support this amendment, too. We were actually quite surprised that the government would not accept the amendment. We think that members ought to be entitled to make voluntary payments to their defined benefit fund in order to reduce their superannuation surcharge liability and to preserve their final benefit.

—As indicated previously, I support this amendment. But I do take up the point that was made by Senator Sherry and I do urge the minister, prior to the end of this evening, to bring all of the committee into his confidence and to share with the committee his understanding of how the states will respond to this legislation, because it is a clear matter of equity. I know that there are people who have indicated to certain states how best they can get around it, and it is not a difficult matter for the states to get around it. You would need only one or two states who are rather peeved with the situation of federal-state finances at the present moment to take certain action. So I hope you can take this on notice and, before the end of this evening, share with us what you know of the states' attitudes to this particular measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —As I mentioned, we will not be resisting this amendment which has been raised. We note the comments which have been made by the various senators and the indication that this will provide an option for members of defined benefit schemes. The government will therefore not, after consultation with a number of groups, resist this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to Senator Harradine's remark, I am not sure I can add anything more. I would not want members of the Senate to feel that I am withholding knowledge from them. I have received advice in relation to the states that the general view is that they are waiting for this bill to proceed. But you did make a good point: it is a matter of equity. Perhaps if people attempted to avoid the surcharge on high income earners that would not be well received by the public at all. But, as I said, I think the passage of this bill will hopefully lead to a speedy resolution of any matters which are outstanding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did notice—and I do not know the gentleman's name—that one of the advisers to the Treasurer (Mr Costello) was in the advisers box earlier. He is not here at the moment, and I do not normally refer to advisers, but I am aware he is Mr Costello's adviser. Minister, could I ask you to check carefully with Mr Costello's office about this issue of the attitude of the states, because we would not want you to be in a position of providing the wrong information to the Senate. Could you or your very trusty Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Campbell) check on this matter? We still have some time to go to conclude the legislation and it would be useful for you to double‐check with the Treasurer before we conclude tonight on this very important issue of the attitude of the states.

SPEECH.PARA: I do persist on this matter because it is very important that we have as much information as possible to avoid what could be a very serious wrangle about the possible constitutionality of this bill if even one state decides to give you some trouble. Mr Costello's adviser is not here. I do not know who the gentleman in the middle there is who is shaking his head; I do not know whether he is from the department. It is information that is best checked with a minister's office directly and I ask you to make that inquiry before we conclude tonight.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the chamber has amendments from Senator Allison relating to amendments Nos 6 and 8. We will need some time to go through this. I have not had an opportunity to read it yet and I do not want to go back to it straight away, because it is five pages long. It is quite complex and difficult and we have to get some advice about the effect of it. I request that we come back to it later.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to our amendment No. 27. We oppose clause 18, the tax file number issue. The government announced on 20 August last year a measure that it argued was designed to introduce greater equity into superannuation. It certainly was not apparent, when the government announced on 20 August the so-called surcharge, that it was introducing a tax on people who failed to provide their tax file numbers to their superannuation fund.

I understand superannuation funds are not regulated by privacy laws and, indeed, the government recently announced that there would be no extension of privacy laws to private entities. Yet the government expects and in fact penalises harshly—it is an interesting principle—individuals who fail to provide their tax file numbers to their superannuation fund. It certainly was not envisaged—I can recall the debate on tax file numbers and I can certainly recall some of the warnings Senator Harradine gave at the time—that, if you did not provide your tax file number, you would have to cop a 15 per cent tax. Senator Harradine, I do not think even you thought it would be quite that serious if you did not provide your tax file number. But I have to say it is reflecting on this issue.

Over the last few months some of the warnings that were made at the time have proved correct. As I say, no‐one would have believed that a 15 per cent tax would be applied to people who did not provide their tax file number. This is very significant. It has not had a lot of debate or coverage. Senator Margetts and Senator Harradine have raised it in the context of this issue. This is a very significant privacy issue in this country. I think it is somewhat ironic that, although this government is a self‐proclaimed protector of individuals and believes that the individual is paramount, as reflected in its broad philosophical position on so many aspects of its attitude to government, and although we have continually heard the notion of choice being used in the debate surrounding this issue, the RSA issue and other legislation before the parliament, you have a right to choose and that right is fine as long as if you exercise that right as an individual and do not provide the tax file number you pay a 15 per cent tax.

That is an extraordinary set of parameters around the issue of the choice of an individual. Labor finds this concept and outcome in the application of the tax in this set of legislation to be outrageous. Senator Kemp has said that individuals who have a conscientious objection to providing their tax file number to their superannuation fund can contact the tax office and request the tax office to contact the fund. That is a ludicrous procedure, Senator Kemp. If it were implemented by any sizeable number of people, you would have a line a mile long outside the tax offices in Australia. It is an abhorrent principle if it is applied in that way. The entire industry has made contact with Labor and highlighted this particular problem with implementation because of the very complex and indirect way in which the government has attempted to collect this extra $½ billion a year in revenue.

I do not want to heighten emotions at this late stage of the night—we are making reasonable progress on the legislation—but regrettably we have come to the conclusion that the Treasurer has been incredibly arrogant. He does know the effect of the non‐provision of tax file numbers by individuals. The Treasurer has been arrogant and even bloody‐minded. I do not want to trespass on the use of allowable language in the chamber—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's one thing they would never accuse you of.

—That is right, Senator Calvert. The Treasurer has certainly been extraordinarily arrogant in refusing to accept the particular set of problems and consequences. Senator Calvert, once this set of bills goes through you will discover the extraordinary set of problems the government is creating for itself by this arrogant approach by the Treasurer. I say it is arrogance in the Treasurer's case because I think the Treasurer is smart enough and knowledgeable enough to know of the problems that will flow. A report in the West Australian today quoted one of your colleagues, Senator Kemp—it did not name him. It said that, when the egg flies and lands on the face of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer as a consequence of the problems that will flow from this legislation, your colleagues will know who to blame. Labor is certainly doing its best to try to minimise some of the problems that will flow.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kemp made a point earlier about the Australian Taxation Office being required to put information relating to the surcharge in the Tax Pack. I do note Senator Kemp's assurance that in the 1996‐97 Tax Pack there will be information on the new surcharge. Did we get that? Is that correct, Senator Kemp?

TALK.START.PARA: —We're just checking. We're getting some advice for you, Senator.

—Okay. We certainly hope it is in the 1996‐97 Tax Pack . You also said, Senator Kemp, that the Australian Taxation Office will be required to contact people who fail to provide their tax file numbers to their superannuation funds.
—`Try' to contact.
—Yes, try. That brings me to my next point: how will they do this? What if they are not on the phone? If they are not on the phone, will there be a personal visit?
—We would propose to write where there's an address.
—What if it is returned `Address unknown'? I understand about 750,000 people change address each year in Australia. How do you propose to track down those people?

—The amendment before the chamber would, frankly, totally undermine the surcharge. That may be Labor's intention. But, if that is the case, let me assure you, Senator, if this goes through the first people not to provide tax file numbers would be high income earners. That is the effect of your amendment. We certainly will not be supporting it. To the extent that there are issues of substance which you have raised regarding the need for greater assurances for low and middle income earners, I think the Democrats do have an amendment before the chamber—which we will return to—which addresses that particular issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did raise with you the point about what I think you referred to as an intensive campaign by the tax office—I note with no additional resources being allocated. There will be resources but they will come from presumably other areas of the tax office. There are serious problems with this tax file issue. Why should people who either do not provide their tax file number or for whom it is simply not possible to provide their tax file number, particularly in the first year of operation, be slugged the 15 per cent tax? Why should they? We are not talking about one per cent which is what applied at $70,000; we are talking about the full 15 per cent tax, Senator Kemp. Give us an example of this particular principle with such potentially widespread application.
—Bank accounts.

—Senator Kemp, that was introduced in order to minimise tax avoidance, not collect a new tax. That is a substantially different principle. I notice my colleague Senator Cooney is outraged by the principles behind this particular approach. Is it fair? The Prime Minister keeps saying that this is a fair measure. The fairness of all of this is: if you do not provide your tax file number you are taxed at 15 per cent. The Prime Minister has a fascinating new approach to fairness in this country, particularly when there were other options. Senator Kemp is well aware of those. I will not extend the debate by going into the reasons why the government refused to consider the other options. We have canvassed that already in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not believe that it is appropriate to rely on tax file numbers in this way in order to collect what is a tax and to penalise significantly people who should not have to pay the tax in this way. We believe you should have considered alternative collection mechanisms. You have talked a lot about consultation, Senator Kemp, but on this particular issue it was a decree on budget night with no further consultation on this issue, no further change to the fundamental problems that arose from the collection mechanism.

Again, there is not one person you can name in industry, amongst people who are involved with the administration of superannuation, across a wide spectrum of industry professional and, I have to say, political views, too, who accept this approach. Some of your political colleagues are astounded by your approach on this particular legislation. We do not believe it is acceptable to use tax file numbers in this way. We do not believe people should be penalised when they choose not to provide their tax file number or are not able to provide their tax file number because it is simply not practicable for them to be contacted.

BREAK.PARA: As a concluding point, what will happen with people who are overseas? How will they be contacted? Will there be correspondence overseas or contact through the appropriate embassy for people who have moved overseas for a period?

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be assumed they are rich.

—That is right. Backpackers are rich. I am sure that the people who are on flights overseas, who go away for a holiday for one year or two years, are all earning more than $70,000! I am sure that the people I have seen in Europe and Canada on the occasions I have been there are all earning more than $70,000 and that the blazing publicity and the massive campaign from the tax office is going to contact all these people—and there would be many thousands of them overseas with their backpacks and their Tax Pack in their back pack, trudging around Europe, pulling out the Tax Pack to check to see whether this surcharge is going to apply to them. They will come back in 18 months time and say, `Whoopee! I have my statements. Oh, I did not read the Tax Pack . I did not get the telegram from the embassy in London. I did not get the letter in the mail. Where was the phone call?' They might have had a mobile phone on them. They might have been contacted that way.
—Not if it was Lyn Allison.

—No, not after today. We have to find a little bit of levity in all of this because it is such a serious issue with detrimental consequences to so many Australians. We do not believe it is proper in principle to be using the tax file system in this way, given the enormous detrimental consequences to so many hundreds of thousands if not a million people in having to pay a tax through the non provision of a tax file number.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I am really pleased to hear these words from Senator Sherry. When I looked at the section of the act that they are asking to be removed, clause 18, it does seem a little bit like closing the door after the horse has bolted. If I recall, we did say this earlier. We have already gone through the legislation allowing the tax file number to be used this way. We were up there saying, `Hey, guys, this is something we ought to be concerned about.' At that stage, unfortunately, Labor was not concerned. But I am pleased to see that Labor is concerned now. Unfortunately, the bit in the bill, as I read it, says that they already have the ability to get your tax file number through the previous bill and this bill says that you can get some money back potentially if they get your tax file number.

SPEECH.PARA: This might in fact mean that they will have to reassess the whole issue of tax file numbers. I do need some further explanation, because my understanding is that they already have the power to get your tax file number; that was in a previous bill. And this bit may indicate, unfortunately, that those people who get slogged tax may lose the ability to get that extra tax back if they were not actually liable to pay it. That is my reading of it. It might make the bill unworkable in relation to tax file numbers—and maybe that is a good idea—but it might also backfire and affect only those large numbers of people who did not quote their tax file number, and who now will not have a mechanism to get the money back.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, is this in fact legislative creep, in the sense that this a further example of where legislation has extended the use of the tax file number? If that is so, was any advice taken from the Privacy Commissioner before this was extended, or is it simply a mechanism used by the Australian Taxation Office? I can understand the tax office using this, but it is a matter of concern. And it is a matter of concern especially for you, Minister, because you are noted not only for the outstanding work you did in making sure that international conventions were not introduced into Australia except in a proper way, but also for your stand over many years—it was broadcast around Melbourne—on civil rights. I have heard it said again and again, `Senator Kemp has stood up for our rights, including the use of tax file numbers, as he stood up against the Australia card.' I would like to know if there is any hope that you could battle the onslaught of the use of this number which comes out of Treasury and the tax office? I would like an answer to those questions. Is this a retreat by you? And, if you have advice from the Privacy Commissioner, would it be too much to let us have a look at that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for those initial comments, Senator; they are greatly appreciated. However, in relation to the battle for international treaties and proper procedures, Senator Harradine also helped lead the charge. In fact, he may well have been in advance of the charge. In wanting to get this bill through quickly, I wanted to make sure that Senator Harradine did not feel that his great contribution in that important battle had been ignored. I do not know if it will influence him; I am sure it will not.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a couple of matters which have been raised—and I will come back to your questions, Senator Cooney. I want to respond, firstly, to the earlier comment by Senator Sherry that the Tax Pack should have a note which tells taxpayers how important it is to quote a TFN to their superannuation funds. There will be a note in the Tax Pack, and notices of assessment which will follow lodgment of tax returns this year will also prompt taxpayers in regard to TFN quotation. They are just two examples.

Your histrionics, Senator Sherry, about the use of the tax file number and the distinction you tried to make between bank accounts—when your government required a TFN to be lodged with a bank—and this particular measure does not wash. The purpose of the banks requiring tax file numbers for accounts was to ensure the proper collection of a tax, and this TFN assists in the proper collection of a surcharge—or, in that case, will actually ensure that a surcharge for low and middle income earners will not be imposed. For you to carry on with your histrionics about this does not wash one iota with me, Senator Sherry.

On the issue of privacy, Senator Cooney, I return the compliment: you have been a great supporter of civil rights. I am not too sure how far out in front you were on the Australia card, but I do not think we have to revisit that issue. In general, the principle that I have stated is quite correct, and the tax file numbers should only be used in the proper circumstances. The whole issue of privacy in this matter was, I am advised, extensively discussed before Senator Watson's committee. The Privacy Commissioner gave evidence to that committee and I think that evidence and advice that she gave is publicly available. You were quite right to draw that to our attention, Senator Cooney, and it has been extensively canvassed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will oppose the deletion of clause 18 in amendment 27. It is our understanding that this clause requires the commissioner to reduce the surcharge liability if a tax file number is subsequently quoted. We think that the clause serves a valid purpose and that is the reason we will be opposing its deletion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point that Senator Margetts raised: the amendment before us, if it was carried in isolation, would have the problem that you identified. But it needs to be seen in light of the amendment we are moving to the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge Imposition Bill and, in fact, the two amendments need to be considered together. So, if this motion was carried, then the amendment to the imposition bill would need to be carried. It would obviously be a ridiculous position if this amendment was carried and the further amendment which we will come to later was defeated. I hope we will not be in that position, but that would take care of the problem that you have identified. I am advised that we have to move the amendments in this way because of the package of bills with which we are dealing.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That clause 18 stand as printed.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Jacinta Collins did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza)

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 18 agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (46) Page 42 (after line 3), after clause 39, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 39A Australian actuarial practice guidelines

SPEECH.PARA: (1) For the purposes of this Act, Australian actuarial practice is to be determined in accordance with guidelines published by the Institute of Actuaries of Australia, as in force for the time being.
(2) An instrument under subclause (I) is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

Amendment 46 goes to the issue of actuarial guidelines. I am not going to speak for very long on this issue because we have discussed the particular problems with actuarial guidelines as they apply, and we have yet to see the actuarial guidelines. They are to be published in a month. That is very unsatisfactory for people who are inquiring as to how they will be affected.

This amendment seeks to ensure that the actuarial standard, which is to be used to determine the notional surcharge contributions factor, is a disallowable instrument in both houses of parliament. Given that this standard will have to be reviewed, it is entirely appropriate that the houses of parliament are able to disallow the standard should it breach the actual intention of the 15 per cent tax on superannuation. We do not believe that it is excessive or unreasonable for the parliament to have a say in the actuarial guidelines. We believe that is appropriate.

Given that the actuarial standard will not be presented to us for another month, according to the advice given to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, for example, it is entirely appropriate for the Senate to decide that the actuarial guidelines should be subject to parliamentary review in order to ensure that the standards are in keeping with the intention of the government's policy. Quite simply, we do not accept all the assurances given by the government in respect of this package of legislation, so why should we accept their assurances in respect of actuarial guidelines?

While there are now a few more senators than we have had in this chamber so far tonight, I might say that the actuarial guidelines are very important. For example, there is conflicting advice about the possibility of the tax effectively being more than 15 per cent on a number of defined benefit funds, and colleagues in here may find that of some interest. We believe that these actuarial guidelines should be subject to parliamentary review in order to ensure that the standards the government continually asserts are in keeping with the intention of the government's policy.

We are sceptical—we have a right to be sceptical—about the government's stated policy on the package of bills. There have been a number of significant changes, for a number of reasons, in respect of the package of legislation that has been before us over the last few months. The hour is late so I am not going to go in the detail of why that has occurred. We have already traversed that in this debate. We believe it is an important principle that the actuarial guidelines are brought before the parliament and that they can be subject to disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —One can only assume that the fact that the government has indicated that the actuarial guidelines will not be available for a couple of months means that the world will not fall apart in the meantime. One would assume that means that in the meantime they will be operating within normal actuarial guidelines. So it does not seem unreasonable that once the government does produce these guidelines they can be established as a disallowable instrument.

SPEECH.PARA: If the world is not going to fall part, according to the government, between now and when the actual actuarial guidelines are out, we can assume that means that in the meantime they will operate in accordance with normal actuarial guidelines. This will give the Senate a chance to make sure that the government keeps to its stated aims in relation to the content of these guidelines. The Greens will support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that the propositions put by Senator Sherry and Senator Margetts are absolutely right. If there is one thing parliament ought to do it is to supervise the collection of taxation—to set the level of taxes and to make sure that those taxes are collected in accordance with what parliament says. If parliament has had a function over the centuries, that is it. It seems to me that we have almost got an obligation to have this put in.

SPEECH.PARA: The points made by Senator Sherry and Senator Margetts are absolutely right, that these guidelines will operate until they are disallowed. So it is not as if anything is going to happen before they are disallowed. All this does is give the parliament the ability it ought to have to supervise the rate and level at which tax, or payments in the nature of tax, are made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —We are fortunate to have with us the Australian Government Actuary, who can write quickly.
—Make sure he comes to the committee hearings next time.

—Senator, you have already had that rather unpleasant crack. I think we can move on from that. This amendment seeks to make guidelines published by the Institute of Actuaries of Australia a disallowable instrument. The guidance note is to be prepared by the Institute of Actuaries of Australia to govern the actions of actuaries practising in Australia. Actuarial standards are binding on all practising actuaries in Australia. The safeguards in this approach include the manner in which these guidelines are developed, which involves consultation on all issues with superannuation actuaries. If the Senate were to disallow them—and there is an Institute of Actuaries document on issues of actuarial practice—it is simply not clear that the actuaries would still not have to abide by them.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, we rely on a number of occasions on standards which are developed by the Institute of Actuaries. It is a document of the Institute of Actuaries. It is not a government document. We believe there are sufficient safeguards in the system. We have gone through areas where a number of senators have raised questions about appeals, and the government will not be supporting this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —While we have some sympathy with Senator Sherry's amendment here, in a practical sense, I think it does create problems, which the government has already outlined. That and perhaps the notion of the legal difficulty in a private sector instrument becoming a disallowable instrument lead us to believe that this amendment ought to be opposed.

—Senator Allison, I find that a very interesting proposition. The Standards Association of Australia set out criteria which, I hope, if made relevant to any legislation, would be a disallowable instrument. Perhaps I should ask the minister: what is the difference between the criteria put out by the Standards Association of Australia and the criteria put out by actuaries? To say that the parliament should not have the ability to have a look at what the private sector puts out, simply because it is the private sector—
—To collect a tax.

—To collect a tax, which is, as I said before, a fundamental function of parliament, just seems to be extraordinary. If we gave over, as they did in biblical times, the collection of taxation to private enterprise, does that mean to say that we would not be able to set up any standards? To say that we can control and properly make regulations about the taxation department—or any other government department—but not about a private group which that taxation department is going to rely on to determine how much money would be gathered in, just seems to me to be absolutely extraordinary. To come in here and say that parliament cannot look at what actuaries do and, if they find something, disallow it, seems extraordinary, particularly when we can disallow in this chamber rules of court. To think that we can disallow the rules of the High Court of Australia or the rules of the Federal Court of Australia but not disallow some rules made by a private group—namely, a group of actuaries—just seems to me a most extraordinary thing.

—I think Senator Allison expressed it very well actually. This is a private sector document and, if this amendment had got through, it would become a disallowable instrument. It would raise complexities which the government is not prepared to accept. These are standards which I have said are developed by the Institute of Actuaries of Australia, and they are developed in consultation with virtually all actuaries in the superannuation industry. Those who are unhappy with the results of the application of these standards have the right of appeal, as I have outlined previously.
—But not the parliament.

—I am just saying that the government believes this is an appropriate way to go. It has gone this way before in relation to other matters which have come before it. I quoted an example earlier where a taxation bill relied on actuarial advice. I do not think it was an issue then and I believe that what I have outlined and the safeguards that are involved are sufficient.

—If there was a dispute about an actuarial guideline in the private sector that went before the court—and there may well be a dispute about that—is it a fact that the guidelines or the workings out that are done by the actuaries would be dealt with by a court, which could say something about that, whereas the parliament cannot, and yet that court would have its rules supervised by this chamber? Is that the effect of what happens? If your advisers say that matters of actuarial calculation could not be decided by the court, can they give that guarantee that there will be no litigation in respect of actuarial guidelines?

—Anyone can dispute a wide range of issues in court, as you know. If courts made decisions which we did not feel were appropriate, the parliament as a whole could legislate. I do not think the Senate supervises the rulings of courts in that sense.
—They certainly supervise their rules. So what you are saying is that the courts can do something about these guidelines but this parliament cannot?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —On the same line of questioning, I imagine that there would be a few other people besides myself for whom major warning bells are ringing at the moment. In the last couple of weeks we have just heard about the federal government's intention to privatise data processing in a whole range of departments. Defence have put down their number nines and refused not to—good for them!—because they want to keep things private. However, in the meantime the government is saying, `No, we can't require them to keep things private.'

SPEECH.PARA: This is just the thin edge of the wedge. As Senator Cooney has indicated, it is ridiculous. If you are actually getting private enterprise, which a lot of people do not think is a good idea, to collect tax and then say, `We can't regulate them', for heaven's sake, what is this coming to and what is the thick end of the wedge? What are we going to be seeing? Are we going to be seeing ministers coming in, as they are in Britain, saying, `I'm sorry, you can't ask me this question because I am not responsible for it any more'?

This is not the way we should be going. The very warning bells that are ringing now would probably indicate that we have to start looking at what is happening under the competition policy bill that went through in 1995. We should start looking at major amendments to that before we get anywhere near the thick end of the wedge that I can see looming.

I would agree with Senator Cooney that it is a ridiculous assumption to stand there, as we are pushing more and more for private enterprise to take over the roles of government—in this case, to take over tax collection—and say, `No, we are not able as a parliament to oversee or regulate how that is done.' It is just appalling. It should be ringing warning bells with people. If it is not, it will be mentioned again and again in this chamber as we are pushing more and more into things that involve people's lives, their privacy, their livelihoods and their ability to survive.

There is nothing that upsets people more than taxes in general terms. There are lots of other things that upset people. The one thing that annoys people is when things go wrong within the bureaucracy and how that is regulated. If government is going to indicate that they want to step back from that, I would like to get some further explanation of what we will see in the future.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Sherry's ) be agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Bolkus did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

SPEECH.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (51) Clause 43, page 49 (after line 12), after the definition of superannuation (unfunded defined benefits) provider, insert:
surcharge (wherever occurring) means a tax.

This is a very important amendment. That is not to decry the amendments that we have been considering so far in regard to this legislation. Before I speak to the amendment, I want to note that we received the Democrat-government amendment on the exemption of low and middle income earners from the collection of the new 15 per cent tax where a tax file number has not been provided. There was some formatting problem that Senator Allison has explained to me. We regret that we received the corrected, formatted amendment only in the last 10 or 15 minutes. It is 24 hours after the government and the Democrats reached agreement.

This is a complex issue. I am not having a go at Senator Kemp. I just want it noted clearly for the record that we have been waiting on this government-Democrat amendment for the past 24 hours. It is very important; it is difficult; it is complex. We understand and appreciate the difficulty that the Democrats and the government had in finalising the wording of this very important amendment, but I will make some comments on that shortly. In the very brief time we have had a chance to have a look at it, we have found that it is quite extensive and very complex. We will make some comments on that shortly.

Our amendment 51 is very important. Is the committee tonight dealing with a surcharge or a tax? We have to recall the words of the Liberal Party manifesto prior to the last election: no increases in existing taxes, no new taxes. On budget night in August last year, the Treasurer, Mr Costello, announced a massive new revenue raising measure worth an average of $1.5 billion over three years. At the same time, he said he would not be increasing taxes. This is the government's largest single revenue raising measure.

I emphasise that it is not our fault that we are dealing with the government's largest single revenue raising measure six days before the following year's budget. This legislation was presented to the parliament—I forget the particular date—in February, and the government has presented some significant amendments and a readjustment of its position, particularly in respect to the legal criticisms from Mr Rose representing the Business Council.

I understand the government forgot to include federal public servants in its initial package of legislation. I suppose it is fairly understandable that these major elements of tax policy and tax legislation would be omitted because of the general chaos that surrounded the preparation and presentation of this legislation. We were left with the regrettable situation of being presented with these bills prior to the Easter adjournment at 10 o'clock—two hours before the midnight cut‐off for the Senate to conclude its deliberations. That was squarely in the government's court; it presented that legislation two hours before the cut-off.

This is very complex legislation. I handled the industrial relations bills in the chamber. I think we spent some two weeks on that legislation last year. Whilst this legislation has been less exhaustive in that much less time has been spent, the technical detail is considerable. If you compare it to the industrial relations package, it is much more complex, particularly given the various aspects of tax legislation that one has to have knowledge of.

Is it a tax or is it a surcharge? If we look at the budget papers presented last year by the Treasurer, Mr Costello, it is described in those budget papers as a tax. When we asked for an explanation from the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, he said it was a typographical error that it was described as a tax. The real reason the government will not acknowledge that this is a tax—even though it is a half a billion dollar a year revenue raising measure—is that it did not want to be seen to be breaking its specific election commitment: no new taxes, no increase in existing taxes.

That was the very specific promise that the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, and Mr Costello made, but of course this measure is a tax. I will come to references made by the Prime Minister, the Assistant Treasurer and the Treasurer on this matter shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Excuse me, Senator Sherry, would you be able to at this stage move amendments Nos 1 and 2 from sheet 472, which I believe go to the same point?
—Yes. I am aware that that would speed up the debate. I certainly do not want to speak 10 or 15 times about why this is a tax and not a surcharge, so I seek leave to move those amendments together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 1, page 1 (line 17), omit "Surcharge", substitute "Tax".
(2) Title, page 1 (line 11), omit "surcharge", substitute "tax".

It is a very important principle that the Senate ensure that the government is required to acknowledge that this is a tax; that there is a fundamental breach of the election commitment given at the last election that there would be no increase in taxes and no new taxes. The government in imposing this new tax—it calls it a surcharge—does rely on the taxation powers of the Commonwealth in the constitution.

Why has the government called it a surcharge? In addition to the Prime Minister wanting to avoid being accused of breaking an election commitment, it went one step further than calling it a surcharge and required the superannuation funds to collect the so-called surcharge themselves. The government had a hope—and I think a vain hope—that, by requiring the superannuation funds to collect a new tax, it would not be as noticeable.

Certainly the people in the industry who have spoken first-hand to the Treasurer about this matter believe that that is the base cynical approach of the very arrogant Treasurer on this matter. Some would believe the Prime Minister is not capable of cynicism. Indeed, he did ask us to call a spade a spade. I would certainly believe the Prime Minister should have called a tax a tax.

The government called it a surcharge to make sure that it could not be accused of breaking an election promise and it also tried to hide the charge by getting the superannuation funds to collect it in the vain hope that people would not notice it. But when fund members receive their statements over the next six months or year, they will see that there is an existing superannuation tax of 15 per cent—surprise, surprise! I do not think it is just coincidence that the existing tax on superannuation is 15 per cent. The government struck a rate of 15 per cent surcharge in addition to the existing 15 per cent tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not very imaginative.

—No, not very imaginative, Senator Harradine; in fact, an insult to the intelligence of the Australian electorate. They are not dumb, Senator Kemp; they are not silly. They can see through the pretence that has been built around this issue of trying to call a tax a surcharge and trying to hide it by requiring the superannuation funds to collect it. The Australian electorate are not silly. I credit them with a great deal of intelligence.

SPEECH.PARA: When they receive those statements, they will have the existing 15 per cent tax and the additional 15 per cent tax. For the first year there will be a 7½ per cent advance instalment tax and in addition there will be the subtraction of administrative charges. I am informed that in some cases the funds are going to put an additional administrative charge on the statement to cover the cost of collecting the new tax. It is estimated to cost—and I will not take the more alarmist position of the industry—between $20 million and $100 million to collect this new tax. That will be detailed on fund statements.

I am pleased to note Senator Heffernan is taking some interest in this debate because I think, once this package of legislation is passed and once the complaints start to flow, he will take a lot of interest in the consequences of the imposition of this new tax.

So on the statements in the next year there will be the 15 per cent existing tax, the 15 per cent new tax called a surcharge by the government, the advanced instalment of 7½ per cent—that is 37½ per cent so far—minus administrative costs and in some cases additional administrative costs for the collection of the new tax.
