Unfortunately, I do not think many Australian people are aware that the money in that year will effectively be taxed another 15 per cent when they leave the fund—a grand total of 52½ per cent tax in the first year of operation of the surcharge. It is no wonder that there is a significant amount of angst, concern and anger in the Australian community about this package of measures.

This surcharge is supposed to apply to high income earners. We have exhaustively covered why it is going to apply to low and middle income earners. I do not believe that higher income earners in their wildest dreams believed when they voted for this government that their superannuation would effectively be hit with 52½ per cent tax plus the increased administrative costs in the first year after the election of the new government which promised them lower taxes. The government has maintained that it is a fair measure to apply this new tax in the way it has outlined.

The government has gone to considerable efforts, as I have said, to avoid using the word `tax' in this debate. It has been grossly untruthful during the debate and over the past five months in this regard. The new tax has been met with considerable anger, which has been magnified by it continually being referred to—by Mr Howard, in particular—as a `surcharge'. People do not like to be kidded when a new tax is being applied, particularly when commitments were given at the election that no new taxes would be applied. They do not like being treated as fools by the Prime Minister with his continuingly misleading statements that this is a surcharge.
The claims being made that there were no new taxes in the last budget are clearly ridiculous—and this is the worst example. As I said earlier, it is the largest single revenue raising measure.

BREAK.PARA: The Treasurer was questioned on the John Laws program about the issue of Dennis Rose QC's remarks before the Senate select committee—and Dennis Rose himself said, `It is plainly a tax.' In fact, Justice Davies, who is a sitting Federal Court judge, last week also called it a tax; that was his view. On the John Laws program, the Treasurer said:
The tax that is being collected on employer contributions will be 30 per cent rather than 15 per cent.
He was acknowledging that it was a tax. Also, on the National Radio breakfast program with Pru Goward, he said:

So this is nothing new that we're introducing in the sense of the contributions tax. It's been operating for quite some time. What we're doing is we're changing the rate in relation to high income earners from 15 per cent to 30 per cent.

It is a tax. The committee should pass this amendment and the following amendments to indicate clearly to the Australian people that the Treasurer has accepted it is a tax, everyone else says it is a tax, we believe it is a tax, it should be called a tax—and, hopefully, the last person in Australia who does not believe it is a tax, Mr Howard, will finally be convinced it is not a surcharge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I call this amendment `calling a spade a spade', and that seems to be the kind of terminology the Prime Minister is using too. This amendment, as has been mentioned, changes the word `surcharge' to `tax'. We fully support the amendment on the basis of truth: it is a tax. Moreover, it is specifically an income tax, or at least that is its announced intention. Its intention is based on total income—not on the level of superannuation contribution, not on whether the superannuation is a salary sacrifice for tax evasion purposes, and not on whether it is a rort or not.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand why the government might want to make out that this is not a tax. It has made promises not to raise taxes; it is already fudging it by saying `no new taxes'; but it did not say that it would not raise the same old taxes. It is hard trying to weasel out of acknowledging what it is doing.

Many government promises, however, should not be kept. I have to say that many are awful—or plainly stupid. I for one do not think I should hold governments to stupid promises. I would rather that they were repentant, honestly repentant, and stopped targeting the weak and poor, stopped targeting marginal people like Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, and stopped targeting students and the old and the sick. Those are the kinds of promises that I think should not be kept because they should never have made them.

I would rather that government realise they cannot provide services for the community while reducing the tax base—and as Mr Costello has indicated, he might go even further in this next budget—and eliminating any obligations for business to include such things as equity and human consideration because it adds to the cost of compliance, for instance. I would much rather see government become repentant than keep it honestly horrible.

This amendment and several subsequent amendments seek to change the word `surcharge' to `tax'. I do not think we should ask government to stick to negative promises and I would prefer repentant fibbers to barefaced fibbers. But that does not mean that we should allow them to become deceitful. This is a tax and it should be so called.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will support these amendments. The changes, we believe, are important and, even though we have been unable to get the government to agree that they are important, we are happy to support the ALP in this regard. We think that, whilst we have reached agreement with the government on excluding redundancy benefits from the definition of `income' and exempting low income earners from paying the surcharge, it is still very important to insist that the government concede that this $1.5 billion tax is in fact a tax. We think it is entirely appropriate that the Senate say to the government in the House of Representatives, `If you want this bill, accept that it is a tax and get on with it.'

SPEECH.PARA: I think it would be quite dishonest for parliament to let the government get away with pretending that this tax is not a tax simply because the government chooses to call it a surcharge. Indeed, I suspect that half of the problem for the government in designing the collection mechanism was to try to build a whole complicated edifice to deny that the surcharge is a tax. If the government had admitted it was a tax up-front and collected it through the normal PAYE system, then none of the problems that have been identified by the Senate super committee—and, I have to say, by the industry—would have arisen.

There is no question that this surcharge is a tax. Indeed, this is a point acknowledged by the tax officials in their evidence to the super committee when they said that the surcharge relies on the taxation power of the constitution. If it is not a tax, it is not constitutional.

The 1996-97 budget papers clearly recognised it as a tax as the largest single revenue measure. Indeed, the proceeds from the surcharge have been added into income tax collections. It has been pointed out that a key factor in the nine per cent increase in income tax collections this year and the 7.6 per cent increase next year was the `increase in superannuation contributions tax for higher income earners'.

It is a tax, Senator Kemp, so why not call it a tax? Why all the subterfuge and the elaborate avoidance of the issue? The Democrats will support these amendments as being at least one small step in teaching the government that a little bit of honesty in presenting its decisions and policies is worthwhile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I just say that I, too, will be supporting this amendment. A tax is a tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I take this opportunity to extend my congratulations to you on your appointment as Deputy President and wish you all the very best for the future. I thank the Senate for this opportunity to say a few words on what is my last occasion in this chamber. Next week I leave for London to take up my new position as the Australian member of the executive board of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. In many respects, I am returning to the area of professional interest that I pursued before first entering federal parliament in 1975. I welcome the opportunity to move to this next stage in my life.

SPEECH.PARA: This, of course, is the second time that I have left parliament. The circumstances are very different. The first occasion, in October 1980, was involuntary on my part when the voters of Ballarat fell half a per cent short of returning Short to Canberra after five years as their representative. That involuntary departure also proved to be temporary as I returned to parliament, but this time in the Senate, in the election of 1984. This time I am leaving totally voluntarily and, I can assure you, totally permanently.

So this is the end of a long political road that began in 1975. My association with the parliament actually predates that by almost a dozen years because in 1964 I came to Parliament House for a near two‐year stint as private secretary to the then Treasurer, Harold Holt.

The political road has been one of highs and lows, from being part of Malcolm Fraser's new team in 1975; to the defeat in Ballarat in 1980; to election to the Senate in 1984; to the frontbench in 1987; to the backbench in 1988, as a victim of the so‐called rotisserie reshuffle of the then opposition leader, John Howard; to the shadow finance portfolio in 1990 and a heavy involvement in the development of Fightback; to coalition deputy Senate leader in 1992; to the despair of the election loss in 1993; to three rewarding years as shadow minister for immigration and ethnic affairs; to the high of Assistant Treasurer in the first Howard government; to the disappointment of resignation just seven months later because of my belief in the Westminster principles despite the fact that, as the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said, at no stage had I acted with any impropriety whatsoever.

BREAK.PARA: But, after spending most of the past decade on the coalition frontbench, I think my decision to move on to what will be an exciting and challenging new stage of my life is the right decision at the right time. In my decision to leave I draw support from Ecclesiastes 3:1, which says:
To every thing there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven . . .

I leave with certain regrets but many happy memories. I have enjoyed virtually all the issues with which I have been involved as a member of the federal parliament in both the House of Representatives and the Senate. If I were to single out what I would regard as my most significant personal involvements over my more than 17 years in this parliament, I think I would list five.

The first was my role in initiating and pursuing in the parliament consideration of what became known as the Dollar Sweets and Troubleshooters cases in the mid‐1980s. Those cases ultimately had a quite profound impact, eventually for the better, on the industrial relations climate in this country.

The second was the opportunity to be part of the small team that did much of the detailed work in putting together the most comprehensive program for reform that has ever been presented to the Australian people. It is one of the truly great tragedies of Australian history that we were unable, in 1993, to explain sufficiently clearly to the people just what huge benefits the Fightback program conferred on our prospects both as individuals and as a nation.

The third highlight was as Assistant Treasurer in playing what the Prime Minister described as a major role in the preparation of the first budget of the first Howard government in 1996. That budget did much to put our national public finances back on track and to lay the foundations for a sustainable better future for all Australians. And I have every confidence that next week's budget will build on the foundations laid last year.

But there are two other areas of my political involvement from which I gain most satisfaction. The first is my involvement right from the start in that initial group of people both inside and outside the parliament who pushed for the removal of the barriers to economic growth that were so severely hampering the ability of Australians to achieve their individual and national potential. We were known initially as the economic dries and later as economic rationalists. Both terms are essentially pejorative and meaningless. Their use I think displays a lack of understanding of what greater economic freedom and competition can do to provide jobs, improve living standards and produce a fairer and better society.

Fortunately, despite the pejorative labels, the advocates of that agenda won the philosophical, political and policy debate in the marketplace of ideas in the 1980s and, as a result, the future of Australia is much more positive and exciting. However, there is still much reform that needs to occur. The directions already set must be maintained and pursued, including the pressing need for a comprehensive review and overhaul of our taxation system.

The other area, and the one that I derived the greatest personal satisfaction from, is the wonderful privilege I have had both before and throughout virtually all my political career, including in particular my three years as shadow minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, of meeting and working with Australians whose origins reflect the richly diverse, harmonious, tolerant, multicultural nation that is the Australia of the late 1990s and the envy of almost every other nation on Earth. I want to say to all Australians whose ethnic or racial origins are the 150 or more nations from which immigrants have built the Australia of today that collectively we have much to be proud of.

I also want to thank the huge number of Australians of widely varying ethnic, racial and religious origins whom I have had the enormous pleasure and privilege of getting to know, many of whom I can genuinely call friend. Overwhelmingly these people are fiercely proud to be Australian—to give a total commitment to Australia, to share common values with other Australians and to join in shaping the exciting, evolving Australia of the late 20th century. It is the very diversity of the contributions that each of us brings to our society that has helped Australia throughout our history to forge a unique, cohesive and above all united nation.

I would have expected that it is self-evident that we are a nation blessed by this richness of cultural and ethnic origins and the very special qualities it has produced. But it is clear that that is not the case. We cannot ignore that people like Pauline Hanson—with narrow, prejudiced, negative, distorted, divisive, insular views, widely inaccurate facts and a lack of any acceptable rational policy proposals—have a certain following in Australia today. If that following were to grow, it would impose a very real threat to the stability and fabric of our society and to our role in the world. It is the responsibility of all of us and of this parliament to do all that is needed to ensure that Pauline Hanson and her manipulators are exposed as peddlers of a farrago of inaccuracies, distortions and ignorance whose views cannot survive objective analysis and debate.

I entered the Senate after the 1984 election in august company. Those of us who were sworn in on 21 February 1985 were, from the coalition, Senators Brownhill, Knowles, Parer, Short and Vanstone. From Labor we had Senators Aulich, Black, Cooney, Devlin and McKiernan. From the Australian Democrats we had Senator Vigor. It is salutary to note that, after my departure, only six of those 11 senators will still be here.

But it is indicative of the high quality of that 1984 intake however that, of the four remaining coalition senators, two, Senators Vanstone and Parer, are important ministers in the Howard government; one, Senator Brownhill, is parliamentary secretary to both the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) and the Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Anderson); and the fourth, Senator Knowles, has in the past been deputy whip, a member of the coalition frontbench and now plays an important role as chairman of the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee. The two remaining Labor senators, Senator Cooney and Senator McKiernan, are also distinguished members of this chamber. Without any disrespect to Senator McKiernan, could I say of Senator Cooney that I believe he has made a unique contribution.

It was the expansion of the Senate in 1984 from 10 to 12 senators from each state that enabled me to be elected. Whilst I of course welcome that, there is no doubt that this expansion has led to instability and makes it extremely difficult for the government of the day ever again to have control of the Senate. I share the concerns expressed by the outgoing Federal Director of the Liberal Party, Andrew Robb. I agree with him that the situation warrants urgent review. It is of course, though, much easier to identify the problem than to propose a practicable solution.

I want to thank Senator Hill, who has been coalition leader in the Senate for the past seven years, for all his support and encouragement, particularly during the period in which I served as his deputy in 1992-93. I thank you very much indeed, Robert, for everything. I also want to thank my other colleagues, and in particular my Victorian coalition senator colleagues Senators Alston, Kemp, Patterson, Troeth and McGauran for their friendship and cooperation over the years. My thanks extend to senators on all sides of politics. Some have become close friends and I hope that they will remain so.

I would like to thank the staff of the Senate for all their wonderful assistance to me over the years. It would be unfair to single out individuals, but I do want to put on record my deep appreciation of the work of the Clerk of the Senate, Harry Evans, his deputy, Anne Lynch, and their assistants. They are tireless, they are always objective and rarely, if ever, do they lose the composure that I am sure our antics from time to time put under severe pressure. I thank also all of those persons who play such important roles in allowing us to perform our duties: the Transport Office, the Comcar drivers, Hansard, the highly professional staff of our many committees, the library staff, the attendants, the relevant officers of DAS—and there are many others as well.

To all my personal staff over the years, I put on the record my heartfelt thanks for their professionalism, efficiency and friendship— and I am delighted to see a couple of them here tonight. I have been very fortunate, indeed, to have had at all times a very supportive team. Most important of all, to my family and particularly to my dear wife, Jan, who is in the gallery tonight and who will be missed as convener of the Parliamentary Partners Association, may I thank you for putting up with me and supporting me so unfailingly in politics with all the stresses and strains over all these years on family life and on individual members of the family that political life brings. I only hope I may be able to repay you with more time, attention and care in the years ahead than I have during my political life.

It is a wonderful privilege to have had the opportunity to serve in the federal parliament. I have been deeply honoured and feel deeply grateful to have had that opportunity. For that, I thank the Liberal Party for choosing me as one of its candidates and the people of Victoria for electing me. I have at all times tried to serve my Victorian constituents and the people of Australia—for all of whom we share a common responsibility as members of this national parliament—to the best of my ability. I hope I have succeeded in meeting the trust put in me. I wish my successor, Karen Synon, every success and enjoyment in her new life as a senator. I know that she will more than adequately fill my shoes.

I wish Prime Minister John Howard and his government every success in the great challenges that lie ahead. I wish the Senate well in its vital role as parliamentary watchdog over the actions of the executive. I wish all of you well in your individual responsibilities and lives, both within and outside the parliament. It has been a great pleasure to be part of the team. I shall remember it with very fond memories for many years to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the opportunity to express on my own behalf—I am the first of a long queue, I can assure you, Jim, so you will have to be patient tonight—my appreciation for your contribution to public service and public life in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Yours has been quite an extraordinary career when one looks at it—varied, eventful, exciting. You talked about highs and lows: certainly one can see the pitfalls, but you have also had a tremendous capacity, I might say, to land on your feet. After all, you lost your seat in the House of Representatives after five years, but you were elevated to the Australian Senate! After the unpleasant experience of October last year, you are now to be elevated to the exalted role of Alternate Executive Director of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. Throughout your career, as I say, you seem to have landed on your feet with an even more challenging and interesting role.

You have, as you have told us, served in the House of Representatives for five years, and then for 13 years in the Senate. You have served on so many parliamentary committees that I will not take the time of the Senate to recall them tonight. You have served in our shadow ministry in finance, in home affairs and in immigration and ethnic affairs.

In the latter capacity, I particularly recall and remember with appreciation the way in which you gathered around you so many immigrants to our country, particularly those who came from what were referred to as the `captive nations'. But in your case it was the old captive nations of Europe and then a little later the new captive nations of Asia. All seemed to see in you somebody who was sympathetic to their interests, prepared to listen to their case and, perhaps most important, prepared to act rather than simply express support. You went out and worked for these people in a constructive and positive way. You have hinted at it but I can confirm that there are literally hundreds if not thousands of Australians who you probably do not know but who appreciate something that you did for them during those years.

Jim, even before you got here, as you said, your career was varied. You worked in the Treasury, you were Private Secretary to the then Treasurer, the Rt Hon. Harold Holt, and you went into the private sector as General Manager, Corporate Affairs, for ACI. On that basis, as I said, it has been an incredibly full public commitment and an interesting working life.

I note, and you touched upon it also, that in coming here and in your service to the parliament you never forgot the political party that put you here. Your service to the Liberal Party as a country vice‐president in Victoria, a member of the Victorian Administrative Committee, Chairman of the Development Committee and a member of the Federal Strategy Committee put something back into the organisation of the party for the opportunity it gave to you to be a federal parliamentarian.

Jim, you will leave us and for that we will obviously be disappointed. You have been a good friend and a loyal colleague. Your approach to politics has always been that of the thoughtful kind: thoughtful, hardworking and dedicated to the beliefs that you hold. You mentioned some of those here tonight. You were always a team player—something that we will remember with gratitude.

Jim, I particularly wanted to take the opportunity to express my appreciation for your support during the years in which you were my deputy in this place. They were not necessarily easy years. Opposition, as that lot over there will find, is not a lot of fun, particularly as the years go by. There is your value as an economist and your value, as I said, as a thoughtful contributor; somebody who was always prepared to buck in and give the necessary speech. Some occasionally thought a little too often, I might say, but you would not be an orphan in politics for it to be suggested that you might speak too often. Yours was always a very strong contribution based on knowledge and commitment.

I will miss you as a friend and a colleague, Jim. I wish you well in this next step in what I have said is obviously a fascinating career. I will miss Jan, as well. There are those who are lucky to travel, unlike me. I could be confident that you will find a guest or two from amongst your old political colleagues who might occasionally drop in on you in London. I am sure that they will receive a warm welcome from you. Jim, all the best to you and your family in the next step of your career. We thank you for your support and loyalty over the years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —If I can say on behalf of the opposition to you, Jim, we also wish you very well in your future career. As you indicated, it has been a long parliamentary career that you have had as a member of the House of Representatives from 1975 to 1980 and of course as senator since 1984. You did hold high office in your parliamentary party during that time.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we all understand that in recent times obviously your parliamentary career has been tinged with some disappointment because you were only able to serve as a minister for a brief time in John Howard's administration. I think that all of us would acknowledge that the nature of your political involvement and political career has really been quite remarkable. You have been a ministerial staffer. You have had a lot of the experience in your party machine and as a party activist. You have been a member of the House of Representatives. You have been a senator. You have had extensive parliamentary committee service. You have been a shadow minister. You have been a minister. You have been deputy leader of your party. I think you can look back on that and say on any count that is a very significant contribution to the political party for which you have worked very hard over a very long period of time.

Whenever members of the opposition speak in debates like this I think it is sensible to acknowledge that we have had our differences from time to time. I think everyone understands that is the case. I was very interested to hear your contribution and your comments, albeit very brief comments, on the role of the Senate. As I looked at the first speech you made in the Senate before I came down, I wondered if there had been just a little revisionism there because I note that in your first speech to the Senate you said:

The Senate plays an essential watchdog role on behalf of the basic rights and freedoms of all Australians, and over the excesses of any executive government. Any attempts to weaken or dilute that role, or the responsibility of the Senate, must be vigorously resisted by every member of this chamber.
That was the note on which you commenced your career as a senator.

I have been informed that you are a very committed supporter of the Carlton Football Club. As someone who comes from the fair city of Sydney, I suspect it is probably because of last weekend's results that you are on your way overseas. But you of course have decided to conclude your political career. You have taken up what is a very important and senior position as Executive Director of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development in London.

I think, and I say this very genuinely to you, you will bring great experience to that position. You will bring expertise. You will bring knowledge. I am very confident you will do that very important office great credit, and I say to you very genuinely that I, as do all opposition senators, wish you and your family well for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to wish Jim and his wife all the best as they face a new career after a very successful parliamentary career that spanned some 17 years in both houses of parliament. You have had a wonderful career as far as a parliamentarian is concerned. You have seen it from both sides—from the staffing side, being in the ministerial offices, and then from the parliament side, being deputy leader of the Senate, having senior roles in the shadow ministry and then as Minister Assisting the Treasurer. You have seen it all and you have done a great job. There are always ups and downs in parliament and you hit a snake, but that is as it happens in parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Jim, I thought about a word that I could describe you as. I wrote down `involvement' and `contributor'. You contributed in every phase of your party, the parliament, the committee system. You were one of those guys who just rolled up his sleeves and got in and did it when required. I remember certain times when you used to come around and counsel me on my wayward economic rationalism and tried to point out the errors of my ways.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not succeed.
—No. Nevertheless, we did listen and shared some different views on things like sugar and a few other issues.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the National Party, I offer to you and your wife all best wishes as you go as Australia's representative to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. I know that you will do a good job because you are one of those people who has always done a good job in anything you have done. God bless you. We wish you all the best in a happy new career and we would like to see you when we are over in England, and no doubt we will see you in the Senate when you come back.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Jim Short, by any measure, has had a unique political career—in many ways a classic example of the vicissitudes of this business. I think it would be undignified to call Jim a political junkie, but he has been in and around politics for getting on for 40 years and you have to have a special affinity for the craft to be that dedicated or that masochistic.

SPEECH.PARA: Jim has been a classic example of what we all admire about politics: someone who really took the responsibilities very seriously and who was very conscientious in the performance of his duties. I thought that finance was his forte and, as the shadow minister for finance over those turbulent years in the early 1990s, he really did bring to bear all the experience and knowledge of economics that had, in many ways, always fitted him uniquely for that role. I have to say that one of the great disappointments of his career—as it was for all of us, I suppose—has to be that we did not get to government in 1993. As it was something for which I think he was peculiarly well fitted, it must be an additional disappointment.

The measure of the man is that he then went on to become an excellent shadow minister for immigration and ethnic affairs—I think a very daunting, tiring task and one that involves endless rounds of functions. Not only did Jim perform those duties with diligence; I think he actually enjoyed them. He certainly had the respect of those who attended the functions and we always got very positive feedback in the Victorian division. It always seemed to me that he was, again, very well qualified for that role. It shows the breadth of his character and personality that he could, on the one hand, be very interested in financial and economic issues and, on the other hand, have a very keen interest in social issues.

You probably deserve to be the patron saint of lost causes, Jim, if you thought you could teach Boswell anything about economics, but I must say that, again, it shows a generosity of spirit that others probably could not bring to bear. We would all like to educate him in various ways, but I would never take on that task.

Jim and I actually went through a few contests together and I have to confess that in a couple of preselections he finished well in front of me. He also served in the Victorian organisation as vice‐president around the time that I was president and I was always very struck with the way in which he approached the business. It was not just a matter of numbers or a matter of politics; it was really a matter of the issues and the common welfare. Jim has always had that aspect to his political career that I think we all find very admirable. I know Jan is very proud of him and so she should be. He can leave this parliament with his head held high because he should have the satisfaction of knowing that he has played a very significant role in Australian politics.

I am sad to see him leave. We even got to the point of being co‐tenants not so long ago. Now that he is moving on to a bigger and better house, he will probably enjoy himself greatly—and he has earned that reward. I am sure he will serve his country with distinction and I have no doubt he will be able to look back on a career that has brought us all great credit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to say farewell to another member of the class of 1984, I must admit that there were a few occasions during the period from 1993 to 1996 when I wished that Jim Short was actually moving then instead of waiting until now. I am referring, of course, in that time frame to when he was deputy to me on the Joint Standing Committee on Migration but also—and probably more importantly—to when he served as a member of Senate Estimates Committee E, which later became the Legal and Constitutional Committee, looking at matters associated with the Attorney‐General and the department of immigration. Jim certainly did put the officials through interminable questioning, going to the nth degree to get information—masses of information. I am not too sure what he ever did with it or whether it is of any use to the coalition now that they are in government. Nonetheless, there were many long hours spent in those committees gathering the information.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to the other committee—the migration committee—in retrospect, it turns out that it was a very good and productive committee for the parliament, which is a mark not only of the chair, who generally gets the credit for these things, but of the committee itself, particularly the work of the deputy chair. If you can get the chair and the deputy chair working in committees—that is a hint to your colleague sitting beside you, Senator Abetz—you can produce constructive and productive work to benefit not only the parliament but also, more importantly, the community of Australia.

My other immediate association with Jimmy Short was when again he served as deputy to me on a parliamentary delegation that went to Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos in the back end of 1993. Both of us on that occasion travelled separately to see some detention centres in South‐East Asia; detention centres which I am pleased to say have now closed and, hopefully, will never need to be opened again. Together, we—with the other members of the committee, including Senator Cooney—worked very hard to help Australia relieve itself of the problem created by people illegally entering this country. It was a contentious issue which was a very difficult issue for government to handle at the time. I think the committee, and the work of Senator Short as deputy on the committee, played a very constructive role in that. We did broaden ourselves and go beyond Australia to look at things.

I promised Jim when we were in a town called Siem Reap in Cambodia, not far from Angkor Wat, after we spotted an Australian flag, that I would put it in the memory bank and remind him about it on another day. I have chosen tonight to be magnanimous and not further develop the story about that flag. That is in appreciation, Jim, of your assistance over the years and of your friendship and comradeship and that of Jan over the years. My wife, Jackie, asked that her best regards to you be recorded as well.

In joining with my colleague Senator Faulkner, I want wish you and your family all the very best for the future. I want to remind you that you are going to Europe at a particularly exciting time. I am not referring to the fact that there will be quite a large delegation of members of this house and the other place going to Europe in July—subject to the sitting of the Senate. I hope good sense will prevail on that. It is also a very exciting time not only for the Green Tiger, which is off where you are going to be living, but also for Britain itself. I am referring, of course, to the great happenings there last week when the British people exercised their wisdom and elected a Labour government to Westminster. I think, Senator Short, you will be seeing many ties like mine. You will be seeing lots of red ties with the Socialist rose on them. It is a very important time for you personally and a very important time for the institution you are going to join and represent Australia on.

I join with your leader, my leader and all other senators in this place in wishing you and Jan and all the other members of your family all the very best for the future. It is sad to lose another member from the class of `84, but at least you are going on to something that is perhaps better than what you have here. Certainly, I think the hours are going to be a bit easier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, join in the remarks that are being made about our colleague Senator Short. I, unlike some of them, feel it is a great loss to the parliament that you are going. I think your capacity for hard work is legendary. My staff pulled out some statistics today which have not yet been tabled. In your time in this parliament you made 1,448 speeches and asked 639 questions of Labor ministers in the parliament—this excludes all the estimates, I might say, and all the committees. We just could not do that work. I think Senator Hill made the comment that your efforts were thoughtful and weighty, and someone who has worked that hard is always going to be missed.

SPEECH.PARA: You listed a number of things which you thought were important. I would list a number of others. I think your sense of decency and your standards are a fine example to this parliament. No-one on either side would dispute that. Another feature is your very high intelligence. I have mentioned the contributions you have made. I might say that with that intelligence of yours you have reached a philosophy which I profoundly agree with. I certainly would be on the Jim Short team rather than the Ronnie Boswell team. And you would understand that Ronnie.

I think you have an enormous capacity for friendship. The fact that there are so many in this chamber this evening is demonstration of that. I certainly have enjoyed your friendship over a long period. It is so long that I cannot even remember when and how we met. You might remember, but it has been a very long time. You have always been of assistance to me and most supportive, and that has been greatly appreciated.

What I would like to give some emphasis to—and it was touched on by Senator Hill—is that your interest in migrant groups has been very important to our party. Throughout the 1980s there were quite a number of migrant groups which were very unfashionable in this country. And, Jim, you were typically the only politician at so many of those functions. In more recent years you cannot get a seat at the top table. But you, Jim, were the politician there amongst groups that were often perceived by the wider community as being unfashionable. They remember that. I have been to a number of functions in recent years, on your behalf on occasions, and your name is always spoken with great fondness. They remember that when people did not take an interest Jim Short was there.

The other thing I would like to mention briefly is the fact that Jim has been, as I said, an enormous help to me. I think it would be appropriate to mention the names of the staff that you were able to pass to me—all of whom speak highly of you and all of whom have been of enormous assistance to me. I mention: Richard King, Alan Mallory, Virginia Lopilato, Roger Brake, Mark Sheen and Angela Ryan, whom I worked with in my first six months in this job. The respect with which you are held at Treasury is well known.

For all the reasons that I have mentioned you will be greatly missed. Jan is a personal friend and we wish her well. She has been a great support to you over the years. I think you will, of course, miss our beloved Carlton. I hope we will be able to keep you deluged with reports of Carlton victory. That is another interest we share. I know you have a special interest in Paris. One of the advantages in being there is perhaps the closeness to Paris. I join with all my colleagues in wishing you and Jan all the best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia can be justly proud of the person it is sending to be its director of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. It is personally a great pleasure to me, Jim, to see that you have got a reward, though it is even less than you deserve. Jim has been a most honourable man and may I turn around to the President's gallery and say, Jim, that you are married to a most honourable woman. Jan, it is good to see you here.

SPEECH.PARA: Jim, you have been through some torrid times recently. This can be a torrid place, and it does not always treat the people in here with all the fairness and justice that they deserve. Jan, you have been through some difficult times but now there is a good reward. Jim, you will be close to Michael and Sophie—I hope you get over there a lot—and of course Edith and Tom. We might even join you over there, as everybody else is expecting to do.

I agree with what everybody has said so far. Senator Kemp has talked about your work. Rod, I think that Jim has been active not only amongst the ethnic communities down there but also generally in Victoria. Jim, you have done the country proud, the state proud, the party proud and this place proud. I do not want to go on. There is a long list of people who will be speaking here tonight. Jim, I wish you all the best, and it has been a pleasure to have been in this Senate with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that, of all the people in this place, I am the one who could go on for a long time about Jim. I will not, and I am sure that will please Jim and the Senate. It is a great personal sadness and regret that tonight we are bidding farewell to my close friend and colleague Jim Short. I first met Jim over 20 years ago when he was a senior officer in Treasury responsible for foreign investment. I did not know him very well, but I viewed him with great suspicion because at that time he was studiously trying to implement a Whitlam policy which he must have thought was lunacy. If he did, I might say that he gave no inkling of it at the time, which reflected his professionalism and dedication as a departmental officer whose role was to implement government policy. Neither of us at that time would have imagined that 10 years later we would meet up as Liberal senators—Jim from Victoria and I from Queensland—and develop a close friendship which extended to our respective wives and families.

SPEECH.PARA: We were, as other senators have said, the group of 84. All of us ended up in the same corridor. There are lots of great stories about that, but I will not go into them. Maybe Senator Knowles will, but I will leave that to her; there is one story in particular.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will.
—Oh, oh!

—Senator Short says, `Oh, oh!' On the retirement of Senator Tony Messner from the Senate, Jim Short joined John Howard and myself in a unit in Kingston. Following the 1996 election, John Howard went up‐market and Jim and Jan purchased their own unit. One thing that I have never asked Jim and that I have never been able to find the answer to, and it has been a curiosity to me, is why he always spent three‐quarters of an hour every morning in the bathroom.
—Washing his hair—blow‐drying it.

—It was a complete mystery and still is. As is the way with politics, I have shared the roller‐coaster ride of good and bad times with Jim—and, I might say, John Howard. Your career in politics, Jim, could certainly not be described as boring. One thing that stands out was the role that Jim Short played in Fightback. He referred to that as one of the five major issues in his career. At that time he was shadow minister for finance, and he was responsible for the costing of the package. He and his staff put in the most incredible number of hours over many months on the meticulous work that was required, often extending into the early hours of the morning. I know because he used to wake me up when he banged the door coming in. He had a workload that few could have sustained. Even though the 1993 election was lost because of an outrageous fear campaign, it was a credit to Jim that the figures for which he was responsible stood up to extreme scrutiny. As those on the other side of the chamber would know very well, Jim, you would have gone through them with a fine toothcomb. It was an onerous responsibility, as a single error could have destroyed the credibility of the document. Those opposite could not find a single error.

SPEECH.PARA: Jim leaves to take up a three‐year posting with the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. In view of his past experi ence in Treasury—internationally and domestically, in AIDC and foreign investment—even though it was a lousy policy, Jim, that you were trying to implement, in business and subsequently in the parliament, I know of no person more qualified or experienced for this appointment.

Jim is a man of deep principles and strong convictions. His beliefs are based on the fundamental precept of, and I quote from one of his speeches, `greater freedom of economic choice, a smaller role for government in terms of spending and taxing and in regulating our commercial and other activities and the encouragement and strengthening of the family'. This was reflected in his maiden speech in the Senate in which he identified the principles that would guide him when he said that, as a Liberal, he believed passionately that it was people—through economic freedom of the competitive market—who had built our nation, not government.

Others have already given the details of Jim's distinguished career. To me he has been a true friend and a great gentleman. He leaves this place as we all will with the passage of time but he leaves it with his head held very high as a man of great integrity and principles who will be missed by the parliament, who will be a loss to the coalition, the nation, his home state of Victoria and his friends on both sides of the chamber. My wife, Kathi, and I will certainly miss the close relationship we have had with the Shorts over the past 10 years. I know that the break with parliament, particularly since we are in government, will be of great regret to Jim but I am sure that will be more than compensated for by his and Jan's ability to spend some time with their two grandchildren. I am envious, Jim. I wish you the best of luck in your new role.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be brief as I know that many more friends wish to speak. I say `friends' advisedly. Jim's departure is voluntary in the true sense. He resigned by his own choice on a matter of principle and he leaves this chamber with his head held high. The hypocrisy of politics almost ensures that the truth is told only on our departure.

SPEECH.PARA: Those of us who are your friends, Jim—and that is all of us—respect you for what and for who you are, an honest, honourable contributor to the public life of this nation. All of us wish you and Jan success in your next career and we look forward to your continuing contribution on behalf of the nation. Think back on us kindly, Jim, from afar, as we soldier on in this chamber enduring the frustrations that you bore so nobly. You have been lovingly supported by Jan, and I know we all thank her for her involvement in public life as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —Jim Short has enjoyed a very similar parliamentary career to myself in that he spent a period of time in the House of Representatives before being elected to the Senate where he has subsequently spent over a decade serving the people of Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, in chronological order, Jim was first elected to the House of Representatives in 1975 and served through to 1980. I was elected to the House of Representatives in 1980 and served a single term through to 1983. Jim was then elected to the Senate in 1984 and has served through to the present, whilst I was elected to the Senate in 1987. Jim's resignation to take on a special task for Australia in Europe should not be seen as setting any precedent for my own parliamentary career.

In the term I spent in private enterprise between losing the House of Representatives seat and being elected to the Senate, I learnt probably a lot more about politics and the voting behaviour of the electorate. I learnt it because I was a newsagent at that time and I discovered what the general community reads and why and everything else, and it changed my pattern. But I note from Jim's first Senate speech of March 1985 that he, too, learnt a number of salient lessons about the electorate in the interim, between his time in the House of Representatives and being elected to the Senate. He said:
Those four years spent in the private sector, away from active politics, have clearly brought home to me the fact that the electorate is very cynical about politics.
Jim went on:

Australians are desperately looking for leadership based on firm principles which they understand and which accord with long‐standing basic values of our society and the desire for growth, stability and security in an increasingly unstable world.

I know that Jim Short was honoured to play an active part in the formulation of coalition policies, aimed at delivering what he described as this `growth, stability and security'. Those of us still here will accept the challenge to be part of the team with the responsibility of implementing those policies and creating widespread change, particularly in the areas that Jim pioneered for us and gave us sound advice on, particularly that of financial administration and developing federalist policies.

Jim, I have somewhere in my documentation, as I am sure you do, a document that I remember you authored during the Hewson years in opposition relating to federal affairs. Perhaps we had both better keep those documents in a bottom drawer for a few more years, but I am sure that they were and are, and form part of, the strong legacy of many very important issues that you gave us and the challenges that you put before us.

I have always appreciated Jim Short's warm friendship, sound counsel and support for the Northern Territory's constitutional development issues; and our close working arrangements in parliamentary and political forums. I wish you, Jim and Jan, well for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to take this opportunity to join with my colleagues in offering warm congratulations to our friend and colleague, Jim Short, on his appointment as Director of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development in London. I wish him good health and happiness in the years ahead and thank him for his contribution to this place.

BREAK.PARA: Jim's expertise in the financial sphere is second to none and he has an outstanding record of accomplishments in this area. I know that the kinds of skills and knowledge that he possesses are highly sought after, and the contribution which he will be able to make in this new role will be quite invaluable.

It was because of his financial expertise that the Prime Minister, John Howard, appointed Jim Assistant Treasurer in his new government in March last year, and the seeds of the policies which have brought the outstanding achievements of its first year of office can be seen in the approach to government which Jim Short has consistently advocated. He has invariably contended that the real issue facing all sectors of industry, both large and small, is competitiveness, and that the underlying cause of the decline in our business sector in the 1980s and early 1990s was the result of losing our competitive advantage against rival nations.

In his bid to reverse the trend of Australia's decline from fourth to 20th per capita standard of living and from seventh to 23rd in export earnings over 30 years, Jim continually espoused the need for international competitiveness. The role of government, in pursuing this, he declared, was, among other things, to reduce the tax burden for business, to reduce the government's budget deficit and to reduce the size of government.

This is what he consistently fought for when the coalition was in opposition, particularly as chairman of the opposition's Industry, Commerce, Technology and Science Committee. And when the coalition won government in a landslide in 1996, it was this course of action which he pursued.

On being appointed Assistant Treasurer, Jim Short brought to his portfolio the expertise Australia desperately needed after 13 years of mismanagement under Labor governments. This expertise had been achieved over many years, as he applied a remarkable intellect and assiduous hard work, which others have referred to, to the most difficult and wide‐ranging issues in the Australian financial world.

In his early career in Treasury Senator Short rose very quickly to senior responsibilities. Between 1967 and 1970 he held the important position of Treasury representative in London. It is to London that he will be returning. It is London where he is still regarded in the greatest esteem for his competence and integrity, despite the passage of years. Between 1971 and 1975 he held two high level positions—Assistant Secretary in the Overseas Economic Relations Division and Assistant Secretary in the Foreign Investment Division of Treasury. From 1973 to 1974 he was Executive Secretary to the AIDC.

On entering federal parliament as the member for Ballarat, he immediately took up a position on the Joint Statutory Committee for Public Accounts, where I first met him. I have always appreciated his wisdom ever since that first meeting. He also became a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, a position he held for nearly four years.

Following his defeat in the election of 1980 he became General Manager, Corporate Affairs, of ACI International, a position which equipped him very suitably for service in the financial area of government.

During his time in the Senate he has held a number of key positions where his informed contributions, especially in finance, have been of great benefit. These include being spokesman on finance and Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. His outstanding ability to grasp the complexities of the economics scene has been an invaluable asset, not just to the government but to all Australians.

But Jim Short saw beyond the financial field. He saw the effects of financial management on the social structure of Australian society. In his maiden speech he highlighted the link between our taxation system and unemployment and poverty. He said:

A primary aim of social policy must surely be to enable people to provide for themselves by their own efforts. We can make social progress in Australia only through economic discipline based on sound economic principles.

Tax reform should aim for equity, neutrality and simplicity, but within these parameters its overall objective must be to encourage the creation of income and wealth in an entrepreneurial environment in which effort is rewarded and economic growth and job creation encouraged.

He has also taken a keen interest in the people at the small end of town—the small businesses which have been over‐burdened with government regulation and crippled by industrial rigidity. It was Jim Short who in this chamber raised the matter of Dollar Sweets being strangled by union action when Telecom workers refused to restore their telephone service which had been cut off through union vandalism. Shortly afterwards those services were restored.

He pointed out in opening a debate on industry and business in 1985 that `we must create an environment in which all Australians are encouraged to dare to strive to achieve—as a nation there is no alternative.' I am sure it is very satisfying to Jim to see the gains made over the last year in reducing Australia's budget deficit, the reduction in the size of the government and the improved industrial relations regime.

Senator Short has consistently promoted privatisation as being an encouragement to greater competition. He saw that it was the only way of using the nation's assets efficiently. Through privatisation the government could fulfil its commitment to reducing the tax burden, reducing the deficit and reducing the size of government. It would have been very pleasing for them, therefore, I know, to see the legislation passed last year enabling part of Telstra to be privatised. The contribution he has made as a member of parliament over the last two decades will be remembered and valued for many years to come.

As Jim takes up his position, I wish to extend my very best wishes not only to him but to his wife, Jan, who is in the gallery tonight. I am confident that this new era in their lives will be exciting, challenging and rewarding. I thank you for a job well done.
Thursday, 8 May 1997

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —I first met Senator Short—don't look so worried; it will be okay—when we were both elected in 1984. I was left in no doubt at that time that I then had the pleasure of meeting a truly nice bloke. I have not changed my impression since. You have done nothing but enhance that first impression that I had. So to be saying goodbye to you, Jim, is to be closing the book on a chapter of our lives that has in the main been highlighted by good times. The exceptions to those good times, I would hasten to add, have been the elections we have lost and when you resigned from the ministry last year.

SPEECH.PARA: You and Jan really do deserve a wonderful time in London while you go about doing a job for which you are eminently qualified. The circumstance of your departure from the ministry is still a great source of sadness for me, as it no doubt is to you. I, like you, have sat here for 12 years of opposition and seen the conduct of ministers, the number of times they were censured and the number of times they have misled the Senate, yet they survived.

You at least had the dignity, through no illegality but a sheer oversight, to resign. That, to me, is a credit to you, and the mark of the man that you took that course, even if I was not the greatest advocate of you taking that course. That is the honourable way in which you have operated throughout your entire life. That is the honourable way in which you have conducted yourself in this chamber. But I still have a feeling—and you must as well—that you have been somewhat cheated from having a great ministerial career.

Apart from your obvious sheer intellect and great ability, I am left with those great memories of our times with the rest of the class of `84 in the corridor of the old Parliament House. I remember the night we somehow celebrated your 50th birthday one year early—what is more, we did not know about it until about four years later—and the same night when I frogmarched you into the Senate chamber while you were wearing your birthday present, not your birthday suit, which was a pair of spurs. To this very point, I do not know why we gave you a pair of spurs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't know either!

—Senator Parer is saying that he does not know either. If I live to be 150, I will never forget the look on Alan Platt's face—Alan was the then chief chamber attendant—when you walked in with me close behind you and you were rattling your spurs because they had been strung on with string. I still do not understand how that happened.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember the times that you helped me with the experience that you gained over your years in the House of Representatives before you came here and the great times that we had selling Fightback. You and John Hewson were the main engineers of that. I suppose it was a great time but in another way it is a sad time because today the people of Australia realise that that was a very sensible, correct policy for Australia to take.

The 18 months or so when I was your junior shadow minister for multicultural affairs was a great time for me because of your wonderful experience and the rapport that you had with the ethnic communities; the celebration of your elevation to the ministry; the pleasure of trying to keep the lid on your exuberance in the chamber, since you have been seated between Senator Patterson and me; and the great times that I have had the pleasure of sharing the company of both you and Jan.

Needless to say, Jim, I was aghast when you told me that you would be resigning. I suppose at first one invariably thinks of what the Senate would be like without you, instead of rejoicing in your new career and your new opportunities. Thankfully, we have had so many great times, both with work and socially, that they are the things I will remember most about you.

Jan, you have been a martyr to the cause in your support of Jim in his job and of the Liberal Party. We thank you for that, because it has not been easy. The many hours, days, weeks and months that you have spent alone while Jim has been serving the Liberal Party and the parliament is something for which we are very grateful, and I know Jim is too.
Before concluding, I would like to pass on to you the very best wishes of Sue Oldham in my office. As you know, she has the utmost admiration for you.

TALK.START.PARA: —She is in the gallery.

—Goodness gracious me, I did not recognise her. Sue wished me to extend her best wishes to you. I trust that you and Jan will be able to see much more of your grandchildren in France and thoroughly enjoy the entire new chapter of your lives that is just beginning. Good luck to you both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth, Sen Judith

TALK.START.PARA: —As a fellow Victorian senator, I would like to pay tribute to the work that you have contributed to this parliament and to your role in the wider world. You certainly brought the knowledge of many worlds to this parliament when you came here in 1975. Not least, as the member for Ballarat and from your birthplace in Shepparton you brought an understanding of rural Victoria. That is something that is very important for every member of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: You were unfortunate enough to leave your House of Representatives seat in 1980 and it was four years before you were elected to the Senate. Between those years your interest and enthusiasm for the Liberal Party did not flag. You were a country vice‐president in 1982, a member of our administrative committee, a chair of the party development committee, and you have always been a very enthusiastic member of our federal strategy committee from 1985 onwards. You and I have played a role on that together.

When I looked at your first speech, there were probably two or three strands running through it which you exhibited at the time and which you have continued to exhibit in the rest of your parliamentary life. The themes that you stressed then and have carried on are the necessity for economic growth of our nation and the necessity for tax reform, which also encourages the creation of income and wealth.

I noticed when reading your first speech that you foreshadowed many of the successful industrial relations reforms which we have implemented since we have come to government. I know that they were very important to you. Last but not least you stressed the importance of the private sector in any economy. That is something that you have always emphasised. You also mentioned youth unemployment, which unfortunately is still with us today, and, true to the Christian values that I know you hold, a promotion of the basic values that everyone should feel in their life.

As both Senator Kemp and Senator Hill have mentioned, your later roles as shadow minister for multicultural Australia, immigration, ethnic and citizenship affairs, and later on immigration and ethnic affairs were particularly successful ones. The amount of work which you have done in Victoria and Australia wide with these groups is simply phenomenal. Like Senator Kemp, I want you to know that every group that we visit on your behalf speaks well of you. During the last few weeks when I have represented you and Minister Ruddock with ethnic affairs groups, every one of them wished to pass on their very best wishes. They all spoke extremely well of you.

I was fortunate enough to be in third position on the Senate ticket when you were positioned first in 1993. I would like to thank you very much for the education process you put me through during the 1993 campaign and in our subsequent work in the Senate. You have always been renowned for your hard work, Jim, whether it is in an area of policy development for which you have worked or the other areas that I have mentioned, not to mention the very long list of committee work which takes up much of the entry in the parliamentary handbook.

I would also like to mention Jan. Jan, you have not only been a most supportive partner for Jim; you have also had a career of your own. That is not easy when your partner is in parliament and you need to support him. You also have a renowned reputation in community and other groups in Victoria. You will be sadly missed as well as Jim.

I sincerely wish you all the best for your sojourn in London. We look forward to seeing you when you return from the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development in London. I sincerely hope that you do reconstruct and develop but, given your parlia mentary reputation, I feel sure that will happen. All the best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I was preselected by the Liberal Party in Victoria for the No. 2 spot on the Senate ticket, I hit a small snake when the double dissolution was called: I slipped from No. 2 to No. 5 on the Senate ticket. After the election in 1987, I learnt the reality of a week being a long time in politics. The only thing was that it was five weeks in politics. That was an awfully long time in politics.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a long count for that Senate spot. Mr Halfpenny, whom we do not hear much of these days, had his bags packed to come to Canberra. I thought he might be coming to Canberra because all the press said that. I have to say that every single night of those five weeks Jim Short was on the telephone to me, reporting to me the count and how he thought I was faring. He was very hopeful and I, most probably, was not as hopeful.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was a good counter.

—He was a good counter. I felt great gratitude that Jim understood the tension and the anxiety I felt and did everything he could to allay that. I was glad on the night I celebrated my election that Jim and Jan were able to be there and share that with me. I very much appreciate that care he showed. I know, now that I am in the job, that it was not easy to make sure you phoned every night and told me exactly what was going on. I appreciated that very much, Jim. I never forgot that.

SPEECH.PARA: Everyone has said very nice things about you tonight. We really ought to be very honest when we come to these times. I have to say that a couple of times your small problem with the clock would make me almost become agitated, especially when we were campaigning and I would get up at some ungodly hour to get to your house at 7 a.m. and you were not ready.

Tonight I have discovered why: because he spent three‐quarters of an hour in the bathroom. I do not know why he might have spent three-quarters of an hour in the bathroom, but I know the outcome of spending three-quarters of an hour in the bathroom. I am sure he has got better with time, but just that attention to the clock was probably his greatest failing. If that is the only failing you have, then it is very minor.

Jim, I have never in the time I have been here heard you speak ill of anyone. People gossip around these corridors and they chatter. That is not your style. I think that is why there are so many people here tonight. You are held in very high regard by all your colleagues. Somebody said to me once when I came here, `You might be a nice person now, but you will not be as nice a person when you leave.' I am sure when you came here you were a person of honour and integrity. Unlike some who are tarnished by the time here, I do not think one can say that about you. You have not been tarnished.

I noticed while sitting in the chair tonight that nearly every person mentioned the words `honour', `honourable' or `integrity'. If you had to choose words to describe you, I think they would be the words. I think people say that about very few politicians when they leave. I think it is a great credit to you that during that time you have shown honour, integrity, great loyalty and friendship.

The big ladder you hit to go to this new job also meant that I had a small ladder because I was then able to go to the United Nations. So in some ways, your gain was my gain as well. I know that you are going to do a wonderful job there. I know you will have an opportunity to see more of your son, his wife and their children. That will be tremendous for you and Jan.

I also want to thank both of you for your hospitality. From time to time on the way home from the airport a quick drink has been an enormous comfort to me. I would also like to thank Jan for some of the long chats we have had about issues. I know it has not been easy. As some people have said, it is never easy for anybody's spouse or family who tolerate us being in parliament to be separated as long as they are. I know that that has not always been easy.

To Jan, we say thank you very much for the contribution you have made in your own career but also the contribution you have made in sharing the work with Jim. I know the ethnic communities have appreciated your attendance with Jim at various functions. Senator Troeth, Senator Kemp, Senator Alston and I have been to functions and know the high regard in which Jim is held. I think the fact that so many of them have wanted to farewell him in their own groups speaks volumes for his contribution.
I wish you well in the future, Jim. I am sure you have set a very high standard for all of us. I congratulate you on the contribution you have made to this parliament, to the party and to Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Due to the number of speakers, I will keep my comments brief. During my relatively short time as an opposition senator, I learnt a great deal working with Jim Short on various migration bills in numerous estimates hearings conducted by the Senate's legal and constitutional committee. More particularly, in the election of 1996, I saw Jim, as the shadow minister for immigration, in Western Australia working very hard. I witnessed him to have a rapport with a wide range of ethnic groups, particularly with the Vietnamese.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a mark of the man that his expertise and interest can range from such things as economics to immigration and ethnic affairs. Jim, you leave the Senate having spent some 18 years in all as an elected representative in the federal parliament of Australia. Those 18 years span some three decades. You have set a high standard of parliamentary behaviour and integrity. It is, as others say, somewhat sad that you will not be enjoying more the fruits of government.

You have served your party, your state and your country with unswerving commitment. I am sure you will do the same with respect to the European bank. I wish you and your wife, Jan, every success and happiness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —Being the 18th person to say farewell to Jim tonight, I do not have to say all those words everybody else has said. The superlatives that have been used are most fitting. I was wondering whether anybody was going to use the term that Jill and I know him as and have always known him as—Gentleman Jim. No-one has used that term yet. I think Gentleman Jim sums Jim up. He is one of nature's gentlemen in every way.

SPEECH.PARA: Since I was first elected to this place in 1987, I have always classed him and Jan as friends. Whilst we have heard all about your hard work, tenacity and dedication to the job tonight, I like to think of the happier moments. I was sitting in Westminster Abbey with my wife one day and I looked across the nave and there was Jim. We went and enjoyed a pint at the Sherlock Holmes afterwards. He escorted us down to the Three Pigeons one evening. I look back on that with happy memories.

Much has been said tonight about the committees you have worked on and your efforts in immigration and finance, and whatever, and I too remember and pay credit to all those. Might I say that nothing has been said about your ability at tennis, and I hope that some of us will be gathering tomorrow morning to play a game of tennis and show you that we will not forget your ability on the court.

I know that there are many people here tonight and people who are not here tonight who would want to wish you well—people such as Roger Shipton, Michael Baume and David Brownhill. I was thinking, when Barney Cooney was talking tonight, that one committee that has not been spoken of tonight is the animal welfare committee and the terrific contribution you made when you were an honorary member of it back in 1991. We had the opportunity of visiting the Melbourne Cup on very important business for the day, and the contribution you made on that day will certainly live in my memory, as will the hat you wore. And I am sure that Jan will remember the condition that we returned you home in, late that evening—and that also reinforces the remarks which have been made about the great patience of your wife.

Jim, you meet a lot of people in this place, but I think one thing you can say is that everybody in it is a friend of yours and will remain so. I hope that you are available on Tuesday the 8th to receive a delegation of people who will be visiting London.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —At this hour I will keep it very, very brief. Jim, you and I first met when you were with ACI in the early 1980s. We met through a common philosophy, and a common interest in economic management—and we have shared that ever since, and I was delighted to come and join you here in the Senate about four years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not go over all the details. Your career here has been characterised by everyone as being very professional and having great integrity. You have made a great contribution to Australia. I wish you and Jan well. I know you will succeed very well in your career with the bank in London, and I wish you well there. I look forward to seeing you there and when you visit us back in Australia in the near future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the hour is late, I too would like to join in paying a short tribute to Jim, and also to Jan who is present in the gallery. Jim, I am just going to touch on a few words that you said tonight—things which I think are very important to the Australian community—and the changes that have occurred over the last 10 or 15 years.

SPEECH.PARA: The first one is Dollar Sweets, which some of us know a little bit about. I think that was one of the bastion landmark cases that changed the course of Australia. Your part in and contribution to that will always, I believe, be recognised as very, very significant in what has happened, as I said, over the last 15 years.

You mentioned the term `economic dries and rationalists'. I well remember at that particular time people trying to denigrate what was being done and others being thumped around and branded with such names as the New Right, et cetera. I think now that time has proven that it was economic commonsense. I pay tribute to you for your contribution to that economic commonsense and reform, which was really about providing a larger cake for all Australians to enjoy. Of course, as time goes by, that becomes very evident. Your principles as far as economic fundamentals are concerned I think are well understood and have been adopted not by all but virtually by most sides of politics in Australia today.

I would touch just briefly on the industrial reform arena, in which you also played a significant part. Your philosophy was to create higher productivity so that there was an opportunity for all Australians to enjoy in increased wealth and more job opportunities. That also has stood the test of time. Others have mentioned a range of matters, from ethnic affairs with your contribution on committees, and what have you, which I will not go over other than to acknowledge them and congratulate you on them.

Finally, I also pay tribute to your wife and her contribution to your long career in politics. However, I just say to you: I think it's 7 o'clock in the morning for tennis with a number of us; don't be late for breakfast, and we'll enjoy a good game. Thank you very much, Jim. I have enjoyed your company, your counsel and working with you since 1990 in this parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman, Sen Grant

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join these tributes that have been rendered this evening to my retiring colleague Jim Short. Jim and I were elected together in the House of Representatives on 13 December 1975. Subsequent to that, we both served in both of the chambers of this parliament—both for approximately 17½ years. Our careers in parliament do not exactly overlap. I think Jim had from 1975 to 1980 in the Reps, about five years, whereas I was there until 1983. But Jim has been in the Senate since late 1984, whereas in my case I have been here since mid‐1987.
