So I guess, quite clearly, Jim can claim to be more senatorial than I am—and that was certainly reflected in his remarks in his speech tonight. I also recall that, at one stage during our time together in the Reps, he claimed me as a protege. I am not quite sure whether he would still want to make that claim.

SPEECH.PARA: But along with that other recently departed Senate colleague Michael Baume, who also commenced his parliamentary career in 1975, Jim and I were amongst that group of new members who delighted in the epithet `oncers' that was hurled at us across the chamber by the then Labor opposition in the first term of the Fraser coalition government. Virtually all of those so-called oncers survived to become twicers—and that was Jim's achievement—and some of us to be thricers.

The seventy-fivers were indeed a close‐knit group, and their extracurricular activities contributed a lot to the morale of the then Fraser coalition government. To this day, they have maintained an annual dinner get‐together, and over the years three groups of those oncers have emerged—the survivors, those who have continuously served in this Parliament to the present day; the resurrected, those who for one reason or another were defeated in their seats and returned either to other lower house seats or as senators; and, indeed, the departed, those who were defeated not to return or, in more recent years, those who retired voluntarily.

Jim has always played a very prominent part in those get‐togethers, and our departed colleagues who have returned either regularly or intermittently to those get‐together dinners have always been eager to catch up with Jim and share some time with him. And I am sure that the departed will welcome his second coming to their numbers—this time, it occurring voluntarily.

Jim was a significant backbench member in the House of Representatives and, as Winston Crane mentioned a few moments ago, he was a leading advocate of the importance of economic rectitude and the benefits of a market economy and less interventionist government—the so-called dry philosophy, to which Jim referred in his own remarks. Of course, that was not as fashionable a philosophy at that time as it has become in more recent years, and certainly Jim's advocacy during that period was very important in the Liberal Party becoming more committed to that philosophy in the 1980s and the 1990s.

Jim suffered defeat at the 1980 election in his House of Representatives seat of Ballarat, but he showed the courage and the persistence to return to this place as a senator. In the context of the overall numbers of people who serve in this place, in the history of this parliament there are not all that many members who, once defeated, actually return.

It was in the Senate that Jim's career really blossomed. Most of his period as a senator has been spent on the front bench, either in economic or migration related portfolios. I guess the highlight of his career here was, firstly, his period as Deputy Leader of the Opposition and, more recently, as Assistant Treasurer. He certainly did not deserve the fate that befell him recently as a minister in a portfolio.

The combination of his parliamentary experience and background in Treasury certainly equips him brilliantly for his new career as Australia's representative director on the board of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. I have valued Jim's wise counsel and advice over the years we have served together in both chambers of this parliament but, above all, I have valued his friendship—although, I have to say, that friendship was strained on that AFL finals day in 1993 at Waverley when together we watched Carlton just pip the Adelaide Crows for the direct route to the grand final.

My wife, Sally, has also valued her friendship with Jan over the years that Jim and I have served together in the parliament. I am sure she joins me in wishing them both well as they meet new challenges.

I conclude by saying that, with Baume in New York and Short in London, the oncers are certainly well placed on the international stage. I am sure I speak for all oncers—survivors, resurrected and departed—in wishing Jim and Jan a happy respite from politics, and great success and enjoyment in London. I am sure that we all wish that occasionally you will be able to return to Australia in November to attend the oncers dinner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Jim, to you and Jan, my best wishes for the future. Lesley particularly wanted to be associated with the good wishes. She had only a relatively short association with Jan, but it was one that she treasured. She greatly admired Jan and wanted that to be said.

SPEECH.PARA: Jim, I concur with all the fine things that have been said. You will be remembered for many things but most of all your integrity. Good luck. See you in London.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the spouse of a oncer—and a spouse who shared good times with Jan, who is another spouse—and then having the pleasure of being a colleague of my husband's colleague when I came to the Senate and found Jim already here, it would be remiss of me if I did not say, on behalf of the Newman family, thank you to Jim for his service to our nation. He is a fine man. He is a man of integrity. We shall miss him very much. We will miss them both. Jan is the most loyal and passionate supporter of her husband, and I think she is a great example to any of us who know what it is like to serve the nation. I have seen it from both sides, as a spouse and as a participant, and I know how difficult both roles are.

SPEECH.PARA: The Shorts have been a great team and they go on to be a great team, I am sure, for Australia in London. I have now discovered, however, one of the qualities that will make Jim into a fine banker—not just his economic ability but his interest in the clock, or lack of it. I understand bankers, particularly European bankers, keep very special hours. Good luck.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short has tonight given the Senate a great and gracious speech, as is befitting a great and gracious man. Jim, it is with great sadness we are all here tonight to watch you leave. I want to thank you on two accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I want to thank you on behalf of thousands of people who cannot be here. They are particularly the Chinese dissidents who were left stranded here as a result of Tiananmen Square. I want to put on record that your contribution in achieving and easing a bipartisan acceptance of their place in our community will not go unnoticed. There are many thousands of people whose lives you have changed through the work that you quietly achieved in 1993. I am here to bear testimony to what you did and thank you on their behalf. You were truly great in what you did.

Secondly, I want to give you my thanks because when I arrived here as a young 24-year-old you were one of the people who actively encouraged me to get involved in the economic debate, to get involved in the life of the chamber, to get involved in the work of the committees. For that I thank you very much because it made me feel like I was somebody who could make a difference. Jim, you have had a great influence on me.

Can I say in conclusion that I know you are going to the European Bank for Economic Reconstruction and Development. I might note in Senator Boswell's defence that, having had the opportunity to observe Russia's unbridled economics, Jim might be coming back in a couple of months time to ask Senator Boswell some advice on a few matters of government regulation of the economy. Good luck, Jim.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to say that I have very much appreciated the time that I have spent in this parliament with Jim Short. I remember exactly where I was, as I guess everyone else remembers where they were—I remember because of the shock that hit me—on the morning that I heard the announcement that Jim had resigned from the frontbench of the Howard government after such a short time. I was going for a walk at Scarborough Beach with young Edward, and it was late spring. I was in shock, Jim, as I said to you at the time by way of a letter.

SPEECH.PARA: I had very privately—because I had never said this to Jim or probably anyone else—as a young senator coming into this place, virtually the same week as Senator O'Chee, as I recall, having met Jim on the tennis court on the first freezing cold morning I was here, found very quickly that Jim was an inspiration to me. I think that is probably the best thanks that a younger senator can give to an older senator.

He did inspire me for a couple of reasons, and I will not take too much time. The first reason was his work ethic in this place. We are elected to this place to work very hard. As Jim said in his own speech, it is a great honour and privilege to be elected to serve in the Australian parliament. Hundreds and thousands of people try over the years to get here and very few do. So, when you get here, it is a great honour and privilege, and you are expected to and should work extremely hard in your chosen fields. In all of the portfolio areas and policy areas that Jim has had responsibility for throughout his distinguished career, he has shown that work ethic. He has always gone the extra yard in terms of putting the extra work in and, because of his intellect and his commitment, that has borne fruit for Australia.

The other reason why Jim has been an inspiration to me is that he came to this place, if you read his maiden speech, with a very clear policy framework, a very clear philosophical framework and a commitment to an ideology, principles and a philosophy which he has brought and carried through his entire career. Many people come here with fine ideals and a strong sense of philosophy and principles and see them whittled away. Jim has stuck by those and it is a philosophy that he and I share.

It is a philosophy that supports economic freedom and believes that economic freedom helps to create political freedom in other parts of world. But, most importantly at home, a commitment to smaller government, lower taxes, less state intervention and less regula tion of the private sector to ensure that individuals can maximise their own place in this society and therefore help the whole society is a commitment that we share. It was an unpopular commitment through much of the 1980s. But we did, Jim, as you say, win the battle of ideas not only here in Australia but around the globe.

Indeed, Senator McKiernan refers to the victory of the Blair New Labour Party in Great Britain. He did not tell the Senate of course that in the United Kingdom and the United States in recent elections both of the parties of the centre left there have had to dump their traditional tax and spend policies, their `big government, big intervention' policies. The Clinton administration and the Blair New Labour government have had to dump those policies and effectively adopt policies that could broadly be termed as economically rational. That was a prerequisite to Mr Blair getting elected and that is support for the philosophies in a way that you have supported all your career.

Jim, I earnestly say that you have provided inspiration. You said to me when you announced your resignation that we must keep the faith, keep the torch blowing and stick to our guns on these important principles, philosophies and ideologies. I can give you a commitment that I will. I do not need to say that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) will. We will be here, we will be fighting, we will be thinking of you in London and we will miss you at tennis in the mornings and in the chamber during the days, but we do look forward to seeing you again. Thank you for everything you have done for me.

BREAK.PARA: May I conclude by saying that I did not know Jan very well. But, Jan, I can say that my wife, Brenda, never used to enjoy the parliamentary spouses association. She used to shun it and she did not enjoy going along. But, since you have taken over, she has taken a big interest. So it must be a remarkable achievement by you. So best wishes to you as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Goodbye and good luck to Senator the Hon. Jim Short.

Employment, Education and Training Act—National Board of Employment, Education and Training—Higher Education Council—Report—A review of institutional use of Commonwealth higher education funding for Indigenous Australian students, March 1997.

Currency Act—Currency Determination No. 2 of 1997.
The following document was tabled pursuant to the order of the Senate of 30 May 1996.

Public Service and Merit Protection Commission
The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the announcement made by the Minister on 19 June 1996 that the cut to funding in SkillShare would be reduced from 33 per cent to 20 per cent through the exemption of the Job Clubs provided by some SkillShares:
(1) How much of this money has now been allocated.
(2) To which SkillShares has it been allocated.
(3) In which federal electorates are those SkillShares located.
(4) What is the current unemployment rate in each of the areas in which those SkillShares are located.
(5) On what basis was the money allocated to these particular SkillShares and not to others.
(6) Was the level of unemployment in the local area considered in the decision to allocate these funds; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: It is presumed that in the introductory paragraph of the honourable's Senator's question, he means "extension" of Job Clubs rather than "exemption".
(1) During the period July to September 1996 a total of $4.8million under the Job Clubs programme was allocated to SkillShare projects to conduct Jobsearch Assistance Activities (JAA).

(2), (3) and (4) The attached tables list by Departmental Areas the SkillShare projects that received JAA funds, the funding each project received, the federal electorate in which the projects are located and the unemployment rate for the Departmental Region in which the project is located. The unemployment rates provided are from the DEETYA publication "Small Area Labour Markets', June Quarter 1996.

While the name of the federal electorate in which each SkillShare project is located has been provided, it is possible that some of the other JAA funding allocated to these projects would be spent assisting clients living in other electorates.
(5) JAA funding was offered to every SkillShare sponsor on the basis of reducing the 33 per cent funding cut to 20 per cent.
(6) No. See the answer to Question 5.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 4 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the department aware that, on occasion, spoilt franking machine impressions have been converted to cash rather than recredited to the franking machine.
(2) Is there any provision in the department's guidelines allowing franking machine impressions to be converted to cash.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) No. Australia Post has advised that it amended its Accounting Instructions in 1996 to eliminate access by Parliamentarians to cash refunds for franking machine spoilt impressions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 4 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the department receive a request to check an incoming flight into Brisbane in approximately April or May 1995 in order to establish whether airline bookings were being abused.
(2) Is it a fact that the department had insufficient staff to investigate this potential abuse.
(3) Did it later come to the attention of the department that a mileage claim was potentially fraudulent because of an airline booking made for the same time.
(4) Did an officer from the department bring it to the attention of the person's employer. Senator Colston.
(5) Did Senator Colston immediately write out a cheque to cover the amount; if so, how much was eventually repaid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services had provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No
(2) No
(3) No
(4) No
(5) No

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 4 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: How much travel allowance was claimed by Douglas Colston, an employee of Senator Colston, in the years 1992, 1993, 1994, 1995, 1996 and up to and including 3 March 1997.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

BREAK.PARA: My Department's records are maintained on a financial year rather than a calendar year basis and indicate that the following travelling allowance payments were made to Mr Douglas Colston:
* Claims paid to 6 March 1997.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 4 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: How much overtime was claimed by Douglas Colston, an employee of Senator
Colston, in the years 1992, 1993, 1994, 1995, 1996 and up to and including 3 March

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: My Department's records are maintained on a financial year rather than a calendar year basis and indicate that the following overtime payments were made to Mr Douglas Colston:
* Payments made to 6 March 1997.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 4 March 1997

QUESTION.PARA: Given that Senator Colston has stated on the public record that his son Douglas was overseas when his 1995 exam results came in, can the department advise whether Douglas Colston took official leave when he travelled overseas or did he remain on the payroll.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: According to my Department's records, Mr Douglas Colston was on approved leave from 19 June to 21 July in 1995. The Department has no record of when Mr Colston's examination results were notified nor when, if he did so, he travelled overseas.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 4 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are senators entitled to ban staff from claiming overtime.
(2) What rights do staff have in such circumstances.
(3) Is a senator entitled to direct that only members of the senator's family are entitled to submit claims for overtime.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)(2)(3) Overtime may be paid to electorate staff for duty performed outside normal hours of work. It must be approved by the Senator or Member or a person so authorised by the Senator or Member. Overtime should only be authorised to meet unavoidable workloads which cannot reasonably be met in standard hours.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Senator Colston: Use of Official Car

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 4 March 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What entitlements to a Commonwealth car in Queensland does Senator Colston have in his capacity as Deputy President.
(2) Is use restricted to trips to and from the airport and for official functions only.
(3) Has the department been informed as to what official functions have been taking place at the residence of the Member for Greenslopes (Mr Radke).
(4) Has the department been informed as to what official functions have been taking place at an undisclosed address in Beenleigh.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In accordance with Clause 3 of Remuneration Tribunal Determination 22 of 1995, Clause l(l)(d) of Part 2, Schedule 1, Parliamentary Entitlements Act 1990, and guidelines issued in 1993 by the former Government, Senator Colston, in his capacity as Deputy President of the Senate, is entitled to the use of official cars in Queensland for the following purposes when travelling on Parliamentary business, but excluding party business:
• for direct travel between home, electorate office or place of employment and the nearest airport or railway station;
• when travelling in the course of official Parliamentary committee business; and
• when travelling on official duty connected with the office of Deputy President of the Senate.

(2) No. Senator Colston is also entitled to use official cars to travel on official business in Queensland, such as when he has a requirement to attend formal functions or on other occasions when a car with driver service is appropriate in the circumstances.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 4 March l 997

QUESTION.PARA: Have there been any instances of payouts to any of Senator Colston's former staff; if so: (a) on how many occasions; and (b) what was the value of each payout.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: This answer is based on supplementary advice provided by the Senator that his question applies to separation moneys, termination payments, unfair dismissal payments and COMCARE from 1990. For the purpose of this question separation payments include payments in lieu of recreation leave, leave bonus and long service leave payments when applicable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 4 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the department's attention been drawn to the fact that a Queensland Senator may have flown to Perth, remained in the airport lounge and then returned.
(2) (a) Did such a flight occur at Commonwealth expense; and (b) how many frequent flyer points would accrue on such a journey.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) (a) More information about the Senator concerned and the date of the flight is required before the Department could confirm whether such a flight occurred at Government expense.
(2) (b) The number of frequent flyer points which would accrue on any return flight to Perth would depend on the departure point, the class at which the travel was undertaken and the airline used.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 4 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Senator Colston have a DASFLEET car charged to his charter allowance in the period March/April/May 1996.
(2) Did a staff member drive this car exclusively for three and a half weeks.
(3) Would such use contravene the guidelines issued by the department in relation to the use of senators' charter allowance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) This is not known to the Department.
(3) Remuneration Tribunal Determination 22 of 1995 provides an allowance for use of charter transport, including self-drive vehicles. Clause 6.1 of Determination 22 specifies that:

"This entitlement does not extend. . . to the use by any other person other than the senator or member except when another senator or member or the spouse or member of the staff of the senator or member is accompanying the senator or member."

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 5 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it appropriate for senators to direct members of their staff to act as secretaries of family trusts and companies.
(2) Is the Minister aware that a Queensland senator so directed his staff.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Staff of both Senators and Members of the House of Representatives are employed for the purpose of assisting that Senator or Member in carrying out their duties as a member of Parliament.

It would be expected that staff of a Senator or Member would not be directed to undertake any form of activity that would be detrimental to the performance of that role or, if undertaken by the Senator or Member themselves. would represent a conflict of interest for that Senator or Member.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the answer to a question without notice from the Member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) on 27 February 1997 (House of Representatives Hansard, p.1410) in which the Minister stated that the Board of the Australian Defence Industries (ADI) had advised the Government that it was now in a position where privatisation of the ADI could be a viable option:
(1) Does the Government concede that the sale of the ADI would constitute another broken election promise.

(2) Can details of the following matters be provided: (a) the measures the ADI Board is using to indicate its improved operating performance; (b) which company or companies are showing the reported `considerable interest' in the purchase of ADI and whether they are Australian companies; (c) what the privatisation of the ADI might be worth to the Government; and (d) whether the figure takes into consideration the amount the Government would have to make to clear the remaining debt from the corporatisation of the ADI.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) (a) ADI's performance is measured in the same way as any other public company, and is based on a range of financial indicators such as total revenue (sales), earnings before tax and abnormals, earnings after tax and abnormals, earnings per share (EPS), dividends per share (DPS), return on net assets and shareholder value.
(b) It would be inappropriate for me to comment on who may have an interest in buying the Company.
(c) This information is commercial‐in‐confidence.
(d) This information is commercial‐in‐confidence.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 13 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 345 (Senate Hansard, 4 February 1997, p.76):
(1) Can the Australian Heritage Commission (AHC) advise if any other speakers were invited by the AHC to the conference, whose travel costs were not met; if so, who and what were their backgrounds.

(2) With reference to Mr Cadman's published works: was the contribution by Mr Cadman in Forgotten Wilderness: North West Tasmania in fact on botany, and not biology as previously stated in answer to question on notice (Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee, Additional Information Received, Volume 2, November 1996, p.243) and repeated in the answer to question on notice no. 345.

(3) With reference to Mr Cadman's employment: (a) can the Commission provide the dates when Mr Cadman was employed as secretariat support research officer, including part‐time and full-time dates in this role; (b) between what dates was Mr Cadman, as Cadman and Norwood, employed as a consultant; (c) was one purpose of Mr Cadman's consultancy to consider places that were the subject of nominations to the Register of the National Estate; (d) was another purpose of the consultancy to make recommendations on whether each place was of National Estate significance; (e) if Mr Cadman's consultancy was `to make recommendations', why then was it necessary for commission staff to vet this work; (f) has Mr Cadman been a member of the Natural Environment subcommittee or evaluation panel; if so, please provide details such as time of and duration of his membership; and (g) please advise the total remuneration Mr Cadman has received from or through the AHC, either in person or through Cadman and Norwood.

(4) With reference to paragraph 5(f) of the answer provided to question on notice no. 345, can an explanation be provided as to why $1,016 was paid as meal allowance to AHC staff who attended the conference, on whose behalf the AHC paid the full registration fee, when conference invoice 6870, dated 14 July 1995, states that the conference included 200 meals at $33.64 and 150 meals at $8.
(5) Given that it is noted in the receipts provided that there is one for $44.58 from Liqourland, what was the purchase to which this is related and for what was it used.

(6) With reference to an answer provided at the Senate estimates hearings on 17 September 1996 and the answer to question on notice no. 345 (4): (a) given that, on 17 September 1996 Ms Sullivan referred to `a quite complex document' in the context of the AHC, ensuring `that its sponsorship was only employed for that particular purpose', how can it be asserted in the context of the Hansard that the `complex document' referred to by Ms Sullivan meant the report by `the industry observer' referred to in NAFI News; (b) given that Ms Sullivan told the estimates hearing, `I would like to take that on notice and provide you with the information that we have already put together on that', is it correct to assume that Ms Sullivan did not put together `the industry observer's' report in the NAFI News; and (c) with reference to Ms Sullivan's assertion to the estimates hearing that an investigation had been done, and her answer that details of the investigation could not be revealed `because it is quite a complex document': (i) how does the AHC assert that the `complex document' referred to relates to a document that the AHC had no part in preparing or investigating, and (ii) can a copy of the document referred to by Ms Sullivan be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Significant time has passed since the events which are the subjects of the honourable senator's questions. The details sought are provided, although it required considerable resources to extract and collate.
(1) The Australian Heritage Commission (AHC) did not undertake the invitation of speakers.
(2) Yes.

(3) (a) Research Officers are employed on a part-time basis. Mr Cadman was employed by the Tasmanian Environment Centre, following agreement from the AHC, as a Research Officer between February 1985 and September 1994.
(b) Cadman & Norwood were contracted between March 1994 and September 1994.

(c) Yes, one purpose of Mr Cadman's consultancy was to research and provide information on the national estate values of places which were the subject of nominations to the Register of the National Estate.

(d) Mr Cadman was required to provide the AHC with advice as to whether nominated places had national estate significance. The AHC regularly uses consultants to research the national estate values of places and to provide advice as to whether they are of national estate significance.
(e) AHC staff have final responsibility for making recommendations to the Commission, so they vet work done by consultants.
(f) No.

(g) The Statutory period under the Archives Act 1983 for keeping expenditure records is six years. For the financial years 1990-91 through 1994-95 the Research Officer contracts were for the period 1 October through to 30 September of the next year. The amount paid to the Tasmanian Environment Centre under the Natural Environment Documentation Project for the period 1 October 1990 to 30 September 1994 was $83,900. Under the contract, this amount included a minimum of $15,000 per annum as salary for the research officer for two days per week. The remainder of the funds were to cover travel expenses and general office administration costs associated with the Research Officer's work for the AHC. The Tasmanian Environment Centre was free to pay the Research Officer an amount greater than $15,000, however, any additional salary was to come from the general administration funds. The total amount paid to Cadman & Norwood was $25,000.

(4) The conference organiser has advised the AHC that the 200 covers were for morning teas, afternoon teas and sandwiches over the two days, and that the 150 covers were a pre-payment for the conference dinner, later paid for by participants.

AHC Records covering the attendance of individual staff do not indicate that these staff partook of any luncheon refreshments over the two days. However, we are currently seeking to verify this with AHC staff who attended, and if any error is identified, the luncheon components ($13.10 per day) of the travelling allowance paid will be recovered.

The payment of $1,016 was the total payable based on the individual claims of the AHC staff who attended the conference as to their appropriate meal allowances. Meal allowances are a standard Australian Public Service entitlement for breakfasts, lunches and dinners, based on the expected duration of the staff member's travel, less any meals provided by other persons or organisations.

(5) The conference organiser has advised the AHC that this purchase was for refreshments for a pre-conference session at which the conference organisers briefed plenary speakers, workshop leaders and facilitators

(6) (a) The report by the industry observer had been indirectly referred to during the exchanges prior to the comments quoted from Ms Sullivan in this question. In particular, the letter which Ms Sullivan asked to table reflected the outcomes of the AHC's investigation into the issues raised in the industry observer's report. It was in this context that Ms Sullivan referred to the industry observer's report as `a quite complex document'.
(b) Yes.
(c) (i) See (a) above.

(ii) A copy of the document referred to by Ms Sullivan was provided with the answers tabled on 4 February 1997 to the questions asked on notice by Senator Abetz on 28 November 1996, and is tabled with these answers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 17 March 1997

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the reasons for overturning the agreed World Heritage Management Plan decision to close the Mt McCall Road.

(2) (a) What information was provided, and what representations were made, to the Minister or the department by agencies or ministers.of the Tasmanian Government since March 1996 relating to the Mt McCall Road; (b) what was the date and the nature of each contact; (c) what were the contents of each document or letter; and (d) can a copy of each document or letter be provided.

(3) (a) What information was provided, and what representations were made, to the Minister or the department by Peregrine since March 1996 relating to the Mt McCall Road; (b) what was the date and the nature of each contact; (c) what were the contents of each document or letter; and (d) can a copy of each document or letter be provided.

(4) Has the department made or commissioned an economic evaluation of the costs or benefits of the Mt McCall road; if so, can a copy of the evaluation be provided; if no such evaluation was made or commissioned, what economic information was used in coming to the decision.

(5) Has the department made or commissioned an environmental evaluation of the impacts of the Mt McCall road; if so, can a copy of the evaluation be provided; if no such evaluation was made or commissioned, what environmental information was used in coming to
the decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The in-principle decision to retain access to the Mt McCall Road was taken by the full Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area Ministerial Council. In making my decision in relation to this matter, I was mindful of the fact that the closure of the Road was a requirement contained in the Management Plan for the World Heritage area. My general view is that World Heritage Management Plans should not be amended without good cause. In this instance, I was persuaded by the fact that the Road provides a valuable opportunity for members of the public to view parts of the World Heritage area that are normally only seen by the hardiest of bushwalkers. Similarly, I was concerned that a decision to close the Road would bring to an end the shorter rafting trips along the Franklin River which are important for the Tasmanian tourism industry. By allowing visitors to experience the environment around Mt McCall and along the Franklin, I believe that we can actually increase support and appreciation for the protection of Tasmania's south-west among both Tasmanians and the wider community.

The World Heritage values of this region will continue to be protected. Enhanced measures will be introduced to address any possible impacts on values, including actions to limit access to responsible users, the establishment of wash-down facilities for vehicles and the investigation of the resurfacing of key sites to reduce visual and environmental impacts. The Ministerial Council also agreed to continue the revegetation of verges along the Road to reduce the impact of erosion and provide further camouflaging.

(2)(a)—(d) I have received many representations from a wide range of sources relating to the Mt McCall Road since March 1996. These representations presented widely diverging views in relation to the management of the road, and provided an equally diverse range of information in support of particular views. Included among them, were representations from the Tasmanian Government. I do not intend to make available copies of the documentation I have received on this matter. To do so would incur a heavy workload on my Department which I do not consider to be warranted.
(3) See answer to question (2).

(4) A cost-benefit analysis prepared by the Tasmanian Government was included in the papers considered by the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area Ministerial Council meeting on 14 March 1997. My Department's assessment of that analysis was included in the Departmental briefing I received for that meeting. It is not normally my practice to release internal departmental advice.

(5) My department provided advice to me on the environmental consequences of closing or retaining the Mount McCall road as part of its briefing material for the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area Ministerial Council meeting on 14 March 1997. It is not normally my practice to release internal departmental advice.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer upon notice, on 17 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the Government's position in relation to the development of the Multilateral Agreement on Investment by the Ministerial Council of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development.
(2) Does the Government consider that foreign investors should have the same rights to invest and to market access as domestic competitors.
(3) If the Agreement is adopted at the May 1997 Ministerial Council meeting, by what date would the Australian Government accept or reject the Agreement.
(4) What input has the Australian Government made to the development of the Agreement.
(5) Which domestic industries would be most affected if Australia were to accept the Agreement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In 1995, OECD member countries (including Australia) endorsed the commencement of negotiations for a Multilateral Agreement on Investment (MAI). The Government endorses an MAI that would strengthen the framework for international investment flows. This objective should be achievable while maintaining Australia's foreign investment policy and taking into account respective Commonwealth/State responsibilities in this area as provided for under the Constitution.

(2) In the administration of foreign investment policy, the Government applies the most‐favoured‐nation (MFN) principle whereby all foreign investors are treated equally, regardless of their country of origin. Since the requirements of Australia's foreign investment policy necessarily involve different treatment for foreign investors relative to Australian investors, Australia does not accord full "national treatment" for foreign investors.
(3) The May 1997 Ministerial Council meeting of the OECD is not expected to adopt the MAI. An extension of time for the negotiations is now expected.

(4) Australia supported the establishment of the Negotiating Group on the MAI at the May 1995 meeting of the OECD Ministerial Council Meeting and has since participated in all the deliberations of that group and of the related committees.

(5) The details of the MAI have yet to be determined. However, it is likely that the domestic industries to be affected by the MAI, if Australia were to accept the Agreement, would include those investing offshore, because of the expected increased transparency for foreign investment policy regimes of other countries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 17 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What environmental conditions apply to the export licence granted to Consolidated Rutile Ltd for the export of mineral sand products from North Stradbroke Island.
(2) Who is responsible for monitoring compliance with these conditions.
(3) (a) What investigations or audits have been undertaken to
determine whether the conditions are being complied with; (b) who has conducted them; (c) when were they conducted; (d) what was outcome; and (e) can a copy of any relevant report be provided.
(4) If no investigations have been made, are any planned; if so: (a) when will they be undertaken; and (b) who will conduct them.
(5) If the conditions of the export licence are not complied with: (a) what sanctions can be applied; and (b) who is responsible for applying the sanctions.
(6) Under what circumstances can the licence issued to Consolidated Rutile Ltd be revoked.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Brown's question raises issues which fall within the portfolio responsibilities of both the Minister for Resources and Energy and myself. As such, I have consulted with my colleague, Senator Parer, about this matter and the following reply represents the Government's response.

(1) Nine environmental conditions were recommended by the incumbent Minister for the Environment in April 1991, in relation to the granting of a total volume Mineral Export Permit for mineral sand mined on North Stradbroke Island and following examination of the proposal under the provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. These recommendations were subsequently incorporated as conditions attached to the Mineral Export Permit granted by the Minister for Resources and Energy
A copy of the recommendations has been forwarded to the honourable senator and additional copies are available from the Senate Table Office.

(2) Under the terms of the Customs (Prohibited Export) Regulations of the Customs Act 1901 it is the Minister for Resources and Energy, or the Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DPIE) on behalf of the Minister, that is responsible for the granting of Mineral Export Permits, and any conditions applied to the granting of such permits. Notwithstanding this formal position, there was, of course, close consultation between my Department and DPIE following the reporting of an incident in October last year at the Gordon mine. See (3) below.

The Queensland Department of Mines and Energy (QDME) has the primary responsibility for environmental oversight of the mining operations on a day to day basis and I am informed that DPIE liaises with QDME concerning environmental management of Consolidated Rutile's (CRL) operations on North Stradbroke Island, and that QDME monitors compliance with all environmental performance conditions, including those attached to the Mineral Export Permit.

(3) (a) Following the reporting of the off-lease seepage of clean water at the Gordon mine and given the possible implications for CRL's export approval, two DPIE officers and an officer from the Environment Protection Group travelled to Brisbane in early November 1996 to discuss the incident and appropriate remedial action with QDME and CRL.

The Minister for Resources and Energy recently advised me that, given the nature of the Gordon incident, he had undertaken a formal review of CRL's export approval and concluded that the relevant environmental concerns were being adequately addressed through State environmental processes. He therefore decided that no further action was necessary in relation to this incident.

In coming to this decision, the Minister for Resources and Energy emphasised to me that his Department would continue to liaise closely with QDME to ensure that the requirements of CRL's export approval are adequately met. He has also asked his Department to continue liaising with Environment Australia on this matter.

(b & c) The Queensland Department of Mines and Energy has advised that their most recent compliance assessment (equivalent to an audit) was conducted on 5 November 1996, and that there have been five separate site inspections since then.

(d) The outcomes of these assessments and site inspections include a Notice to Show Cause (why the mining lease not be withdrawn) in relation to off-site seepage of clean water, an Order to Comply in relation to the provision of hydrological assessments for mine planning of two current dredge operations, and seven written directives relating to several other aspects of the environmental management performance of the company, from improving fuel storage and delivery systems to downgrading the CRL performance category and consequent increase in the security deposit held by QDME for CRL operations. The Queensland Department of Mines and Energy has advised that the company has responded appropriately to these orders and directives.

(e) I have been advised that copies of relevant reports and related material held by QDME are available from the Department at—Queensland Minerals and Energy Centre, 61 Mary Street, Brisbane, Queensland 4000.
(4) See (3) above.

(5) As explained at (2) above, these are matters for consideration by Senator Parer. CRL's Mineral Export Permit requires the Minister for Resources and Energy to review the company's export approval if the permit's conditions and objectives are not being adequately met. Under the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations, the Minister for Resources and Energy has the power to revoke a Minerals Export Permit if the person who holds the permit has failed to comply with a condition or requirement of the permit. However, in considering such an option, the Minister for Resources and Energy would need to ensure that he had provided the permit holder with an opportunity to make submissions about the proposed decision, in order to meet the requirements of natural justice.

(6) See (5) above. In addition to addressing the immediate environmental impacts raised by the Gordon incident, CRL has made a long term commitment to improving its environmental management practices on North Stradbroke Island and to extending the scope of premining environmental assessments for both existing and future projects on the Island. These commitments include an undertaking by the Company to revise its Environmental Management Overview Strategy and to increase consultation with community groups.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 19 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that in July 1996 Telstra offered a select group of politicians, including the Premier of Victoria (Mr Kennett) and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory (Mr Stone), all expenses paid trips to the Olympic Games.
(2) Can a list be provided of the politicians: (a) who were forwarded invitations; and (b) who actually accepted this offer by Telstra.
(3) Can details be provided of the total cost for each trip made by these politicians, courtesy of Telstra.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer, based on advice from Telstra, to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) As the appointed telecommunications infrastructure supplier for the Sydney 2000 Olympics Telstra has a close association with the Olympic Games. Telstra considered that the Atlanta Olympic Games provided an opportunity to reinforce existing business relationships between Telstra and its private and public sector customers.

Telstra has advised that private and public sector key customers were canvassed seeking expressions of interest to attend the Atlanta Games. From this process representatives from ten global and domestic private sector companies and two public sector guests accepted invitations to attend the Games as guests of Telstra. The two public sector guests were Mr S Stone, Chief Minister, Northern Territory and Mr P Gude, a Minister in the Victorian Govern‐
ment. Telstra has indicated that these twelve guests of Telstra were present in Atlanta for varying periods of 3 to 6 days.
(3) Telstra has advised that the average combined costs for an Olympic package for the two politicians was $12 500 each.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Denman, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: On the latest data available, how many Child Support Agency clients, divided into payers and payees, reside within the postcode areas of: (a) 7310; (b) 7315; (c) 7316; (d) 7320; (e) 7325; (f) 7330; and (g) 7256.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
