ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sydney Opera House: World Heritage Nomination

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 19 March 1997

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has a detailed World Heritage nomination document for the Sydney Opera House and its setting been prepared.
(2) What was the cost of producing the nomination document, including departmental staff time.
(3) Have the views of Australian and international experts been sought about the possible World Heritage values of the Sydney Opera House and its setting; if so, what conclusions did they reach.
(4) Does the New South Wales Government support the nomination.
(5) Will the Government be submitting a World Heritage nomination for the Sydney Opera House and its setting in 1997; if not, why not.

(6) Is it a fact that World Heritage procedures for nomination will be changed on 1 July 1997 and that, if the current nomination document, which has been prepared for the existing rules, is not submitted in 1997, the work undertaken will be wasted.
(7) Can a copy of the nomination be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The Commonwealth provided New South Wales with $192,293 over the 1994/95 and 1995/96 financial years to undertake the assessment and preparation of the nomination. The New South Wales Government also made contributions to the project from various State agencies.

My Department has not separately costed staff time spent on preparation of the nomination, as it was but one of a number of concurrent projects undertaken by my Department on World Heritage matters. My Department's main involvement was its representation on the Steering Committee which oversaw the assessment and preparation of the nomination documents. The major staff time input was borne by officers of the New South Wales Heritage Office.

(3) Yes. The nomination document was prepared with contributions from a number of national and international experts. The document argues that the property meets three of the six criteria for Cultural Heritage under the terms of the World Heritage Convention. The document claims that the criteria met are (i) A masterpiece of the human creative genius; (iv) An outstanding continuing landscape which illustrates significant stages in human history; and (vi) A property directly associated with an event of outstanding universal value and with artistic and literary works. The property needs to meet only one criterion to qualify.
(4) Yes.

(5) I announced in the Senate on 18 March 1997 that the Commonwealth has decided not to proceed with a nomination at this time. The area proposed for nomination is the Sydney Opera House in its Harbour Setting. This raises complex questions of where the Opera House would fit within an urban planning framework and the responsibility that the Commonwealth would assume in relation to urban planning issues as the party submitting the nomination.

(6) The World Heritage Committee, at its meeting in Mexico in December 1996, adopted the revised format for nomination documentation. If a nomination were to be submitted in the future, some supplementary information would be needed to ensure the nomination could meet the new requirements.
(7) A copy of the nomination document has been provided to the honourable senator and additional copies are available from the Senate Table Office.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 19 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What Commonwealth money or other investment has gone into programs related to the orange-bellied parrot over the past 10 years.
(2) What has been the return on that expenditure.
(3) (a) What specific impact will the establishment of the chemical storage facility at Point Lillias have on the orange-bellied parrot; and (b) who has made this assessment and when.

(4) To what extent will the loss of habitat, both directly and through disturbance created by the new port, dredging and storage facility, negate the effects of previous expenditure on conservation and recovery for the orange-bellied parrot.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

BREAK.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth has spent $404,180 on projects directly relating to the conservation of the orange-bellied parrot over the past ten years. In addition to this there has been a significant combined cash and in-kind contribution made by the State Governments of Tasmania, Victoria and South Australia.

(2) The above Commonwealth expenditure, combined with the contribution of the range States, has resulted in the build up of a considerable amount of knowledge on the orange-bellied parrot. This includes knowledge of its habitat usage and requirements, population numbers and structure, breeding biology and other ecological information. This knowledge has been brought together in a Recovery Plan for this species, which is being implemented in a cooperative manner by the Commonwealth and the range States. The most significant advance made by the implementation of this recovery plan is the apparent stabilisation of the previously declining population of the species, largely through better habitat management and protection in both wintering and breeding areas. Other promising achievements are the development of more robust population census techniques, successful captive breeding of the species and the subsequent successful re-introduction of some captive-bred birds to supplement other measures taken to increase the wild population.

(3) (a) While it is not possible to be absolutely certain of impacts, I understand that with a suitable well-resourced management program combined with guarantees of perpetual habitat protection throughout the western coasts of Port Phillip Bay, the construction of a chemical storage facility at Point Lillias is likely to have a minimal, if not negligible, impact on the survival of the orange-bellied parrot.
(b) This assessment is based on advice from my Department and the assessment conducted by the Victorian Government as part of their Environment Effects Statement studies.

(4) The reduction in amenity for the species caused by construction of a chemical storage facility at Point Lillias would be outweighed by the measures summarised above, i.e. a properly managed and resourced conservation program coupled with reserve protection of habitat.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the status of the `Echelon' security surveillance system.
(2) Does the Defence Signals Directorate (DSD) use Echelon to monitor all electronic communications to and from Australia, including: (a) telephone; (b) facsimile; and (c) e‐mail communications.

(3) Is there an intelligence surveillance agreement involving Australia's DSD and equivalent agencies in the United States of America, the United Kingdom, Canada and New Zealand that commits the sharing of information obtained from this surveillance.
(4) What are the pre‐programmed words in the dictionary system used by the interception facilities monitoring such telecommunications networks.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) It is the long established practice of Australian governments not to comment on intelligence operations. The Defence Signals Directorate (DSD) collects and disseminates foreign intelligence to meet the requirements of the Commonwealth Government. It operates strictly within Australian law and in accordance with Australian Government Rules to protect the privacy of Australian citizens. Within that framework DSD participates in arrangements providing for the exchange of information between Australia and its allies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 19 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the current volume of possum meat being exported from Tasmania?
(2) Is possum meat being exported from any State other than Tasmania?
(3) Are export licences required to be issued for each location from which possum meat is exported?
(4) What role is the Federal Government playing to ensure the development, operation and enforcement of adequate animal welfare guidelines in the possum meat industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Approximately 10,383 kgs of possum meat was exported from Tasmania in calender year 1996, and 154 kgs has been exported in the year to date.
(2) Possum meat is produced for export only in Tasmania.

(3) Yes. All consignments of possum meat intended for export require clearance by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) and in addition, each shipment requires an export permit from Environment Australia.

(4) The harvesting of possum meat for export from Tasmania is subject to a Federally approved management program. That program includes a Code of Practice for the Capture, Handling, Transport and Slaughter of Brush Possums. The primary responsibility for possums under this Code resides with the relevant Tasmanian authorities. However, AQIS monitors aspects of the Code at export possum establishments.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Veterans' Affairs: Running Costs and Staff Reductions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 26 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 380 (Senate Hansard, 5 March 1997, p. 1383):
(1) Are details available as to how the review will be conducted, for example will it be conducted by the department or by outside consultants.
(2) Are details available as to the format of the review, for example will public submissions be called for.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) As noted in the my previous response, the Government has embarked on a progressive review of the significant issues of concern to the veteran community.
A decision has yet to be taken on the timing and the mechanism for the review of the treatment of war widows who remarried prior to 1984.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Troeth, Sen Judith

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Royal Australian Navy (RAN) Uniform Review carried out recently:
(1) In relation to the changes to be made to the RAN uniforms: (a) what will be the total cost; and (b) what is the reason for the change.
(2) What was the consultation process employed before the changes were made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) A final figure on the cost of the changes is not yet available, but the original estimate of $2.7m is accurate at this time. It should be noted that this cost pertains to the one‐off gratuitous issue to current serving junior sailors; longer term savings will result, as the New Junior Sailors' uniforms are less expensive to provide to males ($53.35 cheaper) and females ($347.35 cheaper) on entry, based on the current clothing price list.

(b) The changes provide greater alignment of uniforms between genders at the junior sailor level, remove items which are obsolete relative to contemporary dress norms, and reduce the range of clothing items that make up RAN uniforms.

(2) The change in uniform was affected following the 1994 RAN Uniform Survey, which revealed that 67 percent of those personnel surveyed were in favour of the change. An extensive consultation process took place both in initiating and conducting the uniform survey, and as a result of the survey findings. All RAN personnel have the opportunity to raise uniform issues at any time and a feed back system (called `Stitch This'), where ideas are put forward by members to the Director of Supply Policy, has been in place for some years. In the case of the 1994 survey, in addition to the feedback system, 3000 survey forms were widely disseminated throughout the RAN and 2100 were subsequently returned useable. This represented a surveyed population base of approximately 14.7 percent of the RAN Permanent Naval Forces. The results of the survey were subsequently considered by the Naval Planning Committee (one star level) and the Chief of Naval Staff's Advisory Committee (two star level), before being approved by Chief of the Navy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 26 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Federal-State Agreement for the Shark Bay World Heritage Area, originally signed by the former Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and the former Western Australia Minister for the Environment (Mr Pearce) in 1991:
(1) When will a World Heritage community consultation committee be established.
(2) When will the Terrestrial Reserves management plan be finalised.
(3) When will the Monkey Mia management plan be finalised.

(4) In the absence of any community consultation and establishment-management plans, how have tourist, aquaculture and oil exploration projects been assessed and regulated between 1991 and 1997 for their environmental impact.
(5) (a) What discussions have occurred with the Minister's State counterpart over the possibility of oil-drilling in the Shark Bay World Heritage Area.
(b) Will the Federal Government override oil exploration and oil drilling in the Shark Bay World Heritage Area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Expressions of interest were sought last year, by letters to local authorities and relevant groups, and by newspaper advertisements for membership of the Shark Bay World Heritage Community Consultative Committee. Following that process, I am liaising with the Western Australian Minister for the Environment to finalise the Committee membership. It is intended that the Committee be established in the coming months.

(2) The Shark Bay Terrestrial Reserves Draft Management Plan is being prepared by the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management (CALM) with input from a community-based advisory committee. It is intended that it be released for public comment later this year.

(3) The Western Australian Government has conducted a review of the 1988 Shark Bay Region Plan, with the assistance of a Steering Committee comprising community and other stakeholder representatives, and with a public comment process during 1996. I understand that the resulting Shark Bay Regional Strategy is nearing finalisation and that the Regional Strategy will set the framework for future management at Monkey Mia, and a more detailed management plan for the Monkey Mia Reserve.
(4) I am advised that there has not been an absence of community consultation and management plans. In addition to the plans and community consultative arrangements referred to in (2) and (3) above:
. the Shark Bay Marine Reserves Management Plan has been finalised with input from a community-based advisory committee and public submissions;
. the Shark Bay World Heritage Management Paper for Fish Resources has been finalised following a period of public submissions;

. the Monkey Mia Management Committee comprising representatives of the Shire of Shark Bay, the Department of Conservation and Land Management and the Gascoyne Development Commission has overseen the management of Monkey Mia; and

. a community-based advisory committee has been integral to the success of CALM's Project Eden which aims to eliminate feral animals from the Peron Peninsula and re-establish abundant populations of threatened native fauna.
Furthermore, the terrestrial and marine conservation reserves are vested in the National Parks and Nature Conservation Authority which consists predominantly of community-based members.

In addition to being required to meet all relevant statutory requirements including local authority and planning laws, all projects which may have a significant impact on the environment are subject to referral to the Western Australian Environmental Protection Authority and assessment under the Environmental Protection Act 1986.

I have discussed the issue of petroleum exploration and drilling with the WA Environment Minister. The Commonwealth is committed to ensuring the protection of Shark Bay's World Heritage values, in cooperation with the Western Australian Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 26 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the public environmental review for the Perth-Bunbury highway, Western Australia, Peel deviation:

Was the Federal Government advised about the potential environmental impact of the Peel deviation on the Ramsar wetlands, and areas adjacent, contained in the study area of the proposal; if so, what was the department's advice about the impact of the Peel deviation on the Ramsar wetlands, and areas adjacent, contained in the study area of the proposal; if the Government was not advised, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No. However my Department has made a submission to the Western Australian Environmental Protection Authority on the Public Environmental Review and has raised a number of concerns, including its potential to impact on the Peel-Yalgorup Ramsar wetland. My Department is preparing a brief to me on these concerns.
The answer to the latter part of the question, as to why the Federal Government was not advised of the Public Environmental Review, is a matter for the Western Australian Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 27 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have the scientific criteria, benchmarks and definitions to be used to conduct the Western Australia regional forest assessment and to establish a comprehensive, adequate and representative conservation reserve system for Western Australia been finalised: if not, at what stage is the process of concluding and approving the criteria, and when will it be finalised.

(2) If the process has been concluded: (a) what exactly are the adopted criteria, benchmarks and definitions: (b) where are they published: (c) who was responsible for drawing up the criteria, benchmarks and definitions and who approved them: (d) how do these criteria, benchmarks and definitions vary from those used for the Deferred Forest Assessment of 1995: (e) have the criteria, benchmarks and definitions been assessed by any independent person or body, such as the Australian Biodiversity Council: and (f) are these criteria, benchmarks and definitions to be applied flexibly to Western Australia: if so, what exactly does that mean.
(3) Has the Panel of Independent Scientists been established for the Western Australia regional forest assessment process: if so, who is on the panel: if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, these are the Nationally Agreed Criteria for the Establishment of a Comprehensive, Adequate and Representative Reserve System for Forests in Australia known as "the JANIS Criteria".

In addition, the Commonwealth and Western Australian governments are, through the RFA Steering Committee, determining the on-ground operational interpretation and application of those criteria. For example, the Steering Committee is currently considering the appropriate vegetation mapping system for Western Australian forests. It is expected that determination of the vegetation mapping system will be concluded shortly in a way that is consistent with the JANIS criteria and is comparable with the approach adopted in other States.
(2) (a) Details of the criteria are provided in the aforementioned document. In summary, the criteria provide for the reservation or protection of:
. 15% of the pre-1750 distribution of each forest ecosystem;
. at least 60% of forest ecosystems that are recognised as vulnerable;
. all remaining occurrences of rare and endangered forest ecosystems;
. 60% of old growth within each forest ecosystem;
. all viable occurrences of old-growth where it is rare or depleted within a forest ecosystem; and
. 90% (or more if practicable) of high quality wilderness that meet minimum area requirements.

(2) (b) The criteria, benchmarks and definitions are contained in the report Nationally Agreed Criteria for the Establishment of a Comprehensive, Adequate and Representative Reserve System for Forests in Australia.

(2) (c) The report on the national forest reserve criteria was prepared by the Joint Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council (ANZECC)/Ministerial Council on Forestry, Fisheries and Aquaculture (MCFFA) National Forest Policy Statement Implementation Sub-committee (JANIS).
(2) (d) The criteria, benchmarks and definitions have been drawn from:
. The principles set out in the National Forest Policy Statement;
. the JANIS Technical Working Group draft report of 1995, Broad Criteria for the Establishment of a Comprehensive, Adequate and Representative Forest Reserve System in Australia;
. the Commonwealth's 1995 Position Paper, National Forest Conservation Reserve: Commonwealth Proposed Criteria; and
. extensive public submissions on the latter two reports.

The criteria used in the 1995 Deferred Forest Assessment were based on the Commonwealth 1995 Position Paper, National Forest Conservation Reserve: Commonwealth Proposed Criteria, and are summarised in paragraphs 8 to 12 of the Executive Summary in the Report of the Deferred Forest Assessment process. The criteria to be used in the RFA are those documented in the final JANIS report, and although more detailed, are essentially similar, with some variations resulting from discussion among the Commonwealth and the States and Territories, through the JANIS process. A copy of the Report of the Deferred Forest Assessment process and a copy of the JANIS report are tabled for your information.
(2) (e) The JANIS criteria have been developed with the involvement of a range of independent bodies and individuals, including:

. the appointment by the Commonwealth in 1995 of a Scientific Advisory Group to provide advice on a scientifically based set of criteria for a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system for forests, including consideration of the JANIS Technical Working Group draft report and Commonwealth option papers;

. assessment of, and endorsement by, the Chief Biodiversity Officer of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) of the Commonwealth's 1995 Position Paper, National Forest Conservation Reserves: Commonwealth Proposed Criteria, which contributed significantly to the development of the JANIS criteria; and
. a three week period of public consultation on the draft JANIS criteria paper, with a specific meeting held in Canberra in August 1996 for the scientific community.

(2) (f) The JANIS report provides for flexibility in the application of the criteria to ensure that the comprehensive, adequate and representative (CAR) forest reserve system delivers optimal nature conservation, social and economic outcomes.

The provisions for flexibility in the application of the criteria are outlined in Section 5.2 (Flexibility) and in Section 5.4 (Social and Economic Considerations) of the JANIS report. Further discussion on flexibility in the application of the criteria is found in sections 6.1.1, 6.2.1 and 6.2.2 of the report

(3) The Scoping Agreement for the RFA in Western Australia provides for scientific matters to be referred to a Panel of Independent Scientists and Experts (PoISE) at the discretion of the Steering Committee. The establishment of PoISE is currently under consideration by the two Governments. Both governments remain committed to the establishment of the PoISE.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 4 April 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) What process has been established within the National Registration Authority (NRA) for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals to address staff complaints; (b) when was that process established; and (c) how many staff are employed in that section.

(2) (a) What is the level of the officer responsible for the management of that section; (b) how many people have been employed in that position since that section was first established; and (c) assuming a number of people have filled that position over time, what was the reason for their departure.

(3) (a) How many complaints has that section received, by year, since the section was established; (b) what was the nature of those complaints; and (c) how many of those complaints were dealt with to the satisfaction of both the complainant and the authority.
(4) What appeal or review process is in place to address complaints not satisfactorily dealt with by the authority.
(S) On how many occasions has that appeal process been required and what was the outcome of each appeal.
(6) How was the salary structure for the NRA determined, is it aligned to the Australian Public Service in any way.
(7) How many employees were performing higher duties in the 1995-96 and 1996‐97 financial years and were they in receipt of higher salaries as a result.
(8) Does the NRA offer any programs or assistance to employees to upgrade their skills; if so, what types of programs or assistance are available.

(9) Has the NRA undertaken a performance review of its staff annually; if so: (a) how many people were found to be under-performing in each review; (b) what action was taken as a result; and (c) what was the outcome of that action for each employee identified as under-performing; and if not, how often has such a review been undertaken.
(10) (a) What reviews have been undertaken into the efficiency of the organisation; (b) when were those reviews undertaken and by whom; and (c) what was the outcome of each review.

(11) Did any of the above reviews recommend a downsizing of any section of the NRA; if so: (a) in which sections and how many positions; and (b) what happened to the employees employed in those positions.

(12) (a) When was the survey of employee attitudes within the NRA conducted by Rodski and Falls Behavioural Group commissioned; (b) by whom; (c) for what purpose; and (d) what was the cost of the survey
(13) Have any similar surveys been undertaken in the NRA in the past; if so, (a) when and (b) what was the result.
(14) (a) What were the main findings of the Rodski and Falls survey; and (b) what action is underway, or is planned, to address these findings.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

BREAK.PARA: (1) (a) The process for staff complaints is as per clause 11, pages 36 and 37 of the NRA's Enterprise Agreement. This is as follows:

"It is an objective of the NRA that employees have a right to a working environment which addresses issues raised by staff in a manner which is non‐threatening and conciliatory. Where an employee feels aggrieved about a course of action or a decision made relating to their employment with the NRA, the aggrieved employee shall adopt the following procedure to have those concerns formally addressed.
A grievance is defined as a problem, concern or complaint of an employee related to work or work environment.
(a) Where possible the aggrieved employee shall discuss the matter with the person(s) to whom the grievance relates.

(b) If the matter is unable to be resolved at step (a), or if there is some reason why the matter cannot be discussed with the person(s) to whom the grievance relates, the aggrieved employee shall discuss the matter with their immediate manager;

(c) If the matter is unable to be resolved at step (b), or if there is some reason why the matter cannot be discussed with the immediate manager, the aggrieved employee will refer the matter in writing, to the Human Resource Manager;

(d) If the matter is unable to be resolved at step (c), or if there is some reason why the matter cannot be discussed with the Human Resource manager, the grievance should be referred, in writing, to the Chief Executive Officer;
If the matter is unable to be resolved at step (d), the matter can be referred to an independent body, such as the Merit Protection and Review Agency (MPRA) for review;
At any time during this process the employee reserves the right to involve the relevant union.
Matters relating to the interpretation of this agreement should be addressed in accordance with the dispute settling process outlined in this agreement."
(b) 15 August 1995
(2) (a) Human Resources Manager (NRA Band 5), who reports to the Executive Manager, Corporate Services.
(b) Four (4), including current Manager.

(c) 1 st: Left to take up a position with a local council in a country NSW area; 2nd: Temporary employee who left to commence a full time position elsewhere; and 3rd: Temporary employee whose services were discontinued upon the commencement of the current HR Manager.
(b) a) 1 x grievance due to a position selection process; b) 1 x complaint to Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC) re salary; c) Other complaints due to interpersonal concerns.
(c) a) Grievance dismissed as no grounds found after investigation; b) HREOC—resolution reached to both parties satisfaction; c) Interpersonal complaints resolved by mediation in 90% of cases.

(4) Parties who believe that complaints are not dealt with to their satisfaction may exercise their rights by appealing to HREOC, Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC), Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) etc depending on their particular concern.
(5) Once, to HREOC. Issue resolved to all parties satisfaction.

(6) The NRA's salary structure was determined by using an Aiken Job evaluation methodology, which looked at a systematic and detailed analysis and valuing of the content of a job. Once a job was evaluated, it was benchmarked against similar private and public sector agencies in the ACT to determine an NRA specific salary structure. This was carried out in consultation with staff and unions, and then incorporated into the NRA's Enterprise Agreement. The salary structure is not currently aligned with the Public Service.
(7) Undertaking Higher Duties: 1995/96—29; 1996/97—27.
All the above employees received HDA's over periods ranging from one week to twelve months.
NB: Some of the above persons may have undertaken (and been paid for) higher duties for more than one period within the financial year.

(8) The NRA budget for the year ended 30 June, 1997 has provided an amount of $255,312 for training and development. This amount is approximately 5.2% of the budgeted salaries for the same period and is in the upper quartile of the Public Service training expenditure as a percentage of base salary costs. It represents an increase of $147,098 (136%) over the previous year.

As at 28 February, 1997 a total of $169,787 has been expended on training and development including financial and `time off) assistance to staff. Examples of such training are as follows: Conflict Resolution; Individual Training Programs; Specific Management Development Course; Process Management; Senior Management Training; Stakeholder Conferences; ISO Standard 9002; Staff Development Performance Assessment Training; Field Trips for all staff; etc.
On a per staff basis the budgeted training expenditure per employee is $2,775. This amount exceeds the highest Public Sector expenditure on training per employee by 11%.
(9) The NRA's Enterprise Agreement for 1995/96 provided for the development and implementation of an annual performance review of all staff.

Development of a competency framework and assessment process, known as the `Skills Development and Performance Assessment' (SDPA) system was undertaken by the Enterprise Agreement Consultative Committee commencing December 1995. The necessary development of the SDPA system, and training of all staff and supervisors in its use, was completed in July 1996 and the first round of performance assessments was carried out in August 1996.

(a) The system focuses on competencies, with up to eight competencies assessed for each person. An overall rating is also determined and used to drive salary progression within the NRA classification system.
Four (4) staff (out of a total of 69 assessed) were identified as having an overall average level of achievement of competency below that required for their job classification.

(b) All staff, including the four mentioned above, received feedback on areas where competency was deficient and were given an opportunity to identify training needs to overcome these deficiencies. A training plan covering all staff in the organisation has been prepared and is being carried out.

(c) Insufficient time has elapsed since the assessment for a final outcome to be known. The SDPA system is being `fine tuned' to take account of lessons learned and the next round of assessments, which will include job goal achievement as well as competencies, will take place in July 1997.

(10) (a) a) Continuous Improvement in a Service Environment; b) Review of Financial Management Reporting; c) Review of National Chemical Registration System; d) Review of Support Functions; e) ANAO Performance Efficiency Audit
(b) a) April 1995. Skeldale Consulting; b) December 1995—Coopers & Lybrand; c) January 1996—Coopers & Lybrand; d) June 1996—Coopers & Lybrand; e) August 1996—Australian National Audit Office

In addition, the NRA undertook the process towards accreditation under ISO 9002 (achieved at the first attempt in late 1996). The accreditation under ISO 9002 will form a basis for further, ongoing business improvement and the development of best practice procedures in the registration process.

(c) a) Over a period of time most of the recommendations have been implemented including, improvements in the administration and evaluation of submissions for veterinary drug approval; improved process for NRA/client communication.

b) Recommendations substantially implemented including monthly, sectional financial reports containing monthly, year to date actual and budget figures; sectional managers fully accountable for their sections finances; capital equipment plan in place; all accounts prepared on an accrual basis; annual capital and operation budgets (section specific) prepared etc.
c) Recommendation substantially implemented including separation of levy and renewal requests for payment; request for payment form simplified and clarified; backlog of queries cleared etc.

d) Recommendations substantially implemented including the production of detailed job descriptions for all staff in those Corporate Services sections under review; significant changes to the operational process in each area etc.
e) lncomplete—ANAO yet to report findings.
(11) Yes
(a) i) Finance & Administration 3 positions *; ii) Human Resources 2 positions *; iii) Information Technology 1 position.
* includes a staff member who was 50% Finance and 50% HR.
Current resources in these areas are equal to, or better than, benchmarked standards for both private and public section organisations.

(b) Finance & Administration—All were offered positions elsewhere in the NRA and suitable training (if necessary). One accepted (the person formerly employed in the Finance & Administration section on a 50% basis) and is still currently employed in the new position. Two declined and accepted voluntary redundancies instead.

Human Resources—All were offered positions elsewhere in the NRA and suitable training (if necessary). One accepted (the person formerly employed in the HR section on a 50% basis) and is still currently employed in the new position. The other declined and accepted a voluntary redundancy instead.
Information Technology—Person was offered another position elsewhere in the NRA and suitable training (if necessary). This was declined and the person accepted a voluntary redundancy instead.
(12) (a) August 1996
(b) The Executive of the NRA.

(c) To determine the current attitudes of all staff members to the organisation in order to identify areas of concern and from these to formulate a plan to implement changes for the benefit of staff and the organisation.
$ 11,400 Survey + report
$ 2,800 Employee focus groups
$ 1,400 Management workshop
$ 1,795 Disbursements (travel, accommodation etc)
$17,395 Total

(14) (a) The survey benchmarked the NRA against Australian quality standards of other public service organisations and the NRA was found to be in the lower quartile of performance however, this was not inconsistent with other public service bodies.
Areas of specific concern were training; level of communication and; confidence in senior management.
. The NRA's Human Resources section is actively pursuing a policy of improving communications throughout the NRA.

. A Staff Liaison Committee has been formed to address concerns of staff and to facilitate discussions on matters involving all staff. In addition, this Committee considers and (where appropriate) recommends to management suggestions for change put forward by staff members.

. A process of team building has been instigated via additional training field trips for all staff members. These are normally undertaken by a group of several members of staff of a section and involve visits to private enterprise companies and facilities in order to gain knowledge of private sector practices and the potential impact upon NRA operations.

. The continuation of a periodic NRA staff newsletter (commenced in 1996) where staff are kept informed of issues that may affect them and/or the organisation. Staff are always invited to contribute to this journal.

. The continuation of NRA bi-weekly staff meetings (commenced in 1994) where staff are informed of past events and future proposals likely to affect them and/or the organisation and are invited to put forward their views and comments.
. The continuation of the publication of the minutes of bi-weekly managers meetings (commenced in 1996) so that staff are aware of current issues being discussed by managers.
. The continuation of an `open door' policy employed by the CEO and all Executive Managers allowing staff ongoing access to discuss any matters of concern to them at the highest level.
. Through the SDPA process a formal training program for all staff is current being implemented. This process will be ongoing as the staff and the organisations needs grow and change.
. High priority has been given to clarify, develop and implement specific NRA Human Resource policies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy upon notice, on 7 April 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to a national list of woolgrowers, known as the Wool International Numbers (WIN) Tax Register, held by Wool International (formed with a sunset clause and due to be dismantled by the year 2000) for its tax collecting duties:

Given that the list is a unique industry resource and the only known comprehensive mailing list of all woolgrowers in Australia, is believed to contain around 200 000 names and addresses, is currently protected by statute, and can only be accessed by Wool International staff for tax collection or ballot purposes;
(1) What does the department, which has responsibility for Wool International, plan to do with the WIN Tax Register when Wool International is wound up,
(2) Has the Government considered giving the wool industry or woolgrowers access to this resource.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Wool International is required to maintain a register of wool tax payers so that they may receive a return on the amount of wool tax paid in respect of the wool stockpile debt. On 27 June 1996 the Minister announced the reduction of the rate of debt reduction wool tax to zero and on 27 March 1997 he announced the return of the first instalment of grower equity, amounting to some $75 million, in 1997.

The equity entitlement of each grower to the net value of the stockpile and Wool International's other assets, principally the proceeds of sale of wool stores, will be calculated on the basis of the amount of debt reduction wool tax paid by each grower over the three years to 30 June 1996.
The register therefore contains a record of wool tax payments and wool tax payers over that period and has not been revised to reflect changes in the industry since the end of debt reduction tax.

The Privacy Act 1988 limits the purposes for which the information in the register may be used. The Wool International Act 1993 does, however, provide for the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation (AWRAP) to have access to the register, provided the individual tax payer gives his or her consent.

AWRAP is intending to seek the cooperation of Wool International with a view to utilising the register to contact levy payers to obtain their consent to have their names included on a separate register of woolgrowers for the purposes of the AWRAP annual general meeting and the wool tax ballot.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism upon notice, on 8 April 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What, if any, protection will forthcoming legislation concerning trade marks and patents include to protect the unregistered use of the term, `trade marks agent' and `agent for obtaining the registration of trade marks'.
(2) If the professions of trade marks agent and agent for obtaining the registration of trade marks are not to be protected, why not.

(3) In the absence of legislative protection for the professions of trade marks agent and agent for obtaining the registration of trade marks, what is there to prevent unlicensed and unauthorised persons from operating under those designations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The use of the term `trade mark agent' will be protected in accordance with the provision of the Trade Marks Act 1995, which carried through from the Trade Marks Act 1955, because of its close similarity with the term "trade mark attorney" and because there are persons who continue to have a legitimate right to use the term. The term "Agent for obtaining the registration of trade marks" is not a restricted term under the existing legislation and the Government does not intend to restrict the use of that term.

(2) The Government does not consider use of the term "Agent for obtaining the registration of trade marks" should be restricted given its objectives to open access to professional service in the field of trade marks.
(3) See 2 above.
